DOC.HEAD: Hungary Denies Involvement in Selling Soviet Arms to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The deputy defense minister denied Monday that Hungary was involved in selling advanced Soviet military technology to the United States, as alleged in a published report. The state MTI news agency said the newspaper Mai Nap quoted Brig. Gen. Ferenc Szombathelyi as saying in an interview published Monday, ``As far as Hungary is concerned, I am positive that the Hungarian military authorities did nothing which could have endangered our national integrity.'' Defense Ministry spokesman Col. Gyoergy Keleti told MTI that ``Soviet military technological means and secrets could not have been supplied ... from Hungary.'' He said Hungary never had the most modern Soviet military equipment, that the standard of military technology here lagged behind the most up-to-date Soviet technology by up to 10 years, MTI reported. The Washington Post, quoting unidentified ``intelligence sources'' in Washington and abroad, said in Sunday's editions that the United States secretly bought advanced Soviet military technology from Romania for 10 years prior to the December revolution that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu was executed on Christmas Day. The newspaper said the Romanian connection was part of a larger weapons-buying operation that allowed the U.S. military to obtain important components of Soviet air defense systems. It quoted its sources as saying the United States paid more than $250 million the past 10 years to obtain the latest versions of Soviet-made weapons systems through contacts in other East bloc countries, including Hungary. Asked if he considered the Washington Post article a ``mere slander,'' Szombathelyi was quoted as replying, ``As far as Hungary is concerned, it definitely is.'' But he was quoted as adding that ``a thorough inquiry'' would be launched into the matter and that a parliamentary inquiry was also expected. Mai Nap said Szombathelyi responded, when asked how Moscow counterintelligence could have been unaware of the reportedly extensive operation: ``That is exactly why I consider these allegations pure nonsense.'' He was said to have added, however, that that ``everything is possible in trade.'' The Washington Post report said the democratization of Eastern Europe had disrupted the broader operation, but not stopped it.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury to Investigate Shooting Incident
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury will investigate a weekend clash in which Vietnamese immigrants and longtime Louisiana shrimp fishermen exchanged gunfire and rammed each other's boats, the FBI said Monday. ``We turned the results of our investigation over to the U.S. Attorney. Those results will be presented to a grand jury and any criminal charges that result will come out of that investigation,'' said FBI spokesman Volney Hayes. No injuries were reported in the Saturday gun battle at Whiskey Pass, one of Louisiana's barrier islands in the Gulf of Mexico about 75 miles southwest of New Orleans. Six shrimp boats, some with bullet holes, were taken to the small fishing community of Port Fourchon on Sunday, the Coast Guard said. After crew members were questioned, the boats were released, a spokesman for the Harbor Police said. Four Vietnamese fishermen were detained for their own safety but no one was arrested, the Coast Guard said. They were interviewed by federal agents Sunday at Grand Isle, then returned to their boat Sunday afternoon. The Vietnamese fishermen would not discuss the incident with reporters who gathered Sunday at Port Fourchon. Louisiana fishermen said the Vietnamese shot first. The Coast Guard said the shooting broke out after the anchor of the vessel Our Mama, manned by longtime Louisiana fishermen, became entangled in the net of the vessel Freedom I, manned by Vietnamese living in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalist Guerrilla Warns Against Superpower Deal
DOC.TEXT: A fundamentalist Moslem guerrilla leader threatened to fight against any superpower deal to end the 12-year-old struggle to oust Afghanistan's pro-Moscow government. Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, firebrand leader of Hezb-i-Islami or Party of Islam, has vowed to launch a jihad or ``holy war'' if a dealis worked out at this month's U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington. The Afghan war is expected to figure prominently in talks beginning May 30 between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``The superpowers have agreed to prevent the formation of an Islamic government in Afghanistan,'' said Abdul Qadir Karyab, who heads Hekmatyar's politicial committee. ``We will not only continue our jihad on the battlefield, but we also have other ways should the superpowers interfere in our internal affairs,'' Karyab told The Associated Press. Western diplomats and Afghan experts in Islamabad have hinted the superpowers are close to a deal, but decline to give any specific details. The likeliest scenario, they said, was have elections in Afghanistan run jointly by the United Nations and the Organization of the Islamic Conference or by a neutral group chosen by the two organizations. But they also warned it will be very difficult to find a political solution acceptable to both the rebels and the Afghan government. Afghan President Najibullah has refused to step down prior to elections, a pre-condition set by even the most moderate guerrilla groups headquartered in Pakistan's rugged frontier city of Peshawar. The guerrillas have come under increasing pressure, particularly from the United States, to end their internal rivalries and devise a political settlement to the war. But the seven guerrilla groups are deeply divided. The president of the guerrilla's self-proclaimed government-in-exile, Sibghatullah Mojaddidi, has branded Hekmatyar a ``murderer'' and accused him of killing more innocent Afghans than Soviet or Afghan soldiers. Karyab said the Hezb-i-Islami would consider imposing its will on the other guerrilla groups. ``If they can't agree with our reasonable proposals, we have our unreasonable ways,'' he said refusing to elaborate. Hekmatyar is also feuding with Burhanuddin Rabbani, leader of the powerful Jamiat-i-Islami or Society of Islam. The two have traded threats and accusations of murder, kidnapping and theft. Hekmatyar, who is strongly anti-Western, fought ferociously against the Soviets and received the lion's share of U.S. military assistance during the 12-year-old war. Karyab said Washington now fears Hekmatyar's strength in Afghanistan. ``As far as I can see, the United States has very dangerous plans, including certain activity, even terrorist acts against the Hezb-i-Islami leader,'' Karyab said. The United States sends $500 million a year in aid to the guerrillas while the Soviet Union gives an estimated $5 billion a year to the Kabul government.

DOC.HEAD: Study Suggests Location of Second Alzheimer's Disease Gene
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they may have found the approximate location of a second defective gene that promotes Alzheimer's disease, a possible step toward a treatment. The work, which follows a 1987 report of one such genetic defect, ``sort of shines a flashlight on a new area'' to pursue, said researcher Dr. Allen D. Roses of the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. The new work focused on a form of Alzheimer's that runs in families and strikes at an average age of about 69, said Roses. The genetic defect located earlier was associated with Alzheimer's that strikes at a younger age. Alzheimer's is a progressive, degenerative disorder that attacks the brain and impairs memory, thinking and behavior. Some 4.4 million Americans are affected, most of them older than 65, according to the Alzheimer's Association. No cause or cure is known. Roses reported the new study last week at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Neurology. In a telephone interview Monday, he said it is not clear what percentage of Alzheimer's cases is accounted for by the form of the disease the researchers studied. But he said that his findings might be applicable to so-called sporadic cases of Alzheimer's. The new work was aimed at finding a location for a second gene among the body's 23 pairs of chromosomes. The results suggest a ``very high likelihood'' that a defective gene conferring susceptibility to late-onset familial Alzheimer's resides in a portion of the chromosome numbered 19, Roses said. In 1987, other researchers said they had found evidence that a gene or genes in a region of chromosome 21 was linked to a form of Alzheimer's that strikes before age 65. Alzheimer's researcher Gerard Schellenberg of the University of Washington in Seattle said Monday that while he has not seen a final report of the new work, it appears to be ``extremely interesting'' and worth more investigation. By a standard statistical measure, the strength of the evidence is quite strong, he said. The work was done by studying genetic material from 258 members of 28 families that included cases of late-onset familial Alzheimer's. Researchers essentially used three locations on chromosome 19 as signposts and analyzed their data to check the likelihood that an Alzheimer's gene lay near those locations.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Heir, A LaRouche Supporter, Going to Court to Show He Can Run Life
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An heir to the Du Pont chemical fortune who was found mentally incompetent after he gave money to political extremist Lyndon LaRouche goes to court this week seeking to prove he is fit to manage his own affairs. Lewis du Pont Smith, 33, heir to about $10 million, is due to appear Tuesday in Common Pleas Court before Chester County Judge Lawrence E. Wood. It will mark the latest development in a 5-year-old squabble pitting Smith against his parents. ``I have never had any mental illness or a breakdown in my life,'' Smith said in an interview. ``I hope with this petition that will be cleared up once and for all.'' David Foulke, the attorney for Smith's parents, E. Newbold and Margaret du Pont Smith of Paoli, said family members will testify against him. ``They don't have to, but a couple of them will,'' he said. ``I'm not sure who will yet. I don't want to get into that at this time.'' On one side, the wealthy du Pont clan believes Smith is being influenced by LaRouche. On the other, Smith says the family is irked because they don't approve of his political beliefs. Relations between Smith and his family soured after he gave LaRouche $212,000 for what Smith said was to benefit ``a publishing venture.'' Smith's parents argued in court that his association with LaRouche indicated his inability to handle his money, and in November 1985, Wood ordered that the family-owned Wilmington Trust Co. monitor Smith's spending. Since that ruling, LaRouche has been convicted on conspiracy, mail-and-tax fraud charges stemming from political fund-raising and is serving a 15-year federal sentence. Smith said he hasn't given any money to LaRounche since 1985 but still considers himself a supporter. He is running for Congress as an independent, and his advertising cites LaRouche as ``the world's leading physical economist.'' And Smith continues to argue that his family is wrong about LaRouche. ``Lyndon LaRouche was best man at my wedding, but he has no magical powers over me,'' Smith said. ``I have no intentions of throwing away or giving away my fortune to Lyndon LaRouche. This whole thing is so ridiculous.'' He notes that under the order taking away his control over his total fortune, he is allowed $15,000 a month, or $180,000 a year. ``If I'm competent to manage $180,000 a year, that seems to be an inconsistency,'' he said. Through a series of appeals and hearings, Smith has repeatedly asked the judge to reconsider his ruling and each time Wood has refused. Over the objections of his family, Wood did agree to validate Smith's marriage in December 1986 to 25-year-old Andrea Diano of south Philadelphia. The hearing coming up this week will be the first at which Smith actually takes the stand to testify. ``It really hurts,'' he said. ``I'm nervous about testifying, but my life is riding on this.'' Foulke countered that ``the family believes Lewis is mentally ill and it is in his best interest that the guardianship be continued.'' Meanwhile, Smith is waging a political campaign to get himself elected to the 5th District congressional seat. The district includes Philadelphia suburbs to the west and north. In order to run against incumbent Rep. Dick Schulze, R-Pa., in the November election, Smith must collect 3,000 signatures on election petitions by August. He will run as an independent. He said the campaign is going ``extremely well'' and expects to gather far more than the minimum number of signatures needed. ``The people know me well. They smell blood and their rooting for the underdog.'' Smith has bought blocks of time on six Philadelphia-area radio stations to broadcast messages in support of independence for the Soviet Republic of Lithuania. The air time reportedly cost an estimated $6,000 to $8,000 a week. He also has run newspaper advertising. ``My five-year long association with the world's leading physical economist, Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the only economist to forecast the October 1987 stock market crash five months before it occurred, will enable me to bring a degree of economic expertise to Washington, that is otherwise sorely lacking,'' he said in an ad last month in the Daily Local News of West Chester. ``It is high time that the American citizenry took it upon itself to sweep the economic incompetents that dominate the U.S. Congress, out of Washington, D.C.''

DOC.HEAD: Central America Struggles Toward Peace and Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Central America has achieved neither peace nor complete democracy through the pact President Oscar Arias drafted in 1987, but has taken steps toward both and is poised for more. Arias, who ends his four-year term Tuesday and hands the presidency to Rafael Calderon, wants to see the isthmus demilitarized and its 28 million inhabitants achieve full human and political rights in this decade. His departure marks the symbolic end of the group of five presidents who set a region embroiled in wars on a path toward peace. Arias won the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for leading the effort. Former President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador died of cancer Feb. 23. Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras left office in January and Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua surrendered power last month after an upset loss to Violetta Barrios de Chamorro. In a region known for coups and revolutions, all were replaced in free elections. The fifth president who signed the peace plan in 1987 is Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala, scheduled to leave office in January 1991 after elections later this year. Arias feels the Central American gains could be diminished or erased unless economic development accompanies democratization. ``It will not be possible to consolidate the democracies that have emerged in Central America unless we're successful in the economic and social fields,'' he said in an interview. ``This is the great challenge. If the democracies don't deliver the goods, we will not end the decade with democratic regimes.'' Rodrigo Madrigal Nieto, his foreign minister, said in a separate interview: ``If a person lives in misery, liberty loses its meaning.'' Costa Rica is relatively prosperous, but misery abounds in the four other nations between it and Mexico. Depressing statistics of life expectancy, infant mortality, literacy and access to potable water make the region one of the world's most desperate. Arias sees his country, the area's showcase of civic culture, as a model for the others. Costa Rica abolished its armed forces 41 years ago and has lived in peace and democracy since. ``The decade of the '90s must be the decade of disarmament if we want greater development,'' he said. ``Costa Rica buys tractors while the rest of Central America buys tanks. Tractors produce food. Tanks do not. ``The gap between the rich northern nations and the poor southern ones continues to widen. Rich countries' (financial) commitments to poor countries are not increasing, so we must depend more on internal savings. We must dedicate our resources to the satisfaction of our peoples' needs and not to buying arms.'' The highest remaining hurdle for the Arias plan is El Salvador, where a 10-year-old civil war continues to claim lives and spread destruction. Leftist rebels and representatives of President Alfredo Cristiani's U.S.-backed government are to resume peace talks this month. Negotiations broke off late in 1989 after two fruitless sessions. Rebel leaders say they want to abandon armed struggle for political action, but also call Cristiani's government little more than a civilian facade for a military regime that grossly violates human rights. Insurgent demands include a purge of rights abusers from the armed forces and reform of the judicial and electoral systems. Arias and Foreign Minister Madrigal say recent changes in Eastern Europe and, as Arias put it, ``the end of the Cold War,'' make a propitious time for the Salvadoran talks. Neither the government nor rebels appears to have substantially modified positions that led to stalemate last year, however. Moving Nicaragua's election ahead to February and an internal agreement to end its civil war are the firmest results of the Arias plan so far. A pact signed by U.S.-backed Contra rebels, the Sandinista army and Mrs. Chamorro's anti-Sandinista government commits the Contras to disband by June 10, but peace is not assured. Several thousand Contras are assembled in five internationally monitored security zones inside Nicaragua. Contra commanders have made tough demands of Mrs. Chamorro, principally that Sandinistas be purged from ranking positions in the army and police, and express readiness to resume battle otherwise. Honduras lost a great burden in April when thousands of Contras based there for years abandoned their camps and returned to Nicaragua, but consolidation of democracy in both Honduras and Guatemala is proving slow and difficult. Their armed forces retain independent power far beyond that afforded the military in true democracies. Corruption and drug trafficking threaten to undermine progress toward modern democratic systems. ``We cannot say the peace plan has been a success, that peace and democracy have been established,'' Madrigal said, ``but we have made notable advances and I see a new attitude that favors further progress.'' He spoke of the other countries, where dictatorships were the norm for most of this century, as advancing along a sort of democratic scale. ``Before, they were at zero,'' he said. ``Now they are at 10 or 15. They're far from 100, but it is inevitable that they will continue to advance _ some in the short term; others will take longer.'' The Arias plan provides for a Central American parliament to present a united voice to the world. Ironically, it is delayed because the Costa Rican legislature has yet to approve. Arias described the reluctance as ``an idiotic superiority complex.'' Many Costa Rican legislators argue that an established democracy should not get involved in such a regional project with less democratic governments.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Radio Ship Unwanted in a Nervous Region
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Goddess of Democracy radio ship is headed for troubled waters on its mission to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China, risking retaliation from Beijing and raising tensions in the region. The 1,200-ton ship, outfitted by Chinese dissidents, set sail from France in March and began the last leg of its journey Thursday after picking up provisions in Singapore. It is expected to reach international waters off China in about two weeks to begin broadcasting. Chinese officials, who sent the army into Tiananmen Square to crush the pro-democracy movement in June 1989, have refused to rule out using force to stop the ship. Analysts believe China probably will jam the Goddess of Democracy's broadcasts and may direct its navy to board the ship, seize its equipment and make arrests. One diplomat said, on condition of anonymity, that the Chinese might try to incapacitate the vessel by ramming it. What action international law would allow on the high seas was unclear, he added. Xu Tianfang, deputy secretary of the Paris-based Boat for China Foundation, the project's main organizer, said from Taipei he could not predict whether China would use force. ``We have sent journalists on board the ship and they will be the witnesses if any such action occurs,'' he said. Using force against the ship probably would lead to confrontation between China and several governments. The Goddess of Democracy is registered in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, has a French crew and carries Western journalists. The Chinese have pressured nearby governments to refuse assistance to the ship. The Taiwan stock market fell for three straight days after China accused the island of ``open provocation'' by offering help to the vessel. As Taiwan became increasingly jittery, Goddess of Democracy organizers said they would seek permission to call at Hong Kong, on China's southeastern coast, to take on provisions. Officials of the British crown colony, which reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, are extremely sensitive about relations with Beijing and announced Thursday the ship would not be allowed in its waters. Chu Yung-chuan of Taiwan's Communications Ministry said Friday the ship would be allowed to dock at the northern port of Keelung unless his ministry received orders otherwise. So far, the government has indicated the Goddess of Democracy could take on provisions. An independent legislator announced plans to organize a flotilla of fishing boats to escort the vessel when it approaches the island. A Defense Ministry spokesman, Maj. Gen. Wei Chia-ching, has said the Taiwan military would protect the vessel if it came under attack within Taiwan's ``defense zone,'' an area he refused to define. The timing could not be worse for Taiwan, which is experiencing a thaw in its historically chilly relations with the Communist government in Beijing. Tension across the 100-mile-wide Taiwan Strait has eased dramatically in recent years, accompanied by increasing trade and travel. Secretary-general Hu Chi-Chiang of the Anti-Communist League, a semi-official group, said 70 private Taiwan organizations had decided to withhold donations to the ship. ``We absolutely support the ship, but we don't want to see tension increase because of our support,'' he said. Threats from Beijing also forced organizers to abandon the possibility of having Chinese dissident leaders who escaped to the West, such as Wu'er Kaixi and Chai Ling, broadcast from the vessel. Xu said there would be no dissidents on the ship, but refused to say who would make the broadcasts. The Goddess of Democracy, which left France on March 17, is named for a statue erected by pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in May 1989, before the military crackdown in which hundreds, perhaps thousands, were killed.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Not Sending Cabinet Minister To Environment Parley
DOC.TEXT: Unlike other Western countries, the United States will not be represented on the ministerial level at a conference on the environment that opens this week in Bergen, the national news agency NTB reported. The ``Action for a Common Future'' conference in the west coast city is expected to be attended by between 40 and 50 Cabinet ministers among a total of 600 delegates from 34 countries. It begins Tuesday and runs to May 16. The American delegation will be headed by John A. Knauss, a Commerce Department official and former professor of oceanography, the agency quoted press attache John Matel of the U.S. Embassy as saying. NTB said in the report Sunday that Knauss would be heading ``a delegation of 12 politicians and low-level civil servants representing the Departments of State and Energy and the Environment Protection Agency.'' The Norwegian government expressed regret that the United States was not being represented by a Cabinet minister, the agency said. It quoted Norway's state secretary Kai Eide as saying it had hoped EPA chief William K. Reilly would have taken part. The Bergen conference aims to follow up recommendations of the ``Our Common Future'' report by the U.N. World Commission on Environment and Development. It was organized by Norway in cooperation with the European Commission for Europe, which includes the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks Likely With No Preconditions, Congressional Leaders Say
LaserPhotos WX7-8
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Congress say serious budget negotiations with the White House now appear likely, with everything on the table _ including the possibility of new taxes. The leaders left the White House Sunday night after a private 90-minute meeting with President Bush saying they would be back for more talks with the president after consulting with other lawmakers. They said they discussed no specifics with Bush, but established that whatever negotiations take place will be without preconditions. House Speaker Tom Foley, asked if things now were on track for full-scale budget negotiations, said, ``I think that's going to be the outcome.'' Asked if Bush stood ready to drop his no-new-taxes pledge, Foley said no specifics were discussed, but he added, ``The assumption is that all matters would be on the table, that we would not enter any talks with preconditions.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said, ``There was a general agreement that any discussions will be without preconditions, if and when they occur.'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole said the lawmakers expect to meet again with Bush late Tuesday after conferring with colleagues, including leaders of the key budget and tax-writing committees. The White House had no comment on the talks, deputy spokesman Stephen Hart said. House Minority Leader Bob Michel also took part in the unusual 90-minute session in Bush's private residence. The talks took place after Bush, the congressional leaders and 200 other guests attended a lecture on Theodore Roosevelt's presidency by author David McCullough. The full House and Senate Budget Committees approved Democratic versions of the 1991 budget last week. Congress and the White House have made repeated efforts in recent years to forge grand compromises on the deficit. Most have fallen short of expectations. Congress has ignored the $1.2 trillion budget blueprint that Bush submitted Jan. 29. That budget was supposed to meet the Gramm-Rudman target of a deficit no larger than $64 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Sluggish economic growth and rising interest rates have driven up the deficit since then. Foley said he expects more lasting results this time. ``All of us who took part in this meeting today feel that we need a major and meaningful effort that has been somewhat lacking for various reasons in past years'' to narrow the deficit for next year and over several years, the speaker said. ``I think there's goodwill on all sides in attempting to deal with the fiscal problems the country faces,'' said Foley. ``We're going to, I think, find a way to deal effectively with them.'' Bush was joined at the meeting by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, budget director Richard Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Brady came directly from talks on Capitol Hill with finance ministers from the Group of Seven nations _ the other major Western democracies. The 1990 deficit was supposed to be $99 billion under a budget deal that Bush and Congress struck in April 1989. But that has been undone by higher spending and slower than expected growth of tax revenues. Now the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office expects the 1990 shortfall to reach $159 billion, up from $152 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Machete-Wielding Youth Attacks Judge In Court
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old youth on trial for assault pulled out a machete in court today and attacked the judge hearing his case, seriously injuring her, authorities said. The 60-year-old judge, Augusta Wallace, suffered deep facial wounds and was rushed to Middlemore Hospital, where she was listed in stable condition. Police said it was the first time in New Zealand that a judge had been attacked in court. They said the youth apparently smuggled the machete into the Children and Young Persons Court by hiding it inside his trouser leg. The teen-ager was appearing on a charge of reckless driving, excess blood alcohol, car stealing and assault on police. Police said he had not been in police custody before the hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Life a Tedious Limbo at Immigration Holding Center
LaserPhoto MH2 of May 3.
DOC.TEXT: Life is a slow, tedious limbo at a place called Krome, and tempers are short and getting shorter. Krome, the Krome Service Processing Center, is where newcomers from Haiti and other countries await word on their future in the United States. Many people pass through the fenced-in holding center, but most are Haitian refugees, some with stories to tell of alleged abuse and neglect at the hands of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. Miami's Haitian community is generally considered peaceful, but on April 29, more than 1,000 Haitians demonstrated outside Krome, tearing at its fences after years of seeing their countrymen locked up while others go free. ``We want freedom and justice for the Haitian refugees and all the refugees detained,'' said the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, a Haitian community leader. ``We must break down the walls of Krome, which reminds us of Hitlerism.'' On average, two-thirds of the center's 400 or so residents are Haitians. They are picked up at the airport with fake passports and visas or plucked from rickety boats by the Coast Guard while trying to slip into the United States. Arrivals at Krome, a former missile base on the steamy edge of the Everglades 25 miles west of Miami, are dressed in orange uniforms and given medical exams. And then they wait. ``The most horrible part of this place is time,'' said Nuhu Aminu, 35, a TV production specialist from Nigeria. The average stay at Krome is 18 months, sometimes more than two years. Detainees wait to learn whether they will be deported or released. ``The one thing people kind of lose sight of is that we don't go out and try to shanghai these people,'' Krome administrator Constance Weiss said. ``They're here because they attempted to break the law.'' In affidavits, many signed with encoded names to avoid reprisals, Krome detainees have told of experiences far more horrible than agonized waiting. Women have said they are sexually abused and harassed by guards. ``The Krome officers often told the male detainees at Krome that they had sex with the female detainees. They bragged about this and laughed and thought it was real great,'' said Chantale Pierre, a former detainee who now lives in Miami. Men and women have complained of beatings and restricted access to telephones and bathrooms. Haitian detainees say Latins get preferential treatment. Detainees say they often aren't given enough time to eat their meals and have charged that an aspirin substitute is given for any complaint. ``On many occasions we are physically abused,'' one detainee said. ``Since we are scared and don't speak English, we keep quiet.'' The allegations angered many in the Haitian community, sparking the April 29 demonstration that ended with no arrests and the retreat of the protesters. The allegations have stirred up INS officials, two of whom visited Krome on April 24. Shortly afterward the agency announced the additions of two more immigration judges and 27 guards to improve conditions and speed up the wait. On May 1, the INS began an already-planned test program under which about 200 detainees will be released in Miami, Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco. They must meet certain conditions, including having what appears to be a good case for asylum and a source of income or support, posting a bond of $500 to $2,500, and agreeing in writing to surrender for deportation if ordered. The Justice Department is looking into allegations of abuse at Krome. Because of the investigation, Miami INS director Richard Smith and Krome officials would not comment on the detainees' complaints. Meanwhile, life at Krome drags on. Detainees spend their days cleaning their quarters, watching television, playing volleyball or basketball outside or lounging under shelters. Men and women cluster at the 10-foot fences that keep them apart. ``Sometimes we stay in bed, think about everything,'' said a Haitian who asked that her name not be revealed. ``Think about your country, think about your family. We suffer.'' Detainees also take classes. They can work toward high school equivalency diplomas, learn English or study crafts such as ceramics and sewing. Some work, earning a dollar a day as laborers at the camp. Sick detainees go to a clinic with an emergency room and X-ray and dental facilities. Mental health professionals also are on duty. Detainess watch video movies, mostly in English, every night, Weiss said. ``One thing you have to do is keep yourself together,'' said Detto Bilkerdyk, who works in the Krome sign shop. A former military policeman from Suriname, he said he left home fearing for his life after refusing orders to commit executions. ``If they deport me back home I know I'm dead,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Congressman, Populist Attorney General Vie for McClure's Seat
DOC.TEXT: Republican James McClure's decision to retire from the U.S. Senate has set up a struggle between two would-be successors in a plot straight from a Frank Capra movie. Jim Jones, a plucky, populist attorney general with almost no cash or campaign staff, is giving five-term congressman Larry Craig a spirited but possibly futile run for his money in the May 22 Republican primary. ``I've always been an underdog in my political races,'' said Jones, who ran for the House twice before winning the state's top legal office in 1982. ``It's a role that I don't mind; you have to try harder.'' Craig, 44, is campaigning on his record and generally playing the role of the cautious, veteran politician above the fray. Jones, 47, is cast as the scrappy, nothing-to-lose challenger with a folksy, accessible style and independent agenda. ``I've got more courage and innovation than Craig has,'' Jones said. ``He's been in Congress for 10 years and has done very little.'' The Craig campaign is a juggernaut fueled by essentially the same field and fundraising organization that made McClure all but unbeatable for three House and three Senate terms. McClure, however, has made no formal endorsement. Through the first three months of the year, Craig had built up a war chest of $260,000 while spending $135,000. Jones had received contributions of less than $19,000 and most of it was quickly spent. The winner of the GOP primary is expected to face Boise businessman Ron Twilegar in November. Twilegar, 46, is a former state Senate minority leader who faces token opposition in the Democratic primary. While Craig is the heavy favorite, there is a perception he remains a relatively untested and possibly thin-skinned campaigner, with a formal, somewhat stiff manner. Democrats had to scramble to find replacement candidates to challenge him when the 1984 nominee died in a car accident and the front-runner in the party's 1986 primary was killed in a plane crash. The implication irks Craig. ``I've won, but I've worked hard in each case,'' he said. With a network of volunteers in every county, Craig contends he has made quick progress in heavily Republican eastern and southern Idaho, where most of the party's statewide primaries are decided. ``We've spent a lot of time there, and I may run very well in the south and southeast, better than I had anticipated,'' he said. ``I'm finding the support for Jim Jones there is very soft.'' If true, that may be partially a result of Jones' lack of money for major advertising in a far-flung state where key markets are separated by mountains and hundreds of miles. Jones has tried to get his message out through news conferences and personal appearances, usually traveling alone. His primary focus has been on pocketbook issues such as consumer protection, possible pricing collusion in the oil and meatpacking industries and action needed to reduce the federal budget deficit. Jones has tried to undercut Craig's position as a primary sponsor of a proposed balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Over the past 10 years, Jones contends, Craig has ``continually weakened it to the point where it's meaningless in an effort to get more co-sponsors.'' Jones knows his kind of underfinanced, one-man campaign has not succeeded in Idaho since Democrat Glen Taylor, known as the ``Singing Cowboy,'' won a Senate seat in 1944. But he remains optimistic. ``It's a disadvantage, but it's something that can be overcome by just sheer determination, hard work and free publicity, and I've been pretty good over the years in generating coverage,'' he said. Craig is clearly ahead, but he won't reveal the results of his own polling. He credits organization, but chafes at Jones' contention it was inherited from McClure. ``I inherited nothing,'' Craig said. ``Jim McClure did not call anyone or ask anyone to work on my behalf. I did it myself.''

DOC.HEAD: Sakharov Memoirs Recall Exile, Despair and Triumph
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Andrei Sakharov, the late Soviet physicist and human rights champion, wrote that his life and work in many ways paralleled the violence, repression and eventually the reforms that have swept his homeland. Excerpts from Sakharov's memoirs appeared in The Sunday Times of London in advance of British publication in July. He died in Moscow on Dec. 14 at age 68 after a heart attack. The book, titled ``Memoirs,'' will be published in June in the United States by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. Excerpts also will appear in Time magazine's May 14 and May 21 issues. Sakharov, who endured years of persecution by Soviet authorities but was mourned as a hero and visionary, recalled the awe and fear he felt when he heard of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima by the United States in 1945. ``I was so stunned that my legs practically gave way,'' wrote Sakharov, who was considered the father of his own country's hydrogen bomb. ``There could be no doubt that my fate and the fate of many others, perhaps of the entire world, had changed overnight,'' he said in The Sunday Times excerpts. ``Something new and awesome had entered our lives, a product of the greatest of the sciences, of the discipline I revered.'' In the Time excerpts, he wrote of the ``tragedy, cruelty and terror'' of the era of his childhood, the 1920s and early 1930s, and remembered the Stalinist repression that left parents afraid to speak freely before their children. ``This reluctance to reveal one's thoughts even to one's own son may be the most haunting sign of those times,'' he wrote. Later, Sakharov's calls for political reforms presaged many of the changes under Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who allowed Sakharov to return to Moscow in 1986 after nearly seven years of internal exile in the city of Gorky. In the memoirs, Sakharov said that after World War II, when he was made a member of Igor Tamm's top-secret team developing the H-bomb at the Physics Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, ``nobody asked if I wanted to take part _ I had no real choice.'' ``But the concentration, total absorption and energy that I brought to the task were my own,'' he recalled in The Sunday Times exceprts. ``I understood the terrifying, inhuman nature of the weapons we were building,'' he wrote. ``But the recent war had also been an exercise in barbarity.'' It was Sakharov's call for a worldwide nuclear test ban in the late 1950s that first brought him into conflict with Soviet authorities. During the last three decades of his life, he fought against the jailing of innocent people, for free emigration and for disarmament and other causes. He said he was not convinced that mutual assured nuclear destruction had truly helped to keep the peace. ``Thermonuclear weapons could end human civilization. They have become so frightening that the very thought of using them seems unreal. Their credibility as a deterrent has thus decreased, while their threat has increased enormously,'' he wrote. The first extract from Sakharov's memoirs dealt mainly with his being sent to internal exile in 1980 for criticizing Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Yoko Ono says her son, Sean, helped her pull through after the murder of her husband, John Lennon. ``Some days, I felt life wasn't worth it, but it was important that I stay around for Sean, or he would have lost two parents,'' Ono said in an interview in Sunday's Daily News Magazine. Sean, now 14, was 5 when his ex-Beatle father was slain. He attends school in Switzerland and hopes for a music career. Ono said she prefers he choose another path but won't stand in his way. ``I love him very much, wish John was here to see him grow,'' she said. ``Maybe he's watching.'' Lennon was shot to death in 1980. His killer, Mark Chapman, is serving a life sentence.

Prince Charles' artwork is on display in surroundings that could humble a heir to the British throne. Charles attended an invitation-only unveiling Sunday of 57 of his watercolors at the Raphael Academy, in the building where the Renaissance artist was born in 1483. ``I still can't believe that my amateur sketching will go on display in Raphael's house,'' Charles said. ``I only hope the great master doesn't turn in his grave.'' Captured in the prince's drawings are, among other images, the Tuscan countryside, a sandy scene in Saudia Arabia and places in Scotland and Hong Kong. The exhibit runs through June 14.

Norman Vincent Peale wants to honor a few just-plain-folk who do good deeds with none of the glory. The author-minister announced Sunday that a nationwide search is on for ``unsung heroes'' to be lauded with America's Awards and $1,000 each. ``We're looking for unsung heroes who personify American character and spirit, for `ordinary folks' who are extraordinary examples of such values as compassion, honesty, courage or even friendliness,'' he said. The author of ``The Power of Positive Thinking'' is honorary chairman of a selection committee that includes U.S. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., Walter Cronkite, Barbara Mandrell and Disney chief Michael Eisner. The awards will be administered by the non-profit Positive Thinking Foundation.

Barbara Bush kept the senior class of Kennebunk High School waiting nearly a year before she accepted an invitation to deliver the commencement address in June. Class officers at the school sent the invitation in August to the White House and to President Bush's summer home in neighboring Kennebunkport. ``They were told her calendar for spring would not be determined until January,'' Principal Williami Gentile said. ``They're very fond of Mrs. Bush.'' Confirmation came about five weeks ago, he said. Kennebunk will graduate 147 seniors June 10. Mrs. Bush also is scheduled to deliver the commencement address at Wellesley College over objections from some students at the women's school in Massachusetts that the speaker should be a woman known more for her own accomplishments than for her husband's.

A closed museum boasting the world's largest collection of Bruce Springsteen memorabilia wants to sell it intact for at least $50,000. Among the items for sale: a rare 1966 unreleased single by Springsteen's first band, the Castiles; a surfboard; Springsteen's 1970 driver's license, and his draft card. The Asbury Park Rock 'n' Roll Museum shut down last year. Billy Smith, a co-owner of most of the Springsteen artifacts, said he hopes a buyer will keep them in Asbury Park, where the singer got his start. ``Hopefully, somebody will buy this stuff and display it,'' Smith said. Asbury Park, a down-at-the-heels resort town, is the setting for some of Springsteen's early songs. The museum was in the Palace Amusement Arcade, where parts of Springsteen's ``Tunnel of Love'' video were shot. When the arcade closed last year, so did the museum, and its contents went into storage.

Mel Harris has defined yuppie wife and mom on television's ``thirtysomething,'' and now she's living it. Two years ago, Harris, who plays Hope Steadman on the ABC series, wasn't thinking of domestic bliss after her marriage to photographer David Hume Kennerly ended. ``I didn't want a relationship or anything even remotely similar to the life I have now,'' Harris said in an interview in the May 14 People magazine. But Harris remarried 18 months ago, to actor Cotter Smith of ABC's ``Equal Justice,'' and their life together has definite ``thirtysomething'' tendencies. Harris is breast-feeding the couple's month-old daughter. Her 6-year-old son from her marriage to Kennerly is in kindergarten. She has two dogs. Construction workers are busy remodeling the couple's house. Smith, who also considered himself a sufferer of post-romantic stress disorder, met Harris on the set of a 1987 horror film. ``Both of our relationships had fallen apart, so we had a lot to talk about,'' Harris said.

DOC.HEAD: FmHA Reports Foreclosure Activity Rising
DOC.TEXT: The Farmers Home Administration has written off nearly one-third of $8.8 billion owed by delinquent borrowers and says there is an increase in foreclosure activity to collect the rest. As of March 31, reports by the Agriculture Department agency show that proceedings were initiated against 4,110 farmers in the first six months of the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. That compared with 5,002 in all of the 1989 fiscal year and 1,459 in 1988. Agency officials say the trend is expected to continue at least through the rest of this year. Spokeswoman Marlyn Aycock said that 75,352 collection notices were sent out beginning in late 1988 and that 32,584 were resolved by being paid off, brought up to date or otherwise settled. But that left more than 42,000 overdue loans still hanging fire. Many of those have been appealed or are in some kind of mediation with the agency. The FmHA often is called the government's farm lender of last resort, and eligible borrowers cannot qualify for loans from commercial lenders. Procedures for collecting and servicing FmHA loans were refined by Congress in the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, including requirements that collectors tell delinquent borrowers about various liberalized debt-serving options available. The law also provided for write-downs and write-offs of loans in cases where collection costs would exceed the recovery value. In many cases, FmHA had made loans far in excess of the eventual value of a farmer's assets. Land values, the main asset of farmers, plummeted in the 1980s and wiped out much of the collateral worth held by borrowers. As a result many wound up owing a bundle without sufficient net worth or cash flow. Aycock said that as of Nov. 30 _ the most recent tabulation _ about $796 million had been written down, an average of $172,857 on 4,608 loans. In these cases, loans were reduced to the current value of the collateral. Similarly, 5,029 borrowers were allowed to ``buy out'' their loans at current liquidation values. This write-off amounted to more than $1.03 billion, an average of $205,674. The excused debts have included nearly 100 individuals who each have had FmHA loans reduced or written off by $1 million or more. Aycock said that $933 million in old debt also has been written off by FmHA as uncollectable. Those involve 6,341 dead-end accounts, some going back 10 years or more. The number of potential foreclosures is indicated by ``acceleration letters'' sent to thousands of delinquent borrowers. The acceleration process is a major step toward final closeout of an FmHA loan through foreclosure. Another indicator _ the next step _ is the number of accelerated cases referred to USDA lawyers to await formal foreclosure action by the government. By comparison, the number of actual foreclosures by the agency _ those that have gone through final settlement _ is relatively small. But those also are beginning to increase. So far this fiscal year, the records showed 107 foreclosure actions completed, plus 113 by banks and other lienholders that share loans with the agency. That compared with only 45 foreclosures by FmHA and 258 by other lienholders in fiscal 1989. In 1988, FmHA foreclosed on 58 borrowers and other lienholders, 504. But foreclosures aren't the only way FmHA can collect what is owed, nor are foreclosures the only reason for farmers to go out of business. Pressure by FmHA can result in the sale of property, in which case the debt is often settled, or voluntary transfer of property to the agency as part of a settlement deal. Although the FmHA records are still sketchy, figures for the first half of fiscal 1990 show that the pace of those who are quitting the farm ``due to financial difficulties'' of all types, is increasing. In fiscal 1988, 3,159 FmHA farm borrowers quit because of financial trouble. That represented 1.3 percent of the agency's total number of farm borrowers. In 1989, the number dropped to 2,046 who left farming, or 0.9 percent of the agency's borrowers. So far this year, according to first-half figures, 1,314 farmers, or 0.6 percent of the FmHA's 218,000 farm borrowers, have quit the land. That would be an annual rate of 1.2 percent if the pace continues the remainder of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Situtation Seethes in Pre-Election Romania
DOC.TEXT: Political passions have come alive in Romania after decades of repression and their target is often interim President Ion Iliesco, seen by critics as a Communist agent in liberal disguise. A round-the-clock rally by Iliescu's foes, which began sixteen days ago, has transformed downtown University Square into what the demonstrators call a ``Communist-free zone.'' Iliescu was a high official under dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown and executed in December, but fell out of favor and was given relatively unimportant party jobs. He gained prominence during the revolution, when the National Salvation Front was formed to run the government. Up to 10,000 people have filled the square to applaud speakers, from national figures to workers, who demand that Iliescu resign. About 40 tents have been pitched around the square and 57 protesters are on a hunger strike. Supporters of Iliescu have held at least one rally and rumors persist of plans for an attack on the University Square protest. Knots of people form around University Square every day to argue about Iliescu and the elections scheduled for May 20, which will be the first free vote for Romanians in 50 years. ``People here in the square hate Iliescu because he wants us to live in darkness!'' a woman shouted, thrusting her chin toward a supporter of the president, who retorted: ``He doesn't want to keep Romania in darkness! He wants to create a bright Romania!'' Another woman swept an arm toward the crowd in the square and asked: ``How can Romania become a prosperous country, if people camp outside like this without working?'' On April 29, tens of thousands of people demonstrated against Iliescu in Timisoara, Dej and the port city of Constanta. Timisoara, in western Romania, was where the uprising against Ceausecu began. In rural Romania, horse carts still are the principal mode of transport and people wait up to a week for telephone calls to or from abroad. Many have no access to television, cannot read newspapers and accept rumors as fact. ``Is it true that revolution has broken out in the capital?'' asked a gypsy woman openly selling black market cigarettes in Tecuci, a Moldavian town 150 miles northeast of Bucharest. Moldavia has been relatively quiet, but there is a surge of nationalism among Moldavians across the Soviet border, which was opened for six hours of visa-free travel on Sunday. Vasile Dogaru, deputy mayor of Iasi, the cultural capital of Moldavia, said Moldavians in Romania ``seek no more than increased cultural ties with our brethren'' in the Soviet Union. Many Romanians, however _ including Iliescu _ have said all Moldavia must be part of Romania. In Transylvania, where Timisoara is located, historic frictions between Romanians and the large ethnic Hungarian minority turned violent in March. At least six people were killed in Tirgu Mures, 180 miles northwest of Bucharest, and 300 were injured before the army could restore order. Representatives of Romania's 2.2 million Hungarians say their struggle for minority rights is being suppressed, as it was under Ceausescu. Part of the support for Iliescu rests on the interim government's ability to provide relative plenty after years of privation under Ceausescu, who starved the people to pay off the foreign debt with exports. Generous foreign aid, an end to food exports, increased energy imports and mild weather since February have kept people fed and warm, but luxury items such as chocolate and citrus fruits are in short supply.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Moscow is a long way to travel for a burger and fries, but there's a lesson to be learned for the four students making the trip. To make sure the 14-year-olds from Enslow Middle School understand the ins and outs of world economics, the trip's sponsor, Steel of West Virginia Inc., is laying down just one rule: they must stand in line at the Moscow McDonald's during their 11-day tour of the Soviet Union and Berlin. The company's vice president of human affairs, Larry Gue, said the lesson will be found in the difference between the inexpensive fast-food at McDonald's in Huntington and the one in Moscow, where customers stand in line for hours to spend a substantial chunk of their paycheck for essentially the same items. ``The idea is hopefully they'll understand the American free enterprise system,'' Gue said. The students, chosen from among 25 members of an eighth-grade civics class, leave on Wednesday.

Elvis. The man, the music, the curtain. The elementary school that Elvis Presley attended is cashing in on its most famous pupil, selling scraps of the maroon velveteen curtains that hung on the stage when Presley was a shy, barefoot boy singing at weekday devotionals. The going price is $5 for a 5-inch square, and the Lawhon School has already reaped $3,000. The money has gone toward new playground equipment and a $1,700 sound system for the auditorium. Principal Dale Dobbs said he's amazed that Elvis fans are so eager to buy anything connected to him. ``When the old stage curtains were taken down, they were stored away and not disposed of, probably because someone had the foresight to realize that they might be a novelty. They are definitely that,'' Dobbs said. The sales started last summer after the school's parent-teacher organization got the idea to offer scraps of the tattered curtains to visitors arriving for the anniversary of Presley's death on Aug. 16, 1977. Superintendent Richard Thompson said that for years fans have stopped by the school to beg for anything that Elvis might have used as a student. ``Now we have something to offer them,'' he said.

Thomas Catherall had to be on his best behavior as a judge in the U.S. Chefs Open, especially when he started chewing one amateur chef's lamb kebab. ``I could have eaten my shoe and it would have been more tasty,'' said Catherall, head chef at the Cherokee Town and Country Club in Atlanta. But overall, Catherall, one of 33 certified master chefs in the country, gave the amateur chefs high marks for their culinary creations. ``There was some awful stuff, but there was some very good stuff, too,'' the 26-year cooking veteran said as he pulled two rolls of antacid tablets from his pocket. ``I only went through half a roll yesterday.'' As Catherall and a team of top chefs from around the country judged entries from professional chefs Sunday, thousands of food-loving spectators tasted their way through 100,000 square feet of wines, cheeses, lobster, chicken and pizza offered by restaurants and food vendors who set up shop inside the Georgia World Congress Center. Sponsors said 60,000 people attended this year's second annual chefs open. The top student, amateur and professional chefs who competed in the competition were chosen from among 10,000 entrants and collected cash prizes of up to $2,500. The grand-prize winners also won a week at Le Cordon Bleu, the international cooking school in Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Rainbow Conference Ends; Jackson, Young, Wilder and Barry Slap Backs
DOC.TEXT: The National Rainbow Coalition came to town to put together its strategy for the next year, and a lot of political attitudes got adjusted in Jesse Jackson's favor. The conference, which ended Sunday, was billed as a plenary session with an eye toward reapportionment in the South in 1991. It wound up tangling with the question of black unity within the Democratic Party. Jackson, the Rainbow Coalition leader who has run twice for president, slapped backs with major black Democrats _ Democratic National Committee Chairman Ronald Brown, Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young. Jackson spent much of his time pushing for statehood for the District of Columbia _ something that would create a congressional seat for which he could run. Young and Wilder, whose quiet, mainstream politics are in stark contrast to Jackson's vocal, activist style, came out in support of Jackson's efforts. And Jackson endorsed the gubernatorial bid of Young, who was roundly booed by Jackson delegates during the 1984 Democratic National Convention. There was talk of working within the Democratic Party and moves to end speculation that Jackson and Wilder are locked in a battle over how the party should proceed to become competitive again in presidential elections. Wilder, whose status as the nation's first black elected governor could make him a formidable rival to Jackson's position as the top black politician in the party, said he has no problem with Jackson's leadership. He said he came to Jackson's conference to ``show those who would care to see there isn't that opportunity to split us up or cause us to go one-on-one with one another.'' Jackson, who has never been elected to public office, said he and Wilder are ``inextricably bound'' in their direction; they simply have differing styles. ``He calls it the new mainstream,'' Jackson said. ``I call it expansion.'' Brown, the DNC's first black chairman, set out to discourage talk that Jackson was a divisive force in the party. He said Jackson's bringing thousands of voters into the party proves he was no impediment during the 1988 presidential campaign. ``In fact, he's one of the greatest assets to our party,'' Brown said. ``He was not the reason we do not have a Democrat in the White House.'' But those under the Rainbow wanted to make it clear that they will play hardball with the Democrats to make sure the party addresses the concerns they expressed in Atlanta. ``I don't think we have a Democratic Party I can give my support to, in spite of what Ron Brown says,'' said Mayor Ben Nichols of Ithaca, N.Y. ``What I do know is that in the long run, we can have a Democratic Party which is a real Democratic Party, because we can organize it together.'' Meanwhile, Washington Mayor Marion Barry quietly took part in a mayoral conference on re-shaping urban America _ one that skimmed over the issue of drugs and drug crime in big cities. Barry, who faces trial June 4 on cocaine possession and perjury charges, got at least two standing ovations from people loyal to Jackson, who turned down a chance to run for Barry's job. Barry humbly thanked the crowd for ``your heartfelt and deep-running prayers during my situation.'' He deferred to Jackson's leadership, expressing ``great excitement'' about ``the vision of Jesse Jackson ... to call us together here in Atlanta.'' ``I'm glad to be here on the cutting edge of this progressive agenda,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reed Says He Was Beaten Severely After Escape Attempts
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed, in a riveting account of the brutal beatings he suffered at the hands of his Islamic captors, says he kept his spirits up by using matches to draw pictures of his family. He drew images of his Syrian-born wife, Fifi, and son, Tarek, on the ceiling and the door of his cell to remind himself that he must stay alive if he wanted to see them again, Reed said Sunday at a news conference. ``I knew ... if I didn't keep my life going there certainly wasn't going to be any Fifi or any Tarek,'' he said. ``And that permeates and transcends all of our thinking.'' Reed called for negotiations to free the remaining six Americans and 10 other Westerners held hostage, ``even if you have to get in bed with the devil.'' He said that on several occasions his captors told him that ``all they want is someone to talk to us. ... We had some not so nice (thoughts) ... about people we thought weren't willing to trade or negotiate for our lives.'' The 57-year-old Reed interrupted his hospital stay to give reporters a chilling glimpse of his life as a hostage in Lebanon for 44 months. He said he was double-chained to a wall or radiator and blindfolded much of the time. Reed said his Islamic kidnappers broke his nose, jaw and ribs, slightly fractured his feet with iron rods and bloodied his kidneys for trying to escape twice. ``Thank God they didn't kill me,'' he said. ``I was one of their pet whackers. I did everything in my power not to cry out and not let them think they were ever going to get a single advantage on me. And I didn't.'' His account stunned another freed hostage, fellow educator Robert Polhill, who was at his side at the news conference. Polhill was freed eight days before Reed, who was released a week ago. ``I was as shocked as you were to hear what Frank has been saying here,'' Polhill said. ``I can't say that I was maltreated. I was never beaten. We were not blindfolded, things of that sort.'' Polhill also differed with Reed on negotiations. He said he agreed with President Bush's position of refusing to negotiate for their release. ``I don't like the thought of negotiating for human lives,'' Polhill said. ``I just don't think it's right.'' Reed said other hostages were mistreated but not as badly as he was. He did not elaborate or identify them. But he said he was held at varying times with Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press; Thomas Sutherland, a dean at the American University of Beirut; John McCarthy, a British television journalist; and Brian Keenan, an Irish teacher of English at the American University of Beirut. Reed said he last saw Anderson 18 months ago and Sutherland 14 months ago. He left McCarthy, he said, two days before he was freed. He said the kidnappers made doctors and dentists available to the hostages if they asked for them. ``Fortunately for me,'' Reed said, ``the worst I had was maybe one cold and a half all the time I was there ... The others have not been quite as fortunate. They have been ill and I pray that whatever the illness was, it is not that serious that it can't eventually be corrected.'' He said Anderson, Sutherland, McCarthy and Keenan had been vigorously exercising and ``look wonderful physically.'' He said he stopped exercising because ``I was angry that I had no freedom.'' Over the past two years, he said, the hostages were given boxes of books to read. ``John and Brian and especially Terry go through a book a day,'' he said. They were held in bedrooms in apartments most of the time, he said. At one point, the kidnappers allowed them to have a radio for about three months over which they listened to BBC, the Voice of America and local stations. The hostages heard one broadcast quoting the kidnappers as threatening to kill Anderson and Sutherland if the United States didn't take a certain action. ``The reaction from us was `baloney, they won't do it,''' said Reed. ``And within 30 minutes some captain came down and said, `Don't worry about that,' and we said, `We're not going to.''' Reed said that after his first escape attempt, his Hezbollah guards battered him with more than 200 blows, and he was eventually put in solitary confinement for more than two years. Sen. Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader from Kansas, and Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., also spoke at the news conference, calling for the release of the remaining hostages. Dole urged foreign leaders to press for the hostages' release, and Moynihan urged Israel to release the Moslem prisoners it holds. ``It is in their interest to do and if they're part of the world nations seeking legality and decency, they should now act to bring it about in Lebanon,'' Moynihan said. Syrian and Iranian officials said Sunday the release of any more American hostages likely hinges on Israel's willingness to free hundreds of Moslem prisoners, including Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a Shiite cleric taken from his home in southern Lebanon in 1989. President Bush on Thursday again appealed for the release of all hostages, but avoided comment on whether that should include 400 Shiites held by Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's Economic Woes Have Migrants Returning Home
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people who came to industrialized southern Brazil seeking work are now returning home, frustrated by the rising unemployment the government's austerity plan has wrought. ``I arrived here with almost nothing, and I'm going back with less,'' said Jose Loreno Filho, 30, as he prepared to board a bus late last week at Sao Paulo's huge Tiete bus station. He had a ticket home to a tiny village in impoverished Alagoas state on the northeastern coast. Loreno Filho, who had once worked a small plot of land in Alagoas, scrimped together about $50 and bus fare to come to Sao Paulo in early March. He stayed with relatives and hoped to earn money to bring his wife and four children to join him. But on March 16, Brazil's new president, Fernando Collor de Mello, launched his austerity plan in a bid to defeat record inflation that reached nearly 5,000 percent over the past year. While the initiatives, which include an 18-month freeze on $115 billion in bank deposits, have drastically reduced the cost of living, businesses have fired hundreds of thousands of workers. ``I walked the streets for the past two months, and there aren't any jobs,'' said Loreno Filho. ``The streets aren't paved with gold the way I imagined. Sao Paulo, Brazil's industrial and financial center, has attracted millions of migrants during the past two decades. Most came from the northeast to escape that region's grinding poverty. But since Collor's economic plan was announced, the stream of economic refugees has been at least temporarily reversed. ``Our buses to the northeast have been packed for the past six weeks. And when buses from the region arrive at the station, they've been almost empty,'' said Elias Perreira, manager of the Sao Geraldo bus line, the major company servicing the northeast from Sao Paulo, a city of 7 million people. He said the movement to the northeast is now only slightly above normal. But in mid-April, the company was carrying 1,700 passengers a day, twice the normal number. It needed 11 extra buses a day to accommodate the crunch. Many of the returning migrants were working in construction, which was especially hard hit by Collor's program. An estimated 300,000 construction workers were laid off nationwide, more than one-third of them in Sao Paulo. Edmilson Mariano de Oliveira, 27, who arrived in Sao Paulo eight months ago from the northeastern state of Piaui, recently lost his construction job. ``I've got a wife and two young kids back there, so I'd always planned on going back. But I didn't think it would be so soon,'' he said. ``I'll be happy to see my family, but there's not much work to be had other than subsistence farming,'' he said. Ana Correia Salles, a local social worker, said 99 percent of construction workers in the area are northeasterners, and most sleep and eat at the job site: ``If they lose their job, they lose everything, so it's either live on the streets or return home.'' Even some longtime residents of the city are packing their bags. Jose Francilino, 40, brought his family here from the northeastern state of Pernambuco in 1977. He said he'd always been able to find work. One week after Collor took office, though, he was fired from his longtime job as a metalworker. He was now heading to Pernambuco. ``I never thought I'd be leaving, but I don't know what else to do. My father still works the land, and I wrote to tell him we'd be needing a place to stay for awhile,'' he said as his wife tried to quiet the youngest of their four children. Ms. Salles, the social worker, said the plight of migrants shows Collor was wrong when he claimed that only the rich were paying the cost of economic adjustment. ``The wealthy lost their savings, but the poor are losing their jobs. I'd say that's just as important,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates Worry About Loss of Interest in Inner-City Drug Woes
DOC.TEXT: The perception that illegal drug use is decreasing among suburban whites could lead to a reduced sense of urgency in fighting the nation's war on drugs, some analysts say. As a result, they say, mostly black inner-city neighborhoods may have to find their own solutions to drug-related problems. ``I can see it happening and it's unfortunate,'' said Kevin B. Zeese, director of the Washington-based Center for the Study of Drug Policy, which advocates legalization of some drugs like marijuana and cocaine. Zeese was a speaker at a conference last week sponsored by the Washington Journalism Center. ``Casual use is declining. What is left is a hard-core group of people who are heavily into drugs,'' said Charles R. Schuster, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. NIDA is the federal government's lead agency in researching drug abuse problems. Schuster said studies have shown that in 1985, an estimated 5.8 million Americans used cocaine at least once a month. By 1988, he said, the number had decreased to about 2.9 million. At the same time, he said, the number of weekly users rose from an estimated 650,000 to about 800,000, although he said he believed those estimates are low. Studies have shown that the decline in drug use is primarily in mostly white suburban America, Schuster noted, while use is on the upswing in poor, predominantly black inner-city neighborhoods. Conference speakers said, however, that differences are better linked to socioeconomic status than race. Schuster said he worries that policy makers may lose concern about illegal drugs if they're convinced that anti-drug efforts have worked in middle-class communities. ``There is always that potential; the attitude may be out of sight, out of mind,'' added Reggie Walton, a deputy to federal drug policy coordinator William Bennett and a former District of Columbia Superior Court judge. ``For a long time (illicit drug use) was perceived as an inner-city, minority problem and it wasn't aggressively attacked,'' he said. But a federal Drug Enforcement Administration official said he believes problems related to the inner-city drug trade will keep public attention focused on drug abuse in both urban and outlying communities. ``The issue of violence will keep this on the front burner,'' said David Westrate, DEA assistant administrator for operations. Walton said that while the drug problem appears to ``manifest itself in its worse sense in our inner cities,'' it is simply ``covered up a lot better'' in suburbia, where parents can afford private treatment programs. ``A lot of parents in inner cities do a tremendous job in deterring their kids from drug use,'' he said. Drug abuse ``did not become a real issue in this country until it affected middle- and upper-class families,'' added Joanne C. Benson, principal of John H. Bain Elementary School in Capitol Heights, Md., just outside Washington. Benson has been recognized for her efforts to rid the neighborhood around the school of drug pushers and to get parents involved in drug rehabilitation and community improvement projects. Benson said drug policy makers must make sure that no community is forgotten, even those with little political clout like Capitol Heights.

DOC.HEAD: Family Leave Bill Would Require Job-Protected Time Off
DOC.TEXT: Five Mother's Days have passed since Rep. Patricia Schroeder first advanced a plan guaranteeing job-protected time off to workers with new babies or an illness in the family. The sixth could be a charm. This week, just before Mother's Day 1990, the Family and Medical Leave Act is scheduled to come up on the House floor for the first time. Is it an intrusive mandate that would dictate corporate personnel policies, inhibit flexibility and deprive workers of other benefits? That's what the influential business lobby contends. But supporters say they're asking lawmakers to consider the plight of American families and simply make sure people don't lose their jobs when they are needed at home. ``We're not talking about the M-word, mandates, here. We're talking about the V-word, values,'' said Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J. She said she's telling her colleagues: ``Don't give us lip service about family values if you don't recognize them in this bill.'' Under the family and medical leave act, employees would be entitled to unpaid time off to care for newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children, to cope with personal health problems, and to tend stricken spouses or parents. As Schroeder, D-Colo., introduced it five years ago, all businesses employing more than five people would have had to offer 18-week leaves. In its present form, all businesses with fewer than 50 employees would be exempt and the companies would have to offer 12 weeks of unpaid leave. ``I obviously would much prefer to have something else,'' Schroeder said. ``But we have to act on it. We can't just keep introducing it.'' The business community says it cannot accept a federally mandated benefit in any form. ``There can be no compromise on this legislation,'' the National Federation of Independent Business told Schroeder in a letter last week. ``Moreover, mandated leave is just the first step toward 100 percent coverage and paid leave.'' But House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said many successful companies offer leaves and consider them investments in their work force. ``In the modern world, more parents work and more children are left without the kind of supervision and help they need,'' he said. ``Child care and family leave can begin to fill in those gaps.'' Gephardt said he took advantage of his St. Louis law firm's leave policy when his son had cancer years ago. Companies without such arrangements put employees into a real bind, he said. ``You feel like a trapped animal,'' he said. ``You realize that if you leave, you're likely to lose your job, and that's the last thing you need to do at a time of tremendous expense and stress.'' Supporters of the family leave bill range from the House leadership to a coalition that includes feminist and church groups, pediatricians and labor unions. A House vote is expected in mid-week, and they predict they will prevail on a close vote and send the bill to the Senate. Roukema said she has urged the Bush administration to avoid veto threats before Congress completes action on the measure. She said she is getting mixed White House signals on the bill's prospects: ``Some people say the administration is totally against all new mandates. Others say, well, we'll see.'' Bush, who espoused family values during the 1988 campaign, has said he favors job-protected leave for new mothers, but says employers should provide it voluntarily. ``It is voluntary and a lot of companies aren't doing it,'' Schroeder said. Roukema said she fears the issue could damage her party unless Bush and her GOP colleagues change their minds. ``I'm very worried that this will be used against Republicans,'' Roukema said. ``Polls have demonstrated that Republicans ... are not perceived to be responsive to the working family issue. And what could be more of a defining issue than family and medical leave? It defines where you stand on women, children, grandma and grandpa.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Lawmakers Tackle Campaign Finance Reform
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: A close observer may doubt Congress' sincerity on issues such as the environment, abortion and the deficit. But not on campaign finance reform. Many lawmakers sincerely want to reform their campaign opponents out of contention. For the past two years, the idea of revamping the federal campaign finance system has been at the top of the congressional agenda. But so far there's been more heat than light from the 535 experts grappling with the issue from their seats in the Capitol. The Senate deadlocked repeatedly on the issue in 1988, and agreement remains elusive today. House Republican and Democratic leaders formed a task force on campaign reform in the wake of the ethics-related resignation of former Speaker Jim Wright, and nearly a year later it is stalled. There's little disagreement over the problem. Campaigns cost so much that raising money for them is a full-time job, prone to conflicts of interest and not leaving much time for legislating. But almost any solution favors one side over another. The main Democratic proposal would cap the total amount that candidates may spend in a campaign. Republicans don't like the idea because the Democrats get a lot of off-the-books help, primarily from labor unions. The GOP would eliminate most donations from political action committees, non-monetary help from labor and other groups, and give the political parties a bigger role in House and Senate elections. PACs give mightily to Democratic incumbents while the Republican Party, with President Bush as chief fundraiser, can easily outspend the Democratic Party. Some Democrats favor public financing of campaigns, perhaps through an income tax checkoff, but that proposal is anathema to most conservatives. The differences between the parties are so sharp that in the House, Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., recently agreed to hold off action until later in the spring in hopes the Senate can find some common ground. It is widely expected that the House's majority Democrats will muscle their bill past Republican objections, but the GOP members will get a chance to vote on their alternative. That way, both sides can go home to the voters and say they supported ``reform.'' The Senate could do the same thing, but probably not as tidily and with more acrimony. If pushed hard enough, perhaps by the continuing scandal over campaign donations from executives from failed savings and loans, it's possible a bill could emerge. There are a few areas of possible agreement _ for example, mandated discounts for television campaign advertising. But even proposals that would hit incumbent candidates from both parties equally can be sensitive, such as the proposal by Senate Republicans to place tough restrictions on taxpayer-financed mailings by senators in an election year. The congressional ``frank'' is one of the big advantages incumbents have over their challengers.
