The minority Republicans are looking to make all of Congress more vulnerable, to increase their own chances of taking over. But House Speaker Foley recently refused to consider even the moderate step of disclosing publicly how much each House member spends on mass mailings. Foley said the public has repeatedly said in polls that it wants to hear from elected officials more often, not less. It's too early to rule out a significant revamping of campaign laws. But resistance to any proposed changes must be expected because those 535 experts on Capitol Hill have proven they can master the current system. Despite grumbling about its burdens, it's still the devil they know.
Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Teddy Roosevelt: Bold President, Lousy Speller
DOC.TEXT: Theodore Roosevelt boldly shaped the powers of the presidency but wasn't too busy for nightly pillow fights with his kids, according to a White House lecturer's fond remembrance. President Bush and 200 guests listened raptly to the lecture on the ``bold, noisy, irrepressibly energetic'' 26th president on Sunday by prize-winning biographer David McCullough. Bush called Roosevelt ``a favorite of mine, a man who helped shape the modern presidency, the inexhaustible T.R.'' The audience included congressional leaders who met afterward with Bush to discuss future budget negotiations. Bush smiled broadly at House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., when McCullough read from one letter in which Roosevelt complained he felt ``like a stewed owl'' after dealing with members of Congress all day. Roosevelt's solution to such frustrations was vigorous physical activity, including workouts with Japanese wrestlers that left him bruised from head to toe. He once marched two British visitors right through a duck pond on the White House grounds that fortunately turned out to be only three feet deep. Roosevelt, only 42 when he became president in 1901 upon the assassination of William McKinley, was the first tennis-playing president, as well as the first to ride in an automobile, fly in a plane, sail on a submarine and venture abroad. He dispensed with the formality of being addressed as ``Your Excellency'' and paid no heed to public opinion. McCullough quoted the Rough Rider as saying, ``I don't know what they think. I just know what they ought to think.'' When Congress objected to his sending 16 U.S. battleships on a tour around the world, Roosevelt sent the fleet off anyway. ``Theodore determined that there was enough money in the Treasury to send them halfway. So he said, `I'll send them halfway and Congress can decide whether to appropriate the money to bring them back again,''' said McCullough, author of ``Mornings on Horseback,'' an account of Roosevelt's early years. Roosevelt was a prime participant in ``rampant, wild pillow fights almost every night'' with his six children, the writer said. He went on a real-life safari after leaving office in 1909, but his reluctance once to fire upon a small bear led a New York toymaker to conceive a novelty item: the ``teddy'' bear. He set aside millions of acres for national forests and parks and ``did more for conservation than any president before and very few since,'' McCullough said. He renovated a ``somewhat creepy'' White House and scuttled plans to fill the mansion with offices and make the president live elsewhere. ``He couldn't spell worth anything,'' but read a book each night and could quote from them years later, the author said. He created a stir in the South by inviting Booker T. Washington of Tuskegee Institute as the first black dinner guest at the White House. That so delighted pianist Scott Joplin that he promptly wrote ``The Strenuous Life Rag'' in Roosevelt's honor. McCullough interrupted his narrative and had a pianist play the piece for the East Room audience. ``His words, many of them, written or spoken so long ago, still have enormous validity today,'' said McCullough. Among Roosevelt's sayings: ``This country will not be a permanently good place for any of us to live unless we make it a reasonably good place for all of us to live.'''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Evidence Missing, Witnesses Abroad in Jesuit Slay Case
DOC.TEXT: A diary that could help convict a Salvadoran army colonel in the slayings of six Jesuit priests and two women in 1989 has vanished, The New York Times reported today. The loss of the colonel's diary and the transfers overseas of four soldiers who may be important witnesses have greatly weakened the case against Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides Moreno, the newspaper said. The developments also may hurt efforts to prove that other high military officials were involved in or tried to cover up the killings, the Times quoted unidentified Salvadoran judicial officials as saying. Six priests, their cook and her daughter were slain Nov. 16 in a pre-dawn attack at the Jesuit-run Central American University, which lies just outside the capital, San Salvador. Benavides and seven other officials were chargd with the slayings in January. Critical evidence, including the diary, has disappeared, the Times said. Also, four soldiers who were stationed at a military school run by Benavides have been transferred abroad to study, and two other witnesses failed to appear to testify, the Times said. The only evidence so far against Benavides, the highest ranking official ever charged in a human rights case in the country, consists of statements by some of the seven other officials charged in the case. In El Salvador, a defendant's statement can't be used against a co-defendant, the paper said. Investigators believe the colonel's diary lists his activities and the meetings he attended before the killings, the Times said. Another missing piece of evidence is a log from the military school that the colonel headed. The tribunal investigating the slayings was told that the log was lost. It might show who entered and left the school the night of the killings, the report said. The four soldiers who were transferred also may have been able to say who was at the campus that night. They were responsible for logging the names of anyone entering or leaving the campus.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,956.27, up 782.63 points, or 2.59 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Medical Student Wants to be Doctor by 17
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: He's 12 years old and his goal is not to set video game scoring records but to be the youngest doctor in the world. Meet third-year pre-medical student Balamurati Krishna Ambati, a prodigy who wants to graduate medical school before he turns 18. While the would-be ``Doogie Howser'' is causing some nervousness at New York University, Friedrich Ulfers, director of the Presidential Scholars program, which awarded him a full scholarship, is pleased with his pace. ``What if we had told Mozart he was too precocious?'' Ulfers said. The youngster mastered calculus at age 4 and described himself as ``a prodigy with a purpose'' on his college application. He said that after learning that an Israeli, at 18, was the youngest medical school graduate, he decided that he wanted to beat that record. A reference to the TV program ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' about a teen-age doctor, doesn't draw much of a response from Bala, as he is known. He's never seen the show, preferring the news, ``Jeopardy'' and ``Star Trek, the Next Generation.'' He was born in India and was 3 when his parents moved to Buffalo. As his father, Ambati Murati, an industrial engineer, and his mother, Gomathi Rao, a mathematics teacher, moved around the country, Bala skipped grades and excelled. Some of his professors don't share the enthusiasm of Bala and his family. ``I worry that it is the parents that are pushing,'' said physics professor Leposava Vuskovic. ``It is one thing to perform and be creative, but he just wants to get the degree.'' The boy's father said he has had to fight school administrators to get Bala skipped to higher grades. And the idea of a 14-year-old medical school applicant doesn't sit too well in some quarters. ``I think questions might be legitimately raised about his emotional maturity,'' said Dr. Andrew Frantz, chairman of the admissions committee at Columbia University's medical school. ``Why does he need to? Why not wait?'' The boy's father won't listen to that kind of talk. ``As we have set this goal, even if he only gets into the worst medical school in New York, we will go for it,'' Murati said.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar PACs Sweeten Coffers of Friendly Congressmen
DOC.TEXT: Sugar growers contributed more than $3.3 million to congressional campaigns between 1983 and 1989 as part of an effort to keep U.S. sugar prices artificially high, a consumer group says. ``U.S. sugar support policies artificially keep the price of sugar so high that consumers have spent billions more than they should have,'' Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, said Sunday. Officials for the sugar industry acknowledge the campaign contributions but disputed the contention that consumers are paying too much for their product. ``The program keeps prices stable,'' said Joe Terrell, spokesman for the American Sugar Alliance. ``Consumers in this country pay on average about what is paid in developed countries worldwide, or less in some cases.'' Critics contend that the system of price supports and quotas for sugar is among the most blatantly protectionist of any U.S. farm programs. Many foreign suppliers are Third World countries whose economies rise and fall dramatically depending their access to the U.S. market.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. and Japanese Politicians Urged To Lower their Voices
DOC.TEXT: A business group is telling political leaders in Japan and the United States to go to work solving their own problems at home rather than blame each other for trade friction. The Commission on U.S.-Japan Relations for the 21st Century, including corporate chiefs whose firms have prospered in Japan, said some of the home-grown problems in the United States are the federal budget deficit and the American emphasis on quick corporate profits. The two countries should ``acknowledge that there is blame enough to go around, get on with expanding the horizons of cooperation, while working through the disputes that frustrate both,'' said a report issued by the commission last week. Besides protectionism and economic decline, a breakdown of U.S.-Japanese cooperation could have serious political consequences, said commission Chairman Edson W. Spencer, former chief executive officer of Honeywell Corp., chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council and board chairman of the Ford Foundation.
DOC.HEAD: Farrakhan Says Washington Politicians Ineffective
DOC.TEXT: Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, says Muslims are fielding candidates for public office because current officeholders in the Washington area have been ineffective in dealing with drugs, crime and other social problems. Farrakhan's statements Saturday angered some Congressional leaders and black politicians who say chances of building a coalition have been hurt. ``I don't think anyone can go around and make a blanket indictment on black leadership,'' said Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga. ``These people who are so apt to question black leadership, where were they 25 years ago when we marched across the bridge to Selma?'' Farrakhan made the comments at a local housing project where Muslims two years ago launched a local antidrug program that rid the neighborhood of open-air drug markets. Abdul Alim Muhammad, Farrakhan's national spokesman and executive director of the neighborhood antidrug program, said he will seek the Fifth District U.S. House seat from Prince Georges County, a Maryland suburb of Washington. George X Cure, a legal adviser to a group of Muslims who have fought drug trafficking through an organization called Dopebusters, said he will run for the District of Columbia's non-voting seat in the House.

DOC.HEAD: JCS Head Says Pentagon Review Could Cut Budget by 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A comprehensive review of U.S. defenses could permit spending cuts of 20 to 25 percent, the nation's top military officer was quoted as saying today. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said American weapons systems, personnel levels, training practices and military strategy should be transformed to adjust to the much-diminished Soviet threat, the Washington Post reported. ``We know we have to get smaller,'' Powell said in the Post interview. ``We can go down considerably.'' But Powell, an Army general who served as national security adviser in the Reagan administration, said some congressional critics were proposing to put the defense budget ``in too steep a dive.'' The aim of a top-to-bottom review would be to determine the minimum forces the United States needs, he said. ``There is a base level below which you can't go ... because we are a superpower with worldwide interests,'' the newspaper quoted him as saying. Powell said he did not want to spell out his views for future budgets, but said he believed a ``fundamental break point'' would occur ``somewhere in the neighborhood of maybe a 20 to 25 percent reduction from where we are now'' in both force size and military spending, the Post reported. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proposed cutting the current $291 defense billion budget by 2 percent each year through 1997, after taking into account the effects of inflation. Powell told the Post that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political and military changes mean the United States no longer needs to see the Soviet Union as ``a real and present danger who's coming at me tomorrow.'' Instead of seeing the Soviets as the enemy, Powell said, ``I want to deal straight up with them as businessmen ... like two real estate lawyers closing a deal. I want title insurance, I want a termite inspector.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Secretly Bought Soviet Weapons From Romania
DOC.TEXT: Over the past decade, Communist Romania sold advanced Soviet weaponry to the United States in secret deals worth more than $40 million, according to a published report. Two brothers of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu served as brokers for the deals, and 20 percent of the money wound up in Swiss bank accounts controlled by the Ceausescu family, The Washington Post reported on Sunday. The paper based its account on unnamed intelligence sources, and said the arms purchases were of immense value to U.S. intelligence. The Romanian operation was interrupted when Ceausescu was overthrown and executed, the Post said. A few days later, one of the brothers, Marin Ceausescu, was found hanged in the basement of the Romanian trade mission in Vienna, which he headed. The other, Lt. Gen. Ilie Ceausescu, deputy defense minister, is under arrest in the Romanian capital Bucharest. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, speaking with reporters en route back to Washington from Europe on Sunday, said ``I'm not aware of the story. I'm not aware of it (the arrangement).'' Stephen Hart, a deputy White House spokesman, declined to discuss the report. The Post reported that ``the Ceausescu connection'' was part of a larger, $250 million operation by the CIA and U.S. military to buy weapons and technology from the military in Eastern European countries allied with the Soviets. Last year's pro-democracy upheaval in Eastern Europe has disrupted the broader operation, but not stopped it, the newspaper said. From Romania alone, the acquisitions included the latest version of an antiaircraft system called the Shilka; mobile rocket launchers modified and improved by the Romanians; and radar systems used by Soviet antiaircraft weapons, the newspaper said. ``The potential value of these things is almost incalculable,'' an unidentified U.S. intelligence officer was quoted as saying. ``The only way you can truly unlock the secrets of your adversaries' weapons is to physically have them.'' Nicolae Ceausescu was not personally involved in the dozen or so sales, the Post said, but it quoted American officials as saying they believed the sales could not have taken place without the dictator's tacit approval.

DOC.HEAD: Last of Flood Victims at Shelter Waiting to Go Home
DOC.TEXT: Richard Cooksie tried to walk home over the weekend but turned back. He would have had to swim the last block. The 63-year-old retired construction worker found himself back at a temporary shelter Sunday night, passing his time making mental lists of what possessions he might be able to save from the Trinity River flood that has swamped his home since Thursday. It's not the first time Cooksie has been forced out by high water. Flooding devastated his previous home in Rochester Park, a suburb southeast of Dallas, last summer. ``Everything I had was totally destroyed, for two years in a row,'' he lamented. ``I had moved from where I lived before. It was higher. I thought it was high ground. I moved two blocks up, but the same thing happened.'' The only thing Cooksie managed to grab when he discovered water from the rain-swollen river was rising rapidly early Thursday was one pair of pants and a few changes of underwear, he said. Flood stage is 30 feet and the Trinity stood at 43.8 feet in Dallas early today. More than 400 people have been forced from their homes. Cooksie, who said he depends entirely on monthly Social Security checks, was one of the last flood victims to remain at the Exline Recreation Center, which has served as Dallas' main shelter for flood victims. Many others have found lodging with relatives or have been given vouchers for hotel rooms, authorities said. Officials expected no more than 10 people to spend Sunday night at the shelter, down from more than 50 the night before. Rickey Henderson, a 30-year-old unemployed handyman staying at the shelter, said he had managed to make it back to Rochester Park over the weekend. His gamble of storing all his furniture in someone else's apartment on the second floor had paid off, he said. It was still there. Police reported at least two looters were arrested for wading into the flooded areas and floating stolen goods out using inner tubes and trash cans. ``It's not bad here, and it's not good, but it's better than being nowhere,'' Henderson said of life at the shelter. ``We watch TV here, we go outside, we walk kids around, we play basketball, or something, but mostly we just talk to other people.'' Henderson said he would like to move to an area where floods are something people only watch on TV, but he can't afford to move away from the federally subsidized housing project where he lives along with his mother and two nieces. ``They say it's not going to be until 1993 until they can stop flooding down there,'' he said. ``I would like to move to a better location, but I don't know how.''

DOC.HEAD: Wreckage Checked for Clues to Cause of Guatemala Crash
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are picking through the wreckage of a U.S.-manned cargo plane in efforts to determine why it crashed into a residential neighborhood, ripping through homes and killing 19 people. Relatives of victims in the DC-6 crash worked with officials Sunday to identify charred bodies. The crash had caused propane tanks used for cooking to catch fire, hampering rescue efforts. Three U.S. crew members and 16 people on the ground were killed when the Aerial Transit Co. plane, carrying snow peas and cloth to Miami, crashed shortly after takeoff Saturday afternoon. Twenty people were injured and 16 houses damaged in two densely populated neighborhoods in southwestern Guatemala City. Efforts to identify victims were suspended Sunday night but were expected to resume today, officials at the morgue at San Vicente Hospital said. All but the tail of the plane was removed from the site Sunday, and investigators began examining the wreckage for clues to the cause of the crash. The plane went down about five minutes after taking off from the city's international airport. ``They apparently had some problem with one engine, and as they were making the go-around, apparently it crashed,'' Tom Stocks, vice president of Aerial Transit, said at the company's base in Miami. He said there were no problems when the plane left Miami on Saturday for El Salvador and Guatemala. He said he expected a U.S. investigation of the crash. The U.S. crew members were Capt. Joseph Babody of Detroit; co-pilot J. Theodore of Palm Beach, Fla.; and engineer Dallas White of Miami Springs, Fla., he said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Flock into Soviet Union During Brief Border Opening
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people, some chanting ``Greater Romania,'' streamed across the Soviet border to visit their ethnic Romanian brethren after the frontier was opened for the first time in decades. For six hours on Sunday, Romanians needed no visas to cross into the Soviet republic of Moldavia, which was known as Bessarabia and was part of Romania before the Soviets seized it 50 years ago. ``Let's cover the wound of Moldavia with flowers ... and see our forgotten brothers again,'' said an appeal published in Faclia, the local daily in the Soviet republic's capital of Kishenev. Demands for the return of Bessarabia have grown strongly on both sides of the border since the December overthrow and execution of hard-line Communist Nicolae Ceausescu in a popular revolution. Political reforms have allowed free expression of nationalist yearnings in the Soviet Union and the nationalist fervor was tangible Sunday as Romanians streamed through eight temporarily opened border crossings into Soviet Moldavia. At least 40,000 exuberant, flag-waving people poured over Ungheni bridge, throwing flowers into the Prut River that forms the frontier. Many carried Romanian-language books and records to their kin in the Soviet Union. When the bridge became crowded, some people decided not to wait and swam the river instead. Other groups of people stood on the banks of the Prut, heatedly arguing the question of possible reunification. ``This `bridge of flowers' is our first crack in the wall, for Bessarabia was always Romanian,'' said 24-year-old electrician Vasile Haciu. Local inhabitants said hundreds of thousands of people flooded through the border crossings into Soviet Moldavia, but no official figures were available. The border opening occurred at the initiative of the Popular Front of Moldavia and other cultural organizations, official and independent, on both sides of the river. Soviet sources said the request was approved April 17 by Moldavia's Parliament. It was not known whether Moscow gave its formal approval. Soviet citizens were not allowed to cross into Romania, but small groups from Kishinev sneaked in. The Soviet Union occupied Bessarabia and the north of Bukovina in 1940 after signing the Hitler-Stalin pact with Nazi Germany. The two regions were then joined as Soviet Moldavia, and for decades _ under Stalinist leaders in both countries _ talk of reunification was taboo. But with the dramatic political changes in Romania and the Soviet Union, people on both sides of the border are now talking of increased ties. Soviet Moldavians last year were finally permitted to restore the Latin script for their language, which is virtually identical to that of Romania. Stalin imposed the Russian Cyrillic script on the area. ``The tragedy of the Romanian people started with the Hitler-Stalin pact, when unjust frontiers were imposed,'' said Gheorghe Ghimpu, head of the official Popular Front of Moldavia, a Communist-run umbrella organization. Many fear that talk of reuniting Romania and Soviet Moldavia will exacerbate political tensions in the Soviet Union, where Moscow is already feuding with secessionist republics in the Baltics. The interim government in Bucharest that took over after Ceausescu's executed has not explicitly rejected the idea of reunification. But it has offered no specific initiatives.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says He Won't Travel to Cuba This Year
With PM-Pope-Mexico, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II says he will not visit Cuba this year, despite a Vatican announcement last month that the pontiff might travel to the Communist country in December. ``It seems that this project will not be mature for the end of the year,'' John Paul told reporters Sunday on the papal flight from Rome to Mexico City. ``The invitations have arrived,'' the pontiff said, but the Cuban bishops, the Vatican and the government of President Fidel Castro have yet to agree on a date. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said December had been only one of several possible dates for a trip. John Paul has visited every country in Central and South America during his pontificate, but he has never been able to visit Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dips, Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar eased against the Japanese yen today, sending share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange soaring. The dollar closed at 157.80 yen, down 0.75 yen from Wednesday's close of 158.55 yen. The market was closed Thursday and Friday for holidays. It opened at 158.36 yen and rose no higher than 158.37 yen before falling on news reports that financial authorities of seven major industrialized nations had agreed to correct the current level of exchange rates. Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven _ the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada _ agreed Sunday that the present level ``may still have undesirable consequences for the global adjustment process,'' David Mulford, the U.S. Treasury's undersecretary for international affairs, told a news conference. Now, however, ``market players are sitting on the sidelines ahead of the U.S. government bond auction that starts Tuesday,'' said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 483.81 points on Wednesday, rose another 782.63 points, or 2.59 percent, closing at 30,956.27. Securities dealers said investors were encouraged by the strong showing of stock markets around the world and the strengthening of the Japanese yen. ``The yen's rise gave investors incentive to buy domestic market-oriented shares,'' said a dealer with a major Japanese brokerage, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said construction, real estate and mining-related shares were main beneficiaries of the yen's rise today. But the rising yen worked against export-oriented issues such as electricity and automobile shares, which had led the Tokyo market in recent weeks when the yen was falling. Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer with Nikko Securities, said the strong showing of foreign stock markets, especially New York's, also encouraged investors in Tokyo. In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.19 points last Friday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 86.29, up 0.37 points from 85.92 points on Wednesday. The yield fell to 7.310 percent from 7.390 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Retarded Man, Ostracized by Neighbors, Accused in Theft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arraignment scheduled for noon EDT.
DOC.TEXT: A retarded man whose release to a group home after three decades in a mental hospital spurred a public outcry was behind bars today for investigation of theft and attempted burglary. Bernt Murphy, 52, was jailed Sunday following a report of an attempted break-in Saturday night at a home about seven blocks from where he lives, said Detective Gerald Nielsen. Murphy awaited arraignment today. The incident renewed the outrage of neighbors who have argued that retarded men with histories of violence should not be housed in a residential area. Murphy spent 31 years in the Utah State Hospital after being arrested in the 1957 rape of a 5-year-old girl. During police interviews, he confessed to killing a 23-year-old woman. He was judged incompetent to stand trial for rape and was never charged in the slaying. In 1989, the Utah Supreme Court ordered his release after finding Murphy had been mistakenly ruled insane. He moved into the group home in January, and within days neighbors stormed a City Council meeting to demand his removal. In the weekend incident, the house was not entered, but the homeowner's dog was stolen and trophy bearing Murphy's name was discovered outside the back door and a pair of his sunglasses was found in the animal's doghouse, Nielsen said. Witnesses reported seeing Murphy with the dog, police said. Nielsen said it was unlikely, based on the evidence, that Murphy had been framed. He would not elaborate. Murphy had called police at least twice Thursday and Friday to report he was being harassed by boys, but officers found no indication of trouble, Nielsen said. The group home houses three other men under a restrictive permit issued by the City Council. Murphy's attorney filed a complaint with the Department of Housing and Urban Development, charging that the protests and the city requirements violated Murphy's rights. HUD is investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovaks Belatedly Thank Americans for Liberating City
DOC.TEXT: Forty-five years after Gen. George Patton's 3rd Army drove the Nazis from this city, its Czech residents finally had another chance to thank the Americans. The Communists who ruled Czechoslovakia until November had written the American liberation of Pilsen out of their history books. ``Finally the day has come when we can express our gratitude and thanks publicly to all those persecuted, forgotten or erased from world history,'' President Vaclav Havel told up to 40,000 people who packed the city's central square Sunday for Liberation Day celebrations. ``Many of them ... did not live to see this well-deserved recognition by our country,'' said the former dissident playwright. But scores of U.S. veterans did take part in the weekend celebrations in this western Bohemian city, which was for the first time the site of the main Czechoslovak observance of the end of World War II. In past years, the celebrations took place in Prague, the capital, and highlighted only the Soviet role in the country's liberation. Under the hard-line Communist rulers toppled in last fall's peaceful revolution, the official position was that only the Soviet Red Army liberated Czechoslovakia in 1945. Czech revelers drove restored World War II jeeps through Pilsen and wore American Army uniforms. It was a moving experience for the many elderly American veterans who took part. Many were making their first trip back. ``They stole our hearts then, and they are doing it again today,'' said Bobby Capps, of Birmingham, Ala., now retired to Lake Alfred, Fla., who was a member of the 396th Field Artillery. ``You can't describe how much love there is.'' The holiday brought tens of thousands of people to Pilsen from across western Czechoslovakia to drink the famous Pilsener beer, eat sausages, hear speeches and indulge in a festival of Americana, including country and western bands, swing music and a U.S. film festival featuring ``Patton,'' starring George C. Scott. People displayed U.S. and Czechoslovak flags in the windows of their homes and flew the Stars and Stripes from car antennae. ``This is a dream, something genuinely unbelievable,'' said Czech singer Pavel Bobek, who recalled visiting Pilsen as a 7-year-old and seeing the U.S. troops. During a ceremony at city hall, a plaque commemorating the U.S. liberation was remounted. It had been taken down by Stalinist authorities at the height of the Cold War in 1951. ``All Americans thank Czechoslovakia for putting American soldiers back in their true place in history,'' U.S. Ambassador Shirley Temple Black, the former child film star, said during the ceremony. Earlier in the day, Havel spoke at a ceremony in the small town of Rokycany, where a plaque was unveiled honoring the troops of the U.S. 9th Infantry Regiment, 2nd Division, who rolled into town in their jeeps on May 5, 1945. Rokycany is near the demarcation line where U.S. troops halted their eastward advance in World War II's closing days as part of the Yalta Conference agreement, which allowed the Red Army to occupy much of Eastern Europe. Under the agreement, U.S. troops were prevented from pushing on to liberate Prague, just 50 miles away. In 1949, the Communists established full control and set up a Soviet-style state.

DOC.HEAD: Sea of Lava Lapping at Ocean's Edge
DOC.TEXT: Molten rock from Kilauea Volcano flowed to the ocean's edge, and officials warned of hazardous steam clouds when the lava plunges into the sea. The seven-year eruption has destroyed 138 homes in Kalapana and elsewhere on the volcano's flank, 60 of them since April 4. The unpredictable flow has encircled this tiny coastal town, and scientists said lava could overrun what's left of the community within days. All residents have left, some of them bringing their houses with them. Highway 130 is littered with displaced houses and the Roman Catholic Star of the Sea Church, which have been temporarily moved out of harm's way. One arm of the flow pooled at the base of sand dunes near Harry K. Brown State Park, said Bruce Butts, deputy administrator for Hawaii County Civil Defense. It was just a matter of time until enough lava amassedto spill over the sand and into the ocean, he said. Hot lava mixing with salt water produces steam clouds, known as laze, that contain hydrochloric acid and other hazardous chemicals. ``Our main concern is the trade winds,'' said Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. ``As long as there are trade winds, the laze will be blown away.'' The Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church and Kalapana Store and Drive-In at the heart of the community were standing Sunday, but Butts said the lava threatened both. Lava felled two more houses Sunday and overran the park, forcing the Civil Defense command center to move to higher ground at a papaya grove. Gov. John Waihee asked that the town and other coastal communities inundated by lava over the years be declared a federal disaster area. Waihee estimated damage at $61 million.

DOC.HEAD: Sweepstakes Winner Elected Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Bob Castleberry always wanted to be mayor but couldn't afford a non-paying job. That is, until he won $10 million in the Publishers Clearing House Sweepstakes. Castleberry, 60, beat two-term incumbent Ray Stephens 50 percent to 45 percent to become mayor Saturday. Castleberry picked up his sweepstakes bonanza a year ago. After announcing his candidacy, he retired in January from his sales job in Denton, 35 miles from Dallas. He had eyed the mayor's race for years. His father served on the City Council from 1929-30 and again in the early 1950s. ``I grew up watching my father giving everything to the community,'' Castleberry said. ``Now I just want to do what I can.'' The $10 million comes in installments. He got $500,000 last year and gets $250,000 a year for the next 27 years, when a lump sum of $2 million is due.

DOC.HEAD: Lifespan of Condoms Under Study
DOC.TEXT: When is a condom too old for safe sex? The Robert Wood Johnson Medical School is recruiting 40 couples for a nationwide study that may provide an answer. Under inspection are condoms up to 10 years old found in Third World warehouses that are part of a U.S. contraceptive distribution program. Sandra J. Gonzalez, a program development specialist at the medical school, said each couple will be given six condoms, brand new to 10 years old. The couples must have intercourse two or more times a week using the condoms and report back on which, if any, are defective. Only couples 18 and over, in which the women also are using birth control pills or intrauterine devices, will be accepted, she said. Each couple will receive $60. The $30,000 study is sponsored by Family Health International of Research Triangle Park, N.C., a non-profit agency that concentrates on family planning issues in Third World countries. About 150 couples nationwide are expected to participate. Condoms are said to have a shelf life of about five years, but that may not hold true under conditions such as a warehouse in the tropics, said Robin Foldesy, director of materials technology for Family Health International. ``There is probably some sort of threshold,'' he said. ``We don't know where that threshold exists.''

DOC.HEAD: Fair Weather Across Nation
DOC.TEXT: Most of the nation enjoyed fair weather early today, while a cold front dropped temperatures into the 30s and 40s in the Northwest. Showers were forecast today for the Northeast, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and northern Utah. Thunderstorms were forecast for southern Texas. Flooding continued along the Trinity River in Texas, the Arkansas River in Arkansas and on reservoirs in Oklahoma. Low-lying neighborhoods were sandbagged in North Little Rock, Ark., and the Red Cross has sheltered about 1,500 evacuees since heavy rain, flooding and tornadoes swept across North Texas a week ago. Temperatures fell into the 30s and 40s early today in Montana, Idaho, Seattle and Washington. On Sunday, a warm front sent temperatures soaring into the mid-80s across western portions of the Dakotas and near 90 degrees over eastern Montana. Temperatures also were unseasonably high over portions of Florida, including a record for the date of 93 degrees in West Palm Beach. Elsewhere Sunday, showers and thunderstorms developed over much of New York, central and northern New England, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, eastern Tennessee, western North Carolina, northern Georgia, central and southern Florida, southwest Utah and Washington state. The high for the nation Sunday was 106 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Official: Emergency Brake May Have Caused Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said today they were investigating the possibility of brake-tampering on a steam train that was hit in the rear by an an express train, leaving at least six people dead and more than 100 injured. Rescue teams were still cutting at the wreckage of the steam and intercity express trains today, fearing more people were trapped. The passenger trains crashed Sunday night near the hamlet of Brooklyn, 25 miles north of Sydney as the old-fashioned steam engine, carrying about 300 people from a jazz festival, struggled up a steep gradient. The electric train was carrying about 100 people on two decks, en route to Sydney from Newcastle. New South Wales Transport Minister Bruce Baird said it was possible an emergency brake had been on set on a car of the steam train, which had been trying to pick up speed before it was hit. ``There is evidence the hand-operated brake in the third (passenger) carriage was on,'' Baird said. Investigators were also looking at why the express was not aware of the steam train's presence on the track, which has a signal system. The crash site is surrounded by dense bushland, and rescue workers had to drive down a dirt track to reach it. When they arrived, they found debris from the trains scattered over a 100-yard area. Police said six of the 106 people injured were in critical condition. One survivor, Richard Stohr, said the steam train appeared to have trouble getting up the hill. He said the electric train seemed to be trying to pick up speed to tackle the hill when it emerged from a tunnel and crashed into the other train. ``This woman just flew past me _ just sailed past,'' he said. ``I think she was killed.'' Australia's worst rail disaster killed 83 people when a crowded commuter train derailed and hit a bridge at Granville, in Sydney's western suburbs, in January 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Be Alert for Mail Bombs, FBI Warns Churches
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is warning churches in Arkansas to be on the lookout for mail bombs. FBI agent Charles Williams sent letters to church administrators of several denominations urging them to be wary of any unsolicited packages with a fictitious North Carolina return address that might be rigged to explode when opened. Authorities have said two mail bombs that exploded in a Texas church in January and at the Christian Broadcasting Network in Virginia last month were sent from Bladen County, N.C. The FBI declined to elaborate on what prompted Williams' warning. Margaret Ault, secretary to United Methodist Church Bishop Richard D. Wilke, said the bishop sent about 650 warning letters to every United Methodist church in the state Saturday. ``It's spooky enough as it is,'' said Dr. Merle Allison Johnson, pastor of Trinity United Methodist Church in Little Rock. At the Cathedral of St. Andrew, the Rev. Francis Malone said Roman Catholic Bishop Andrew McDonald sent letters to all Catholic institutions in the state. A bomb exploded in the 10,000-member interdominational Lakewood Church in northeast Houston in late January. One person was injured. On April 27, a bomb in a package addressed to the Rev. Pat Robertson at the Christian Broadcasting Co. in Virginia Beach, Va., exploded in the mailroom when it was opened by a security guard. The guard was hospitalized with shrapnel wounds in one leg.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower in Calm Trading, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower in Europe late this morning as a bank holiday in Britain sharply reduced trading. Gold was slightly higher in Zurich. Traders said that although the dollar was down, trading was calm and the U.S. currency was showing signs of steadying after its sharp sell-off Friday afternoon. That sell-off came in response to surprisingly weak U.S. unemployment figures, which showed the jobless rate rising to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March. A dealer at a European bank in Frankfurt said the momentum for a lower dollar had been building up for several weeks and that the U.S. unemployment report was only the trigger. Dealers said a key reason for the dollar's weakness was positive news for the West German mark, including last week's accord on details of German monetary union. ``The clouds that had been hanging over the D-mark are suddenly gone,'' said a dealer at a West German bank. ``It is safe to buy the mark again.'' One trader in Milan said the meeting of finance ministers from the seven major industrialized nations in Washington on Sunday turned out to be a ``non-event'' for foreign exchange markets. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.75 yen to a closing 157.80 yen. Later, in Europe, it was quoted at a lower rate of 157.75 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6600 West German marks, down from 1.6710 _1.4370 Swiss francs, down from 1.4435 _5.5760 French francs, down from 5.6060 _1.8665 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8782 _1,217.50 Italian lire, down from 1,224.50 _1.1620 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1630 In Europe, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6645, compared with $1.6595 late Friday in London. In Zurich, the bid price for gold was $371.70 a troy ounce, up from $371.00 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 34 cents to close at a bid $373.10.

DOC.HEAD: Breslin Apologizes, But Asian-Americans Want Him Fired
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, `In his ...,' to UPDATE with Breslin comments in his column today; pks up 5th graf, `Newsday spokeswoman ...'
DOC.TEXT: Asian-American groups are demanding Newsday columnist Jimmy Breslin's resignation over a racist, expletive-filled newsroom tirade against a reporter of Korean descent who criticized his column. In the outburst Friday outside Ji-Yeon Mary Yuh's presence, the 61-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist called the reporter ``slant-eyed.'' He also said, ``She's a yellow cur. Let's make it racial.'' Breslin apologized to Newsday staffers Friday in an internal computer message that read in part: ``I am no good and once again I can prove it. ... I am sorry. I said things I shouldn't have said. The racial and sexual insults I spewed are never appropriate.'' Helen Zia, president of the New York chapter of the Asian-American Journalists Association, said the apology was ``very flip.'' On Sunday, Zia's group joined the Coalition Against Anti-Asian Violence and the Organization of Asian Women in demanding Breslin resign or be fired, and that he publicly apologize to Yuh. In his column today, Breslin wrote that ``it is absolutely nuts to say that I am bigoted against a young woman from anywhere, including a young woman who is Asian.'' ``Rage is the only quality that has kept me, or anybody I ever studied, writing newspaper columns,'' he added. ``I can control the rage in my writing, which is what I get paid for. I do not control it when I'm shouting off the written record.'' Newsday spokeswoman Chiara Coletti said the paper plans no further action against Breslin, who writes about New York City in hard-bitten, streetwise fashion and covered the Son of Sam case in 1977 for the Daily News. He won a Pulitzer for commentary in 1986. His remarks were reported by the Daily News and in a letter of complaint to Newsday managers signed by 46 members of the paper's staff. The columnist's apology to the staff came after a computer reprimand from editor Don Forst calling his comments ``offensive and inexcusable.'' ``It proves that racism comes in all kinds of packaging,'' said Yuh, a 25-year-old native of Chicago. ``You can encounter it anywhere, from your colleagues, in the boardroom, from your neighbors _ not necessarily people in a white sheet with baseball bats.'' Yuh said she never met Breslin or communicated with him before she sent him an internal message complaining his Thursday column was ``spewing sexism.'' Breslin had written that he hated ``official women,'' including his wife, City Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge, who he said devoted too much of her time to government duties and not enough to the home. Eldridge was quoted Sunday by the Daily News as saying her husband ``doesn't believe what he wrote in his heart, but the way he is, when he knows he's wrong, he lashes out. He just acts that way.'' Breslin said in today's New York Times that he was ``sorry the vulgar language came out. You're supposed to know what you're doing, but I don't.''

DOC.HEAD: Militants Ignore Presidential Plea; Attack Party Offices and Battle Police
LaserPhoto SEL2
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo warned today of a nation on the brink of ``chaos'' but defiant militants stormed his party's headquarters, firebombed one of its provincial offices and battled police in several cities. In a nationally televised speech, Roh said a wave of strikes and protests by militant workers and radical students were threatening the social fabric and the economy. He said the government would guarantee a legal labor movement but ``will deal strongly with illegal labor disputes or collective actions with political purposes.'' He did not elaborate. But even as the president spoke, 21 radicals yelling ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' stormed governing party headquarters and held it for 10 minutes before being driven out. About 50 people fled the building coughing and choking as police firing tear gas battled students on a stairway, witnesses said. Radicals barricaded themselves inside a third-floor office, broke the windows and threw firebombs down on the police while shouting anti-government slogan, witnesses said. Police and news reports said five students were injured and all 21 who took part in the attack were arrested. The windshields of three cars in an outdoor parking lot were shattered by firebombs, and some furniture inside was smashed, police said. News reports said the group scattered leaflets demanding the ouster of U.S. Ambassador Donald P. Gregg. Radicals claim Gregg devised this year's merger of the governing party with two smaller parties to serve conservative U.S. business interests. Radical students also fought police outside campuses in Kwangju, Muan, Punchon, Yongin and two small towns outside Seoul, according to Yonhap, the national news agency. A total of about 2,500 students took part, it said. There were no reports of arrests or injuries in those clashes. Ten radical students hurled firebombs and smashed windows at the Wonju city chapter of the governing Democratic Liberal Party and fled before police arrived, Yonhap said. Radical students are a small minority, and many Koreans do not approve of their tactics. It is difficult to estimate the numbers of members in outlawed dissident groups, but they number at least several hundred thousand in this country of 42 million. In his television speech flanked by Cabinet ministers, Roh said, ``Right now we are in a difficult time. ``We are on a crossroads where the country can either be on a road toward progress or fall into a road toward chaos.'' Roh, whose party has been losing popularity, asked all South Koreans to work to solve the problems of labor unrest, land speculation, crime and eroding confidence in the economy. But the radical National Council of Student Representatives and the People's Alliance, an umbrella alliance of 17 dissident groups, announced new nationwide protests aimed at forcing the governing party to disband. In Seoul, Professor Oh Se-chul of Yonsei University released a statement signed by 1,041 professors at 57 colleges and universities nationwide demanding the dissolution of the conservative governing party. The statement charged that the party represents an effort ``to prolong the anti-communist, pro-American ultra-rightist rule of the present regime.'' Kim Dae-jung, leader of the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, issued a statement calling the party merger ``a plot by the Roh regime to prolong power.'' In his speech, Roh said the recent ``heightening of uneasiness'' had been partly caused by what he called illegal labor strikes at the state television network and the Hyundai group's shipyard in Ulsan, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul. In the strike at the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard, up to 100 workers on a huge shipyard crane began talks on ending their protest with company executives today, witnesses said by telephone. The workers have been on the 240-foot crane since April 28, when police raided the shipyard, the world's largest, to oust strikers. The raid set off a round of nationwide sympathy strikes, but most workers returned to their jobs by the end of last week. Wages have not been an issue at the shipyard. Workers on the crane are demanding charges be dropped against union leaders arrested in earlier protests. In his speech, Roh appealed to workers to refrain from demanding wage increases higher than productivity until the economy has recovered. Inflation has been increasing at an annual rate of more than 10 percent for the first time in many years and the stock market is at a two-year low. In addition, South Korean products have lost some competitiveness overseas because of domestic labor unrest, huge wage increases and the rise of the South Korean currency against the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Driver in Accident that Killed 3 Blacked Out, Wife Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Asked about...', to add quote from daughter that family opposed man's driving. ADDS 2 grafs with comment from policeman that there was no evidence of alcohol.
DOC.TEXT: The driver of a car that careened off a road and plowed through a Little League baseball game, killing three children, had blacked out at the wheel, his wife says. The driver, James J. Harasek, 59, has refused to answer investigators' questions on the advice of his attorney, said Don Doneske, police chief in this Chicago suburb. Doneske said police would ask a grand jury today to subpoena Harasek and look over his medical records. Two boys and a girl were killed and nine people injured in Saturday's accident, including Harasek and six children. All the youngsters were 7 or 8 years old. Two children were listed in critical condition at Loyola University Medical Center today, and one was in serious condition. A woman who identified herself as Harasek's wife, Loretta, said her husband remembered little of the accident. ``He blacked out. He doesn't remember hitting nothing till he hit the building, that's when he knew he hit something,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``I'm very deeply hurt and so upset I can't even begin to say how bad I feel.'' Asked about a report in the Chicago Sun-Times that her husband had a heart condition, Mrs. Harasek said he had medical problems but refused to comment further. The newspaper quoted Harasek's daughter, Anastasia, as saying, ``We wouldn't allow him to drive, but he decided he wanted to drive today. His health is usually OK.'' Harasek's lawyer, Charles G. Levy, refused to comment on his client's health. Harasek was listed in fair condition at MacNeal Hospital in Berwyn, awaiting surgery on a fractured elbow. Killed in the accident were Colin Anderson, 7; Holly Rizzi, 8; and Ryan Womanck, 8. The car traveled nearly 600 feet across the park, crossed a four-lane road and stopped when it crashed into a medical clinic. No one in the clinic was injured. Officer Robert Gordon said he did not smell alcohol on Harasek's breath after the accident. ``I asked him what happened and he didn't remember,'' said Gordon.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Say Norwegian Skiers First To Reach North Pole Unaided
DOC.TEXT: Two Norwegian skiers reached the North Pole after a 500-mile trek that was the first without dogs, motorized vehicles, or supplies delivered en route, news reports said today. Erling Kagge, 28, and Boerge Ousland, 27, pulled their provisions on sleds weighing up to 264 pounds across the Arctic ice pack, newspapers said. They arrived at the North Pole on Saturday. None of at least 12 previous expeditions bound for the North Pole without dog sleds, snow vehicles or outside supplies covered more than 105 miles, the Norwegian new agency NTB reported. The Norwegians trekked for 58 days to beat British, South Korean and Soviet teams also racing for the pole, NTB said. ``They went unbelievably fast,'' Geir Ramby, a third member of the Norwegian team, told the Verdens Gang newspaper. He was injured and flown out 10 days into the trek, which began March 8 on the ice pack north of Greenland. Ramby was in Resolute Bay, Canada, when he received word of his colleagues' triumph after a U.S. military aircraft picked up their radio signal Saturday, the newspaper reported. He said a plane would fly in to pick them up as soon as possible, probably today. ``It's a great accomplishment to reach the North Pole without help. This feat will awaken the attention among those who know how difficult it is to carry out such an expedition,'' Ramby was quoted as saying by the newsjpaper. Kagge and Ousland crossed crevasses and rough ice, and they skirted patches of open water. They suffered minor frostbite in temperatures as low as minus 67 degrees Fahrenheit but were reported to be in good condition. Many expeditions have reached the North Pole since it was conquered by American Robert Peary in 1909. Ramby said his teammates probably will celebrate with a hot shower when they reach Resolute Bay. ``After using and sweating in the same clothes for two months, they're probably emitting a pretty powerful stink,'' Verdens Gang quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Ends Rallies, Agrees to Sit on Government Advisory Council
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a week of sit-ins and hunger strikes in Mongolia ended after the country's largest opposition group agreed to a compromise and joined a government advisory body, Mongolian radio said today. The Mongolian Democratic Association decided late Sunday to join other opposition groups in accepting a government offer to set up an advisory council from which they can submit draft bills and suggestions to the Communist-dominated legislature. Shortly after the agreement was reached, the MDA and its supporters ended hunger strikes in three cities and sit-ins in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator and several other cities, Mongolian radio said. Mongolian President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat, meanwhile, flew home from China two days earlier than planned, but neither the Chinese nor the Mongolian Embassy gave any explanation. He had arrived Friday for a six-day visit that normalized relations after nearly three decades of coolness caused by the Chinese-Soviet split. Mongolia is a Soviet satellite. After his departure, the official Chinese news agency, Xinhua, released the text of a Chinese-Mongolian communique that said the visit ``opened up a bright prospect for further expanding and developing bilateral relations.'' It said Ochirbat invited Chinese President Yang Shangkun and Premier Li Peng to visit Ulan Bator, and they accepted. No dates were set. The communique also said the two sides ``believed it was useful to exchange information and experience on socialist construction and economic reform'' and were ready to hold more meetings on the subject. Mongolia has been following the Soviet example of allowing vigorous political debate but moving slowly on economic reform, while China has introduced wide-ranging economic reforms without relaxing political controls. China has shown concern about moves toward democracy in Mongolia by curbing travel there by its citizens and increasing surveillance over ethnic Mongols in China. China's Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, advised Ochirbat on Saturday that internal stability is essential for economic development. The wave of sit-ins and hunger strikes in Mongolia began last week to press for the resignation of the legislature, dominated by the ruling Communist Party, and establishment of a multiparty provisional legislature until elections are held this summer. A source in Ulan Bator, interviewed by telephone, said the sit-in by 25 to 30 people in the capital's central square, which began Wednesday, had ended by midnight Sunday. It never attracted crowds of more than several hundred, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In contrast, thousands of people attended rallies in January and February at which the MDA and other opposition groups pressed their initial demands for democratic reform. Many of those demands were met, including that the Communists give up their constitutional guarantee of power and allow opposition parties. Local newspapers reported today that the opposition groups had agreed to work together to restructure Mongolia's political system, the source said. Details of the advisory council's size, function and makeup were not disclosed, but it is to work under the legislature's Council of Ministers and be allowed to draft legislation, the source said. The president proposed the council as an alternative to opposition demands that the 370-member legislature resign and a multiparty legislature be set up until summer elections. More than 93 percent of the lawmakers are members of the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Alleged Drug Cartel Members in Missile Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf pvs, bgng `The New York...' with more details from Times report. ADDS 1 graf at end to explain how Stingers work. News conferences scheduled for 11 a.m. in Miami and Tampa.
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has made several arrests in a plot by Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to buy Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, officials say. The cartel's plan may have been to use the shoulder-fired missiles to assassinate Colombian President Virgilio Barco, according to a federal official in Florida who spoke on condition of anonymity. No missiles changed hands, the source said. The number of people arrested was unclear, and Larry Curtain, FBI spokesman in Tampa, refused to comment Sunday. News conferences were scheduled for this morning. But a law enforcement official in Washington who demanded anonymity said several people were arrested in Miami over the weekend in an undercover oparation. And another man was arrested in the Tampa area, the Florida source said. The Washington source said the suspects claimed to be working for reputed cartel leader Pablo Escobar, who is wanted by U.S. authorities on drug trafficking charges. Also Sunday, ABC News reported that the drug cartel had offered nearly $6 million for more than 100 Stinger missiles and a thousand machine guns. The New York Times today put the number of missiles involved at 24. The Times also said that the case is the most recent of several attempts by drug traffickers to obtain the Stingers, and that none of the earlier negotiations had gone as far as the plot that was foiled Saturday. It cited an unidentified senior federal official as its source. ABC also quoted unidentified sources as saying an alleged cartel member had planned to use the missiles to shoot down planes and helicopters carrying Barco and members of his Cabinet as part of the group's campaign of violence against the Colombian government's war on drugs. Violence linked to Colombia's drug lords has claimed the lives of three presidential candidates in that country in the past year. The Stinger is a ground-to-air missile that uses an infrared homing device to target the heat generated by the engine of an attacking plane or helicopter. It has proven highly effective against low-flying aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Lukens Hasn't Paid $1,500 in State Taxes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens, running for re-election this week under the cloud of a sex-related conviction, is now facing allegations that he owes more than $1,500 in state taxes. The Columbus Dispatch reported Sunday _ two days before the Republican primary for Lukens' congressional seat _ that the Ohio Department of Taxation has certified Lukens as delinquent in paying $1,514 in state taxes, including a penalty and interest, on his 1988 earnings. The paper said the delinquency was certified April 18, and the Ohio attorney general's office filed a lien April 27 with the Butler County clerk of courts in Hamilton to collect the money. Lukens' top spokesman confirmed Sunday night that the 8th District congressman hasn't paid the money. But spokesman Bill Jarrell said Lukens and his staff haven't received any notice about a lien. Jarrell said in a telephone interview that Lukens will pay the state once he receives a $4,000 tax refund from the federal government. ``He's more than willing to pay the money as soon as possible,'' Jarrell said. ``He has no problems with paying that back. They (state officials) have never contacted him.'' Jarrell said he was suspicious about the timing of the report. ``The only thing that's a little strange to us is that it came out two days before the election,'' Jarrell said. ``It brings out a good case that the other candidates in this race are nervous about Buz Lukens.'' Lukens was convicted in Columbus a year ago of contributing to the unruliness of a minor when a 16-year-old girl said she had sexual relations with him. The congressman has said he is innocent of the misdemeanor, but lately has been saying he made a mistake in the matter, without going into detail. He was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500 and remains free on bond while an appeals court considers his case. Last week, despite calls from his party to resign, Lukens officially began a re-election campaign he had delayed, pending a decision on his appeal. Also on the Republican ticket are former Rep. Thomas Kindness, who gave up the congressional seat in 1986 to challenge Sen. John Glenn; state Rep. John Boehner of West Chester; and Mort Meier, a bond underwriter from Hamilton. The nominee will be whoever gets the most votes, regardless of whether he receives a majority. There is no provision for a runoff.

DOC.HEAD: First Trial From Undercover Probe of Commodities Markets Begins Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: The eyes of the futures industry will be on a downtown courtroom this week as the first trial begins stemming from the federal probe of suspected fraud in the nation's largest commodities markets. Jury selection before U.S. District Judge Ann Williams was to begin Tuesday in the case charging three Swiss franc traders with trading violations. The government alleges that the defendants _ Robert Mosky, Danny Scheck and David Zatz _ manipulated customer orders and charged the public for trading errors they should have paid for themselves. All three traded at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. They deny the allegations and have pleaded innocent. They are among 48 people, mostly traders, indicted in the investigation, in which government agents went undercover to ferret out suspected illegalities in the trading pits at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. FBI agent Randall Jannett, who posed as a corrupt trader during the probe, is among those expected to testify at this first trial. Mark Fuhrman and William Walsh, two Swiss franc traders who pleaded guilty to reduced charges and are awaiting sentencing, also are expected to testify against the three defendants. Prosecutors allege that the defendants altered trading cards, traded on inside information and engaged in prearranged trades in an alleged conspiracy involving Jannett and the two traders who pleaded guilty. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz are charged with multiple counts of mail and wire fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0448 to restore cycle designator
Sugar PACs Sweeten Coffers of Friendly Congressmen
DOC.TEXT: Sugar growers contributed more than $3.3 million to congressional campaigns between 1983 and 1989 as part of an effort to keep U.S. sugar prices artificially high, a consumer group says. ``U.S. sugar support policies artificially keep the price of sugar so high that consumers have spent billions more than they should have,'' Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, said Sunday. Officials for the sugar industry acknowledge the campaign contributions but disputed the contention that consumers are paying too much for their product. ``The program keeps prices stable,'' said Joe Terrell, spokesman for the American Sugar Alliance. ``Consumers in this country pay on average about what is paid in developed countries worldwide, or less in some cases.'' Critics contend that the system of price supports and quotas for sugar is among the most blatantly protectionist of any U.S. farm programs. Many foreign suppliers are Third World countries whose economies rise and fall dramatically depending their access to the U.S. market.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. and Japanese Politicians Urged To Lower their Voices
DOC.TEXT: A business group is telling political leaders in Japan and the United States to go to work solving their own problems at home rather than blame each other for trade friction. The Commission on U.S.-Japan Relations for the 21st Century, including corporate chiefs whose firms have prospered in Japan, said some of the home-grown problems in the United States are the federal budget deficit and the American emphasis on quick corporate profits. The two countries should ``acknowledge that there is blame enough to go around, get on with expanding the horizons of cooperation, while working through the disputes that frustrate both,'' said a report issued by the commission last week. Besides protectionism and economic decline, a breakdown of U.S.-Japanese cooperation could have serious political consequences, said commission Chairman Edson W. Spencer, former chief executive officer of Honeywell Corp., chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council and board chairman of the Ford Foundation.
DOC.HEAD: Farrakhan Says Washington Politicians Ineffective
DOC.TEXT: Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, says Muslims are fielding candidates for public office because current officeholders in the Washington area have been ineffective in dealing with drugs, crime and other social problems. Farrakhan's statements Saturday angered some Congressional leaders and black politicians who say chances of building a coalition have been hurt. ``I don't think anyone can go around and make a blanket indictment on black leadership,'' said Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga. ``These people who are so apt to question black leadership, where were they 25 years ago when we marched across the bridge to Selma?'' Farrakhan made the comments at a local housing project where Muslims two years ago launched a local antidrug program that rid the neighborhood of open-air drug markets. Abdul Alim Muhammad, Farrakhan's national spokesman and executive director of the neighborhood antidrug program, said he will seek the Fifth District U.S. House seat from Prince Georges County, a Maryland suburb of Washington. George X Cure, a legal adviser to a group of Muslims who have fought drug trafficking through an organization called Dopebusters, said he will run for the District of Columbia's non-voting seat in the House.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands From U. Of South Carolina Account Spent On Hotels, Gifts
DOC.TEXT: University of South Carolina president James Holderman says spending thousands of dollars from his discretionary fund on luxury hotel rooms and gifts was necessary to help raise donations. ``I meet a lot of people who only want to meet in hotels,'' Holderman said Sunday. ``They're important people who contribute a lot of money. The hotel rooms are being used as meeting rooms.'' The expenditures occurred during the last fiscal year, according to The News of Greenville and The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer, which obtained the records under the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act. The $533,898 spent from the fund, some of it paid with Holderman's state-issued American Express card, was more than double the amount spent the previous year. The total includes items for the school such as new band uniforms and artworks for the university museum as well as the travel and gift expenses. Holderman on Sunday said the expenses on gifts and hotels for him and other officials were justified since they have so far this year helped raise more than $25 million in donations. More than $90,000 of the expenses charged to the account were spent on travel, including hotel charges for Holderman ranging as high as $826 a night, records show. State law does not limit spending by agency heads on expenses such as hotels. But Rep. David Beasley said the spending was a ``grave hypocrisy,'' since university officials had asked the state for more money to maintain education standards. The discretionary account is funded from the proceeds of campus vending and game machines and concessions. It does not include state-appropriated funds, Holderman said. Among other expenditures were a $1,533 Boston hotel bill from Aug. 19, 1988, and $2,738 worth of flatware from Tiffany and Co., The Greenville News said. The discretionary account was used to buy five paintings for the university's McKissick Museum worth $48,195. Holderman used his state-issued American Express card to buy two bronze sculptures worth $6,900, which he said he charged to the museum's account.

DOC.HEAD: US Restricts Import of Peruvian Artifacts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs White House announcement; picks up 4th graf pvs, The tomb...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration announced today it will restrict the import of archaeological treasures from the Sipan region of Peru. The action is ``designed to help curb looting in the Sipan region'' and responds to a request from Peru for help, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. The action means artifacts from Sipan entering the United States without an export permit from the Peruvian government will be seized by U.S. Customs agents and returned, the statement said. ``The United States believes that the illegal trade in cultural property does immense damage to our hemispheric cultural heritage,'' the White House statement said. The South American nation asked for assistance in deterring looting at Sipan, site of what archaeologists call the richest pre-Columbian tomb found intact in the Western Hemisphere. The tomb was discovered at Sipan in 1987. Experts have said it has yielded important new information about the Moche civilization that inhabited the river valleys of northern Peru from A.D. 100 to 700. Intricately crafted gold, gilded copper and silver artifacts reportedly have been discovered at the site. ``The United States believes that the illegal trade in cultural property does immense damage to our hemispheric cultural heritage and is willing to cooperate with other governments of this region and elsewhere to prevent illegal trafficking in archaeological treasures,'' the White House statement said. The United States imposed emergency restrictions on some pre-Columbian artifacts from El Salvador in 1987, and on some Andean textiles from Bolivia last year. Similar requests from the governments of Canada and Guatemala are pending.

DOC.HEAD: World Jewish Congress Leader Says Anti-Semitism on Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Bronfman news conference, EDITS to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The president of the World Jewish Congress said today that economic hardship in Eastern Europe was causing a rise in anti-Semitism. The congress is holding its first meeting ever on German soil, and President Edgar M. Bronfman acknowledged that some delegates had declined to attend the three-day conference because of Berlin's strong links to the Nazi past. Bronfman told the 500 delegates at Sunday's opening session that a united Germany must ``forever teach'' about the Nazi slaughter of 6 million Jews, nearly two-thirds of European Jewry. He called the Holocaust ``the lowest point ever reached in man's inhumanity to man.'' At a news conference today, he expressed concern for the survivors of Eastern Europe's once vibrant Jewish community and for the nearly 1.5 million Jews in the Soviet Union. These countries are trying to introduce democratic changes at a time of economic difficulties, and Bronfman said Jews once again face being singled out for attack. Referring to anti-Semitic tendencies in such countries as the Soviet Union and East Germany, Bronfman cited attempts to revive ``the age-old scapegoat, the Jew'' during economic hard times. ``We don't like it,'' Bronfman told the new conference at the West Berlin Jewish community building. ``The only way to fight it is to expose it.'' He said he had received personal assurances from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that law enforcement officials will take action against those responsible for anti-Semitic activities. In the Soviet Union, ultra-right members of the Russian nationalist Pamyat organization have threatened Jews. In East Germany, groups of young skinheads have expressed pro-Nazi sentiments. Early Sunday, right-wing militants fought with foreigners in street clashes in East Berlin. The official East German news agency ADN said five people were injured and eight people were arrested. Lionel Kopelowitz, head of the European Jewish Congress, said he had also seen signs of anti-Semitism in Romania. During the Romanian election campaign, the right-wing National Peasants Party has attacked interim Prime Minister Petre Roman because he is a Jew, and some older party members have links to the pro-Nazi Iron Guard of World War II. The World Jewish Congress was formed in 1936 in Geneva to mobilize Jews and democratic forces to stop the Nazis from persecuting Jews. The organization's three-day meeting is to end Tuesday with a ceremony dedicating a Holocaust memorial at the villa in Berlin's Wannsee district where Nazi leaders met in January 1942 to plot their so-called Final Solution to kill Jews worldwide. The ceremony coincides with the anniversary of the Allied victory over Nazi Germany. The Congress' executive director, Elan Steinberg, said about 10 percent of the invited delegates from outside Germany declined to attend the Berlin meeting. There are 80 delegates from outside the two Germanys at the meeting. ``There are people who will not come to Berlin, and they have a right not to come,'' Bronfman said. In his speech Sunday, Bronfman told the delegates that Berlin is likely to become the capital of a unified Germany and ``inevitably, the questions of forgiveness and of reconciliation arise.'' ``Reconciliation is possible if we speak the truth. And, the truth is that only the 6 million Jews who were murdered can forgive, Bronfman told the crowd, which included West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. He said a new generation of Germans should not be blamed for the crimes of their fathers, but ``we do demand, nonetheless, an admission of collective responsibility.'' In an address to the delegates, Kohl said: ``Never may it be forgotten that the genocide of the European Jews was prepared and directed by the national socialists (Nazis) under the violent leadership from Berlin.'' He said it remained the duty of ``all democratic powers, also those in a united Germany, to fight without compromise against those who secretly or openly spread prejudice.''

DOC.HEAD: Fort Worth Rejects Sales Tax Increase for Crime-Fighting Taxing District
DOC.TEXT: Voters overwhelmingly rejected a proposed half-cent increase in the sales tax to pay for a new crime-fighting agency touted as the first of its kind in the nation. The proposed Tarrant County Crime Control and Prevention District lost Saturday by a vote of 22,784 against to 9,179 for. It won support from only 29 percent of the voters taking part in the election. Opponents had handed cards to voters on their way to the polls that warned, ``Your taxes are about to go up!'' The crime-fighting tax would have raised an estimated $45 million a year for police, courts, education, crime prevention, punishment and rehabilitation programs. Advocates said the separate taxing district for crime-fighting would have helped dissolve boundaries between governmental agencies and link private organizations involved in the battle against crime. They said it would have been the first of its kind in the nation. In Kansas City, Mo., voters last year approved a special sales tax, but it was for a slightly more narrow purpose, aimed at drugs rather than crime in general. The new tax there went into effect last month. The Fort Worth plan drew opposition from two separate fronts _ conservatives opposed to a tax increase, and minority groups who said the plan wouldn't be an improvement. Some of the revenue would have paid for four new criminal courts in Fort Worth, a state-of-the-art computerized fingerprint identification system to be shared by all police agencies in the county; a ``boot camp'' for young first-time criminal offenders; and several new community jails. Also proposed were drug education and treatment programs and expanded citizen crime-prevention programs. Half the money from the sales tax would have gone to county programs, a quarter would have been divided among the 37 municipalities in the county, and a quarter would have been reserved for multicity projects.

DOC.HEAD: Raids Turn Up Airstrips, Labs and Silos Stuffed With Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT that drug seizure was the biggest ever in Colombia, and that 1989 Los Angeles seizure of 21.4 tons was the world's biggest. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Gen. Humberto...'
DOC.TEXT: In three days of lightning raids on jungle drug labs and airstrips, soldiers seized more than 13 tons of cocaine in Colombia's biggest drug seizure ever, authorities said. They said that in the series of raids, which ended over the weekend, troops found silos stuffed with cocaine awaiting shipment to the United States. One silo alone was said to contain 20,000 pounds of the drug. The raids in the sparsely populated southeastern state of Meta brought to 110,000 pounds the amount of cocaine seized by security forces in the last 16 months, authorities said.
