They began Thursday, ended Saturday and netted 26,400 pounds of the drug, they said. The previous Colombian record was 22,000 pounds, or 11 tons, found in remote southern Colombia six years ago. The world's biggest drug seizure was 21.4 tons, discovered in a raid on a warehouse in the San Fernando Valley near Los Angeles in September 1989. A Colombian army general said the network of laboratories and clandestine runways found by the soldiers in Meta were believed to belong to the powerful Medellin cartel. Gen. Humberto Correa told the radio network RCN that soldiers, backed up by fighter bombers and helicopter gunships, found small silos filled with cocaine ready for transport. The army found 26 runways where coca paste was flown in from Bolivia and Peru and cocaine was flown out to the United States, Correa said in the interview Saturday night. Five airplanes were seized. Two people were killed in fighting and there were 15 arrests, he said. On Sunday, a truck bomb exploded outside Cali, a cocaine trafficking center, and another was deactivated in Medellin, national police said. Rival drug cartels are based in the two cities. Authorities said they did not know of the motive in the planting of the bombs. Drug traffickers have used terrorist attacks to try to end a Colombian government crackdown, but car bombs also have been used in a two-year war between the cocaine cartels. The Cali truck bomb, made of an estimated 220 pounds of dynamite, demolished a tourist complex that included a restaurant, bar, dance hall and swimming pool, the police said. But the complex was empty at the time of the predawn explosion, and no one was hurt, police Col. Rodrigo Millan said in a broadcast interview with the RCN radio chain. In Medellin, a 550-pound dynamite bomb was found in an abandoned truck, the army's headquarters in Medellin said in a communique. The Medellin and Cali cartels, which U.S. officials say supply the majority of cocaine to the United States, have been fighting for control of the cocaine market in the New York City area. In another development, French police on the Caribbean island of Saint Martin seized 770 pounds of cocaine Sunday aboard a twin-engine plane belonging to Colombian drug traffickers, Interior Minister Pierre Joxe announced. Six people were arrested at the small airport in the French part of Saint Martin, the other section of which is administered by the Netherlands. Several dozen police officers and narcotics agents took part in the operation, French officials said. Joxe said the plane belonged to Cali traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Won't Attend Emergency Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: Syria announced today it will not attend an emergency Arab summit in Baghdad, capital of its arch-rival Iraq, Arab officials said. The Syrians instead proposed that foreign ministers of the 22-member Arab League meet in Tunis to recommend an alternative venue. The Syrians have said they weren't consulted before the meeting place was selected. It was not immediately clear whether the summit would go ahead. The Syrian decision stymied Arab efforts led by Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan to mediate a reconciliation between Syrian President Hafez Assad and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and end an 11-year-old rift. Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa conveyed Syria's decision today to Arab League Secretary-General Chadlie Klibi, who arrived in Damascus late Sunday, Arab officials said on condition of anonymity. The official Syrian Arab News Agency reported the meeting between Sharaa and Klibi. Sharaa suggested ``the Arab League Council convene to conduct consultations on a convenient venue and date for the summit and to agree on the topics to be discussed at the forum,'' the news agency said. The Arab League Council comprises the foreign ministers of the 21 member states plus the Palestine Liberation Organiztaion's political department chief, regarded as a foreign minister in the Arab world. Earlier, Saudi Arabia, Syria's main bankroller, threw its weight behind an emergency Arab summit in Baghdad. Saudi Arabia was understood to have said previously that it would not attend a summit in Baghdad unless Syria did. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz flew from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan, today after lengthy talks with the Iraqi president. He met Assad in Damascus Saturday. Abdullah met with King Hussein in Amman. The monarch, who has also sought to mediate an end to the 11-year-old break between Syria and Iraq, is a close ally of Saddam. A senior Jordanian official said on condition of anonymity: ``We believe an Arab summit will be convened for sure this month'' in Baghdad. ``All the indications are that a summit will take place, especially after Saudi Arabia announced it will attend,'' he said. Assad's dispute with Iraq and his 7-year-old feud with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat are the main obstacles to Arab efforts toward a new unity. Arafat has been at odds with Syria since 1983 when Syrian-backed radical Palestinian factions mutinied against him and drove his guerrillas out of their last Lebanese stronghold. Assad has not recognized the Palestinian state, declared in 1988, and still holds 2,000 of Arafat's loyalists in his prisons. Syria and Iraq have been at odds since 1979. The countries are ruled by different wings of the Arab Baath Socialist Party and are rivals for political leadership of the modern Arab world. Arafat in April called for the summit to be held in Baghdad to discuss mass Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, Middle East peace moves and the crisis in Lebanon. The Iraqis have said they also want to discuss perceived threats from Israel and the West against them. Syrian officials have indicated they do not take Iraq's concern seriously. In Iran, the English-language Tehran Times called the summit ``a political venture'' by Saddam to gain Arab backing in face of Western criticism of his government.

DOC.HEAD: Three-Nation Team Reaches Top of Everest
DOC.TEXT: Six climbers from the United States, China and Soviet Union reached the top of Mount Everest today in an expedition intended to foster good will among their nations and pick trash off the world's highest peak. The official Xinhua News Agency said they reached the summit of the 29,028-foot-high peak this afternoon. The climbers had said they would plant the flags of the three nations atop the peak to symbolize achievement possible through cooperation. The six are part of a 46-member expedition that began climbing Everest in March and originally had hoped to put climbers at the top on April 22, Earth Day. The climbers neared the peak in late April but were forced by high winds to retreat to base camp. They set out a second time on April 30. On their way back down the mountain, the climbers are to pick up an estimated 2 tons of cans, tents, oxygen bottles and other debris left by previous expeditions. Xinhua said the six who reached the top included Americans Stephen Gall, who operates a mountain guide service in Aspen, Colo., and Robert Link, whose hometown wasn't given. With them were Soviets Sergey Arsentjev and Grigory Lunjakov and Tibetan climbers Jiabu and Daqimi, on the Chinese team. Both Tibetans use only one name.

DOC.HEAD: Woerner Says Soviets Still Balking at Unified Germany in NATO
DOC.TEXT: NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said today the Soviet Union has not yet accepted the Western allies' insistence that a reunited Germany be a member of NATO. Woerner, after meeting with President Bush, said the upcoming NATO summit in London will ``most likely'' be held in the first half of July, but the dates are not yet set. The annual economic summit of the seven major industrialized democracies _ all NATO members except Japan _ is July 9-11 in Houston. Seeking to calm Soviet concerns about Germany, Woerner said, ``We do not want to change the balance of power to their disadvantage.'' He said the 16-nation NATO compact was taking on a more political role to fit the changing landscape of Europe. ``We are clearly on the move from confrontation to cooperation,'' Woerner told reporters outside the White House. ``We are looking at this alliance ... as an element of cooperation in a new security structure'' for Europe. ``NATO will clearly be one of the essential pillars, if not the essential pillar, in such a structure,'' he said. He said they are moving toward ``a landscape of disarmament and beyond disarmament, a landscape of minimal deterrence, a landscape in which really all (nations) only maintain as much forces as necessary for self-defense and stability.'' But asked if the Soviet Union has reconciled itself to Germany's being a NATO member, he replied, ``As far as I know, not yet.'' Woerner stopped at the White House en route to Canada, where he will attend a meeting of NATO's Nuclear Planning Group on Wednesday and Thursday near Calgary. Bush announced last Thursday that he was scrapping plans to modernize short-range Lance nuclear missiles in Germany and upgrade nuclear artillery shells in view of the shifts toward democracy in the East Bloc. But in a speech at Oklahoma State University on Friday, Bush said NATO must remain ``the foundation for America's peaceful engagement in Europe.'' He promised to keep nuclear weapons in Europe to help maintain peace. Woerner praised Bush's speech, saying, ``His ideas have gotten strong support, broad support, inside our alliance.'' The Soviets have suggested dual German membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Woerner said, ``To be a member of both pacts is just neutrality without a word.''

DOC.HEAD: Here's a Monopoly Game That's REALLY Slow
DOC.TEXT: Monopoly players no longer need to buy the board game to get their vicarious thrills at cornering the market on Boardwalk, Park Place and other properties in this casino city. Would-be wheeler-dealers can be the boot, the hat, the horse, the race car, the thimble or the wheelbarrow when they participate in a new mail-order Monopoly game in which a computer rolls the dice. Patience is a virtue in this version, which is the idea of a Gaithersburg, Md., company called Mail Games. Each round of moves takes about two weeks. Why would anyone want to play in a game that extends the seemingly endless hours of Monopoly play into weeks, months and years? Mail Games founder Glenn Leyba said the answer can be found in the fascination Monopoly has held for people since Parker Brothers first immortalized the streets of Atlantic City 55 years ago, from $60 Mediterranean Avenue to the highly coveted $400 Boardwalk. ``With this game,'' Leyba added, ``there's nobody standing over you telling you to buy or sell a property.'' He said he got the idea after visiting a friend in New York who was managing a ``Dungeons and Dragons'' mail-order game. In the game's first year, Leyba has advertised in magazines devoted to mail-order games to attract 24 players _ six games of four people apiece. Players have the option of spending $25.95 in real money for a six-month subscription or $49.95 for a 12-month subscription. Atlantic City tourism officials are pleased by the prospect of a new twist on the game that helped bring fame to their city. But an attorney for Parker Brothers, which owns Monopoly, gave a more wary appraisal. ``I haven't heard about this,'' said New York attorney Steve Weinberg. ``I'd like to take a look at it.'' In recent years, Parker Brothers has gone to court for alleged infringements spawned by hometown Monopoly games based on local streets and a Worldopoly game. Leyba said he checked out his product with trademark and copyright attorneys before marketing the game. He said he has avoided using the style and design of the game, although the game literature does suggest use of a Monopoly board to follow along.

DOC.HEAD: Mythic Sculpture Stirs Rumors of Devil Worship
DOC.TEXT: Craig and Bonnie Dale didn't realize what they were getting into when they decorated the carriage house behind their new home with a sculpture of the Greek deity Pan, god of pastures, flocks and shepherds. The Dales thought the bearded, horned creature would make a nice rooftop ornament for the carriage house, which they plan to use as an art studio. But rumors soon swept the town that the Dales were devil worshipers. Pan is usually represented with the head, body and arms of a human but the beard, horns, tail and legs of a goat. It didn't help that the couple's Victorian home had formerly served as a funeral parlor. In April, the trouble culminated when a group of teen-agers gathered outside the home, yelling and pointing at Pan. ``It's just bizarre,'' Craig Dale told The Journal of New Ulm. ``People are taking it way too seriously. It's just a wood carving on top of an art studio.'' The Dales say townspeople who have learned about their plight are spreading the word that there's no reason to panic. ``This thing about being a satanist is very offensive,'' said Mrs. Dale. Dale said he has no hard feelings about their chilly initial welcome to New Ulm, a largely German town in southern Minnesota. He said he realizes it's easy for rumors to spread. ``People don't understand, and they react with fear and paranoia,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Ring Accused of Stealing Eyes From Morgue
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested an eye doctor and 11 morgue attendants for allegedly stealing eyes from bodies in the city morgue for use in cornea transplant operations, authorities said Monday. The scandal broke Friday when a pathologist performing an autopsy on the body of a 20-year-old male at the Caracas morgue noticed that the eyes had been removed, police said. She notified other doctors, who began looking though the refrigerated sections where bodies are kept. Five other corpses, all of young people, were also eyeless, police said. On Saturday night, police arrested Juan Gerardo Schultz, a 37-year-old ophthalmologist, at his eye clinic in Maracay, about 60 miles west of Caracas, said police commissioner Alexis Bolivar. Police also were questioning other medical personnel at the eye clinic, he said. Also arrested over the weekend were 11 morgue attendants, including one man who had previously worked for the Eye Bank, a non-profit organization that helps find donor organs for cornea transplant patients. Police sources said Schultz allegedly paid the morgue attendants up to $23 per eye, and charged from $1,500 to $2,000 for a cornea transplant operation. Clear corneas from dead people are used in transplant operations to replace corneas that are clouded by cataracts.

DOC.HEAD: New Device Warns of Driver Fatigue
DOC.TEXT: A group of Japanese scientists has developed a device that determines if a person is too tired to drive, the University of Tokyo announced Monday. Professor Masao Karube of the university's Research Center for Advanced Science and Technology said the device is worn like a wristwatch and equipped with an enzyme sensor that detects lactic acid contained in perspiration. The density of the lactic acid indicates the degree of fatigue, he explained. The information monitored by the device is transmitted by radio waves to an analyzer so that the wearer can move freely but easily read the information on the analyzer's panel, Karube said.

DOC.HEAD: Stuttgart Ballet Musical Director Dies
DOC.TEXT: Ashley Lawrence, musical director of West Germany's Stuttgart Ballet, died in a Tokyo hospital Monday of an aneurysm, doctors said. He was 55. Doctors said Lawrence, who had been in Japan with the ballet since mid-April, fell in a Tokyo hotel last Thursday and was sent to the Metropolitan Hiroo Hospital by ambulance. Lawrence was born in Hamilton, New Zealand. He had been musical director of the Stuttgart Ballet since 1987. Before that, Lawrence spent many years as musical director of the Royal Ballet in London. There was no word on survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out on Siberian Gas Pipeline
DOC.TEXT: A gas pipeline burst open and started a fire in western Siberia early Monday, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. There was no loss of life or danger to nearby settlements as a result of the fire, which occurred on the Urengoi-Surgut-Chelyabinsk pipeline in western Siberia, Tass said. The report did not clarify if the fire had been controlled. It also did not say what caused the pipeline to burst.

DOC.HEAD: Writer For TV Series `Bonanza,' `Perry Mason,' Dies
DOC.TEXT: Milton S. Gelman, whose hundreds of writing credits included scripts for the TV series ``Bonanza,'' ``Perry Mason'' and ``Quincy,'' has died of heart disease. He was 70. Gelman died Wednesday at a Sherman Oaks hospital, according to his daughter, Maggi. He had undergone heart surgery several years ago, she said. His career began as a radio writer in New York. In the 1950s, he moved to television and created storylines for ``Robert Montgomery Presents.'' He wrote for 25 years for TV series including ``Banyon,'' ``The High Chaparral,'' ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,'' ``Tales of Wells Fargo,'' ``Riverboat,'' ``Mr. Novak,'' and ``Schlitz Playhouse of Stars,'' among others. Gelman also taught writing at the University of California, Los Angeles, and Loyola Marymount University. In addition to his daughter, Gelman also is survived by his wife, Gloria, and a sister. A memorial service was held Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Swollen Trinity River Surges Toward Gulf, Swamps Rural Areas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to CORRECT suburb to neighborhood and update with lake falling, and Subs the 16th & 17th grafs, beginning `On the Oklahoma...,' with 4 grafs to add detail on lake. Picks up 18th graf pvs, `In Dallas...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A record flood crest on the rain-swollen Trinity River surged southward toward the Gulf of Mexico today, threatening to swamp rural areas along the way after devastating a Dallas neighborhood. Emergency workers helped sandbag rising streams in Arkansas. A reservoir on the Texas-Oklahoma line that flooded shoreline homes reached a record height and began falling today, but high wind threatened to cause more shoreline damage by kicking up waves. The death toll from the flooding caused by last week's thunderstorms stood at six today, all in Texas. Twelve Texas deaths have been blamed on weather in the past several weeks. The Red Cross in Texas counted 723 dwellings destroyed and more than 2,000 damaged in the last two weeks by the state's most serious flooding since 1908. Water from the Trinity stood several feet deep in the Rochester Park area outside Dallas, and some houses were submerged. Flood stage is 30 feet and the Trinity stood at 43.8 feet in Dallas early today. More than 400 residents were evacuated last week. Alester Crumbley said this is the third time in a year his home has been flooded. He moved back in two weeks ago after spending $11,000 and several months rebuilding from two floods last year. ``I don't think I'll be able to do it again, I'm so deep in debt,'' he said. North Texas has had 22.06 inches of rainfall in the first four months of 1990, the most since 1922. As much as 7 inches of rain fell within 24 hours in some areas in past days. Flooding continued in rural counties along the Trinity south of Dallas, as high water washed out levees. At Trinidad, 60 miles southeast of Dallas, the river was 47.5 feet deep Sunday, far above the 28-foot flood stage. In Dallas, the Red Cross has opened shelters for evacuees since heavy rain, flooding and tornadoes swept across North Texas a week ago. Through the weekend, about 1,500 people had been sheltered and more than 12,000 meals served, the Red Cross said. In Arkansas, the worst of the flooding was likely in the Little Rock area on Tuesday, when the Arkansas River is expected to crest, said Gary Talley of the state Office of Emergency Services. North Little Rock scaled back emergency personnel assigned to flood-control tasks to give workers a rest before Tuesday. ``We feel like we're in pretty good shape, that we've done all we can in expectation of the river rising another foot,'' said North Little Rock Mayor Patrick Henry Hays. ``The sandbags are doing what they're supposed to do. We feel like we've won that battle.'' The Arkansas was expected to rise to 27.5 feet today and reach 28 feet by Tuesday morning, 5 feet above flood stage. Downstream at Pine Bluff, the river reached 45 feet, its highest level in 33 years, and forced more than 400 people from their homes. Officials said a crest of 48 feet is expected Wednesday, topping the 44.7-foot crest of 1973. On the Oklahoma-Texas line, Lake Texoma was expected to crest today at about 644.76 feet, or almost 5 feet above the overflow spillways. The lake topped the old record of 643 feet Saturday and continued rising even though the Army Corps of Engineers was releasing 145,000 cubic feet of water per second. ``The best estimate the (U.S. Army Corps of Engineers) can give you is it'll go down 3 inches per day,'' said Marshall County Civil Defense Director John Martin. He said wind expected to blow at 15 to 25 mph today would kick up waves that could erode foundations of buildings that are already submerged, and push water up into homes that have been dry so far. A preliminary count Sunday found 83 homes in Marshall County partially submerged by water from Texoma. Despite warnings of submerged power lines, floating propane tanks, trees, docks and other obstacles, many sightseers toured the lake by boat. In Dallas, U.S. Rep. John Bryant toured Rochester Park by boat and came across one of the last flood victims awaiting rescue _ a large dog atop a filing cabinet in several feet of water. Bryant's district is among the 16 counties declared disaster areas by President Bush. Officials of the Federal Emergency Management Agency arrived on Sunday to process claims for relief. About 500 requests already have been received.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed When Police Bullet Goes Astray
DOC.TEXT: A woman waiting for a bus was killed Monday when police opened fire to stop a truck from barreling into a group of demonstrators, police said. The gunfire injured a man, who also was at the bus stop. Neither victim was involved in the demonstration by workers protesting the possible closing of their company. The 23-year-old woman was hit in the throat and died in a hospital. The man was slightly injured in the arm by the same bullet, said a police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The shooting occurred as about 500 workers of the PRB gunpowder factory held a sit-in at a major intersection in central Brussels. A truck broke through a police cordon and headed toward the protesters, and a police officer tried to shoot out the truck's tires, officials said. The bullet missed its target and went astray, hitting the man and woman who were waiting for a bus near the intersection. The driver and passenger of the truck were detained. The workers were protesting in front of two banks involved with the company, which filed for bankruptcy Friday. A court will make a decision on the claim later this week.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 163 and Stop Controversial March
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 163 fundamentalist Hindus on Monday and stopped them from laying the foundation of a shrine at a place of worship claimed both by the Hindus and Moslems. The disputed site, in Ayodhya about 240 miles east of New Delhi, was the focus of bloody Hindu-Moslem clashes last year. Indian news reports said two groups of Hindu devotees were stopped from going to Ayodhya to lay a foundation for a Hindu temple. The arrests Monday brought to 313 the number of fundamentalists detained since Saturday in the area. Bricks for the temple's foundation were also seized, the reports said. Police also sealed off roads leading to the disputed site. Ayodhya was at the center of a controversy between Hindus and Moslems last year and led to the deaths of about 300 people in clashes in three states. Last August, Hindu fundamentalists announced they would build a new temple to their god, Ram, on the site of a 17th century mosque in Ayodhya. The Vishwa Hindu Parishad, which backs the temple program, maintains the mosque was built atop an ancient Hindu temple marking the spot where the group says Ram was born 900,000 years ago. Most of the deaths occurred in late October in Bihar state, next to Ayodhya's Uttar Pradesh state, as bricks for the temple were borne by Hindu processions to the dusty town on the Saryu River. The controversy, which occurred shortly before national elections, is thought to have hurt former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Gandhi's Congress Party lost the election and was replaced by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. The problems in Ayodhya also contributed to worsening ties with Moslem Pakistan. During the troubles last year, Pakistan Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto made several statements in support of India's Moslems. Relations between the two countries have deteriorated further because of a bloody separatist campaign in India's state of Jammu-Kashmir. India accuses Pakistan of fomenting the campaign with arms and training. Pakistan denies the charge and says India is crushing a movement for self-determination. Since Jan. 20 when India launched a crackdown in Kashmir, at least 349 people have died in the state. Twelve percent of India's 880 million people are Moslems and 82 percent are Hindus.

DOC.HEAD: Jackal: Original Plan Was to Kidnap, Execute De Gaulle
DOC.TEXT: The hired assassin who almost succeeded in killing French President Charles de Gaulle in 1962 says disgruntled French officers planned to kidnap, try and then execute the general. In an interview published Sunday in the daily El Pais, Georges Henri Watin, better known as ``The Jackal,'' said the plan went awry before he shot at de Gaulle in his presidential vehicle in the French village of Petit Clamart. The incident was dramatized in a 1971 novel by Frederick Forsythe called ``The Day of the Jackal.'' It was later made into a film. Watin, now a Paraguayan citizen who claims to live hand-to-mouth, said the novelistic version of the Aug. 22, 1962, plot bears no relation to what really happened. ``Reality is too dramatic. I know my own story, and one thing I have to make clear is that there was never a plan simply to kill `the old man' in Petit Clamart. The plan was to kidnap him, bring him to justice before a military court-martial, and only then, execute him,'' Watin said. De Gualle was to be tried for his support of Algeria's independence from France. Watin said the plan was to kidnap de Gaulle at sunset, but the officers who did the figuring used an almanac from the previous year and got the time wrong. The presidential cortege arrived earlier than expected. ``Suddenly I realized that the whole plan should be scrapped immediately,'' Watin said. ``But by then it was too late.'' Watin said he and the two other hired guns shot at the rear window of de Gaulle's car and at the two rear tires. ``For a moment I looked directly at his (de Gaulle's) eyes. Our car was right alongside his, but we had calculated shooting at a car that was practically immobile,'' Watin said. ``Later I learned I had missed him by just two centimeters.'' De Gaulle was harshly criticized in the early 1960s for favoring the independence of Algeria. In April 1961, four French generals based in Algiers and belonging to the Secret Army Organization staged an abortive coup against de Gaulle's government. Shortly after the Petit Clamart attack, de Gaulle announced Algeria deserved to become independent. On July 3, 1962, he proclaimed Algeria a sovereign nation. Watin said after the Petit Clamart attack, the Secret Army Organization sent him to Switzerland, where he was arrested six months later. He said the French government immediately sent a special police unit to arrest him but Swiss authorities decided he was not a political detainee so he could not be turned over. ``Two years later the Swiss expelled me, so I went first to Seville and then to South America. I am now a Paraguayan citizen,'' Watin said.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Agree to Set Aside Differences to Bury One of Their Own
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th pvs, bgng `Also slain' to UPDATE with governor's remarks today. Pickup 8th graf, `Boots said...' Funeral, which began at 11 a.m. EDT, was closed to reporters; further lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XMAS1
DOC.TEXT: Mohawks on both sides of a feud over gambling agreed to put aside their differences for the funeral today of an Indian slain in a dispute in which he had no part. Harold Edwards Jr., a 32-year-old ironworker, died Tuesday after being shot near an anti-gambling blockade on the Canadian side of this 28,000-acre reservation, where Mohawks are torn over whether to allow casinos. Edwards was described as neutral on the gambling issue. Authorities said only Mohawks would be allowed at his funeral at St. Regis Catholic Church. Gambling advocates and opponents paid their respects to Edwards' family Sunday, said Barbara Barnes, spokeswoman for an anti-gambling faction. ``He was a friend of everyone. He always had a smile. He was a total victim,'' said Francis Boots, spokesman for the pro-gambling Warrior Society, a self-appointed reservation security force armed with automatic weapons. Also slain Tuesday was 22-year-old Matthew Pyke, an opponent of gambling. Pyke was buried Friday. No arrests have been made. Gov. Mario Cuomo repeated today that his administration is prepared to help negotiate a peaceful settlement to the dispute. At a news conference at the state Capitol, Cuomo said state police would remain on the reservation ``as long as it seems to me to be essential.'' ``None of the elected chiefs have asked us to remove them,'' said Henrik Dullea, Cuomo's director of state operations and the man who will head the state's negotiating team. Some Indians have demanded that the state police be pulled out before negotiations begin. Boots said he doesn't believe Edwards' slaying and the union of pro- and anti-gambling forces at his funeral would bring an end to beatings, gunfire and arson that have torn apart the 9,000-member reservation for nine months. The reservation's six casinos bring busloads of gamblers from the Northeast, offering slot machines, bingo, roulette, craps and other games. Supporters of gambling say the casinos produce jobs and revenue; opponents say gambling has brought drugs, guns and prostitution and is destroying traditional ways. The Canadian military has posted 260 soldiers and 100 vehicles at the border, and about 500 state troopers patrolled in and around the reservation to keep the peace, despite some Mohawks' insistence that the reservation is sovereign territory, authorities said. The reservation was quiet Sunday. About 200 of the 1,000 Mohawks who fled their homes after the slayings remained sheltered Sunday at a military dormitory in Cornwall, Ontario. ``We will let them stay as long as they want to,'' said Jim Ransom, a sub-chief on the Mohawk Tribal Council, one of the reservation's three governing bodies. ``The reservation is still not completely safe.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: A cantankerous Canada goose has taken on the Internal Revenue Service with a vengeance some taxpayers may only dream about. For two months, the goose has settled in on a parking island at the Ogden IRS Center, chasing employees and otherwise taxing the taxers. ``She gets a little bent out of shape,'' said Dennis Howland, assistant public affairs officer. ``She tries to keep people from getting into their cars.'' Howland said one woman was trapped inside her car for 20 minutes while the goose sat outside the vehicle. She was finally rescued when she put in her windshield a cardboard sun visor saying ``Send Emergency Help.'' A woman carrying pizza to her car was chased by the goose. She dropped the food, but made it to the car. The next day, she found the goose on her car's hood. ``That goose literally destroyed her wax job,'' Howland said. A male employee was outwitted by the bird when the goose reached his 4-wheel-drive truck before he did. When the man attempted to run around to the passenger side, the goose beat him by running beneath the vehicle. Thinking maternal instincts might be to blame, IRS officials confiscated the goose's nest of four eggs and moved it to the nearby Ogden Nature Center. But mom didn't follow. Despite the cranky nature of the loose goose, employees like having her around, and center officials have no plans to move her, Howland said. ``We figure she just doesn't want to be bothered during these taxing times,'' he said.

Drought has been turning many lawns brown, but landscapers have a solution: green paint. Walter Barrows said he has received more than 30 calls a week since he began advertising his grass-painting service. Barrows charges $45 to paint the average-size lawn with a vegetable dye. It will stay green for just over a month. ``This kind of thing is done all over the country with football fields, lawn tennis courts and golf greens,'' Barrows said. ``After working hard all day, some people don't want to come home to a brown lawn,'' said Martin Senn, a manager at La Sumida Nursery, which also sells lawn paint. Painting is just one of several tactics residents are using to keep their yards green since the city, faced with an almost 50 percent water shortage for the year, banned lawn watering. Some have replaced lawns with green concrete, green gravel, stone or bark, hoping that when the dry spell is over they can restore their yards, said Bob McNall, owner of McNall Building Material. Others recycle household water and some buy water from private wells that is brought in by tanker trucks.

Really creative excuses for missed assignments only come along every couple of years, says a Duke University professor who won a contest for submitting the best excuse heard for turning in a late paper. The contest was sponsored by The Chronicle, the student newspaper. The winning entries were published April 26. David Canon, an assistant political science professor, won with his account of his protracted struggle with a student over a late paper. The student first claimed computer disk problems, then said she'd locked herself out of her room. Later she claimed to have slipped the paper under Canon's office door _ or was it his mailbox? ``Sure,'' Cannon wrote, ``just like we were told in 1967, `Our boys will be home by Christmas.''' He got the paper two months late. Canon told The Charlotte Observer: ``This semester I had a woman who had almost every personal life crisis you could think of, all in three months. She broke up with her boyfriend of six years, her roommate had an abortion, her mother got sick. ... ``I think if I write that one up I'll have another winner next year.'' One of the excuses submitted was by a professor, not a student. Roger Kaplan, a literature instructor, said his dog really did eat a library book he was reading in preparation for a class.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Killed In Clash With Israelis
DOC.TEXT: One leftist guerrilla was killed and another captured by Israeli troops and their militia allies today during a clash inside Israel's self-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, sources said. The four-hour firefight broke out early this morning near the villages of al-Teebeh and Beit Yahoun in the Israeli-occupied border strip, the sources said on condition of anonymity. The Syrian Social Nationalist Party claimed responsibility for the attack. The party is a leftist Lebanese group that advocates merging Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, pre-1948 Palestine, Iraq, Kuwait and Cyprus into a greater Syria. Several other guerrillas reportedly fled, and the security sources said Israeli soldiers and militiamen of the South Lebanon Army began a search. Israel established the six- to 10-mile-deep border zone when it withdrew most of its army from southern Lebanon in mid-1985, three years after it invaded. The strip, which extends from the Mediterranean coast in the west to the slopes of Mount Hermon in the east, is a buffer to curb guerrilla attacks into northern Israel. Palestinian and Lebanese guerrilla groups repeatedly attack the occupied zone.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani Official Says Foreign Agents May Have Bombed Train
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with one more dead; pickup 5th pvs, `A police...'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's railway minister said agents of the Indian or Afghan governments may have been responsible for a train bombing that killed 13 people and injured 40. The 4-pound bomb exploded Sunday afternoon in the restroom of a first-class passenger car, according to Mohammad Iqram Bed, stationmaster at the Badami Bagh station just outside Lahore in eastern Pakistan. The bomb went off while the train was stopped to allow the track ahead to clear. ``I do not rule out the possibility of either an Indian or Afghan hand behind it,'' Railways Minister Zaffar Leghari told reporters at the site of the bombing late Sunday. No one has claimed responsibility for the blast. Twelve people died at the scene Sunday, and one person died at a Lahore hospital today, authorities said. A police superintendent said the device was a ``foreign-made time bomb.'' The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, declined to identify the country where the bomb was made. The police official said the bomb would have exploded at Lahore's congested downtown train station had it not been for a 10-minute delay en route. The 10-car Taz Gam Express, Pakistan's fastest train, was traveling to the southern port city of Karachi from Rawalpindi in the northeast. Pakistan's relations with neighboring India on the east, less than 10 miles from the bombing, have been strained since January by a Moslem secessionist uprising in Indian-held Kashmir. The Indians accuse the Pakistanis of fomenting the unrest, which Pakistan denies. Some Pakistani newspapers have blamed a series of bombings in Lahore, Rawalpindi and Islamabad on Indian secret service agents. At least four bombs exploded in the cities last month, killing and wounding scores of people. Mainly Hindu India and Pakistan, a Moslem-dominated country, have fought three wars since they became independent in 1947. On Pakistan's western border, Afghan rebels are fighting a 12-year-old war to topple Afghanistan's communist government. The U.S.-backed rebels have headquarters in Pakistan. Most of the hundreds of bombings in Pakistan over the past few years have occurred in the Northwest Frontier Province. They have been routinely blamed on agents of Afghanistan's government.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Prince wowed the hometown crowd with a rendition of ``The Question of U'' from his upcoming film and soundtrack album, ``Grafitti Bridge.'' Sunday night's 17,000-ticket sellout at the St. Paul Civic Center was announced only Thursday night and billed as Prince's only large U.S. concert before beginning his Nude Tour of Europe on June 2 in Rotterdam, Netherlands. Most of the numbers Prince played Sunday were stripped-down rock versions of a cross-section of his older material with his band. ``I've been to a lot of concerts in this place, but they ain't quite like this one,'' said Prince, who lives in suburban Chanhassen. ``Yeah, yeah, yeah, you all belong to me. And you know what? I belong to you.'' The singer concluded the erotic ballad ``Scandalous'' by lying in a crucifixion pose on a stainless steel heart that was hydraulically raised and lowered.

Lindsay Wagner and film producer Lawrence Mortorff have tied the knot, the actress' publicist said. Miss Wagner, 40, best known for ``The Bionic Woman'' television series, wed Mortorff at a private ceremony Sunday in West Los Angeles, said publicist Joel Brokaw. He said the two met in November. Mortorff's producer credits include the films ``Maria's Lovers,'' ``Lady Beware'' and ``Romeo.'' It is the fourth marriage for Wagner and the second for 41-year-old Mortorff. Wagner has two sons from her previous marriage, Dorian, 7, and Alex, 4. Mortorff has three daughters: Morgan, 10; Emily, 7; and Lilly, 4.

Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater has been released from George Washington University Medical Center after almost two weeks of treatment for a blood clot in his left leg, officials said. ``The clot has been taken care of,'' said committee press secretary Leslie Goodman. She said Atwater, walked out of the Washington hospital on his own Saturday and drove home. Doctors discovered the clot last month after he entered a New York City hospital for aggressive radiation treatment of a life-threatening brain tumor. Doctors said the clot was related. Ms. Goodman said Atwater will continue physical therapy at home to strengthen his left leg and his left hand. Atwater's tumor is on the right side of his brain, which controls the body movements on the left side.

Entertainer Michael Jackson this week gets the performing rights organization Broadcast Music Inc.'s latest honor, the Michael Jackson Award. ``The award recognizes an individual who has had an important impact on contemporary culture and who has in a measurable way made an uplifting contribution to society,'' said BMI's Frances Preston. Jackson will be presented with his namesake award during a luncheon Tuesday. Jackson, who records for Epic Records, has sold more than 100 million records worldwide. He was BMI's songwriter of the year in 1983. The new award honors ``a songwriter or composer whose work encompasses important contributions to a wide spectrum of creative disciplines, including, in addition to significant work as a musical composer, acknowledged artistic success in recording, live performance, film and video, dance and fashion.''

It was the Bo and Bo show at Cobo Center as the star of the movie ``10'' joined 2,000 people to honor the legendary ex-leader of the University of Michigan football program. Actress Bo Derek was joined by Indiana University basketball coach Bob Knight, Penn State football coach Joe Paterno and other celebrities and sports figures who turned out for a tribute Sunday to Bo Schembechler. Schembechler resigned recently after 21 years as the Wolverines' coach to become president of the Detroit Tigers. ``He's such a ladies' man,'' Derek said, presenting him with a framed jersey with her name and the number 10, alluding to the movie that gained her fame.

Actor Todd Bridges of the defunct ``Diff'rent Strokes'' television series had another brush with the law, police say. Bridges, 24, was arrested early Saturday for allegedly possessing cocaine for sale. Sgt. Joseph Brazas said 48 grams of cocaine were found in a car in which Bridges and another man were sitting in outside a closed business in North Hollywood. Bridges remained in custody Monday on $25,000 bail, said Officer Bill Frio. Bridges' run-ins with the law have long overshadowed his acting fame. He faces retrial July 30 on a charge stemming from the February 1989 shooting of Kenneth ``Tex'' Clay, who was hit eight times at a crack house.

Ernest K. Gann says he's written his last book and will now devote his creative energies to painting. ``I've said about all there is to say in books,'' the 79-year-old author said in a recent interview with the Seattle Times. ``God bless the man who knows when he's said enough and isn't tempted to say more.'' The aviator, sailor and world traveler wrote 22 best sellers, including ```The High and the Mighty,'' ``Fate Is the Hunter,'' ``Twilight for the Gods,'' and ``The Antagonists.'' His latest, ``The Black Watch,'' is about the U-2 spy plane he once piloted. Gann's artwork is being snapped up at a local gallery. ``These aren't just Sunday-afternoon paintings,'' Gann said of his works, which use bold strokes and vivid colors. ``I'd like to be an inspiration to older people, to let them know that a second career is possible at any age.'' Gann, in failing health from liver, kidney and heart problems, said of his second career: ``If it all ends tomorrow, I'm pretty happy with what I've accomplished in a short time.'' Gann lives with his wife, Dodie, on an 800-acre ranch on San Juan Island, near Canada's Vancouver Island. ``This is the last civilized place in the world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Air India Jet Catches Fire; No Casulties
DOC.TEXT: An Air India jumbo jet carrying 215 people from London to Bombay caught fire minutes before a scheduled stop in New Delhi Monday, but the pilot managed to land the plane safely, airlines sources said. There were 195 passengers and a 20-member crew on board the Boeing 747. The captain noticed the fire in one of the left engines five minutes before the plane was to land, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An emergency was declared in the Indira Gandhi International Airport before the plane landed and all passengers were evacuated. Firefighters put the blaze out after several minutes, the sources said. The plane was on a flight from London to Bombay via New Delhi. Air India has a fleet of 21 aircraft and operates to all major airports in the world.

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Retrial Opening Interrupted By Distraught Juror
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with juror, distraught over recent boat mishap, interrupting proceedings as trial gets under way. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `More than....'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Opening statements in the second molestation trial of Ray Buckey began today but were interrupted when an alternate juror reported she was distraught over a weekend boat fire that imperiled her family. The woman juror, who agreed to go forward with the trial of the McMartin Pre-School case, began coughing violently moments after the prosecutor began his address to the jury and had to be led out of the courtroom. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg called a recess to give the juror time to compose herself and see if she would able to proceed. The woman told Weisberg before the session began that her entire family was aboard the boat, which was engulfed in flames before they were rescued by the shore patrol. She said she and others suffered smoke inhalation. She said she took a tranquilizer before coming to court, but ``I feel very nervous and upset.'' The interruption came as Deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez was beginning to recount for jurors the evidence which he said would prove that three little girls were molested by Buckey at the family owned preschool in Manhattan Beach. He told how one child began to have nightmares and showed other signs of molestation during the two years she attended the McMartin school. As Martinez spoke, Buckey's mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, sat in the audience taking notes. The defendant's father, Charles Buckey, also attended, but the spectator section was not as crowded as it was during the culmination of another trial in which Buckey's mother was acquitted of all charges and Ray Buckey was acquitted of the majority of allegations against him. The district attorney's office decided to retry the 31-year-old Buckey on eight counts involving the three children, a greatly diminished number from the hundreds which were once said to have been molested at the school. The prosecution has said the new trial could last six months. The first trial lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million, making it the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. The first trial ended in January when a jury acquitted Peggy McMartin Buckey of 12 charges. The same jurors acquitted Ray Buckey of 40 charges and deadlocked on 13 other counts. Over the weekend, the parents continued an inch-by-inch search of the school and its foundation. The school is scheduled for demolition, and the current owner agreed to let the parents conduct their search until he brings in the bulldozers. More than a dozen former McMartin students had talked to prosecutors about a trap door, tunnel or secret underground room at the school, but none was ever found, prosecutors say. Only one student actually testified at the trial about a secret molestation room, and he didn't indicate it was underground. A search of the school years ago turned up no passageways or trap doors and no signs that floor tiles had been replaced or concrete patched, prosecutors said. But the parents refused to give up. The McMartin school is now owned by real estate broker Arnold Goldstein, who plans to raze it and put up an office building. He has given the parents until Thursday to do their digging. On Sunday, former Los Angeles FBI bureau chief Ted Gunderson, now a private detective, said disturbed earth was found below the foundation. But he said an expert was prepared to say only that there was ``a probability of a tunnel'' as opposed to something else, such as a garbage pit. Prosecutors have said their current case does not depend on any evidence that might be uncovered during the investigation of the site. The prosecution has said the retrial can be completed in six months.

DOC.HEAD: Famed for Bottled Water, Calistoga's Drinking Supply Running Low
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: The springs are gushing but the municipal tap may go dry as the wine country town of Calistoga, famous for bottled water and hot mineral baths, watches drought and industry drain its only reservoir. The fizzy water fad has been an economic gold mine for Calistoga, but it has severely depleted municipal supplies of drinking water. Countless gallons of mineral-rich bottled water are exported every day, and visitors flock to Calistoga to soak in geothermal mineral baths. Although the bottled water industry is a major contributor to the water shortage, the water that's brought wealth and fame to Calistoga isn't the same stuff that flows through local taps, in part because it can erode and clog heating systems. That has contributed to the supply problem, since the bottling operations of three mineral water companies use drinking water to clean equipment and rinse bottles. The pinch is not nearly as bad as the 1977 drought, but officials recently extended through June a building moratorium that was started in an effort to stem the demand for more water. The town is using water at a rate officials didn't expect to reach until after the year 2000, according to City Administrator Natasha Merkuloff. Planners anticipated the drain on water supplies and spent $5 million to tap into the state's North Bay Aqueduct in 1980. The 26-mile pipeline has provided a buffer for the city, which had relied on one reservoir and a few wells for its water. But four years of drought have aggravated the situation, and stricter state water standards reduced the useful capacity of the town's Kimball Reservoir, forcing the town to rely more on the pipeline and less on local supplies. Within a year, the city hopes to make $500,000 of improvements to Kimball Reservoir to expand its supply of usable water by about 50 percent, Merkuloff said. Meantime, officials say the 4,500 residents of Calistoga, about 50 miles north of San Francisco, are a conscientious bunch. ``You don't see people in Calistoga wasting water like you do in other places,'' said Jo Ellen Noble in the city's planning department. It will be business as usual as tourists flock to the wine country retreat's famous spas, she said. The drought of 1977 is the standard to which locals compare the current shortage. Then, residents were limited to 50 gallons of water per person per day and the town was three weeks shy of having the state truck in water, Noble said. Today, Calistogans use an average of only 90 gallons each per day, less than half the statewide average. Nevertheless, city officials asked industrial users to cut their water use two years ago after they discovered ``the horrendous use of water,'' Merkuloff said. Calistoga Mineral Water Co. was using the equivalent of 25 percent of the pipeline's entire annual allotment, she said, although it has since cut in half its water usage and signed a contract that specifies usage and discharge levels. Five-tier water rates charge heavy water users more, she added. ``Municipal water has always been a problem in Calistoga,'' said Calistoga Mineral Water spokesman Bob Pusey. ``It's not something new. There's always been some form of rationing or moratoriums on building permits or hookups.'' At Crystal Geyser Water Co., drinking water use dropped 25 percent last year _ even though mineral water production increased 50 percent _ because it introduced new labeling and cooling equipment and began recycling water used to rinse bottles, said chairman Peter Gordon. As word of the water pinch leaked beyond city limits, concern grew about the impact the publicity could have on tourism. At Nance's Hot Springs, where mineral water is used in the pool and bathhouse and only the motel relies on municipal supplies, clerk Vickie Vowser has had to reassure worried customers that there's no emergency. ``It's going to hurt business,'' she said. ``I'd like to know who the idiot is who did this.''

DOC.HEAD: `Nameless' Abortion Protesters Enter Third Month in Vermont Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 16th graf `Court records ...' may be offensive to readers
DOC.TEXT: Eleven weeks ago, 47 anti-abortion protesters put bicycle locks around their necks and chained themselves together at the Vermont Women's Health Center in Burlington. They were jailed without bail because they refused to identify themselves in court. That issue was presented Monday to the Vermont Supreme Court. With additional protests, the ranks of the jailed have swelled to 95, all being held without bail on misdemeanor charges of unlawful trespass, punishable by 90 days in jail. The no-bail detention has sparked more protests and a flood of court actions that have made this staunch pro-choice state a focus for the anti-abortion movement. The protesters say they have a constitutional right to bail when charged with a misdemeanor. ``The courts are stomping all over our rights as Americans,'' said the Rev. Michael McHugh, 37, leader of the local anti-abortion movement. The no-bail detention, first imposed Feb. 21, has made District Judge Matthew Katz the movement's Public Enemy No. 1. He says identities are necessary to ensure that people released on bail will show up for trial. On Monday, lawyers for the protesters urged the high court to overturn Katz's ruling. ``It's time for this court to order that the Vermont Constitution means what it says,'' Daniel Lynch told the justices. But prosecutor Edward Sutton argued that detention without bail is justified. He said the protesters forfeited their right to bail when they refused to identify themselves. ``It's reasonable for a trial judge to deny bail until they get basic information,'' he said. There was no indication when the court would rule. Since Feb. 21, eight more demonstrations have been held at Burlington abortion clinics. State officials say these continuing protests prove that the anti-abortion movement is trying to clog the court system. ``We are dealing with people who may have lost their aim,'' said Sutton. ``It seems to have veered over to trying to punish a state. Our legal system is under attack.'' The protesters also have targeted the judge. A series of ``prayer vigils'' outside Katz's Burlington home led to McHugh's arrest on felony charges of obstructing justice. Court records also show that a protester called Katz a ``Jew bastard'' during a March 22 court hearing. McHugh, in an effort to defuse accusations that his movement is anti-Semitic, maintains the court reporter misheard the comment. McHugh also has repeatedly denied Vermont is a national target for the anti-abortion movement. ``To imply that national leaders have decided to make Vermont a rescue focus is absurd,'' McHugh said. But only eight of the 95 jailed are Vermonters. The rest are from Canada, California, Iowa, Michigan, New Mexico, Ohio, Tennessee, Texas, Washington state and the Northeast. In addition, several national leaders of the anti-abortion movement are among those jailed, including Joan Andrews, 41, who helped found the ``rescue'' movement in 1979, and the Rev. Norman Weslin, 59, head of the Victim Souls for the Unborn Christ Child, headquartered in Mountlake Terrace, Wash. In an interview from the temporary jail, Andrews said she came to Vermont in response to a ``national call'' from more than 150 groups. ``We came up here because they were trying to crush the local movement,'' she said. The imprisonments also led to a recent visit by Randall Terry, the national leader of Operation Rescue. He berated what he called Vermont's ``pro-death'' judiciary for carrying out vendettas against his movement.

DOC.HEAD: NBC May Offer Affiliates 24-Hour News Service
DOC.TEXT: NBC, which once tried to buy 51 percent of Cable News Network, is planning its own 24-hour news service for its affiliates, NBC News president Michael Gartner said Monday. The affiliates could use the service as part of their own broadcasts or when NBC is ``dark'' and not broadcasting. The plan likely will be presented to affiliates at their annual convention, on June 3-6 in Washington, D.C. The proposal drew praise from James R. Sefert, chairman of the NBC affiliates' board, although he emphasized he didn't have full details of it. He likened it to an extension of an NBC News service called A-News, which sends affiliates news reports from NBC News and NBC affiliates. But NBC executives have told him in broad terms what the new service would be and ``I think it's terrific,'' said Sefert, president of Cosmos Broadcasting Corp. in Greenville, S.C. ``I really can't comment until I see the full proposal,'' he said when asked if he thought NBC-affiliated stations would approve the idea. ``But the outline sounded good.'' ``It's too early to tell,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said when asked about NBC's plan, which could prove a rival for CNN, at least with NBC affiliates that also take CNN service. ``We still are studying it,'' Haworth said. ``But we've developed very strong relationships with 220 broadcast affiliates over the 10 years that we've been in business. We're certainly confident that those relationships will persist.'' According to Atlanta-based CNN, whose 24-hour news service began in June 1980, 51 of NBC's 208 affiliates also are CNN affiliates. One such double affiliate is WTHR-TV in Indianapolis, whose vice president and general manager, Michael J. Corken, is head of the news subcommittee of the NBC affiliate board. Corken said it was too early to say what he would do. ``I'd have to look and see what the viability of the NBC-proposed system would be,'' he said. NBC officials haven't yet told him what they plan, he said. NBC's effort to buy part of CNN in 1985 failed in part because of its insistence that NBC News have editorial control of any NBC-CNN operation that would result if the purchase went through. NBC's plan to start its own 24-hour news service was disclosed in Monday's editions of The Wall Street Journal. Although not available for an interview, Garter, NBC News' president, confirmed in a statement that such a news service is planned. It would be an operation that is separate from the network's regular newscasts. ``While many details are yet to be determined, we have an outline of the plan and hope to have a final plan by the time of the June affiliates meeting,'' Gartner said. Discusions of the plan ``have focused almost exclusively on the issue of content, the value of our service to the affiliates and the methods of distribution,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan President Names New Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Afghan President Najibullah on Monday named the governor of Herat province, who was nearly killed in a rebel ambush in April, to head his Communist-style government, Radio Kabul reported. The state-run radio also said a rocket attack on the Afghan capital left one person dead and two wounded. The broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, blamed the rocket attack on U.S.-armed rebels. Fazle Haq Khaliq Yaar's appointment as prime minister follows on the heels of Sunday's promotion of Sultan Ali Keshtmand to the vice-presidency. The Herat governor was seriously wounded in April when rebels staged a surprise attack on a ceremony at which thousands of guerrilla fighters were to surrender. Hidden among more than 10,000 defectors at the ceremony in the northwestern province of Herat were a handful of guerrilla fighters, pretending to have embraced Najibullah's Soviet-style government. When Khaliq Yaar stepped out of his helicopter to launch the ceremony, the rebel fighters opened fire. When the shooting stopped 30 minutes later, 110 people were dead and scores were injured. Najibullah lost several top military officers in the Herat shooting. Jamiat-i-Islami rebel group, considered one of the strongest militarily, claimed responsibility for the attack. Meanwhile, Moslem guerrillas claimed Monday to have recaptured ground lost during a week of heavy fighting with Afghan government troops outside the eastern city of Jalalabad. The state-run radio acknowledged the renewed attack but said the guerrillas had been repulsed and 180 of them killed. ``With this operation, the enemy's morale has been completely broken,'' Radio Kabul claimed. The report could not be independently verified. The radio also said government soldiers captured hundreds of anti-tank missiles, even more surface-to-surface missiles and thousands of small arms from the rebel fighters. ``Government soldiers are in a strong position and ready for any kind of opposition attack,'' the radio broadcast said. Meanwhile, MIDIA, the news agency of the Afghan resistance, said guerrillas overran government security outposts 12 miles east of Jalalabad. The report claimed Afghan troops suffered heavy casualties in the weekend battle. The report did not say whether there were any guerrilla casualties, and it could not be independently confirmed. The radio broadcast, however, said four government soldiers were killed and another seven wounded in the past five days. Fighting around Jalalabad has erupted sporadically since the rebels launched a major offensive in March 1989 to take the eastern city. Troops loyal to Najibullah repulsed the attack, in which the U.S.-backed guerrillas suffered some of their heaviest casualties in 12 years of fighting to unseat the Marxist-style government in Kabul. Kabul's state-run radio reported last week that government troops had recaptured several key outposts around Jalalabad in the latest offensive that began May 1. But MIDIA said that over the weekend, guerrillas in captured tanks rolled into government posts in the Khewa district, three miles north of the city. The report did not mention casualty figures. The agency also reported that government warplanes bombed and destroyed a stretch of the highway linking Kabul and Jalalabad, about 45 miles from the border with Pakistan. It said the guerrillas had earlier reconstructed the road under pressure from area tribal leaders who wanted the lucrative trade route reopened. Throughout the war, Afghan traders have continued to ply the eastern highway from Kabul to the border.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MEXICO CITY
Pope Speaks To Latin America's Urban Poor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with pope speaking to poor at Chalco, EDITS thruout to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MO1
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, speaking to a joyous crowd in one of Mexico's poorest cities, said today that living conditions for Latin America's urban poor constitute an urgent call to carry out the church's teachings. ``We cannot live and sleep peacefully while thousands of our brothers, very near to us, lack the necessities for a dignified human life,'' John Paul told about 200,000 worshippers gathered in a muddy field 25 miles southeast of Mexico City. Thousands waved yellow banners, and mariachi bands played ``Cielito Lindo'' _ or ``Beautiful Sky'' _ as the pope swept in by helicopter, although gray clouds sometimes obscured the massive, snow-capped volcanic cones of Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl. The crowd was smaller than predicted, cut down by hours of rain that lasted into the early morning and turned the normally dusty valley to mud. The theme of the pope's Mass was ``The Good Shepherd.'' Seated at a microphone next to a giant crucifix under a yellow-and-white canopy, John Paul told the crowd that the good shepherd could be distinguished from mercenaries ``because he is ready to give his life for his sheep.'' ``Jesus Christ, being rich, made himself poor to enrich us with his poverty,'' said the pope. He called on all Christians and all ``men of good will'' to put into action the church's ``preferential option for the poor,'' first expounded in Puebla, 50 miles east of here, on John Paul's first visit to Mexico in 1979. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has made a point of improving life in Chalco, which has expanded from a population of 6,000 in 1975 to more than 60,000 today as poor peasants migrate to Mexico City's vast urban sprawl. Salinas went to Chalco earlier this year to dedicate new electric lines, sewers and running water. John Paul met with Salinas before flying to Chalco, but neither made any statements afterward. The two exchanged gifts, the pope giving Salinas three medallions and receiving three books in return. As the pope was leaving for a helicopter ride to Chalco, a young woman broke through security lines and hugged him. She was quickly hustled away by guards. In a gesture that indicated warmer church-state relations lie ahead, Salinas changed plans at the last minute and met the pontiff at the airport Sunday instead of sending his foreign minister. Salinas, greeting the pope, said: ``Your visit is a new encounter with the generosity of a nation of many cultures, plural visions and deep religious sentiments.'' Since he took office two years ago, Salinas has encouraged improved ties with the Vatican while officials have widely ignored strict decades-old laws that intend to keep the church out of politics. In February, Salinas named a personal representative to the Vatican, a sign the diplomatic ties Mexico severed in 1926 might soon be restored. During his 13-hour flight to Mexico, the Polish-born pope told reporters his trip was ``something new and very important ... We are making efforts to improve relations between the state and the church.'' The Roman Catholic Church backed the ruling classes against Mexico's native population in the 19th century, which is why restrictions on the church were written into the constitution during the country's 1910-1920 revolution. The 1917 constitution denies recognition to the church and bars priests from speaking about politics from the pulpit or wearing robes in public. The church is also barred from owning property. But Mexico is a country where some independence leaders were priests, and where the Catholic church claims 90 percent of Mexico's 85 million people. The government has thus struck a working arrangement with the church, which runs schools through intermediaries while priests speak out on political issues. The church is seeking to appeal to the poor and indigenous of Latin America, and the pope bolstered those efforts with the beatification of Mexico's most revered Indian, Juan Diego. During the beatification at the Basilica of Guadalupe, he urged Mexicans to emulate that humble 16th-century peasant in their fight to improve society. Later, the pontiff greeted people and watched regional dances performed in his honor. The crowd cheered him wildly as night settled on the city. ``Mexico knows how to dance. Mexico knows how to pray,'' he said. ``It knows how to sing. But more than anything it knows how to shout.'' The 10-city visit is John Paul's 47th trip outside Italy as pope, his 10th to Latin America and his second to Mexico, which he visited first in 1979. Along with Juan Diego, the pope beatified a 19th-century priest and three Indians known as the Child Martyrs of Tlaxcala who died nearly 450 years ago. Beatification is a possible step toward sainthood. According to legend, Juan Diego carried out-of-season roses to his bishop from a hill where the Virgin of Guadalupe appeared to him in 1531. When he opened his white cloak, the image of the Virgin appeared on it.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bars Import of Peruvian Treasures
DOC.TEXT: The United States is barring the import of looted Peruvian archaeologial treasures to protect them from greedy art dealers and collectors, the administration said Monday. ``The import ban is the strongest action possible to assist Peru in preserving its cultural heritage,'' Bruce S. Gelb, director of the U.S. Information Agency, said at a news conference. The ban affects artifacts being stolen by armed looters from the Sipan region of Peru, the site of rich, intact pre-Colombian tombs, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. Cesar Atala, the Peruvian ambassador to the United States, said the ban ``will help us avoid the enormous lure of the U.S. market.'' The President's Cultural Property Advisory Commission found that the U.S. market for objects looted from the tombs ``is so large it is encouraging looting in the region,'' Gelb said. Intricately crafted gold, gilded copper and silver artifacts have been discovered at the site. Michael H. Lane, deputy commissioner of U.S. Customs, compared the looting to drug smuggling. ``We see the same techniques and the same motive _ greed _ as we see every day in the smuggling of narcotics,'' Lane said. Under the presidential order, requested by Peru, artifacts from the region will be seized by Customs agents and returned to Peru unless the items are accompanied by an export permit issued by the Peruvian government. Atala said the looting was preventing archaeologists from evaluating the material in its original sites and from studying the Moche culture, its origins and its relationship to other pre-Colombian cultures. Experts have said the tombs, discovered in 1987, have yielded important information about the civilization that inhabited the river valleys of northern Peru from 100 to 700 A.D. Lane said the ban would not be retroactive, but that objects from the region already in the United States would be affected if the artifacts are proved to have been stolen. The United States imposed emergency restrictions on monumental pre-Colombian artifacts from El Salvador in 1987 and on some Andean textiles from Bolivia last year. Similar requests from Canada and Guatemala are pending.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Carter Named 1990 Recipient of Liberty Medal
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter was named Monday the 1990 recipient of the Philadelphia Liberty Medal for his involvement in ``issues of liberty around the globe.'' Carter will receive the medal and a $100,000 cash award on the Fourth of July at Independence Hall. The medal, established in 1988, honors an individual or organization that has ``demonstrated leadership or vision in the pursuit of liberty of conscience or freedom from oppression, ignorance or deprivation.'' The first medal was given last year to Polish leader Lech Walesa. ``President Carter was cited for his active involvement during the past few years in issues of liberty around the globe and his exemplary use of the post-presidential period,'' said Martin Meyerson, president emeritus of the University of Pennsylvania and chairman of the 12-member selection commission. The commission is made up of leaders from government, world affairs, education and business. The award was established by We the People 2000, a non-profit group that tries to heighten recognition of the principles that founded the nation. The cash grant has been underwritten by the Bell Atlantic Corp. Carter has acted as a mediator in Ethiopia, Latin America, the Middle East and the Sudan since leaving office. He is a ``man of many and diverse roles,'' said Meyerson. ``One day he is a mediator attempting to strike peace between rival factions,'' Myerson said. ``The next he may be found discussing human rights issues with a head of state. ``On another, he may be dealing with the realities of famine, poverty, disease control and other issues which haunt the Third World countries.''

DOC.HEAD: `Grand Hotel' Captures 12 Tony Nominations
DOC.TEXT: ``Grand Hotel'' and ``City of Angels,'' two big musicals, topped the list of Broadway's annual Tony Awards nominations, announced today by the League of American Theaters and Producers. ``Grand Hotel'' received 12 nominations and ``City of Angels'' received nominations in 11 categories for the best of the 1989-90 Broadway season. The two shows were nominated for best musical, along with ``Aspects of Love'' and ``Meet Me in St. Louis.'' Nominated for best play were ``The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama; ``Lettice and Lovage'' by Peter Shaffer; ``Prelude to a Kiss'' by Craig Lucas; and ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' an adaptation of the John Steinbeck novel by Frank Galati. Nominees for best actor in a play were: Charles S. Dutton, ``The Piano Lesson''; Dustin Hoffman, ``The Merchant of Venice''; Tom Hulce, ``A Few Good Men''; and Robert Morse, ``Tru.'' Actress nominations went to Geraldine James, ``The Merchant of Venice''; Mary-Louise Parker, ``Prelude to a Kiss''; Maggie Smith, ``Lettice and Lovage''; and Kathleen Turner, ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' Winners will be announced June 3 in a nationally televised ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Camera Captures Two Falcon Chicks Hatching on Office Ledge
DOC.TEXT: Two peregrine falcon chicks have hatched on the ledge of a downtown office building, to the delight of local cable television watchers. They are the second pair of chicks to be raised on the 21st floor of the Monarch Place office tower. Last year, the parent falcons chose the spot to raise the first two chicks in half a century to be hatched in western Massachusetts. For the second straight year, Continental Cablevision kept a camera on the nest 24 hours a day, broadcasting the birds' activities on a local access channel. The show is one of the company's most popular, and this spring it began showing the birds on local access channels in four communities in Massachusetts and Connecticut. General Manager Brian Lambert said viewers reported the first chick hatched about 7 p.m. Saturday and the second about 3 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Latvians Await Gorbachev's Response to Independence Declaration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Latvian Parliament sending message to Gorbachev, quotes; Pickup 14th pvs, `As the...'
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's Parliament today assured Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that despite the republic's declaration of independence, it will respect Soviet interests and hopes to open talks soon. The parliament's message was in response to a request from Gorbachev for information on Latvia's May 4 declaration of independence. ``We express the certainty that the character of the declaration, the retention of current constitutional norms and sincere desire to respect the interests of the U.S.S.R. will meet with your understanding and open the way to a fruitful dialogue in the spirit of honest cooperation between equals,'' the letter to Gorbachev said. Latvian president Anatoly Gorbunov had told the parliament this morning of the Kremlin's request and charged several deputies with preparing a reply. Dainis Ivans, chairman of the Latvian Popular Front, which has led the independence drive, called Gorbachev's request for more information ``wonderful.'' ``This gives us a chance to present our point of view,'' he told reporters. Ivans said Latvia also planned to send a delegation to Moscow within days and he believed the group would be received by the Kremlin. Delegates from Lithuania, which has also voted to secede, went through a similar exchange with the Kremlin but to no avail. Unlike Lithuania, however, Latvia did not suspend the Soviet constitution when it declared independence, instead merely adding several sections calling for independence and democracy. Gorbunov and other Latvian leaders have said the republic's declaration, with its unspecified transition period to full independence, is calculated to ``leave the door open'' to talks with the Kremlin. They said today the Kremlin's request for an explanation indicated Moscow's reaction might not be as stong as initially indicated. Latvia's Communist Party chief, Alfreds Rubiks, had said Saturday that Gorbachev might retaliate because of the secession vote. The Soviet news agency Tass quoted Rubiks as saying in a statement on television Gorbachev told him the vote violated the Soviet Constitution. Gorbachev said in a telephone call he might impose political, economic and administrative sanctions if the Baltic republic didn't reverse its course, Rubiks reported. Foreign Ministry Spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov, at a briefing today, declined to answer questions about Latvia.``There is no official response yet,'' he said. He said Rubik's statement was ``not a direct response'' to the republic's declaration of independence. Neighboring Lithuania declared immediate independence from Moscow on March 11, and Gorbachev responded by sending troops to occupy some Communist Party buildings and by cutting off fuel and other vital supplies. The third Baltic republic, Estonia, last month declared its intention to secede but set no date and left the door open for negotiations with the Kremlin. As the Latvian Parliament convened today, about 50 Soviet soldiers approached the building and unfurled a red banner reading, ``Comrades! Have No Doubt We Will Defend the Interests of the U.S.S.R. With Honor.'' Thousands of Soviet troops are stationed in Latvia. Several Latvians, incensed by the ominous tone of the slogan, shouted, ``Shame!'' in Russian at the soldiers. The argument remained peaceful. Even before Gorbunov's announcement, Latvian deputies were discounting Rubiks' report that Gorbachev had immediately rejected the Latvian declaration and threatened sanctions. Legislator Janis Krumins said Latvians who spoke with Valentin Falin, head of the International Department of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee in Moscow, thought Gorbachev's reaction would not be as harsh as Rubiks had reported. ``To threaten that there could be a blockade without having fully understood what happened here would be irresponsible,'' said Ivars Kezbers, a Latvian lawmaker who has been involved in talks with Moscow. Lithuanian lawmaker Nikolai Medvedev, visiting the Latvian capital of Riga, said it appeared that although the three Baltic republics have taken different approaches to their independence drives, ``the answer is the same.'' He said separatists in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were forging political and economic ties with such Russian cities as Moscow and Leningrad, where democrats who support the republics' right to self-determination have come to power through popular election. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed the Baltic republics in 1940. They began campaigning for independence shortly after Gorbachev began his reforms. The Soviet president has offered them a greater say in economic and political decisions but not secession itself. Of Latvia's 2.6 million residents, 53 percent are ethnic Latvians and 33 percent ethnic Russians. Many of the non-Latvians, especially Russians, oppose secession.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Refuses to Attend Arab Summit in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Syria announced Monday it will not attend an Arab summit in Baghdad, capital of its archrival Iraq, hindering efforts to patch up the 11-year-old feud that has blocked Arab unity. Officials said Damascus instead proposed that the foreign ministers of the 22 Arab League members meet in Tunis to decide on an alternative summit site.
