In Amman, Jordan's King Hussein insisted the summit be held in Baghdad as planned, reflecting a deepening rift in the Arab world over the issue. ``The upcoming Arab summit will be held in Baghdad and there is no intention whatsoever to change the location to somewhere else,'' Hussein said in a statement broadcast by state-run Jordan Television. ``I hope that Arab leaders will work to make this upcoming summit a successful one and I also hope that our brethren in Syria and Iraq will reconcile soon,'' said Hussein. The Syrian decision stymied efforts led by Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan to mediate a reconciliation between Syrian President Hafez Assad and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. They are the Arab world's most bitter foes. The official Syrian Arab News Agency quoted Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa as telling Arab League Secretary-General Chadli Klibi: ``Fixing a venue for the summit without prior consultations... has cast a negative atmosphere in advance of the conference, and this certainly is not in the interest of the Arab nation.'' Sharaa, SANA added, suggested that ``the Arab League Council convene to conduct consultations on a convenient venue and date for the summit and to agree on the topics to be discussed at the forum.'' The council groups 21 foreign ministers plus the Palestine Liberation Organization's political department chief, who is regarded as a foreign minister in the Arab world. Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt have been making strenuous efforts to persuade Assad to go to Baghdad and end his feud with Saddam. That dispute and Assad's 7-year-old feud with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat are the main obstacles to Arab efforts to forge a new unity after years of fragmentation. Arafat has been at odds with Assad since 1983, when Syrian-backed radical Palestinian factions mutinied against Arafat and drove his guerrillas out of their last Lebanese stronghold. Assad has not recognized the Palestinian state declared in 1988 and still holds about 2,000 of Arafat's loyalists in his prisons. Syria and Iraq have been at odds since 1979. The two countries are ruled by different wings of the Arab Baath Socialist Party and are traditional rivals for political leadership of the modern Arab world. Syria backed Persian Iran in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Iraq supplied weapons to Lebanese Christian Gen. Michel Aoun in his effort to force the Syrian army out of Lebanon last year. Arafat called in April for a summit to be held in Baghdad to discuss Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, Middle East peace moves and the crisis in Lebanon. The Iraqis have said they also want to discuss perceived threats from Israel and the West against them. Saddam wants to demonstrate that the Arab world is behind him amid what he views as a concerted Western campaign against him over his drive to build up his military arsenal. Saddam claims the Western effort is aimed at setting the stage for an Israeli attack to neutralize Iraq's burgeoning military power.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Discovery Back Home
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Discovery returned to Kennedy Space Center on Monday, almost two weeks after it lifted off with the Hubble Space Telescope. The shuttle came strapped atop a specially fitted Boeing 747, which had left Robins Air Force Base in Georgia 1{ hours earlier. The plane was forced to stop at Robins overnight because of bad weather in Florida. It was the second weather delay on the shuttle's piggyback ride home. The spacecraft and jet were held overnight Saturday at Sheppard Air Force Base in Texas after leaving Edwards Air Force Base in California earlier in the day. Discovery was launched April 24 and landed five days later at Edwards. The shuttle's five crew members deployed the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, now orbiting 380 miles above Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Koop Warns AIDS Patients Could Face Growing Resentment from Public
DOC.TEXT: Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop says he's worried that Americans may be losing their tolerance for people with AIDS. ``I fear a growing resentment against all AIDS patients, but blacks and Hispanics in particular,'' Koop said Sunday while accepting the 17th Annual Harry S. Truman Award for Public Service. Koop said Americans have been tolerant of health problems caused by drinking and overeating, but may not be so tolerant of AIDS because of the way it is usually spread, through high-risk sexual contact and intravenous drug use. ``A person becomes infected with HIV by doing things most people don't do,'' Koop said, adding that unlike diseases that can be treated, ``there is no rescue from AIDS.'' However, he said that poverty is the main reason for the spread of AIDS among minorities. He added that the disease poses the biggest challenge ever to public health care. Koop, who served as U.S. Surgeon General from 1981 until 1989, said he knew he would be remembered for his campaign against smoking and his work for education about AIDS, a disease that ``could break the social compact of America.'' Koop is now chairman of the National SAFE KIDS Campaign, a board member of AIDS Care Education and Training, and chairman of the National Museum of Health and Medicine Foundation. Sunday's ceremony at the Truman Library also honored Dr. Wallace Graham, who served as Truman's personal physician during his White House years.

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Award-Winning Inn Sparks Controversy in Little Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf, `The inn ...,' to restore dropped first name of councilman. Picks up 11th graf, `Others cannot ...' Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: When the exclusive Inn at Little Washington opened in an abandoned garage in 1978, some of the 250 residents of this northwestern Virginia hamlet considered its nameplate, well, belittling. The sign, and the residents' fury, eventually faded. But now the award-winning inn, some of whose celebrity guests travel the 67 miles from Washington, D.C., by helicopter, is again provoking the wrath of neighbors who fear for the town's seclusion and its 200-year-old heritage. The Mobil Travel guide ranks it as the only five-star inn in the country. Craig Claiborne, former food columnist of The New York Times, called it ``one of the most exciting retreats in all of America.'' Paul Newman, who celebrated a birthday there, called it ``a most satisfying slice of comfort and royalty.'' Rooms cost $210 to $490 a night, dinner will set you back $68 on weeknights and $88 on Saturdays, and the waiting list is lengthening, said innkeepers Patrick O'Connell and Reinhardt Lynch. They want to triple the capacity of the 10-room inn by adding 22 rooms and a pool. ``We thought the town would be absolutely thrilled to have something magnificent,'' O'Connell said. ``What is so astonishing is people drive in, stay overnight and leave. This doesn't impact the schools or police. It's clean tourism dollars.'' But opponents cannot stomach an expansion, even if it is designed to fit in with its homely surroundings. The Town Council on Wednesday considers the necessary zoning change. It has a year to make a decision. ``I think it's a little too great for this small town,'' said Kermit Weakley, a 20-year resident. The inn became the key point in recent local elections. Both former Councilman William Wickens, who once proposed a ban on the helicopter landings, and Lynch lost a bid for the council. Others cannot understand the fuss. ``You'd think we were talking about a high-rise Holiday Inn,'' said Charles Eldred, who owns a shop and a house across from the inn. ``They're wonderful neighbors.'' Mayor Dean Morehouse favors a middle course _ a limited expansion. ``One thing we don't want to end up with is a huge white elephant in the middle of our small town,'' he said. The inn generates $65,000 of the town's $130,000 budget, he said. The four-block town has a restaurant, beauty salon and bank but no traffic lights. Its theater has a volunteer staff and is open only on Friday and Saturday nights. Official letterheads describe the town as ``The First Washington of All,'' and residents proudly say George Washington surveyed it himself. When they decided to start the inn, Lynch and O'Connell were running a catering business from their nearby farm. Their creation produced instant hostility when they hung out the sign. Some residents said the ``Little'' was negative, but O'Connell said they used the name affectionately. Besides, the sign cost $1,000, or about a fifth of their net worth in 1978, he said. Today, their worth is more than $3 million, and the inn has a staff of 55. The inn has 24-hour room service. Each of the European-style rooms is lavishly furnished with English antiques. The canopied beds are draped with imported fabrics. The bathrooms, some with Jacuzzis, are done in brass and marble. ``We want to offer personal service, much like being in someone's grand country house, but also offer the discerning traveler anything they can find in a luxury hotel with more charm,'' O'Connell said.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Warns of ``Chaos'' But Radicals Step Up Attacks
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said Monday that South Korea must choose between progress or ``the road toward chaos,'' but dissidents and radical students stepped up violent protests demanding his ouster. Radicals armed with firebombs, steel pipes and rocks battled riot police and attacked governing party offices in Seoul and several other cities. Dissidents vowed to hold anti-Roh rallies this week across the nation. As Roh spoke in a nationally televised address, 21 students armed with firebombs and iron pipes charged into the Seoul headquarters of Roh's Liberal Democratic Party and seized a third-floor office. Riot police overpowered the protesters with clubs and tear gas about 10 minutes later. Witnesses said five people, including protesters and police officers, were injured. Office windows, furniture and the windshields of three cars were smashed and a guard post was burned. The protesters scattered leaflets demanding the ouster of U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg. They accused him of concocting this year's merger of the governing party with two minor opposition groups. The merger resulted in a large conservative governing party. About 2,500 students fought police with firebombs and rocks outside campuses in four provincial cities and two small towns outside Seoul, said Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Radical students firebombed Liberal Democratic Party offices in two other cities _ Taejon and Wonju, Yonhap said. There was minor damage but no injuries or arrests were reported. ``Right now we are in a difficult time,'' Roh, surrounded by Cabinet members, said in his speech. ``We are on a crossroad where the country can either be on a road toward progress or fall into a road toward chaos.'' Dissident groups called for new protests Wednesday in 17 cities aimed at forcing the governing party to disband. Dissidents contend the three-party merger in January was an attempt by government conservatives to prolong power. A statement released Monday and signed by 1,041 professors nationwide also demanded the ruling party's dissolution. Roh said the recent ``heightening of uneasiness'' had been partly caused by labor unrest at a shipyard and at the state-run broadcast network, KBS. He called for industrial peace and firm action against illegal strikes. In Ulsan, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, shipyard workers began dialogue with company executives to negotiate an end to a 9-day-old protest. At least 50 workers were perched atop a large crane. Company officials reported little progress, saying the workers insisted that charges against union leaders be dropped. They said the workers also asked the company to withdraw police and guarantee they would not be arrested. The Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard remained at a standstill Monday, with most of its 20,000 union members staying home, witnesses said by telephone. The workers climbed atop the crane after thousands of riot police fired tear gas and stormed the shipyard April 28 to end a strike demanding the release of union leaders arrested in earlier protests. The police assault triggered sympathy strikes in many other industrial plants, but most workers returned to their jobs by the end of last week. In Seoul, the state-run KBS network remained crippled by striking workers. Union leaders at the two other broadcast networks announced an end to their sympathy strikes Monday. The KBS protest began April 12, when police raided the network to arrest workers denouncing their new chief as anti-reform. Police arrested 468 KBS workers, but most were released later.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound President Declares Strike Over; Union Says No Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `The company...', with 2 grafs to DELETE incorrect reference to company serving all by 2 percent of prestrike cities; add that company is dropping a significant amount of unprofitable mileage, at least for the time being. Picks up 17th graf pvs, `Saturday's bargaining...'. CORRECTS title in byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound's chairman declared victory today in the 2-month-old bus drivers' strike, but the union said the bitter walkout was by no means over. ``The strike is over, or at least it is irrelevant,'' said Greyhound Lines Inc. Chairman Fred Currey. The company no longer is ``driver-inhibited'' and is operating as if there were no strike, Currey said at a news conference at Greyhound's headquarters. The statement came two days after the company proposed a four-year wage freeze and the elimination of 4,500 union jobs, a proposal the union called an ``insult.'' The union said the strike was far from over, noting the company's recently announced $56 million quarterly loss. In Washington, spokesman Nick Nichols said Currey should review the bus line's financial documents and look at picket lines for a truer picture of the strike. ``Then, quite frankly, he should jump on a bus and try and travel across the country and see how far he gets,'' said Nichols, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. ``We hope his conclusion will be to get back to the bargaining table,'' he added. As for the company's claim that the strike is now irrelevant, Nichols said that the company has been saying for weeks that it could operate without its striking drivers, but that the company's losses were proof that wasn't true. In his announcement, Currey declared ``a new day in the life of the new Greyhound,'' which he said is currently serving the cities that brought in 98 percent of its revenue last year. Total revenue is about 70 percent of last year. ``We're putting the events of the last two months behind us,'' Currey said. Some 6,300 drivers have been on strike since March 2. Despite proclaiming the strike over, Currey said the company would be willing to negotiate with the union and there would be some jobs available for drivers during the summer. The company has hired hundreds of new drivers since the strike began. Union leaders had said Sunday that the Greyhound offer would force drivers to continue their walkout, which has been marked by violence and bitter trading of accusations. But Greyhound Vice President Anthony P. Lannie had said the union should salvage the 1,300 jobs the company is offering ``or there won't be any jobs'' for striking drivers. Remaining jobs will be filled by non-union workers if the strike continues, he said. Union President Edward M. Strait had said he would not relay the weekend proposal to the drivers for a vote, because ``they'd throw me out the upstairs window. ... It's an insult.'' He caled the company ``greedy'' and said officials ``don't care about their employees.'' Union members will ``stay out on the picket line and hope something changes,'' Strait said Sunday. Bargaining talks were halted indefinitely Saturday after the company made its latest offer. Lannie also said Sunday the company is abandoning charter service in all but 19 of the 197 cities where it was offered. Greyhound had said earlier that it would not restore service, at least anytime soon, for about 30 percent of its pre-strike miles which had been unprofitable. But Currey said today that the towns left unserved by Greyhound would not necessarily be left without transportation as the company would work to establish van service or other alternatives. In addition to cutting the unprofitable miles, Curry said, the company plans to reduce its practice of running additional buses in peak periods when buses are full. Now, passengers will have to wait until the next scheduled bus departs, he said. Saturday's bargaining talks were the first since mid-March and followed Friday's announcement by the company that it lost $56 million for the first three months of this year. Greyhound's offer would give drivers $12.79 an hour rather than their previous 30-cents-a-mile rate, Lannie said. He said the total the typical driver would take home under the new way of calculating pay would be about the same, but Strait contended the company's offer amounts to a wage cut for some employees. The company's financial situation and move to reduce services are forcing it to eliminate about 2,000 of its 6,000 driver jobs, Lannie said. An additional 2,500 union jobs would go to non-union replacement drivers the company hired after the strike began, Lannie said, adding that the 500 union members who crossed picket lines also would be kept. The bus line told union negotiators it had immediate openings for only 620 striking drivers and probably could take an additional 700 back within a few months. Although 4,500 union jobs would be eliminated, 2,000 striking drivers have ``already written Greyhound off'' and found other jobs, Lannie said. An additional 2,500 strikers are either at retirement age or eligible for early retirement incentives the company is offering, he said.

DOC.HEAD: EC to Lift Visa Requirement for East Germans
DOC.TEXT: East German citizens will no longer need visas to enter any of the 12 European Community nations, foreign ministers of the EC decided Monday. EC citizens also will not need visas to visit East Germany. Gerald Collins, the Irish foreign minister and chairman of the meeting, said no date had been fixed for the visa abolition but that it was a question of ``days.'' He added that the EC was also working on a ``coordinated approach'' to lifting visa requirements for citizens from Hungary and Czechoslovakia. This should be settled, ``fairly shortly, maybe in June,'' he told journalists. The 12 EC countries are France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Last School Devastated By Hurricane Reopens
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of delighted pupils returned to Sullivans Island Elementary School on Monday, nearly eight months after Hurricane Hugo battered it with 135 mph wind and a 12-foot wall of water. ``It took something like Hurricane Hugo to make us realize what sort of friends we have,'' Principal Fleming Harris said of the parents and teachers who helped clean up the school. ``We're home and we're going to be back better than ever.'' The school, which stands about two blocks from the Atlantic Ocean, required $1 million worth of repairs after the Sept. 21 storm. Most homes on the island of 1,900 residents were damaged by the storm, which left 29 dead and an estimated $5.9 billion damage in South Carolina. All the other schools in the state that were damaged by the hurricane had already reopened, said Raymond L. Morton, spokesman for the state Department of Education. Until Monday, Sullivans pupils had to attend a school in Mount Pleasant, on the mainland side of the island. ``I've never seen a bunch of students happier to get back in school,'' said Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., who led the pupils in the Pledge of Allegiance outside the school. ``It's an inspiration to us how you joined hands and made it.'' Before going inside for a special pancake breakfast, the school's 360 pupils listened to speeches and a high school pep band. ``It's been a long time since September. This is a time for celebration,'' Harris said. ``We're Back At the Beach to Teach,'' said a sign inside the school. While summer vacation begins in about a month, school officials said it was important the pupils return as quickly as possible. Mayor Melvin Anderegg said it was amazing how many people came from around the country to help rebuild the community. ``It's great to welcome you today to show the fruits of their work,'' he said. Pupils milling about outside the school laughed and smiled. ``I'm really happy we're back,'' said third-grader Tamara Kendalls, who ``wasn't crazy'' about having to attend another school for most of the year. ``We're real glad'' to be back, agreed classmate Brian Austin. ``It feels real good,'' said another third-grader, Clint Gaskins. Parents helped spruce up the grounds at the school and, in recent weeks, read to pupils and conducted other activities to give teachers a chance to return to the repaired building to organize their classrooms. ``I just started to sob when I arrived'' Monday morning, said Corday Rice, the mother of a fourth-grader. ``I said it was the pep band playing off-key but I know it wasn't that.'' While the school has been repaired, evidence of the hurricane is not hard to find on the island. Sullivans Island and the other barrier islands were the first land to feel Hurricane Hugo's wrath. Tree limbs and water-logged home furnishings still clutter many yards, and the sound of hammers and power saws fill the air as workers continue to rebuild.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Officials Set Target Date for Dropping Border Controls
DOC.TEXT: Officials in East and West Berlin said Monday they have set a target date of July 2 to drop all border controls and provide full free access between the two sides of the city. The comments came after East Germany's first free local elections, in which the Social Democrats emerged as the strongest party in East Berlin. The Social Democrats, who won 34.3 percent of the vote in Sunday's local elections in East Berlin, offered coalition talks to other major groups in a move designed to keep the Communists out of the local government. The Communists, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, came in second in East Berlin balloting with 29.9 percent of the vote. Nationwide, the conservative Christian Democratic Union of new Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere finished by far as the strongest party. But it suffered losses compared with the votes it received in March 18 national parliamentary elections. The party dropped about 7 percent from the 41 percent of the vote it received March 18. The leftist-leaning Social Democrats finished second in local elections and the reformed Communists were third, repeating the outcome of the March 18 ballot. The Social Democrats had their strongest showing in East Berlin. The Communists have governed East Berlin since East Germany was founded in 1949 and the former Soviet zone of the divided city was proclaimed its capital. The hard-line national Communist government was ousted by a peaceful revolution last fall that culminated in the opening of the Berlin Wall. The Communists were formally removed from power after the March 18 ballot but ran local governments across the country until Sunday's vote to choose new administrations. The Social Democratic candidate for mayor in East Berlin, Tino Schwierzina, told reporters he would start coalition talks Tuesday with all parties, with the exception of the Communists. Accompanied by West Berlin mayor Walter Momper, a West German Social Democrat, Schwierzina said the first coalition talks would be with the Christian Democrats and the leftist Alliance 90. If Schwierzina forms a three-party governing coalition, it would hold 85 of the 138 seats in East Berlin's legislature. Schwierzina and Momper said such a majority would allow the local government to quickly open all remaining barriers between East and West Berlin. Momper said the two set a target date of ``at the latest July 2 to eliminate all border controls'' between East Berlin and West Berlin. Schwierzina he would push for quick opening of the remaining 140 sections of the Berlin Wall and other barriers blocking streets between West Berlin and East Germany. ``This condition will soon be ended,'' Schwierzina said. ``The wall must go as quickly as possible.'' Schwierzina also said that plans call for joining East and West Berlin's public transportation systems by this fall, including the subway and streetcar systems.

DOC.HEAD: American Workers' Productivity Declines by Annual Rate of 1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American workers' productivity continued to lag in the first three months of 1990, posting its worst performance in a year, the government said Monday. ``It's a reminder of what we already knew _ that the economy isn't doing too well,'' said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. Non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ declined by 1 percent, the biggest drop since productivity fell by an annual rate of 1.3 percent for the January-March period last year. During all of last year, productivity rose just 0.9 percent, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession. Increasing productivity is considered basic to boosting living standards because it allows businesses to pay workers more as their output rises without risking higher inflation. Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust, said productivity sometimes plunges in a quarter because of statistical quirks, but the nation's continuing anemic productivity pace is distressing. ``In the long term, we should be very concerned because we're not being efficient enough to increase our living standard. It's also making it difficult to compete with other countries,'' Kellner said. Meanwhile, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose a sharp 4.9 percent so far this year, the report said, compared with a 4.5 percent increase during all of 1989. ``It suggests a rock-hard underlying inflation rate of 4.5 to 5 percent,'' economist Allen Sinai said of the increase in unit labor costs. ``It's not likely to get much better anytime soon without the economy getting more productivity.'' However, Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co., noted that hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ rose at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the first quarter of 1990. He called the 3.9 percent rise a bright spot, noting those costs increased by 5.5 percent for all of 1989. Economists were also encouraged by the report's figures on productivity in the manufacturing sector, which showed that factory workers registered a seasonally adjusted 4.1 percent increase so far this year. Although calling the decline in the productivity rate extremely disappointing, Sinai said it was not unusual for an economy using most of its workers, plants and equipment. The nation's unemployment rate was 5.4 percent in April, relatively close to the 5 percent jobless rate many economists consider full employment. Low unemployment holds back productivity because ``companies are tapping the bottom of the barrel in terms of qualified workers,'' Sinai said. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.8 percent a year. While a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth rate in the 1970s, it was still far below the 3.3 percent rate of increase posted in the two decades after World War II when American workers enjoyed healthy wage gains and a rising standard of living during those decades. Output in the non-farm sector rose 2.7 percent during the first quarter of 1989, well below the 3.6 percent increase in the number of hours worked, the Labor Department said.

DOC.HEAD: China Tightens Rules on Travel To Tibet
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities in Tibet announced strict new controls Monday on foreign travel to the region, saying each traveler must submit an application in advance to local authorities. The new rules apply even to ordinary tourists, making it unlikely that tourism will get back to the levels of before March 1989, when martial law was imposed to end pro-independence rioting. Martial law was lifted just last week. The official Xinhua News Agency quoted Tang Zhengqi, deputy secretary-general of the regional government, as saying the controls were imposed because Tibet has limited capacity to accommodate foreign travelers. However, authorities clearly were concerned about contact between foreigners and Tibetans who have demonstrated repeatedly over the past three years for independence. China has accused ``hostile foreign forces'' of scheming to help Tibetan separatists. Several Tibetan cities were opened to foreign travelers in 1983. They immediately became popular destinations for backpackers traveling overland from Nepal and for package tours flying in from the Chinese city of Chengdu. About 30,000 tourists visited Tibet in 1986, the last year unmarred by bloody clashes between Tibetan nationalists and Chinese security forces. China says its sovereignty over Tibet dates to the 13th century. Tibetan nationalists say the region was actually independent much of that time and should be now. Authorities expelled all foreigners from Tibet's capital, Lhasa, when martial law was declared on March 8, 1989, and has allowed only a small number of tour groups to visit since. The cold-water hostels where foreign backpackers used to stay have closed for lack of business. The Western-style Lhasa Hotel, run by Holiday Inn, has been nearly empty. Travelers who have visited recently have been given printed notices at the Lhasa airport warning them to not to ``endanger the national security ... Spread words harmful to our national dignity, sovereignty, territorial integrity, or interfere in our national affairs.'' The notices also warn foreigners not to ``take drugs or go whoring.'' Tang said tourists should present their applications to visit Tibet to the regional tourism administration. In practice, authorities have been requiring such applications for several weeks, according to Westerners who said they were given forms by the travel agency arranging their trip. The main purpose appeared to be to screen journalists traveling as tourists. Authorities have allowed few journalists into Tibet since September 1987, when the first of increasingly frequent pro-independence demonstrations was held. Four of the demonstrations since then have ended in bloody clashes between Tibetans and Chinese security. Tibetans say more than 60 people have died. Hundreds have been arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Will Be Released This Week After Month in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Actress Elizabeth Taylor, hospitalized for a month with a near-fatal bout of pneumonia, will be released this week from St. John's Hospital and Health Center, a publicist said Monday. ``She's doing much, much better. She will get out in the next few days or so,'' Chen Sam said. ``She's been improving and she's still getting a lot of mail.'' Miss Taylor, 58, who was reported near death at the hospital on April 22, will continue her recuperation at her Beverly Hills home. The Oscar-winning star of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ``Butterfield 8'' entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a sinus infection, but her condition deteriorated and she was moved to St. John's for treatment of viral pneumonia.

DOC.HEAD: How Broke Are States? Enough To Consider Election-Year Tax Increases
With AM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many state lawmakers have become ``reluctant warriors'' for election-year tax increases. Plans include extending Rhode Island's sales tax to Bibles and broad-based levies on gasoline in California and income in Massachusetts. ``You can't live like a millionaire if you're not one,'' said New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat who wants to raise $1.16 billion in new taxes mostly by increasing the sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent. Massachusetts lawmakers have balked at raising taxes even as the state has earned the lowest bond rating in the nation by falling $800 million to $900 million short of cash to pay bills. New York's legislators have kicked around a $1 billion revenue increase far beyond an April 1 budget deadline. Texas deadlocked on school financing. Illinois got hung up on a phone tax. Florida and Massachusetts hit the brakes on gas tax increases. South Carolina faced a multiple choice and picked none of the above. Proposals for new revenues also are pending in Connecticut, Kansas, Louisiana, North Dakota, Rhode Island and Vermont. The need for new revenues stems mostly from the Northeast's economic slowdown and Sun Belt growth that requires expanded state services. ``There's nobody going to stand up here and embrace a tax, but I think people realize the magnitude of the problem we're facing,'' said Florida House Appropriations Committee Chairman T.K. Wetherell. ``You're going to see some reluctant warriors.'' A researcher who tracks state budgets says many states this year are putting off inevitable hard choices because they have enough reserves to get by or would rather wait until after gubernatorial elections in November. ``What we're seeing this year is sort of a teaser for what we're going to see next year,'' said Marcia Howard, research director with the National Association of State Budget Officers in Washington, D.C. ``One thing that surprises me is that I know of two states already that have raised their sales tax rates,'' she said, referring to Texas and Georgia. ``It's not as easy to raise your sales tax rate as it is some other thing. So it can be viewed as pretty dramatic.'' Rather than hiking a broad-based tax on sales or income, some states are targeting items such as alcohol and gasoline that only fuel some of the people some of the time. Rhode Island Gov. Edward D. DiPrete steadfastly refuses to consider anything called a tax increase. But the Republican governor has persuaded his Democrat-controlled General Assembly to approve increasing fees for such things as auto registrations to stave off a $100 million deficit. Some legislators proposed expanding the state sales tax by closing exemptions on such purchases as Bibles and 12-meter yachts. A study says that could raise as much as $15 million. New York lawmakers, facing a $1.5 billion deficit, are piecing together multiple sources of income that will cost the average New Yorker more than $55 extra this year. The increase includes a corporate tax surcharge of 15 percent, the freeze of an income tax cut that was due this year and a broadening of the state sales tax to cover such things as public relations firms and custom computer programming. Florida has a nearly $1 billion puzzle of revenue increases. The more imaginative pieces are motorist fees such as a $195 ``impact fee'' on any car brought into the state on which Florida sales taxes have not been paid. Last week, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who is fighting for re-election, vetoed a $4.7 billion plan that contained a 4-cent-a-gallon gas tax increase. Gas taxes are of limited help in closing state budget deficits because they often are earmarked by law for highways _ an arrangement guarded by trucking and auto lobbyists. Nevertheless, Massachusetts Democrats are working on a tax plan that combines a 20 percent rise in the state income tax and a 10-cent gas tax increase from the current rate of 11 cents a gallon. In California, voters will decide in the June 5 primary whether to relax an 11-year-old constitutional spending limit to allow the doubling of the state gasoline tax to 18 cents a gallon. The measure is aimed at raising an extra $15.5 billion during the next 10 years for roads and transportation, but probably would free money for other programs.

DOC.HEAD: Students Retain Control of Mills College to Protest Co-Ed Decision
DOC.TEXT: Mills College students kept control of the campus Monday in their protest against the trustees' decision to admit male undergraduates for the first time in the school's 138-year history. Students, who blockaded administration buildings and boycotted classes to halt activities at the liberal arts college, said they will demonstrate through graduation, May 20, or until the decision is reversed. ``Right now we do not want to compromise,'' said sophomore Deborah Egbert, spokeswoman for the Associated Students of Mills College. She estimated 300 students are continuing the demonstration that began Thursday. Administrators met with students during the weekend in an unsuccessful attempt to end the demonstration, according to Mills spokeswoman Vickie Bates. Finals are scheduled to begin Friday. Bates said teachers are considering whether to let students make up assignments, take final grades based on previous school work or proceed with end-of-term tests. Most of Mills' 777 female undergraduates oppose the decision to admit male undergraduates in the fall of 1991. The trustees want to boost enrollment to 1,000 students, which would help balance the school's $24 million annual budget.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Announces Recall of 1985 Plymouths, Dodges
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is recalling eight models of 1985 Plymouths and Dodges that have flunked federal exhaust emission standards, the Environmental Protection Agency announced Monday. The recall to replace part of the carburetor choke system affects 383,700 vehicles: the Plymouth Horizon, Turismo, Reliant and Reliant wagon; and the Dodge Omni, Charger, Aries and Aries wagons, the EPA said. Chrysler agreed to the recall after the cars, all with 2.2-liter engines, exceeded the allowed hydrocarbon and carbon monoxide exhaust emission levels in routine EPA tests, the agency said. The recall does not affect cars sold in California. The manufacturer will replace the choke vacuum delay valve, which allows a richer mixture of fuel and air when the engine is started cold. Chrysler has designed an improved valve, the EPA said. The work is to be done free by Chrysler-Plymouth or Dodge dealers. Hydrocarbons, when combined with sunlight and other pollutants, contribute to the formation of smog. The EPA says that excessive carbon monoxide levels in the atmosphere impair heart functions and are harmful to people with lung disease, anemia and peripheral vascular disease.

DOC.HEAD: World Jewish Congress: Economic Hardship Has Fueled Anti-Semitism
DOC.TEXT: World Jewish Congress officials said Monday economic hardship has fueled anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe and they planned a solemn ceremony at the site where Nazis plotted the extermination of the Jews. On the second day of the congress' annual meeting, a U.S. Justice Department official said Washington has rejected Austrian President Kurt Waldheim's repeated requests for a lifting of the ban that keeps him out of the country. The official said the ban remains in effect because of Waldheim's role ``Nazi-sponsored persecution.'' The three-day meeting in Berlin is the Congress' first in Germany since the organization was founded in Switzerland in 1936 amid the horrors of the Third Reich. Some delegates declined to attend, saying a visit to Berlin, the former Nazi capital, would be too traumatic. Six million Jews were killed by the Nazis between January 1933 and May 1945. On Tuesday, Congress officials will visit Berlin's Wannsee Villa, where on Jan. 20, 1942 leading Nazi officials plotted the Third Reich's so-called Final Solution to exterminate Jews worldwide. A solemn ceremony at the villa will coincide with the 45th anniversary of the Nazis' unconditional surrender in World War II. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir used the anniversary to speak out against arms sales to the Jewish state's Arab enemies. He told Israel's Parliament that a united Germany should ``learn the lessons of the past'' and not sell weapons to Arab nations. At a news conference Monday in the heavily guarded West Berlin Jewish Community headquarters, World Jewish Congress leaders warned about present dangers and emphasized the need to recall past tragedies. ``The Jewish people have something to say to the new Germany that is going to be created in a short time,'' said Congress President Edgar M. Bronfman. He opened the meeting Sunday by saying a united Germany must ``forever teach'' about the Holocaust, ``the lowest point ever reached in man's inhumanity to man.'' Congress leaders said that in Eastern Europe there were indications of growing anti-Semitism, fueled in large part by economic hardship. Decades of Communist mismanagement have driven the economies of East European countries to the brink. Many jobless youths have turned to right-wing extremism, often blaming Jews and foreigners for economic ills. ``Unfortunately, as the economic situation worsens ... and the search for scapegoats goes on, the age-old scapegoat _ the Jew _ again takes his place in the forefront of those to be kicked around,'' Bronfman said. ``When you see tens of thousands of Jews leaving the Soviet Union and going to Israel, one of the main reasons they're going is because of the rise of anti-Semitism,'' he said. Hundreds of thousands of Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel over the next years, in part because of looser Soviet emigration policy but also in response to what they say is increasing religious persecution at home. There are up to 2 million Soviet Jews. Bronfman said that when he visited Poland a few months ago, government leaders and Solidarity chief Lech Walesa issued ``strong statements'' against anti-Semitism. ``The only way to fight it is to expose it,'' Bronfman said of anti-Jewish feeling. Lionel Kopelowitz, head of the European Jewish Congress, said there were indications of growing anti-Jewish feeling in Romania. ``The people are hungry. They look for a scapegoat,'' he said of Romania, home to about 25,000 Jews. Heinz Galinksi, leader of West Germany's 35,000-member Jewish community, said he also sees increased neo-Nazi activities and anti-Semitism in East Germany. Neo-Nazis and other rightists recently went on a rampage in East Berlin, shouting insults against Jews and foreigners. Galinski, a survivor of the Auschwitz death camp, said the Congress meeting in Berlin was ``perhaps one of the most important events'' since the downfall of Nazi Germany. The World Jewish Congress executive director, Elan Steinberg, said 10 percent of delegates from outside East and West Germany declined to participate. About 80 of the 600 delegates were from countries other than East and West Germany. ``There are people who will not come to Berlin, and they have a right not to come to Berlin,'' Bronfman said. ``We're dealing with huge, huge emotions here.'' Neal M. Sher, head of the U.S. Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, said in a speech to delegates that ``Kurt Waldheim had engaged in Nazi-sponsored persecution.'' The U.S. government in April 1987 put Waldheim, an officer in the German army during World War II, on a ``watch list'' of people denied entry into the country. The ban followed allegations Waldheim was involved in Nazi atrocities during the war. Waldheim has denied wrongdoing. ``It is also well-known that Waldheim has tried hard and often to be a removed from the list,'' Sher said. ``But all such approaches to our government have been rebuffed. He will remain persona non grata.''

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Tells Nurses She's Their `Greatest Fan'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3 pvs, The 130, and last graf to CORRECT that Cabinet wives in attendance were not nurses.
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush told nurses Monday she is their ``greatest fan'' and might have become a nurse herself if she hadn't married George Bush. Mrs. Bush hosted a luncheon in honor of National Nursing Day before leaving for Costa Rica as head of the U.S. delegation to Tuesday's inauguration of President-elect Rafael Calderon. The 130 guests included nursing association leaders and several nurses whose husbands serve in Congress. Mrs. Bush recalled that as a congressman's wife in the 1960s, she was surprised to receive an invitation to a luncheon being given by Lady Bird Johnson to honor achievers in the medical field. When she asked why she had been invited, an aide to Mrs. Johnson said the then-Department of Health, Education and Welfare had a computerized list of congressional spouses who were nurses ``and your name ... just popped out.'' ``I was very grateful for a faulty computer,'' Mrs. Bush recalled to laughter. ``It takes a special kind of person to be a nurse,'' she said. ``You are there on the line every day, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. I am your greatest fan.'' ``I always thought that if I hadn't married George Bush ... the second best thing would have been to be a nurse,'' said Mrs. Bush. The first lady was a hospital volunteer for ``many years,'' including two mornings a week at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital in New York while Bush was the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations from 1971 to 1973. She volunteered to repay ``a not-so-little debt I still feel we owe them,'' she told the luncheon. The Bushes had taken their young daughter, Robin, to Sloan Kettering for months of treatment before her death from leukemia in 1953. ``I stand in awe of nurses who assure their patients, encourage them through treatments that are necessary and sometimes painful and many times frightening, calm the fears and then come back the next day for another eight-hour shift,'' said Mrs. Bush. ``Of all the groups, yours is the most welcome'' in the White House, she said. The guests included nurse Marcelle Leahy, whose husband is Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. Several Cabinet wives also attended the luncheon.

DOC.HEAD: Senior General Reprimanded for Criticizing Handling of Uprising
DOC.TEXT: A top general stirred an uproar in the Israeli army Monday by suggesting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir should fire senior commanders for failing to crush the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising. The armed forces chief of staff reprimanded the officer, Maj. Gen. Moshe Bar-Kochba, for going public with his criticism in Israeli newspapers, a military official said. It was one of the few disclosures of high-level army infighting over tactics since the uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987. Bar-Kochba, 60, adviser to the general staff on strategic planning, is a former head of the southern command and won a citation for his role in tank battles during the 1967 Middle East war. In pre-state days, Bar-Kochba fought the British as a member of the underground Irgun Zvi Leumi guerrilla force headed by Menachem Begin. Begin later became prime minister. His criticism appeared Sunday and Monday on the front pages of the Davar, Maariv and Hadashot dailies. According to Davar, Bar-Kochba said he went public after the army rejected his recommendations two months ago to use tanks and more live ammunition to quell riots in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Commanders had said it would be immoral to use armored vehicles against civilians and that it contradicted the army's code of behavior, Maariv said. Eight soldiers have died in the uprising and 683 Palestinians have been killed in confrontations with Israelis. The daily Hadashot said Bar-Kochba sought a meeting with Shamir to recommend that certain commanders be forced ``to take the necessary conclusions,'' or resign, for their failure to put down the uprising. No names were given. The military chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, summoned Bar-Kochba late Sunday and reprimanded him for publishing his allegations, an army official said on condition of anonymity. The official said Shomron told Bar-Kochba his behavior ``was not becoming a soldier with his rank and standing.'' The chief of staff also said Bar-Kochba could freely express his views inside the army, ``but they (officers) were not free to do so, either directly or indirectly, through the media.'' Regulations bar active soldiers from giving interviews without consent from the military spokesman's office. Shomron, 52, is a veteran paratrooper who commanded Israel's rescue of 102 hostages from a hijacked plane at Entebbe Airport in 1976. Believed politically closer to the center-left Labor Party than Shamir's right-wing Likud, Shomron was appointed chief of staff in February 1987 and has been attacked by right-wing politicians for failing to take tough measures. Left-wing Parliament member Yossi Sarid accused Bar-Kochba of using his military service ``to represent the Likud or the even more right wing,'' in Israel, the pro-Labor Davar reported. Rafael Eitan, a former chief of staff and right-wing legislator, said the feud was the apparent beginning of a fight over who would succeed Shomron.

DOC.HEAD: Freeway Closed For Homicide Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A motorist was shot to death early Monday, reportedly by someone in a passing car, and authorities shut down a jampacked freeway for nearly an hour to search for clues. The victim was shot in the head while driving south on the Harbor Freeway about five miles south of downtown, said police Lt. Bruce Hagerty. The victim's car drifted onto the right shoulder before coming to a stop, police said. Police said two motorists reporting from car phones told them the shots came from a yellow Pontiac Trans-Am occupied by two men. All south-bound lanes between Manchester Boulevard and the Imperial Freeway were closed for an hour during the rush hour, backing up traffic for miles, said California Highway Patrol Officer Dwight McDonald. No arrests were made and police would not speculate on the motive for the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegians Become First to Ski to North Pole
DOC.TEXT: Two Norwegian skiers have reached the North Pole, becoming the first people to make the icy trek without dogs, motorized vehicles or outside supplies, their colleagues reported Monday. Erling Kagge, 28, and Boerge Ousland, 27, pulled their provisions on sleds, weighing up to 264 pounds, across 496 miles of Arctic ice after setting out from Canada's Ward Hunt Island north of Greenland on March 8. ``We received a satellite transmission Sunday saying they made it,'' said Trond Skaare of the team's communication center. The pair arrived at the North Pole late Friday or early Saturday, Skaare said. At least 12 previous expeditions failed to reach the earth's northernmost point without animals, snow vehicles or supplies delivered en route. None got further than 105 miles, the Norwegian news agency NTB said. Ousland, a deep-sea diver, and Kagge, a law student, trekked for 58 days to beat British, South Korean and Soviet teams also racing for the pole, Skaare said in a telephone interview. ``They must have gone fantastically fast,'' said Ousland's father, Odd, when he heard the news. ``It was a tremendous relief. There had been no radio contact since April 24,'' Ousland said. ``They could have run into polar bears or other problems, for all we knew.'' Britons Sir Ranulph Fiennes, 45, and Mike Stroud, 35, started from Siberia in early March. They were leading the race to reach the pole unaided when forced to turn back last week. It was Fiennes' fourth unsuccessful attempt, according to newspaper reports. The South Koreans had 188 miles to go, despite airlifted supplies, reports said. Kagge and Ousland crossed crevasses, rough ice and skirted patches of open water. They suffered minor frostbite in temperatures that plummeted to minus 67 but were reported in good condition. Numerous expeditions have reached the North Pole since it was conquered by American Robert Peary in 1909, but all had outside help. The $107,000 Norwegian expedition was funded mostly by the sale of 50 artworks created and donated by Norwegian painter Jakob Weidemann. An airplane was to pick up Ousland and Kagge as soon as possible, probably Monday. Geir Ramby, a third member of the Norwegian team who was injured and flown out 10 days after the trek began, said his teammates probably will celebrate with a hot shower when they reach Resolute Bay as early as Tuesday. ``After using and sweating in the same clothes for two months, they're probably emitting a pretty powerful stink,'' he told the newspaper Verdens Gang.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Nearing Agreement on Boosting Loan Resource Fund
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, struggling to meet increased financial needs in Eastern Europe and Latin America, worked Monday to resolve disagreements that have blocked a 50 percent boost in the agency's loan resources. Delegates to the spring meeting of the 152-nation agency expressed optimism that the IMF's policy-setting interim committee will reach an agreement by Tuesday, ending two years of debate on the issue. The increase would boost IMF resources from $120 billion to $180 billion, making $60 billion more available to support economic reforms in Poland and other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. The additional funds would also be used to support Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's strategy of reducing the financial burden on debt-strapped Latin American countries. The increase would require a $12 billion contribution from the United States. The increase is certain to draw opposition in Congress from critics of American foreign aid efforts. The increase received a big boost Sunday with the approval of the world's seven largest economies. The United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, known as the Group of Seven, endorsed the 50 percent increase, making final approval by the IMF highly likely. The Bush administration, however, has tied its support for any increase to a change in the IMF charter that would allow the fund to suspend the voting rights of any country behind in its loan payments. At present, 11 countries _ Sudan, Zambia, Peru, Honduras, Guyana, Cambodia, Vietnam, Liberia, Panama, Sierra Leone and Somalia _ owe a total of $4.2 billion in back payments. ``These arrears pose a fundamental challenge to the IMF's financial integrity and its central role in the world economy,'' Brady said in a speech to the 22-member committee as it debated the issue. Delegates from debtor nations on the committee objected to the United States' get-tough approach. A coordinating group for Third World countries said in a statement that suspending voting rights would not ``serve a useful purpose and is not acceptable.'' The loan resource increase was also tied up in the ticklish issue of how to rearrange the rankings and voting powers of rich nations. Under the plan expected to win final approval, the United States would remain the No. 1 shareholder in the IMF with little more than 19 percent of its voting power. Japan would move from No. 5 to No. 2, a spot it would share with West Germany. Each country would hold a 6 percent voting share. Britain would drop from No. 2 to a tie for No. 4 with France, with each country holding a 5.5 percent voting share. John Major, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, told reporters he believed the question of rankings was almost resolved. A third issue under debate was the length of time the higher loan resource level would be in effect. The United States is pushing for a five-year period before the IMF again takes up the issue. Other countries lobbied for a readjustment after three years. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel and French Economics Minister Pierre Beregovoy suggested a compromise might be to settle on a four-year period. None of these issues was expected to delay the final resolution of the financing increase. The IMF and its sister agency, the World Bank, are the largest sources for loans to developing countries. ``The fund remains pivotal to the international debt strategy and it will be at the center of international efforts to help Eastern European countries restructure their economies toward free markets,'' Brady said Monday. His remarks, made during the private negotiations, were made available to reporters later. In addition to IMF resources, the finance ministers addressed the progress so far on Brady's one-year-old initiative to reduce the huge $1.3 trillion Third World debt burden and the economic impact likely to result from the unification of East and West Germany. Officials generally gave high marks to the Brady plan, which employs the resources of the IMF and World Bank to provide incentives to commercial banks to cut old bank debt and interest payments owed by Third World nations. The ministers expressed optimism that German unification will not produce the adverse effects feared by some economists of driving up world interest rates and worsening inflationary pressures.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Reject Tax to Pay for Education of `Baby Boom' Children
DOC.TEXT: A 34-child baby boomlet is overwhelming this town's five-room school, but residents rejected a property tax hike to solve the problem. Despite heavy lobbying by parents, residents on Saturday voted down, 263-122, a proposal to override a limit on property tax increases. Officials said the override was needed because schooling costs have risen 25 percent. In Massachusetts, property tax increases of more than 2{ percent must be approved by voters. The baby boom began eight years ago, when 29 women in this Berkshire Hills community of 250 families gave birth _ two to twins _ and three more adopted children. The youngsters are all now in first and second grade driving up costs at the five-room school. Worthington's school costs are up $130,000 over last year. They account for about one-third of the town's $1.7 million annual budget. For a homeowner with property assessed at $100,000, the override would have added $125 to the $896 annual tax bill. Worthington's school funds come from the seven-town Gateway Regional School District. Town officials said after the vote they would wait to see how the other towns in the school district vote before taking further action. ``We haven't really decided what will happen now,'' Selectwoman Julia Sharron said Monday. ``Possibly if the other towns in the district vote it down the school will have to go back and make cuts.'' Mrs. Sharron said she suspected the override failed because ``people just can't afford to have any higher taxes than they had.''

DOC.HEAD: NY Nightmare: Two Cars Stolen In 3 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Leo Vigil is caught in a New York City nightmare. Three weeks ago, his brand-new Nissan Pathfinder was stolen from outside a Manhattan restaurant where he had taken a customer of his tie company for dinner. ``The buyer was telling me about how his car had been stolen. We walk out of the restaurant and my car's gone,'' Vigil said. On Monday, his other car, a 1989 Jaguar, was one of seven autos taken at gunpoint from a Greenwich Village garage. ``My insurance company is totally freaking out,'' Vigil said. His two cars were worth about $75,000. Two of the cars taken Monday _ a Toyota and a Honda _ were abandoned near the garage, but the Jaguar, a BMW, a Porsche and two other cars not yet identified were driven away. ``The luxury cars are very hard to steal, that's why we're having more gunpoint robberies,'' said Sgt. Pete Baglio of the Auto Crime Division. ``The expensive cars have alarm systems that make them tough to get into.'' Once stolen, ``a lot of these cars are being tagged and shipped out of the country. They're not chopping up these cars,'' Baglio added. ``It's just devastating, it really is,'' Vigil said in a telephone interview Monday. ``It's just amazing what happens here.'' He said he'd bought another Pathfinder and would ``hope for the best.'' There were 133,861 reported car thefts in the city in 1989, a rise of 13,921 from 1988, according to police statistics. But nationwide, New York City ranked ninth per capita in car thefts, after top-ranked Boston, Dallas, Detroit, San Diego, Houston, New Orleans, Los Angeles, and Memphis, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Killed, Another Captured in South Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf `One pro-Israeli' to make it `slightly' wounded sted `light.' Picks up 3rd pvs, `Fighters of...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-backed militiamen killed a pro-Syrian guerrilla and captured another Monday in a clash in south Lebanon, the army command said. One pro-Israeli militiaman was slightly wounded when guerrillas fired rifles and a rocket-propelled grenade at a militia patrol near Beit Yahoun, six miles north of the Israeli border, the army said. Fighters of the South Lebanon Army, which is supplied and trained by Israel, returned fire, killing one guerrilla and capturing another, the military said. Security sources in Lebanon said other guerrillas reportedly fled. The army said the guerrillas apparently belonged to the Syrian Socialist Nationalist Party. It is a pro-Syrian militia responsible for a number of suicide attacks and car bombings in southern Lebanon. They carried Soviet-designed Kalashnikov assault rifles, hand grenades, a rocket-propelled grenade launcher, ammunition and other equipment, the army said. Lebanese and Palestinian guerrillas stage frequent attacks on Israel's security zone, which is intended to prevent cross-border raids on Israel. The zone is a stretch of land up to 10 miles wide that Israel established after withdrawing the bulk of its troops from Lebanon in 1985. It is jointly patrolled by Israeli troops and the South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Gather Support Despite Murderous Record
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Convoys of Khmer Rouge trucks filled with the recent rice harvest move freely through this rural village in northwest Cambodia, and young guerrilla fighters flirt with relaxed villagers. ``We are very happy to be back in our country,'' said Khmer Rouge division commander Mit Soe over coconut juice as Cambodian government artillery rumbled in the distance. In a scene played out in scores of villages in rural Cambodia in recent months, Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge have returned to areas they were driven out of when Vietnamese forces invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and installed a pro-Hanoi government. To much of the world, the Khmer Rouge are fanatics who killed hundreds of thousands of their countrymen during the 1970s in a savage bid to create a communist agrarian society. But despite the widely held perception that they continue to be universally despised, the Khmer Rouge maintain significant and increasing support in the long-neglected, poor villages of this ravaged country. Since the announced pullout of Vietnamese troops in September, the Khmer Rouge have seized hundreds of villages in the north, west and southwest of the country. Khmer Rouge officials in Cambodia and western intelligence sources in Bangkok, Thailand say the group is attracting followers by tapping the deep suspicion most Cambodians harbor for their historical enemy, Vietnam. The Khmer Rouge contend that Vietnam intends to ``swallow'' Cambodia. They allege that despite the pledged Vietnamese withdrawal, Vietnamese troops secretly remain in Cambodia disguised as Cambodian soldiers. Although human rights groups have described strict regimentation and brutality in Khmer Rouge-controlled areas over the past decade, the guerrillas seem to have abandoned their harshest practices _ at least temporarily. Analysts are quick to point out that most Cambodians still loathe the Khmer Rouge and note that Pol Pot, Khieu Samphan and other leaders who presided over the 1975-78 reign of terror are still in charge. There is fear that if the Khmer Rouge were to return to power, their murderous ways would simply resurface. But the analysts say the Khmer Rouge have managed to maintain a support network throughout rural Cambodia and have been able to recruit fighters since being driven to sanctuaries along the Thai-Cambodian border after the Vietnamese invasion. ``If they were that evil, they wouldn't have survived the last 11{ years. There must be something they are fighting for that makes the Khmer people join them,'' Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew told the British newspaper The Independent in a recent interview. Although he frequently condemns the Khmer Rouge, Cambodia's exiled leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, recently said they have adopted a ``new style'' that includes scrupulously honest and disciplined behavior when dealing with villagers. Sihanouk, who ruled Cambodia until he was ousted in a 1970 military coup, predicted the Khmer Rouge would win ``many seats'' in parliament should general elections be held in Cambodia. ``You won't get people to vote for Pol Pot himself for president,'' said one Western intelligence analyst in Bangkok, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But as an organization, they have clear popular support based on their honesty, dedication and nationalism.'' By contrast, the pro-Hanoi government in Phnom Penh and the two non-communist guerrilla groups which are loosely allied with the Khmer Rouge are rife with the decades-long scourge of Cambodian politics _ corruption. In recent months, soldiers of the two non-communist groups have also displayed a gross lack of discipline that has shocked even their own commanders. Rape and robbery of villagers occur frequently. ``When the Khmer Rouge come to town, you don't have to hide your daughter and your money,'' said a Bangkok-based diplomat, requesting anonymity. In the U.N. refugee camps that house 300,000 guerrilla-controlled civilians along the Thai border, relief officials say the Khmer Rouge camps are the best-run. ``We have the least problems in the Khmer Rouge camps,'' said a senior U.N. official in the border town of Aranyaprathet. ``A lot less corruption. Their leaders are hardworking and dedicated. Nobody wants to hear it, but it happens to be true.'' He spoke on condition he not be identified. Western and Thai intelligence sources say that as many as 80 percent of the Khmer Rouge ranks are new recruits who have joined since the Vietnamese invasion. Troop strength is generally estimated at between 25,000 and 35,000, more than twice the size of the decimated forces which fled to the Thai border in 1979. Dozens of Khmer Rouge fighters interviewed in recent weeks in newly seized villages in northwest Cambodia say they considered themselves nationalists and openly rejected communism. ``The average Khmer Rouge soldier thinks he is liberating his country from the Vietnamese, not fighting for an ideology,'' said one Western diplomat in Bangkok, requesting anonymity. The Khmer Rouge, which receives Chinese support, says it will continue fighting until there is an internationally verified withdrawal of Vietnamese troops and a coalition government, including the three guerrilla groups and the pro-Hanoi government of Prime Minister Hun Sen. The Phnom Penh government has rejected any interim coalition including the Khmer Rouge, which it accuses of genocide against the Cambodian people.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed as Rival Christian Forces Clash
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces blasted each other with artillery and tank fire in east Beirut and the surrounding countryside Monday, killing 12 people and wounding 27, police said. Several apartment buildings and filling stations in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave were set ablaze. Trucks carrying food across Beirut's dividing Green Line also were burning, police and witnesses said. ``Everything is burning at the crossing. Drivers abandoned their trucks and ran back to the Moslem sector. So did hundreds of Christian residents,'' said Simon Khoury, a Christian electrician who made it back to west Beirut. The fighting marked a sharp escalation in the 3{-month-old battle between army Gen. Michel Aoun and Christian warlord Samir Geagea for mastery of the enclave north and northeast of Beirut. Police said the fatalities included a family of five killed when a shell struck the basement of their building in the Aoun-controlled town of Fanar north of Beirut. Also killed was police Capt. Pierre Ghawi. He died when several artillery rounds strayed from the embattled enclave and landed in the Moslem sector. Four civilians were wounded in west Beirut, police said. Flames lit up the night sky and the roar of shell blasts reverberated across Beirut. Tens of thousands of residents huddled in basements and bomb shelters on both sides of the Green Line. Christian employees of Middle East Airlines and the Trans Mediterranean Airlines, Lebanon's national passenger and cargo carriers, were trapped at Beirut airport, unable to return home. Employees will spend the night at the facility, on the southern edge of Beirut, an airport statement said. Aoun's mountain-top positions poured 155mm howitzer barrages on east Beirut's seaside Karantina district, which houses the military command of Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. A Lebanese Forces gunboat off Karantina was seen unleashing rapid barrages of rockets from multi-barreled launchers on the Metn mountains and then speeding away with shells falling all around. Each side blamed the other for the flare-up, which broke out at midnight Sunday, tapered off four hours later and escalated again in the afternoon. The fighting between Aoun's 19,000 troops and Geagea's 6,000 militiamen has left 934 people dead and 2,483 wounded, by the latest police count. The conflict, the worst inter-christian confrontation in the nation's 15-year-old civil war, has forced more than 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million inhabitants to flee. Material damage has been estimated at $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Killer of Deputies Ruled Senile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: District Attorney General, 2nd graf, cq
DOC.TEXT: An 82-year-old ex-convict charged with murdering two sheriff's deputies is mentally unfit to stand trial but will likely remain locked up for the rest of his life, a prosecutor says. ``We can't try him because he can't understand the charges against him or assist in his defense. If he is ever found competent to stand trial, we'll start the trial process right away. He won't be freed,'' said District Attorney General Paul Summers. The suspect, Ule Reynolds, is charged with shooting two Lauderdale County sheriff's deputies in January. The deputies were giving Reynolds a ride in their cruiser after finding him late at night in a disabled car. Authorities say the deputies, Bobby Nolen, 55, and Kevan Ward, 31, apparently put Reynolds in the back seat of the cruiser without searching him for weapons. Reynolds, who has a criminal record dating from 1927, was armed with a .357-caliber Magnum revolver in a shoulder holster, authorities said. A resident of Gary, Ind., Reynolds apparently ran his car into a ditch near Ripley while driving alone to Tennessee to attend the funeral of a cousin, investigators say. Summers said doctors at the Middle Tennessee Mental Health Institute at Nashville have examined Reynolds and found him to be senile. A Lauderdale County circuit judge accepted that finding Friday and ruled Reynolds incompetent to stand trial, Summers said. Prosecutors have asked for Reynolds to be committed to a mental institution and the court is expected to review his status next month, Summers said. He has remained in custody without bond since his arrest. Reynolds' relatives and friends have told authorities that his mental abilities have deteriorated in recent years. His wife, Minnie, said he told her after the shooting that he thought the deputies were taking him to jail. Reynolds, a barber, was convicted of manslaughter in Tennessee in 1927 and served a two- to five-year prison sentence. He had several arrests on charges involving firearms over the years and was convicted in 1975 in Indiana on a weapons violations and with trying to tamper with a jury in a criminal case.

DOC.HEAD: Man Whose Release Stirred Furor is Charged with Burglary
DOC.TEXT: A retarded man who was released from a mental hospital despite community opposition was held Monday on burglary charges. Bernt Murphy, confined 31 years after being found incompetent to be tried in a rape, was charged in a weekend break-in seven blocks from the group home where he had lived since his release. He was charged with theft and attempted burglary and held at Utah County Jail on $10,000 bail on orders of Circuit Judge John C. Backlund. Murphy, 52, was sent to the Utah State Hospital after being found incompetent to stand trial in the 1957 rape of a 5-year-old girl. During police interviews in that case, he confessed to killing a 23-year-old woman but was never charged in the slaying. In 1989, the Utah Supreme Court ordered his release, ruling he had mistakenly been found insane. He moved into the group home Jan. 22, and has been living with three other retarded men. His presence triggered outraged reaction from neighbors who argued that retarded men with histories of violence shouldn't be housed in a residential area. The owners of the home, which is up for sale, told police Murphy asked to look at the home Friday evening but was turned away because it was too late. Owners Eric and Lisa Gardner said they returned Saturday to find pry marks around a door and a window and the family dog missing. It didn't appear anyone got into the home, said Detective Gerald Nielsen. But a trophy with Murphy's name on it was found on the back porch and his sunglasses were found in the dog run. Murphy's civil attorney, Lisa Marcy of Salt Lake's Legal Center for the Handicapped, said she knew Murphy had been talking about leaving the group home and had told people there that he hoped to buy a home. Neighbor Bobby Jo Jackson, who has protested the decision to place ``high-risk'' residents in the group home, said she felt sorry for Murphy. ``They've all been set up to fail,'' she said. ``People with the mentality of a nine-year-old should have structure and supervision.''

DOC.HEAD: Ocumed Eyewash Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A pharmaceutical company is recalling 2,800 bottles of a non-prescription sterile eyewash called Ocumed because of bacterial contamination that could cause serious eye infections and possible blindness. Ocumed Inc. said the 4-ounce plastic bottles were stamped on the bottom with lot number N4189. The product label says it is manufactured for Rugby Laboratories Inc., Rockville Centre, N.Y., 11570. There have been no reports of injury, the company said. However, the company said testing by the Food and Drug Administration and its own laboratories found bacteria that could cause infection in a scratched or damaged eye, with the potential for loss of vision. The over-the-counter product is used by people with tired eyes or eyes subjected to dusty conditions. Consumers should return the product to the place of purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Testifies that Winnie Mandela Beat and Whipped Captives
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf, `Kenneth Kgase...' to make clear that Kgase was an alleged victim. Pickup 7th graf, `According to...
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's wife, Winnie, whipped, punched and slapped three men and a teen-ager who had been abducted and held captive in her home, a witness testified in a trial Monday. The teen-ager, 14-year-old Stompie Seipei, was found stabbed to death on Jan. 6, 1989. One of Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards, Jerry Richardson, is on trial for his death. Richardson pleaded innocent to the charges of murder, kidnapping, attempted murder and assault. Eight other bodyguards for Mrs. Mandela face separate trials on lesser charges stemming from the incident. The three men said they survived beatings by Mrs. Mandela and her bodyguards in late December 1988. They have given sworn affidavits saying she participated in the assaults on them and on Seipei. Police are investigating the allegations. Mrs. Mandela has not been charged with a crime and denies being present during the attacks. Kenneth Kgase, 30, one of the abducted men, was the first witness to testify in the trial that began Wednesday. On Monday, Kgase said Mrs. Mandela assaulted all four of the captives, punching and whipping them and pulling their hair. According to Kgase, the attack occurred after Mrs. Mandela was told that the four had homosexual relations with a Methodist minister who ran the house where they had been staying in Soweto. The Methodist Church says it has investigated the accusation and cleared the minister. Mrs. Mandela left the room following the attack, and then her bodyguards, also known as the Mandela United soccer team, assaulted the captives, Kgase said. He said the bodyguards lifted the four above their shoulders and then dropped them to the floor. Team members also hit the men on the knees with shoe heels and empty bottles, he alleged. When the beatings ended, Kgase said, the captives were forced to clean their blood from the floor, using a broom and hose. Leaders of major anti-apartheid organizations in South Africa have accused Mrs. Mandela of complicity in the abductions and assault of the four. They said her bodyguards, mostly young men in their teens or early 20s, had waged a ``reign of terror'' in Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. The anti-apartheid leaders called for the black community to shun Mrs. Mandela early last year. But a few months later she began appearing at rallies with other leaders, and she is now regularly at her husband's side when he makes public appearances. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, has made no public comment on the case since being released from prison in February. Mrs. Mandela is not expected to appear at Richardson's trial. She denied last year that she was in her house when the youths were allegedly assaulted. In a separate development Monday, the ANC-affiliated Alexandra Civic Association condemned the re-emergence of kangaroo courts. The civic association, some of whose members had supported the so-called ``people's courts'' during the 1984-86 nationwide political violence, said it was barbaric that inexperienced youths have been judging and meting out punishment to older citizens. The organization's spokesman, Obed Bapela, said people in the township were taking their crime problems to young people known as ``comrades'' instead of to the police because residents had lost confidence in the authorities. ``Crime in Alexandra is escalating every day but that (kangaroo courts) is a crime in itself,'' Bapela said. The public condemnation of the ``people's courts'' was made after front-page newspaper accounts Monday in which a 32-year-old woman said ``comrades'' sentenced her to 100 lashes with a whip, stripped her in front of a large crowd and flogged her, because she had stabbed a man who broke into her home to rape her.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Phone-In Game Begins With $1 Million Prize
DOC.NOTE: Eds: the 900 number, which costs $3 to dial, is 1-900-226-2000
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide phone-in game costing $3 to battle other trivia buffs for a $1 million prize started Monday. A congressman, however, has said callers were gambling and he wants the Justice Department to investigate. ``The Game'' uses computer technology to pit up to nine callers to a 900 area code number against each other in a trivia contest. Winners avance to subsequent rounds by calling a toll-free 800 number. Examples of the questions, which have numerical answers entered on touchtone telephones, include: ``What year did Columbus sail for the New World'' and ``How many keys on a piano?'' Second-round winners get $5, fourth-round winners $100 and sixth round $10,000. Every two weeks, sixth-round winners will compete for the $1 million seventh and final round. ``We think it's going to be a hit,'' said Lynn Folse, vice president of Los Angeles-based 900 Million Productions. But Rep. Bart Gordon, D-Tenn., wants the Justice Department to intervene. ``Participants in this game are effectively betting $2.99 that they will win money, much as participants in a lottery pay for the chance to win cash,'' Gordon said Monday.
