He complained in a letter sent Friday to the Justice Department that ``The Game'' may violate anti-gambling laws. The congressman also noted there was a potential for children to run up telephone bills. ``There is no way to restrict The Game to adults because there is no way to verify age levels over the telephone. Kids can quickly run up huge phone bills without their parents' knowledge,'' Gordon said. ``No one can cash a check unless they are 18 or older so there would be no point in playing,'' Folse argued. ``This has nothing to do with gambling. This is a game of common knowledge and skill. ``It has nothing whatsoever to do with a game of chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Protest Leaders Consider Romanian Gov't Offer for Talks
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of an anti-government protest in a downtown square expressed uncertainty Monday about whether they would accept an invitation to meet with interim President Ion Iliescu. Hundreds of demonstrators demanding Iliescu's resignation occupied the capital's central University Square for the 16th straight day Monday. The crowd swelled from 500 early in the day to about 1,500 by evening. Iliescu had previously ruled out any dialogue with the protesters, but on Saturday he agreed to meet with leaders of the opposition groups coordinating the demonstration. Romanian officials said opposition leaders have yet to respond to an invitation for a meeting Tuesday morning. But representatives of the opposition groups said Monday that they have some hesitation regarding the talks. They expressed concern the meeting was intended only to calm the situation without seriously addressing the issues. The state radio reported one protest leader, Dumitru Dinca, had stopped his nine-day hunger strike to prepare for the meeting with Iliescu. As of Sunday, 57 demonstrators were fasting in University Square to press their demands for Iliescu's resignation. The demonstrators are also demanding free elections scheduled for May 20 be delayed to give newly formed opposition parties more time to organize, and that the electoral law be amended to exclude former Communist officials from high public office. Iliescu has ruled out any discussion of postponing the elections or the electoral law, saying both were approved by the provisional parliament, which includes opposition parties. Iliescu, who heads the National Salvation Front that dominates the interim government, was a high-ranking Communist official under deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, but fell out of favor and was relegated to minor posts. Iliescu's National Salvation Front is considered the favorite in the upcoming election. A poll released this week showed Iliescu with support of 79 percent of the voters. The protesters say they are seriously concerned because the National Salvation Front contains many former Communist Party members who want to introduce a reformed version of Communism. The demand for excluding Communists from top government posts is included in a proclamation drawn up in March in Timisoara by opposition activists who fear that the interim leadership has sold out the anti-Communist aims of the revolution that toppled Ceausescu. The December revolt that led to the ouster and execution of Ceausescu began with the shooting of anti-government protesters in Timisoara, 250 miles west of the capital. In another development Monday, supporters of the Front in the Moldavian town of Vaslui, about 175 miles north of Bucharest, published a proclamation attacking what they described as the provocative rally in University Square. The proclamation accused the demonstrators of trying ``to disturb public peace ... and prevent the normal unfolding of the electoral process.'' In an apparent reference to the protesters' demand to exclude Communists from public office, the proclamation criticized what it called ``attempts to instill a venomous atmosphere and sow division among the electorate.'' The proclamation was also read out Sunday by interim Prime Minister Petre Roman during a pro-Front campaign rally in Vaslui that drew 20,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: FBI to Meet With U.S. Attorney On Shrimper Shootings
DOC.TEXT: The FBI said Monday it was questioning people involved in a weekend clash in which Vietnamese and Louisiana shrimp fishermen reportedly exchanged gunfire and rammed each others' boats. ``We have a number of people left to interview on both sides then we'll talk to the U.S. Attorney'' about a possible grand jury investigation, said FBI spokesman Volney Hayes. Six shrimp boats, some with bullet holes, were taken to Port Fourchon in Lafourche Parish on Sunday, the Coast Guard said. After crew members were questioned, the boats were released, a Harbor Police spokesman said. Four Vietnamese immigrants were detained for their own safety but no one was arrested, the Coast Guard said. They were interviewed by federal agents Sunday at Grand Isle, then returned to their boat at Port Fourchon. No names were released. Donald Lirette of Dulac, president of the Terrebonne Fishermen's Organization, said the fight was a result of tension between longtime area fishermen and Vietnamese newcomers. He said recent bad winter weather kept boats in port much of the time and that, coupled with several bad years for shrimpers, have left tempers short. The Vietnamese fishermen would not discuss the incident with reporters who gathered at the small fishing community of Port Fourchon. Lirette recounted it this way: ``The Vietnamese heard the Americans say they had found a little spot of shrimp and they went in there and tried to run the Americans off. American shrimpers have a problem because they can't communicate with the Vietnamese. They come in with those big boats and know they can run the Americans out of the shrimp.'' No injuries were reported in the Saturday afternoon exchange at Whiskey Pass, one of Louisiana's barrier islands in the Gulf of Mexico, about 75 miles southwest of New Orleans. The anchor of the vessel Our Mama, manned by local fishermen, became entangled in the net of the vessel Freedom I, manned by Vietnamese immigrants, the Coast Guard said. The Coast Guard got a call from Our Mama saying it was being fired on by Freedom I. Our Mama returned fire, the Coast Guard said, and three crewmen from Freedom I jumped overboard. A workboat picked them up and took them to an oil rig. The shooting stopped when Coast Guard helicopters and boats arrived. The crew of a cutter saw what appeared to be weapons thrown overboard, Lt. Michael Tekesky said. The Coast Guard said nine or 10 boats were in the area at the time. One began sinking, but righted itself with pumps from the Coast Guard, Tekesky said. Despite the incident, the Coast Guard did not step up patrols Monday, Petty Officer Bob Morehead said.

DOC.HEAD: Community Stunned by Deaths of Three Youngsters at Little League Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged AM-Children Hit on news advisory
DOC.TEXT: Counselors were sent to six elementary schools Monday to console grieving classmates of three children who were killed when a Cadillac plowed through a Little League field during a baseball game. Police sought grand jury subpoenas to determine if charges should be filed against the driver, who also injured nine people in Saturday's tragedy. Adults shared the shock of their children over the worst disaster in memory in this close-knit community west of Chicago. ``The whole community is very much disturbed. People on the street hug and cry,'' said the Rev. Leon Wagner, pastor at St. Mary's Catholic Church, where families of four children involved in the accident attend services. ``I would say the parents are probably the ones who are worst hit,'' Wagner said. ``Like every other community, time will heal it.'' Police asked the Cook County state's attorney to seek subpoenas for medical records and testimony of the driver, 59-year-old James J. Harasek, to find out why his car plowed into the 7- and 8-year-old Little League players in a park Saturday afternoon, said Police Chief Don Doneske. Harasek, who was hospitalized in fair condition with a fractured left elbow, has refused to answer investigators' questions on the advice of his attorney, Doneske said. Harasek's wife, Loretta, said her husband ``blacked out and doesn't remember hitting nothing till he hit the building, that's when he knew he hit something.'' ``I'm very deeply hurt and so upset I can't even begin to say how bad I feel,'' she said by telephone Sunday. The Chicago Sun-Times reported that Harasek was taking heart medication. ``He does have a heart problem, and we wouldn't allow him to drive, but he decided he wanted to drive today,'' Harasek's daughter Anastasia told the newspaper. ``His health is usually OK.'' Efforts to reach the family Monday were not successful. Several telephone calls to their Westchester home went unanswered. Charles G. Levy, Harasek's attorney, declined to comment Monday about the alleged heart problems. But he did say that tests taken shortly after the accident showed that Harasek's blood contained ``zero percent alcohol, none at all.'' The dead children were identified as Colin Anderson, 7; Holly Rizzi, 8; and Ryan Womanck, 8. Funeral services were scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday for two of the victims. Arrangements were incomplete for Colin Anderson, whose father, Bruce, remained hospitalized Monday in fair condition with a leg injury at Loyola University Medical Center. Two children remained in critical condition at Loyola, and one was in fair condition, said hospital spokesman Michael Maggio. Officials said a Little League game had just begun when Harasek's car veered off the road and plowed into a row of children seated on a bench behind a fence along the third-base line. The car traveled 573 feet across the park, crossed a four-lane road and stopped when it crashed into a medical clinic. No one in the clinic was injured.

DOC.HEAD: BLM, AuCoin Say Owl Conservation Could Trigger Recession
DOC.TEXT: Plans to save the northern spotted owl from extinction could devastate timber-based small towns in the Pacific Northwest, Bureau of Land Management Director Cy Jamison told a congressional panel Monday. Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore., also said economic fallout from the conservation plans and reduced timber harvests ``could literally throw the entire region into a recession.'' Jamison said the expected impact of setting aside millions of acres to protect the rare owl demonstrates weaknesses in the Endangered Species Act. ``If the Act stays the same, somehow we have to look at the management in a different light,'' he said in testimony before the Hosue Appropriatiosn interior subcommittee, on which AuCoin sits. ``If you manage a little area for the spotted owl here, and an area for the desert tortoise over here, and an area for something else here, you end up with a hodge-podge on a map. Pretty soon you have no management system out there at all.'' The Fish and Wildlife Service is to decide June 23 whether to list the spotted owl as a threatened or endangered species, which would require government agencies to protect its habitat _ the old-growth forests of the Northwest. A panel of government scientists led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas alredy has recommended an end to logging across large sections of federal lands in the Northwest to keep the owl alive. Last week, the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management said that if the Thomas recommendation is adopted timber harvests on Northwest federal lands will be cut nearly in half over the next five years, causing a net loss of about 13,000 jobs in Oregon, Washington and northern California. Jamison said his agency has identified 72 communities in Oregon with populations of 3,000 or fewer. Of those, half or more are almost entirely dependent on the timber industry, he said. ``We would basically affect one whole strata of the communities in your state (Oregon). If that isn't drastic, I don't know what it is,'' he said. ``For those communities affected, it could be devastating.'' ``We are really talking aobut enormous, staggering economic consequences.'' AuCoin said, ``There is nothing that has come close to this in the entire history of the Endangered Species Act.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0636 to restore cycle designator
Ocumed Eyewash Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A pharmaceutical company is recalling 2,800 bottles of a non-prescription sterile eyewash called Ocumed because of bacterial contamination that could cause serious eye infections and possible blindness. Ocumed Inc. said the 4-ounce plastic bottles were stamped on the bottom with lot number N4189. The product label says it is manufactured for Rugby Laboratories Inc., Rockville Centre, N.Y., 11570. There have been no reports of injury, the company said. However, the company said testing by the Food and Drug Administration and its own laboratories found bacteria that could cause infection in a scratched or damaged eye, with the potential for loss of vision. The over-the-counter product is used by people with tired eyes or eyes subjected to dusty conditions. Consumers should return the product to the place of purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Woman Gives Birth in Park Restroom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to fix typo in `Park'
DOC.TEXT: A homeless woman gave birth in the restroom of a city park on Monday just before she was discovered by a park worker. The unidentified mother and baby girl were in satisfactory condition at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, said Maureen Flatley, a hospital spokeswoman. ``I'm still shook up,'' said Idell Moore, the attendant at Battery Park who discovered the birth. Moore, 59, a city park worker for nearly 10 years, said she entered the restroom to clean it when she realized a woman was in a stall and a baby was on the floor. ``I said, `Oh, my God,''' Moore recalled. ``The mother was inside the stall. You could see the baby from underneath.'' She then ran out for a supervisor and they called 911. When they returned, the woman ``was washing herself off. She didn't do anything with the baby. The baby was lying there on the floor.'' Moore and the supervisor, Ida Pedalino, took off their shirts to wrap the baby and police officers helped gather cardboard and newspaper to hold the infant. Moore said the woman had been living on benches in the park for about two years.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Wants More Money for Refugee Program
DOC.TEXT: The number of refugees has increased dramatically over the last five years, but a State Department official said Monday that many may be able to go home in the 1990s. However, Princeton Lyman, director of refugee programs, said it will take a lot of money to resettle displaced people around the globe. Lyman told a Senate committee that the department wants $475 million in fiscal 1991 to help refugees. Of the total, $215.5 million is for international programs, an increase of $46.5 million over 1990. Although the number of refugees has swelled to 15 million, Lyman said there are ``brighter prospects of long-awaited opportunities to resolve the situations'' of many of them in the 1990s. He said the United States hoped to see refugees return to their homes in Afghanistan, Nicaragua and several countries in Africa. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., criticized the Bush administration for failing to pay enough attention to refugees. ``The world is changing,'' he said, adding that the administration continues to spend too much on military aid.

DOC.HEAD: Tab For 1990 Congressional Campaigns At $127 Million And Rising
DOC.TEXT: Candidates for this year's congressional elections spent $127 million in the 15 months ending March 31 and had nearly $140 million on hand to begin the final months of the campaign season, the Federal Election Commission said Monday. The agency's analysis of 1990 congressional campaign fund-raising and spending from January 1989 through March showed the benefits of incumbency, particularly in receiving donations from political action committees. Incumbents had a more than 6-to-1 overall fund-raising edge over challengers and a 16-to-1 edge when it came to PAC donations, according to the FEC data. Overall, the FEC computer analysis showed receipts by 1990 congressional campaigns totaled $192.5 million from Jan. 1, 1989, through the end of March, 7 percent more than was raised in the comparable period in the 1987-88 election cycle. Of those receipts, $150 million went to incumbents. And incumbents accounted for the $94.6 million of the reported $127 million in spending. The $127 million spent by 1,269 candidates for House and Senate seats up this year represents a 12 percent increase over the 1987-88 cycle. At this point two years ago, 1,344 candidates had spent $113 million. The analysis was based on the quarterly finance reports all campaigns were required to file last month. The reports detail campaign activity through March 31 and include all candidates who raised and spent money on 1990 congressional races even if they since have dropped out. For many candidates, the campaign season _ and its accompanying fund-raising _ is just kicking into high gear. But the FEC's computer analysis showed the campaigns had a combined $138.5 million on hand at the end of March. The clear leader in cash on hand was Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, who reported having $6.5 million as of March 31. The House candidate with the most on hand was California Democratic Rep. Mel Levine, with $1.5 million. Seventy candidates, most of them longshots in House races, reported zero balances. The biggest spender so far on a 1990 Senate race was New Jersey Democrat Bill Bradley, who reported spending $3.6 million so far on his re-election effort. Leading spending for 1990 House races was California Republican Rep. Robert Dornan, who reported spending $968,525 as of March 31. Other highlights: _The 1,151 candidates in 1990 House elections raised $109.2 million and spent $79.7 million in the January 1989-March 1990 period. Those candidates raised $52.4 million in individual contributions and $41.9 million from PACs. _The 118 Senate candidates raised $83 million and spent $47 million in the 15-month period, with $56.2 million of the receipts coming from individuals and $19.6 million from PACs. _The 444 incumbents seeking re-election reported total campaign receipts of $150 million in the 15-month period, dwarfing the $23.4 million raised by 600 challengers. Another $19 million was raised by the 225 candidates in races in which there is no incumbent. _Of $61 million in PAC donations to 1990 candidates during the 15 months, $54.5 million went to incumbents, $3.3 million to challengers and $3.5 million to candidates for open seats. The latter group includes House members seeking open Senate seats.

DOC.HEAD: `Saturday Night' Cast Member Won't Appear on Show with Andrew Dice Clay
DOC.TEXT: A veteran cast member of ``Saturday Night Live'' said Monday she would refuse to perform on this weekend's show because the program's host is the foul-mouthed comedian Andrew Dice Clay. Nora Dunn, who has been on the show since the 1985-86 season, said in a telephone interview with the Associated Press that she found Clay's comedy act so degrading and repulsive that she refused to help promote his career through ``Saturday Night Live.'' ``In my heart, I know I don't want to work with him,'' Miss Dunn said from New York. She said Clay's comedy act, laced with expletives and frank descriptions sex and submissive women, is ``hateful.'' Clay's management company in Los Angeles didn't immediately return a call seeking comment. Miss Dunn said she didn't know if any other cast members would join her boycott of the NBC comedy show. ``I love `Saturday Night Live' and I feel loyal to my colleagues, my cast members and the writers of the show, and I respect them very much,'' Miss Dunn said. ``But I will not perform with Andrew Dice Clay and I don't want to be associated with him and I oppose his work. ``I don't want to be part of providing an arena for him to make himself legitimate because I don't think he is. Although I feel he has a right to express himself, I have a right to strongly state my position.'' Lorne Michaels, the producer of the 15-year-old ``Saturday Night Live,'' said, ``We're proud of Nora Dunn's statement and her stand on this. But the show will go on.'' Asked if Miss Dunn would be fired for her mutiny, the show's spokeswoman, Rosemary Keenan, said, ``absolutely not.'' Miss Dunn, 37, appeared in the films ``Working Girl'' and ``Miami Blues.'' Her characters on ``Saturday Night Live'' include talk show hostess Pat Stevens; Babette, the international sex-kitten model; Liz Sweeney of the Sweeney Sisters nightclub act, and Linda Dano, a talk show host. Just because Clay is popular doesn't mean his comedy is palatable, said Miss Dunn, adding: ``If I was booking the show in the '30s I wouldn't book Adolf Hitler simply because he's chancellor and has a big following.''

DOC.HEAD: Latvia Promises Gorbachev it Will Respect Soviet Interests
DOC.TEXT: Latvia promised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday that the Baltic republic will respect Soviet interests despite its declaration of independence, and expressed the hope that talks would open soon. Hours before, Gorbachev had asked for complete information about Latvia's independence declaration last Friday. Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov immediately assigned several members of Parliament to prepare a reply. Also Monday, Latvia's Parliament also elected a new prime minister, Ivars Godmanis, a physics professor and leader of the Popular Front. Chairman Dainis Ivans of the Latvian Popular Front, which has led the push for independence, called Gorbachev's request ``wonderful.'' He told reporters, ``This gives us a chance to present our point of view.'' The letter from Parliament explained certain points in the declaration, then concluded, ``We express the certainty that the character of the declaration, the retention of current constitutional norms and sincere desire to respect the interests of the U.S.S.R. will meet with your understanding and open the way to a fruitful dialogue in the spirit of honest cooperation between equals.'' On Monday, Gorbachev condemned ``separatists'' in a speech to a group of veterans. But the Tass report did not say he mentioned Latvia directly. ``There are forces that would like to use the atmosphere of democracy, glasnost and freedom to implement their futile ambitious plans, including separatist plans,'' he said, adding that their policy was ``irresponsible.'' Latvia plans to send a delegation to Moscow this week, Ivans said, and he thinks the delegation will be received. A similar effort by Lithuania, which declared independence March 11, proved fruitless. The Soviet president imposed an oil and natural gas embargo on Lithuania, idling 12,500 workers. He refuses to negotiate with Lithuania until the republic of 3.8 million people rescinds several laws passed after independence was declared. Lithuania also must return to the Soviet Union's constitutional framework, Gorbachev says. The three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were forcibly absorbed into the Soviet Union in 1940. Soon after Gorbachev began his reforms, all three initiated independence drives. He offered them more say in economic and political decisions, but said secession would have to be by Soviet law. Of Latvia's 2.6 million residents, just over half are ethnic Latvians and a third are ethnic Russians. Many of the non-Latvians, especially Russians, oppose secession. Latvia, unlike Lithuania, did not suspend its Soviet constitution upon declaring independence. It just added sections calling for independence and democracy. Estonia last month declared it intends to restore its independence, and called the Soviet Union an occupying power. But it set no date for the split and left the door open for negotiations. Gorbachev threatened Estonia, but took no action against it. Lithuanian lawmaker Nikolai Medvedev, visiting Riga, said it appeared that, although the three Baltic republics have taken different approaches to their independence drives, ``The answer is the same.'' Gorbunov and other Latvian leaders have emphasized that Latvia's declaration, with its unspecified transition period to full independence, is calculated to ``leave the door open'' to talks with the Kremlin. On Saturday night, Latvian Communist Party chief Alfreds Rubiks said he had spoken with Gorbachev, that Gorbachev ruled out talks and was considering sanctions instead. But Latvian politicians and Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said Monday that Rubiks' account did not constitute an official reaction. Godmanis, the new prime minister, told Parliament his economic plan included denationalization of some industries, rationing of some basic foodstuffs and free market prices on most other products. He said the government would work to strengthen economic cooperation among the three Baltic republics and foster direct ties between Latvia and various Soviet regions. Thousands of Soviet soldiers continued to rehearse for the May 9 parade in Riga celebrating victory in Europe in World War II. But Ivans said Latvians were refusing to consider it intimidation, such as the repeated tank movements used in Lithuania to unnerve independence activists there. ``It might mean a demonstration of force,'' Ivans admitted. ``But we are trying to approach it very tolerantly.'' About 50 Soviet soldiers approached the Latvian Parliament building when Monday's session opened. They unfurled a red banner reading, ``Comrades. Have No Doubt We Will Defend the Interests of the U.S.S.R. with Honor.'' Thousands of Soviet troops are stationed in Latvia. Latvians, incensed by the slogan's ominous tone, shouted, ``Shame!'' in Russian at the soldiers. The argument remained peaceful.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Jury Gets Racial Murder Trial of Two Whites
DOC.TEXT: Jurors were urged Monday to return a murder verdict against a white man accused of shooting a black teen-ager who ventured into a mostly-white neighborhood and encountered an angry mob. The attack blamed on defendant Joseph Fama stirred racial tension in the Brooklyn neighborhood where the slaying occurred and throughout the city. The victim, Yusuf Hawkins, 16, went to the Bensonhurst neighborhood Aug. 23 with two friends looking for a used car and was beset by a group of bat-wielding white youths. Hawkins was shot through the chest. ``When the mob turned that corner what did they know about Yusuf Hawkins?'' asked the prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Edward Boyar. ``They knew the color of his skin. That was the only thing they knew about Yusuf Hawkins.'' Pointing across the courtroom at the 19-year-old defendant during his closing argument, the prosecutor said, ``The evidence clearly and beyond a reasonable doubt proves Joseph Fama was the one who took a gun ... and pointed it at the body of Yusuf Hawkins and with a wanton disregard for human life shot again and again and again.'' Defense lawyer David DePetris, in his closing presentation, attacked the credibility of prosecution witnesses, including two jailhouse informants who testified Fama told them he killed Hawkins. The state court jury began deliberating after receiving instructions from Justice Thaddeus Owens. Fama was charged with two counts of second-degree murder. He also was charged with riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, harrassment, discrimination and weapons possession. Summations in the case against Fama's co-defendant, Keith Mondello, also charged with two counts of second-degree murder, were scheduled for Tuesday. The two were tried in the same courtroom, but with different juries. Six other youths are to be tried later. The judge rejected a last-minute effort to reopen the defense case by DePetris, who said a key prosecution witness, Franklin Tighe, was prepared to recant his earlier testimony. Tighe, a 20-year-old Bensonhurst resident with a long history of mental illness including hallucinations, was the only witness to say he saw Fama pull an automatic pistol and shoot Hawkins. Since taking the witness stand on April 27, DePetris said, Tighe contacted him and said he wasn't standing next to Fama when Hawkins was shot, as he had testified. ``It's too late now,'' the judge said in refusing to allow Tighe, who was waiting outside the courtroom, to take the stand. ``The whole thing sounds suspicious to me.'' The exchange took place outside the presence of the jury. After Owens refused to reopen the trial, DePetris showed reporters a 26-minute videotaped interview of Tighe in which the witness says he wasn't standing next to Fama. DePetris told the jury Tighe believed what he was saying when he testified. But he said that the stress of coming upon Hawkins who was dying on the street triggered hallucinations in the mentally unstable man. In his summation, Boyar was highly critical of the many residents of the mostly white neighborhood who saw much or all of the attack but refused to come forward. He spoke of the door stoops ``where the brother and sisterhood of Bensonhurst sat, watching but not seeing, hearing but not listening'' as Hawkins was surrounded by a white mob and shot through the chest.

DOC.HEAD: White House ``Open Debate'' on Budget May Include Talk of New Taxes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 4 grafs for 10th graf pvs, House and, with end of meeting among congressional Democrats
DOC.TEXT: The White House put aside President Bush's pledge against new taxes and said Monday that talks to strike a budget deal with Congress will have ``no preconditions.'' Although Bush's position on taxes ``is well known,'' he wants ``an open debate that is unfettered with conclusions about positions taken in the past,'' said his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. Republicans involved in talks on Capitol Hill praised the White House's acknowledgement that all ways of reducing the deficit would be negotiable. ``That's the only way he can do the job,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. ``There isn't any president who hasn't tried to make good on his promises. There's no president who hasn't lived through times that change, and maybe outdate some promises,'' he said. But Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, predicted it would be tough to pass a budget that includes tax increases. ``It would be hard to get anybody to agree to that, not just Republicans,'' Domenici said. ``The question is overall, how strong is the package in deficit reduction ... so tradeoffs are worth it.'' Fitzwater said Bush intends to follow up his Sunday night session with the four top congressional leaders with further meetings with lawmakers this week to discuss how to ``break the logjam'' that has persisted nearly a decade. He will talk strategy on Tuesday with House and Senate Republican leaders and hopes to hold another bipartisan session later in the week, Fitzwater said. Sixteen leading House and Senate Democrats met for an hour in the Capitol and said afterward that they would consult with rank-and-file lawmakers Tuesday. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said the leaders discussed who would be involved in talks with the administration and when the discussions would start. Asked if the members at the meeting agreed that negotiations should begin, Mitchell said, ``Various opinions were expressed.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he believed congressional Democrats would inform the White House about their desires by Wednesday. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said he was willing to consider new levies, including excise taxes and raising the income tax rate for top-income taxpayers, particularly if Bush continues to seek a cut in the capital gains tax. ``If he's talking about reducing capital gains then I think obviously one of the places you look at is'' the tax rate, Bentsen said in an interview. He said Democrats would not require Bush to endorse publicly a specific tax increase as a precondition to agreement. ``I think that it's a question of walking that plank together,'' he said. Many Democrats have advocated raising the maximum income tax rate to 33 percent for the 600,000 wealthiest Americans, who now pay a 28 percent rate. Some members of both parties have also talked about boosting levies on gasoline, imported oil, cigarettes, beer and alcohol. The administration negotiated with members of Congress last year on a compromise budget, but the White House is pursuing a bipartisan budget pact even more intensely this year. Fearing that rising interest rates would seriously damage the economy, the administration initiated the budget talks following the recent approval of rival $1.2 trillion budget propsals by the full House of Represenatives and the Senate Budget Committee. Bush shares with congressional leaders ``anxiety over a deficit that is fighting every reduction attempt that we can come up,'' Fitzwater said. Bush's own fiscal 1991 budget was never seriously considered by Congress, and the administration claims both House and Senate measures would fall short of reducing the deficit _ over $150 billion this year _ to the $64 billion required under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law. Failure to make this target will touch off automatic, across-the-board spending cuts. Congressional leaders have said that getting the deficit down to the required range to avoid the automatic trigger would almost certainly require substantial tax increases. Fitzwater's comments Monday generally reflected what participants in Sunday night's White House meeting had reported: that Bush had assured them everything was on the table. At his daily briefing for reporters, Fitzwater repeatedly declined to say whether Bush's 1988 campaign vow of ``no new taxes'' was still in force. Bush has not repeated his promise in months. ``The president and the leadership tried to come to this with an open mind,'' Fitzwater said. He said one of the ``operating principles'' Bush and the leaders _ Mitchell, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and House Republican Leader Robert H. Michel of Illinois _ agreed to was ``that there are no preconditions.'' ``Anyone can bring up an issue for discussion and debate,'' Fitzwater said. Bush and the lawmakers also agreed ``that they can't negotiate a budget in public, that it does take a lot of give-and-take and moving back and forth. So we'll try to keep a little mystery in the marriage.'' The spokesman said the leaders also agreed that talks would ``go until we achieve a budget that all sides can agree on.'' Fitzwater said such details as who would participate in the budget talks, where they would be held and how active a role the president would take, had not been decided.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Communist Party Suffers More Declines in Local Elections
By VICTOR L. SIMPSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Italian Communist Party failed to stem its decline in local elections Sunday and Monday in 15 of the country's 20 regions, partial results indicated. The long-dominant Christian Democrats suffered small losses and the Socialists, Italy's No. 3 party, scored gains, according to early results and to projections on state TV's evening newscasts more than eight hours after polls closed. Local parties demanding greater regional autonomy in Lombardy and Veneto in the north showed surprising success. Up for election were 15 of 20 regional governments, 87 provincial governing councils and 6,374 city governments. City elections were not being held in such major centers as Rome, Naples, Trieste, Catania and Bolzano. By 10 p.m., results were complete in two-thirds of the precincts. Complete official results were expected Tuesday. The elections were considered an important barometer of support for the governing coalition, which includes Christian Democrats and Socialists, and for the Communists, who decided on a new course at an extraordinary congress in March. With 49,267 of 73,965 precincts reporting, the Communists had 24 percent, down from 30.2 percent in regional elections five years ago and from 27.8 percent in parliamentary voting in 1987. Christian Democrats had 33.8 percent, down from 35 percent five years ago and from 34.2 percent in the 1987 parliamentary vote. The Socialists had 14.7 percent, up from 13.3 percent and 14.3 percent, respectively. The Communist Party has been steadily losing strength after coming to the brink of power a decade ago. It decided to enter a transition phase that could lead to changing its name and dropping its hammer-and-sickle symbol. But the move angered many old-line Communists, and party leader Achille Occhetto said he would be content with 23 percent of the vote. Occhetto said on state TV that the party's poor showing would not alter the Communist reformist course. ``To do otherwise would be catastrophic,'' he said. He indicated the decline reflected the beatings taken by Eastern European leftist parties in recent elections following the toppling over the past year of Communists regimes there. Final projections indicated the Communists would get 23.6 percent, down from 30.2 percent five years ago and 27.8 percent in 1987; the Christian Democrats 33.1 percent, down from 35 percent five years ago and 34.2 percent in 1987, and the Socialists, 15.4 percent, up from 13.3 percent and 14.3 percent, respectively. Premier Giulio Andreotti, a Christian Democrat, had said that major shifts in the voting could cause his government to collapse. The coalition includes three small parties: Republicans, Social Democrats and Liberals. Christian Democratic Party Secretary Arnaldo Forlani said the results ``encourage the commitment of the (coalition) government to go forward.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 23 in Guatemala Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf to CORRECT co-pilot's name, hometown, according to Aerial Transport officials
DOC.TEXT: Four more people died of injuries from the weekend crash of a U.S.-manned cargo plane in a crowded residential area, raising the death toll to 23, Guatemalan aviation authorities said Monday. A Civil Aeronatics Administration news release said the four died late Sunday and early Monday in hospitals, and that five people were still missing. It said 12 people are hospitalized, some in serious condition. Two of the dead have still not been identified, the news release said. The Miami-bound DC-6, a vintage four-engine propeller cargo plane, crashed shortly after takeoff from the capital's international airport Saturday night, killing all three crew members. The rest of the victims were on the ground. The cause of the crash has not been determined. But Civil Aeronautics said when the plane arrived Saturday in Guatemala, it underwent repairs for an engine problem. U.S. Embassy spokesman James Dickmayer said three U.S. civil aeronautics experts are directing the investigation of the crash. Fire chief Harold Juarez said rescue squads had been picking through the wreckage of 16 homes in the plane's path. The plane, belonging to Miami-based Aerial Transit Co., was carrying a cargo of snow peas and cloth. Tom Stocks, vice president of Aerial Transit, said by telephone that there were no problems with the plane when it left Miami. But when the crew tried to take off for the return flight, he said, ``They apparently had some problem with one engine, and as they were making the go-around, apparently it crashed.'' The crash set off a fireball fueled by propane tanks in neighborhood homes. ``It was a big ball of fire that burst when the right wing of the plane destroyed the house next door and exploded,'' said Lorenzo Hoehn, a resident who saw the crash. ``I saw how children came out like torches and my neighbors were burned to death without us being able to do anything to save them,'' he added. ``It was something horrible, like a nightmare. We thought it was the end of the world.'' The crew members were identified by Aerial Transport as Capt. Joseph Babody of Detroit; co-pilot John Theodorou of Vero Beach, Fla.; and engineer Dallas White of Miami Springs, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Picks Hoosier for Agriculture Job
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday announced his selection of an Indiana farmer, James R. Moseley, to be assistant secretary of agricutlure for natural resources and the environment. If confirmed by the Senate, Moseley, 41, of Peru, Ind., would succeed George S. Dunlop. Moseley is owner and manager of Jim Moseley Farms, Inc., in Clarks Hill, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviets Meet to Plan Summit
DOC.TEXT: A 12-member Soviet advance team met Monday with U.S. officials to discuss logistics for the May 30-June 3 superpower summit, the White House said. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the meeting was ``the first formal full session of the U.S. and Soviet advance teams.'' Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin and Joseph Reed, the U.S. chief of protocol, met last week to discuss summit plans. Soviet officials have toured the White House and Andrews Air Force Base in nearby suburban Maryland, where Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev will arrive and depart, Fitzwater said. Business sessions will be conducted at the White House, Fitzwater said. The White House, he said, was not ready to announce whether President Bush would take Gorbachev to an out-of-town site, such as Camp David, Md., for informal talks during the five-day session.

DOC.HEAD: Court Holds Salvadoran Death Squad Threat Grounds For Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A Salvadoran death squad's threatening letter to an accountant for a land-reform group gave him legitimate grounds to seek political asylum in the United States, a federal appeals court ruled Monday. The death squad was ``arguably tied to (El Salvador's) government,'' the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said. The 3-0 ruling barred the planned deportation of Wilfredo Mendoza Perez and ordered reconsideration of his request for political asylum. Though the government did not control the death squad, testimony about the killings of others who worked for Mendoza's organization suggested that people in such groups were in danger, the court ruled. The threat to Mendoza was specific and real, and persecution was more likely than not if he returned to El Salvador, the court said. ``Given Mendoza's involvement with a land reform organization and the apparent right-wing death squad, Mendoza's testimony that his feared persecution is politically motivated finds support in the record,'' said the opinion by Judge Jerome Farris. Mendoza testified that he was an accountant with the Salvadoran Communal Union for almost five years before he left the country and entered the United States illegally in 1982. He said he had been helping landless farmers form and manage cooperatives throughout the country. The court decision reversed a Board of Immigration Appeals ruling that denied Mendoza's request to stop his deportation. Since asylum is at the discretion of the Attorney General, that portion of the case was sent back to the Justice Department for a decision. Mendoza lives in Phoenix with his wife and children. The Immigration and Naturalization Service began deportation proceedings after arresting Mendoza about 10 months after he arrived in the U.S. An INS judge denied Mendoza's request to stop his deportation and receive political asylum. The Board of Immigration Appeals affirmed that decision in October 1988. Mendoza said that shortly before he left El Salvador, he received a letter threatening him if he did not leave the country within 48 hours. He said officials of the Salvadoran Communal Union told him to take the threat seriously. His attorney, Carolyn P. Blum, called the appeals court's decision and Mendoza's prospects for asylum ``exciting and wonderful for him.'' She said the INS board's decision had been outrageous. She said the decision would send a message that the ``people who actively participate and work with groups in countries like El Salvador and Guatemala can receive asylum in the United States.'' Philip Waters, acting regional director for the INS in San Francisco, declined comment on the case until he and officials in Washington studied the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Father Surrenders In Shooting Death 3-Month-Old Son
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of shooting his 3-month-old son to death as the boy was cradled in his mother's arms surrendered to police Monday. Donnie Wise Brown, 31, was taken into custody without incident after he arrived at police headquarters with two friends. In addition to first-degree murder, Brown was charged with attempted murder and a handgun violation. Police said a .22-caliber bullet that killed Damon Brown may have been intended for the child's mother, Hope Burrell, 24, who was holding the child when a domestic dispute erupted on Sunday. At some point during the argument, the father pulled out a handgun and fired, said Detective Dan Shea.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Jeer as Parliament Opens First Session
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Israelis demanding electoral reform on Monday booed legislators as they drove past the crowd to reach Parliament for the opening of the summer session. Dozens of police officers held back about 4,000 protesters as they jeered and waved placards reading ``We are sick of you'' and ``No less than democracy.'' The rally was the latest protest by a growing electoral reform movement. The protests were sparked by the political horsetrading following the March 15 collapse of the ruling coalition of the left-leaning Labor Party and the right-wing Likud bloc. The two rival parties have been trying the past six weeks to lure defectors from each other's camps with offers of political posts and money. There were growing signs Monday that another Likud-Labor coalition could be in the offing. Israel television reported both parties were considering a compromise proposal by the National Religious Party that would avoid a clear yes-or-no answer to U.S. Mideast peace proposals. The coalition government was toppled by Labor after Likud refused to accept proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that would lead to an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo. At the protest rally in front of Parliament, meanwhile, the crowd chanted ``We are fed up'' as legislators drove past. ``The general feeling is that there is nobody who is actually representing you,'' said Mike Marmer, a rabbinical student who immigrated from London four years ago. Another demonstrator, veteran Soviet Jewish activist Vladimir Slepak, said he never expected he would one day protest against the Israeli government. ``In the Soviet Union we knew there was one party and we knew what they would do. But here nobody knows what will be tomorrow,'' said Slepak, who arrived in Israel after waging a long fight against Soviet authorities for permission to emigrate. Rally organizers accused politicians of abusing democracy and demanded that President Chaim Herzog appoint an independent commission to work out a new electoral system. The campaign, led by dozens of Israeli mayors and army reserve officers, has collected more than a half-million signatures. Under Israel's current system, voters choose party slates and the country is treated as one electoral district. A party needs only one percent of the vote to win a seat in the 120-member Parliament. No party has ever won enough votes to rule alone and smaller factions are often cast in the role of kingmaker. Israelis are used to protracted coalition negotiations after each election, but this time neither Labor nor Likud appears able to break a 60-60 tie. Labor leader Shimon Peres failed after five weeks of negotiations and now caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is trying to form a ruling coalition without Labor. But Shamir's plans have been thwarted by two religious parties, the National Religious Party and Shas, that support Shamir in principle but insist that he form another government with Labor. Under the National Religious Party's compromise, a new Likud-Labor coalition would be based on the guidelines of the outgoing government, including Shamir's proposal to hold elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to determine negotiators for peace talks with Israel. But decisions concerning the peace process would be made by the full 25-member Cabinet, which also includes ministers from smaller coalition partners. In the outgoing government, such decisions were made by the 12-member Inner Cabinet in which only Labor and Likud were represented. The forum was usually deadlocked along party lines.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Elects Prosecutors in Government Corruption Trials
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Monday elected nine legislators to act as prosecutors in the trials of the former prime minister and his deputies, who are accused of wiretapping, fraud and complicity in a $210 million bank scandal. Former Premier Andreas Papandreou was indicted by Parliament in September on involvement in a Bank of Crete scandal and for authorizing the wiretapping of political friends and foes. Four former cabinet members in his socialist government have been charged along with Papandreou in the $210 million bank scandal. Former intelligence service chief Costas Tsimas, now a deputy in the European Parliament, was indicted for involvement in the wiretapping scandal. The men face possible prison sentences of five years to life if convicted. Trial dates have not been set. In another scandal, former deputy finance minister Nikos Athanassopoulos was scheduled to face trial May 28 on charges of covering up a 9,000-ton corn sale in 1986 that defrauded the European Community of trade levies. Two deputies from the ruling conservative New Democracy Party were elected as prosecutors in each of the three cases along with one member from the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress. Two New Democracy deputies and one Coalition deputy were also elected as substitute prosecutors in each case. Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement, which controls 125 seats in the 300-member Parliament, boycotted the vote. The socialists have denied all charges and claim the trials are politically motivated. The socialists ruled Greece for eight years and were replaced in June by an alliance between the conservatives and Communists.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Winds Lash Northwest; Flooding Continues in Arkansas, Texas
DOC.TEXT: Strong, cold winds continued to batter the Pacific Northwest on Monday, carrying heavy snow that lashed the Washington Cascades. Flooding continued in Arkansas and Texas. Weather was mild and sunny over much of the nation, with unusually high temperatures in parts of the upper Plains. Gale warnings were posted over the Washington straits and along portions of California's northern coast as powerful winds continued to pound the region. The gusts pushed colder temperatures into the Northwest during the weekend and brought an early morning temperature of 26 degrees to Colville, Wash. Overnight snowfall across the Cascades included 12 inches at Stampede Pass. There also was snow on the highway through Snoqualmie Pass. Overnight temperatures were expected to drop into the mid 20s in the Helena Valley of Montana by midweek. The Arkansas River approached record heights as flooding continued in Arkansas and Texas. The river was expected to crest at Little Rock on Tuesday and Pine Bluff on Wednesday at levels higher than in the devastating flood of April 1973. On Saturday, the river crested at Van Buren, Ark., at the highest stage since its navigation system was constructed. Extensive flooding also continued along the White and Cache rivers in eastern Arkansas. There was lowland flooding along the Black and St. Francis rivers in northeast Arkansas, as well as along the Quachita River in southern Arkansas. In northern Texas, the Trinity River was expected to crest near Trinidad about two feet lower than the record level recorded in April 1942, but about 15 feet over flood stage near Long Lake. Skies were sunny over much of the nation at noon Monday. Rainshowers were scattered over central New England, from northeast Pennsylvania into central New York state, over eastern Upper Michigan, the lower Texas Gulf Coast and southwest Wyoming. Rainshowers over south central Montana and north central Wyoming changed to snow at the higher elevations. Snow mixed with rain also fell over northwest Montana. On Sunday, unseasonably warm weather moved into the eastern portion of the northern Plains and the Mississippi Valley. Noon temperatures Monday were 15 to 20 degrees warmer than average across eastern South Dakota and southern Minnesota. Redwood Falls, Minn., hit 90 degrees by early afternoon. The low temperature for the nation Monday morning was 22 degrees at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 pm EDT ranged from 33 degrees at Yellowstone, Wyo., to 97 degrees at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Case Against Military Men in Killing of Priests Said to be Weak
DOC.TEXT: A weak prosecution case and missing evidence make it unlikely those blamed for the November slaying of six Jesuit priests and two women will be convicted, a court source said Monday. The United States has warned El Salvador it could face a cutoff of $85 million in annual military aid if it fails to actively pursue its investigation of the deaths of the priests. The House Foreign Relations Committee has approved a proposal to that effect. The source at El Salvador's 4th Criminal Court, who insisted on anonymity, told The Associated Press he believed Col. Guillermo Benavides, commander of the Military School at the time, three lieutenants and five soldiers charged with the crime stood a good chance of being acquitted. The source said the only evidence introduced against Benavides is testimony from other suspects. Under Salvadoran law, a person accused in the same case cannot testify against a co-defendant. ``The evidence makes it difficult'' to convict Benavides, the principal suspect, the source said. The difficulties are compounded because the four cadets who could testify in the case were sent out of the country, the source said. Also, a logbook and a personal diary that could document Benavides' movements have been reported by authorities to be lost. The disclosures regarding the cadets and the diary were made in Monday's editions of The New York Times. ``All these problems raised obstacles to the court's effort to find out if any other high-ranking military men are involved or are trying to cover up for the murderers,'' the source said. Gen. Humberto Larios, the Defense Minister, said sending the cadets abroad was ``part of a project'' but ``if the judge considers the presence of the cadets convenient, they could be recalled.'' A personal diary that Benavides was reported to have kept has also not been found, the source said. The source said Benavides mentioned the diary out of court, but later denied it existed. ``No one has seen the diary. The court never had possession of it, as far as I know,'' the source added. The court also asked the high command for the academy guard logbook, which would show who entered and left the academy Nov. 15-16. But the military claimed it was lost, the source said. The six priests, their housekeeper and her daughter were rousted from their beds by uniformed soldiers at the Central American University campus the night of Nov. 16 and shot to death. The slayings occurred during the worst offensive by leftist guerrillas in a decade of civil war. The campus, branded a bastion of leftist thought by conservatives, was under military control and a dawn-to-dusk curfew at the time of the killings. The four cadets on guard duty at the Military School the night of the murders were sent to the United States and Panama, the court source said, and when the judge asked them to testify, he was told they were out of the country. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, a retired officer, publicly accused the military high command of protecting those who ordered the killings. Ochoa, now a National Assembly member from the conservative ruling ARENA party, said Benavides carried out the slayings on orders from above. But he did not offer proof. Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is handling the case, refused to talk to reporters. But the source said he recently had a long interview with officials of the U.S. Embassy. About 72,000 people have been killed in El Salvador's civil war, mostly civilians slain by rightist death squads.

DOC.HEAD: Photographer Lotte Jacobi Dead at 93
DOC.TEXT: Lotte Jacobi, a photographer known for her candid portraits of such renowed figures as Albert Einstein and Eleanor Roosevelt, has died at age 93. Jacobi died Sunday at the Havenwood Retirement Community. The cause of death wasn't disclosed. During her career, which spanned seven decades, celebrities sought out Jacobi because of her ability to capture them during private moments or in unusual poses. Some of her most famous photographs were of Einstein, including at least one that was turned down by Life magazine because its editors thought the shot _ of Einstein lounging in a leather jacket _ did not treat him with enough respect. Other portraits included Mrs. Roosevelt, poet Robert Frost, actors Peter Lorre and Lotte Lenya and composer Kurt Weill. Jacobi said she relied on her intuition, for knowing whom to photograph and how to photograph them. ``Most people have a preconceived idea about other people, about what the other one has to be,'' she said in an interview in 1978. ``I don't care for a person's station in life, I care for the person.'' Jacobi was born in Thorn, West Prussia, Germany, in 1896 and studied at the Bavarian State Academy of Photography and the University of Munich. She moved to Berlin in 1920, where she later ran her father's photography studio. In 1935, she fled Nazi Germany and moved to New York, where she opened her own studio. Later in her career, Jacobi invented a type of photography known as photogenics, a technique that did not require use of a camera. Jacobi would draw patterns of light on film, using reflected light from candles and flashlights. She then would photograph the resulting lines and images of light. Jacobi moved to New Hampshire in 1955 and opened a studio in Deering. She became active in state and national Democratic politics and was visited by many presidential candidates as they trekked to New Hampshire for its earliest-in-the-nation primary. Jacobi had lived at the Havenwood Retirement Community since 1985. She is survived by a sister, Ruth Jacobi-Roth of California and two daughters-in-law, Bernadette Hunter, of Paris, France, and Beatrice Trum-Hunter of Deering.

DOC.HEAD: Key Post in Monarchy Abolished, Christians Demand Religious Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Nepal on Monday abolished a key post that preserved the monarchy's monopoly on power, and a leader of the opposition-led government reported Nepal's king has pledged cooperation in working toward democracy. Nepalese Christians also demanded an end to a 32-year-old law banning religious conversion and called for the establishment of a secular state in this Hindu kingdom. In an evening radio broadcast, Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai announced the post of zonal commissioner had been abolished. There are 14 such commissioners in Nepal, each responsible for administering a separate region and appointed by the king. The Nepali Congress Party, which heads the coalition government, alleges these commisioners were responsible for suppressing activists during the recent democracy movement. The opposition claims hundreds of people were killed during the two-month campaign for multiparty democracy that forced King Birendra to surrender his stranglehold on political power. Police arrested hundreds of protesters. Nepali Congress Party Secretary General Girija Prasad Koirala urged Monday that legal action be taken against at least seven zonal commissioners who he said were responsible for ordering crackdowns on pro-democracy activists. Bhattarai, a longtime opposition leader, last month was appointed head of an interim coalition government made up of opposition parties, including Nepali Congress and leftist parties. The coalition pressed the king to agree to a multiparty system and scrap a 29-year-old ban on political parties. Multiparty elections are expected within a year. Koirala met the king Sunday and said Monday that Birendra gave assurances of his cooperation in drafting a new constitution. The king also promised Bhattarai would have sufficient powers to accomplish his task of establishing a democracy, Koirala said. The call for greater religious freedom came as 1,500 Protestants kicked off a five-day religious convention organized by the Katmandu-based Nepal Christian Fellowship. The convention called for a revision of the 1958 constitution that bans religious conversion and urged the government to nullify a 1965 law prohibiting proselytism. Under that law, proselytizers can be sentenced to up to six years in jail. Convention participants demanded that 29 Christians serving various jail sentences be immediately released, and cases against 200 other Christians dropped. Nepali Congress Party elder Ganesh Man Singh assured the Christians that his party, which heads the new government, would release the imprisoned Christians and drop charges against the others. Nepalese Christians say there are 35,000 to 40,000 Christians in Nepal. The government says there are only 3,000. Most of the Christians are Protestants not affiliated with international denominations. About 90 percent of Nepal's 17 million people are Hindus, the rest mostly Moslem and Buddhist.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Residents Evacuated as Floods Roll In Three States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf to CORRECT that Pine Bluff is downstream from Little Rock sted upstream.
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 homes were evacuated by Monday because of a slowly rising river in central Arkansas, and a Texas river on a record rampage claimed scores of homes as it bulged out to 2 miles wide. A reservoir on the Texas-Oklahoma line hit a record of more than 27 feet above normal after flooding more than 80 homes and began falling Monday _ but only at a rate of about 6 inches a day. Thirteen deaths have been blamed on the weather during the past two weeks, one in Oklahoma and the rest in Texas. Texans living in rural areas south of Dallas were fleeing flooded homes as the Trinity River _ swollen from the worst northern Texas flooding in more than 80 years _ rolled slowly southward through homes, fields and pastures toward the Gulf of Mexico. Near Palestine, about 90 miles southeast of Dallas, Red Cross officials said about 50 homes had been destroyed or sustained major damage Sunday in the lakeside community of Long Lake. ``We can't tell exactly how many residences are affected yet, because we can't count underwater,'' said Bill Walters, manager of a Red Cross shelter set up in a campground about 100 feet from the river. He said the victims ``saved practically nothing. The water came up too quickly.'' Walters said that although the Trinity had widened to about two miles at Long Lake, many residents were reluctant to leave. ``These people are pretty stubborn, as all Texans are. They think they can stick it out, but they really can't do it,'' he said. In spite of the amount of water at Long Lake, Anderson County sheriff's dispatcher Troy Freeman said he'd been told the river wouldn't crest there until Friday. And 90 miles back up river, water still had not fully drained out of a Dallas neighborhood. Monday was the fifth day residents of the Rochester Park neighborhood ere out of their homes. More than 400 people were evacuated late last week before the water rose above rooftops. In Trinidad, about 60 miles southeast of Dallas, at least 150 people had been evacuated and main roads reported closed. In central Arkansas, relief workers stayed busy around the clock shoring up levees, sandbagging and helping residents rescue valued items from homes likely to be inundated by the Arkansas River. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton added two more counties to last week's disaster declaration Monday, bringing the total to 29 counties. An estimated 325 houses were evacuated in six counties, said state Office of Emergency Services spokesman Gary Talley. The river was expected to crest 5 feet above flood stage Tuesday at Little Rock. Downstream in the area of Pine Bluff, water was up to 3{ feet deep in homes in some low-lying areas, officials said. Officials said the flooding along the Arkansas River was the worst since a 1927 rampage that prompted construction of many of the levees along the river. Lake Texoma on the Texas-Oklahoma line crested during the night at a record 644.76 feet above sea level, or nearly 5 feet above the overflow spillways, only the second time since the dam was built that water flowed out the spillways. Mike McCoy of the Army Corps of Engineers said he expects it will take 45 to 60 days for the lake to return to a ``decent'' level as the Corps plans to try to lower it by 6 to 9 inches a day. A preliminary survey Sunday found 83 homes at least partially submerged in Oklahoma's Marshall County, which is partly cut off from the outside by the swollen lake, which has flooded some highways. Highway flooding made life strange for Judy Peterson, who works in Madill, Okla. Instead of simply driving the 18 miles from her home on Sand Point to the office, she and her husband now must first take a boat a half-mile and then drive a circuitous 56-mile route around the northern edge of Lake Texoma and back to Madill. They'd been doing that for a week as of Monday. ``It's really getting old,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: President Doe Calls for Negotiations with Rebels
DOC.TEXT:
Liberian President Samuel Doe called for negotiations with rebel forces Monday on ending their four-month insurgency, the state News Agency of Nigeria reported. Speaking to reporters after a meeting with Nigerian President Gen. Ibrahim Babanbida at Lagos airport, Doe said the rebels should come to Liberia's capital, Monrovia, so ``we can iron out the differences. Power is not gotten in the forest,'' NAN reported. On Thursday Doe sent a delegation to Washington asking for a meeting between Liberian exiles and U.S. officials to discuss ways to end the fighting. But Doe has repeatedly refused to negotiate with rebel leader Charles Taylor. The rebels are believed to be supported by Libya. The State Department said Wednesday that 380 American officials and their dependents had left Liberia as rebel forces move within striking distance of Monrovia. There were about 500 American officials in Liberia before the fighting broke out. Liberian rebels invaded from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Since then the insurgents have won control of most of eastern Nimba county, bordering Ivory Coast, and are fighting in three other counties. Doe said the guerrillas' hit-and-run tactics in mountainous terrain have made them difficult for government forces to combat. ``We are trying to protect lives and property and at the same time contain the rebels. It has not been easy,'' Doe said. The U.S. Congress has passed a resolution condemning Doe's forces for killing civilians while trying to put down the incursion. Taylor's rebels have been accused of killing non-combatants in response to government attacks on their supporters. International relief agencies estimate 250,000 Liberians have been uprooted from their homes since the fighting started. Many have gone to neighboring Guinea or the Ivory Coast.
Earlier Monday, Doe met with Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema and asked him to press Ivory Coast authorities to block Taylor's forces from receiving supplies across the Ivorian frontier. Liberia, a West African country with about 2.4 million residents, was founded a century and a half ago by freed American slaves and generally has had close ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Independence Party Leads in Croatian Elections
DOC.TEXT: A center-right party that advocates Croatia's independence from the rest of Yugoslavia took a commanding lead Monday in early returns from the final round of the republic's first free elections in 50 years. With partial votes from 95 constituencies counted, candidates for the Croatian Democratic Union were leading in 48 constituencies, the Communists were ahead in 34 districts and independents and other smaller parties led in the remaining 13. The vote is considered crucial to the future of the fragile Yugoslav federation. The apparent victory of the Croatian Democratic Union is likely to exacerbate political and ethnic tensions with Yugoslavia's five other constituent republics _ particularly with Serbia, the country's largest republic. About 1.5 million Croatians voted Sunday and Monday in 111 constituencies throughout the republic for the remaining 225 seats in the region's parliament. Final results were not expected until Tuesday at earliest. In the first round of voting April 22-23, the Democratic Union won 104 of the 131 seats decided for the 356-seat tricameral regional parliament. The Croatian Communist Party, renamed the Party for Democratic Reform, gathered only 13 seats in the first round, while the centrist Coalition for National Accord, considered a pre-election favorite, won three. ``Croatians voted for us because we have offered them democracy to replace years of one-party monopoly,'' Democratic Union leader Franjo Tudjman said in a Monday interview. ``Now we have to start fulfilling everything we promised to our voters,'' he said, celebrating his apparent victory with champagne at the party's Zagreb headquarters. Tudjman waged his party's campaign largely on nationalist sentiments, advocating Croatia's political and economic independence from the rest of Yugoslavia. He says Yugoslavia's republics should become independent states and establish relations only if they have common interests. The reform Communists say the national federation model is adequate but if it fails to reflect the republic's needs in the future, Yugoslavia should become a confederation without central rule. Tudjman, 66, became Yugoslavia's youngest army general, but later spent five years in jail after being convicted of Croatian nationalism and hostile activities against the state. His bid for power has fueled a rivalry between Croatia, the second-largest republic, and Serbia that dates to the creation of Yugoslavia after World War II. Serbia's media, strongly influenced by the republic's hard-line Communist leaders, has accused the Democratic Union of fascism. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces torn by ethnic and ideological tensions. Croatia and Slovenia are pushing for democratic reforms and closer ties with the West. The center-right DEMOS coalition won April's free parliamentary elections in Slovenia, and is establishing the first non-Communist regional government in Yugoslavia in more than 40 years. Serbia and Montenegro have not legalized opposition parties. Macedonia and Bosnia plan free elections this year.

DOC.HEAD: State Senator Convicted on Banking Charges
DOC.TEXT: State Sen. Andrew Jenkins was convicted Monday by a federal jury in a scheme to help a supposed Texas financier launder $150,000 in cash through a bank in Zaire. The financier was really an undercover FBI agent, who arrested Jenkins after giving him a briefcase with the money at a Manhattan hotel in August 1987. Jenkins, 48, was charged under a seldom-used law that makes it a crime to accept deposits without authority to engage in banking business in the United States. He also was charged with using the telephone in interstate or foreign commerce with the intent to promote a crime. Each charge carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. U.S. District Judge Charles Metzner set July 26 for sentencing. Jenkins' seat became vacant upon his conviction. Jenkins, a Democrat who represents the borough of Queens, showed no emotion as the verdict was announced and left the Manhattan courtroom without commenting. Prosecutors said Jenkins took the money to conduct business with the Afro-American Development Bank in Zaire. Prosecutors said he was part owner of the bank. The defense said Jenkins never owned a bank in Zaire but took the money as an investment to create one. Defense attorney Samuel Abady said the charge against Jenkins was a ``made-up crime.'' But Assistant U.S. Attorney Steven Standiford said the statute had been used before, most recently about two years ago in another money-laundering case, which also ended in a conviction. Another judge had, in 1988, dismissed an additional charge that Jenkins had violated a law requiring disclosures to U.S. Customs of overseas bank transactions of more than $10,000. The count was dropped on grounds that Jenkins had not taken the money out of the country. The case began in May 1987 when a man named Louie Moore pleaded guilty to selling stolen and counterfeit checks and agreed to give the FBI information about 12 people, including Jenkins, Standiford said. He said Moore introduced Jenkins to the undercover agent posing as Dan Garth, a Texan with cash to be ``cleaned up.'' Taped conversations revealed that Jenkins devised a plan to put Garth's money in the bank in Zaire, then use it to finance a lumber project there, with profits going to Garth, the prosecutor said. Abady described Jenkins as a diligent legislator who had worked to promote African trade. He dismissed Moore as a ``thief and con man who cut a deal.''

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Lawmaker Shot to Death in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: A Tamil lawmaker was ambushed and shot to death Monday outside the Canadian diplomatic mission where he had gone for a visa, police said. Four attackers fired at Sam Thambimuthu's car, which had stopped outside the Canadian High Commission, according to police. Thambimuthu, a lawmaker of the Tamil United Liberation Front, had an appointment at the High Commission and he was to travel to the United States on a State Department-sponsored program later this week, police said. Thambimuthu, 57, was shot in his head and chest and died before he could be given aid, police said. Thambimuthu's wife Kala, 48, who was also in the vehicle, was critically injured. Their driver was unhurt. Police declined to comment on the killers, who fled on two motorcycles after the afternoon attack. The newspaper Sunday reported that the government had alerted all United Liberation Front lawmakers and other Tamil political parties that a 15-member hit squad was in Colombo. The newspaper did not identify the group. The front, considered a moderate Tamil political party, joined three pro-Indian former Tamil rebel groups to take part in the February 1989 general elections. Ten lawmakers of the joint front, including Thambimuthu, were elected to the 225-seat Sri Lankan Parliament. Thambimuthu has been strongly critical of the most dominant Tamil rebel group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. His wife was abducted by the Tiger rebels in December last year, but was later released. A Tiger rebel in northern Jaffna town said his group was unaware of the killing and declined to comment. Last July, unidentified assailants shot and killed the United Liberation Front's secretary-general, Appapillai Amirthalingham, and another senior member in Colombo.

DOC.HEAD: FBI: Alleged Drug Cartel Associates Stung in Stinger Missile Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf to UPDATE with both arrested men being ordered held without bond.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Two Colombians who claim links to the Medellin drug cartel were in custody Monday, accused of trying to buy Stinger missiles to use against aircraft carrying Colombian officials, the FBI said. The two men agreed to hand over $1 million in cocaine profits as a down payment for 120 Stingers and 50 automatic rifles, plus a plane to transport the weapons to Colombia, FBI Agent Charles A. Salemme testified at a court hearing. The suspects, claiming to work for reputed cartel kingpin Pablo Escobar, said bribed officials would help them smuggle the weapons for attacks on the anti-drug Colombian government. The suspects told undercover agents they would pay $5 million _ from the planned sale of 400 to 600 kilos of cocaine _ for the plane and the weapons, and $1 million to the people who would steal the weapons, Salemme told a federal magistrate. FBI officials said a Stinger sells for about $14,000 on the legitimate arms market. The shoulder-fired missile uses an infrared homing device to aim itself at the heat generated by an aircraft's engine. It has proven highly effective against low-flying aircraft. The 4-foot-long, 35-pound missiles were to be used against official Colombian government aircraft, according to Allen McCreight, FBI chief in Tampa. But he said investigators weren't aware of specific plans by drug traffickers to assassinate Colombian President Virgilio Barco Vargas, who has waged war on drug smugglers, or his cabinet. ``Our investigation is continuing, but at this point we have not established that the purpose of the purchase of the missiles was to be used against any officials and specifically the president of Colombia,'' McCreight said. Violence linked to Colombia's drug lords has claimed the lives of three presidential candidates in that South American country in the past year. The case is the most recent of several reported attempts by drug traffickers to obtain Stingers, but federal officials say none of the earlier negotiations had gone as far as the plot involving the two men arrested Saturday. An undercover drug investigation in Polk County in west-central Florida eventually led to the federal ``sting'' in the weapons deal. ``I think this shows a correlation between narcotics and terrorism,'' said Polk Sheriff Lawrence Crow. ``This time, instead of Stingers, the cartel was stung,'' said Bonnie Tischler, head of the U.S. Customs Service in Tampa. Authorities arrested Alfredo Antonio Ramos-Tinoco, 47, at a Tampa hotel bar, and Luis Fernando Arcila-Giraldo, 28, near Miami International Airport. Both were charged with conspiracy to receive stolen property and export arms illegally, as well as aiding and abetting the importation and possession with intent to distribute marijuana and cocaine. Both have been ordered held without bond. Ramos-Tinoco appeared before a U.S. magistrate Monday in Tampa, but the hearing was recessed after Ramos-Tinoco said he wanted an attorney but couldn't afford to pay one. Magistrate Thomas Wilson told the public defender's office to represent him. Arcila-Giraldo appeared before a magistrate in Miami. An FBI affidavit said Ramos-Tinoco ``described Luis as a close associate'' of Colombian drug boss Pablo Escobar. It also said Ramos-Tinoco ``stated that if this arms exchange deal went well, it would be arranged for the undercover organization to handle future transportation of drugs into the United States on behalf of the Pablo Escobar group.'' However, McCreight cautioned: ``We have not established these negotiations were directed or controlled by Pablo Escobar.'' At a news conference in Miami, FBI agent William A. Gavin said there was at least one more potential suspect, but that a decision on whether to charge that person would depend on how the case unfolded. He also displayed firearms seized from a Miami house where the two had stayed. Among the guns were a MAC-10 machine gun with silencer, an AR-15 assault weapon, and a 9mm automatic weapon. The traffickers were shown a Stinger brought in from Fort Stewart, Ga., Crow said, but no weapons exchanged hands. Federal authorities said there also were discussions of importing narcotics.
