Undercover Polk Sheriff's detectives had spent the past six months on a drug sting that netted 8{ tons of marijuana plus $500,000 in cash and led to the weapons deal, Crow said. ``We had to learn very quickly what a Stinger missile was and how much they cost,'' the sheriff said. ``None of us had any idea what the going price for a Stinger missle was. We had to improvise.'' Sheriff's detectives met with the two Colombians on April 18 to fix the deal for Stingers and automatic weapons to be paid for with cash from the sale of cocaine, authorities said. Then, at a second meeting on May 1 in Lakeland, the detectives and FBI agents showed the pair a Stinger and agreed on the $1 million down payment, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Tribunal Rules France Violated Pact, Rejects New Zealand's Demands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with comment from New Zealand prime minister; pick up 8th pvs, `Under a...'
DOC.TEXT: France broke an agreement with New Zealand by repatriating two French spies convicted in the 1985 bombing of the Greenpeace flagship Rainbow Warrior, a special tribunal ruled Monday. But it rejected New Zealand's demand that the two be made to serve their full sentences on a remote Pacific atoll. The panel instead recommended France pay $2 million to a fund to encourage friendly ties between the two countries. New Zealand's prime minister, Geoffrey Palmer, said that although the French agents were let off, the decision was a victory for New Zealand. ``The time has come to put this whole sorry, tawdry episode behind us. It's dominated the relationship between France and New Zealand since July 1985,'' Palmer told reporters in Wellington. He said, however, that New Zealand would continue to oppose French nuclear testing in the South Pacific. The Rainbow Warrior was to have led a protest flotilla toward a test site on the South Pacific atoll of Mururoa. The French Foreign Ministry, which announced the panel's conclusions, said it marked the end of the affair. It said relations between France and New Zealand could now ``develop in the traditional spirit of friendship.'' The tribunal was set up after France brought home intelligence agents Alain Mafart and Dominique Prieur, both of whom were convicted of manslaughter by New Zealand courts. They had been sentenced to 10-year prison terms each for their roles in the July 1985 sinking of the Rainbow Warrior in Auckland harbor, in which a Greenpeace photographer was killed. Under a U.N.-sponsored accord reached in July 1986, the sentences of the two French agents were commuted to 3-year terms, to be served on the Pacific atoll of Hao, an isolated French military base. The accord also ordered France to pay $7 million in reparations to New Zealand. France brought home Mafart in December 1987 and Prieur in May 1988. The tribunal concluded, in a majority ruling, that France did not violate the accord when it repatriated Mafart for health reasons, without consulting New Zealand, but it said France committed a ``substantial violation'' by not returning him to the base later. It also ruled France committed ``substantial violations'' when it brought Prieur home, also without consultations, due to her pregnancy and her father's poor health. She was not returned to the atoll either. Even so, the tribunal ruled that France was no longer obliged to return either officer to the atoll because its obligations expired in July 1989, when the pair's three-year terms would have ended. The tribunal was presided over by Dr. Eduardo Jimenez de Arechaga of Uruguay, a former president of the International Court of Justice, and two arbitors chosen by France and New Zealand. They were Prof. Jean-Denis Bredin, picked by France, and Sir Kenneth Keith, chosen by New Zealand. Keith, in an addendum to the decision, said he disagreed that French obligations expired with the scheduled end of the sentences, and argued that the two should finish their terms. He also disagreed with the conclusion that Mafart's evacuation without consultation was acceptable.

DOC.HEAD: Danes Indignant Over Attack on Landmark Little Mermaid Statue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details, background, quotes. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Someone tried to decapitate the Little Mermaid, the beloved bronze fairytale figure in Copenhagen harbor, and Danish detectives on Monday were trying to figure out who _ and why. They even assigned a homicide cop to the case. The 7-inch cut in the back of the statue's neck, apparently made with a hacksaw, was discovered Monday by an engineering student, police said. The 76-year-old statue, built in tribute to Danish storyteller Hans Christian Andersen, depicts a winsome girl-sized mermaid gazing pensively over the water from her perch atop a rock. The Little Mermaid's tale is one of Andersen's best-loved, and the statue, within stepping distance of the shore along Langelinie Quay, is something of a Danish national symbol. About 500,000 tourists visit it each year. Homocide inspector Jens Christensen said the verdigris, or blue-green deposits, in the gash indicated the attempt was made at least several days ago. Analysts were trying to pinpoint the time. But so many people touch the statue that fingerprints aren't likely to provide clues, Christensen said. Tourists and locals alike, in their customary cluster at the quay, were indignant. ``It's again a mad person who did this,'' said Ejnar Weikop, a Dane. ``Oh no, not again,'' said Audrey Bates of Sydney, Australia. ``This is ridiculous.'' The Little Mermaid has been the target of vandals before. The original head was stolen in 1964. It was replaced by a new one cast from the original mold. In 1984, an arm was taken, but it was found and reattached. The mermaid has also been marred by graffiti and paint, and one prankster painted a pink brassiere on her. The engineering student, a specialist in metal work, found the cut _ nearly a third of the way through the neck _ while studying the statue's earlier repairs, Christensen said. He declined to disclose the student's name. The detective said a conviction could lead to one to four years in prison for vandalism and damaging public monuments. Danish officials were already busy planning repairs. ``We will have to solder her together,'' said Finn Plov of the municipal works department. ``But we don't know yet if she will be removed with the stone or if we have to built a scaffolding out in the water around her.'' He said the damage would not be permanent. ``Despite her 76 years, the lady is doing fine after all those surgeries she has been through,'' said Plov. Commercial rights to the mermaid are owned by the descendants of its creator, Edvard Eriksen, but Copenhagen is in charge of maintenance. The heirs earn annual royalties of about $750,000.

DOC.HEAD: UNO Faction Says It May Join Sandinistas to Weaken Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Dissidents in Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's ruling coalition said Monday they want to weaken her presidential powers and are willing to team up with their old foes, the Sandinistas, to do so. Mrs. Chamorro won election on the ticket of the 14-party United National Opposition, ending a decade of rule by the leftist Sandinistas led by President Daniel Ortega. But Mrs. Chamorro, inaugurated April 25, excluded UNO party leaders when she named her Cabinet. She instead surrounded herself with technocrats and businessmen with no marked political loyalties. She also raised the ire of some in her fragile coalition by keeping Gen. Humberto Ortega, the former Sandinista defense minister and brother of the former president, as head of the army. Mrs. Chamorro has said she will serve as defense minister. The president is also on the outs with her vice president, Virgilio Godoy, who has sided with those angry about Gen. Ortega's retention. The moves aimed at weakening the presidency would come in the form of constitutional changes. UNO has 51 deputies in the 92-member National Assembly, four short of the 60 percent needed to pass such measures. But Roberto Urroz, the head of the Nicaraguan Democratic Movement, an UNO member, said the Sandinistas also favor a weaker presidency. The Sandinistas have 39 assembly votes, so presidential foes within UNO could easily get the 55 votes needed to change the constitution. Under the constitution, passed in 1987 by a Sandinista-run assembly, the president can veto constitutional changes. That veto can be overridden by a vote from half the deputies plus one. The president also can issue decrees and declare a state of emergency, and is the supreme commander of the armed forces. Urroz, at a news conference, said UNO also plans to introduce reforms forbidding a president to run for two consecutive terms and forbidding the military to vote in national elections. Other reforms inclue a more independent judiciary. Shortly after the Feb. 25 elections, Godoy said UNO's lack of a 60 percent majority in the assembly would not hinder its legislative effectiveness because ``the Sandinistas created a strong executive, and now we're the executive.'' That was before the split within the coalition, which became evident when Mrs. Chamorro denied Godoy an office in the government complex. Godoy, who left Nicaragua suddenly on an unexplained three-day trip, now has offices at UNO campaign headquarters. A secretary and Godoy's aides have said repeatedly he is not available to comment on UNO's views on a strong executive branch.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials and Indian Leaders Meet
LaserPhoto XMAS2
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk leaders met with federal mediators Monday in an effort to end a violent tribal dispute over gambling that has left two dead on the reservation. The meeting began a few hours after a funeral was held at the St. Regis Catholic Church for 32-year-old Harold Edwards. He was killed May 1 in a gunbattle near a barricade in Snye, Quebec. Another Mohawk was killed near the same barricade, on the reservation which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. Some Mohawks oppose casino gambling and bingo as an unwanted outside influence. Supporters note the gambling earns needed cash for the reservation. Outsiders' efforts to end the violence are complicated by the contention of some Mohawks' rejection of state and federal jurisdiction on their land. A team of 10 mediators from the U.S. Justice Department met for several hours with representatives from the reservation's elected councils on the American and Canadian sides as well as the council of hereditary chiefs. The meeting was held to lay the groundwork for negotiations to try to end the 9-month-old gambling dispute, said Brenda LaFrance, a spokeswoman for an anti-gambling faction on the reservation. She said those negotiations could begin Tuesday. Indians at Monday's meeting also were expected to respond to Gov. Mario Cuomo's call for the St. Regis Tribal Council to create its own police force, which could eventually operate on both sides of the border. ``They expressed an interest to respond to the governor's proposal,'' said Dan Gaspe, a spokesman for anti-gambling Indian leaders. The tribal police force was abolished in 1981. Since then, there has been no local law enforcement on the American side of the reservation, called Akwesasne _ ``where the partridge drums'' _ by Mohawks. Mohawks on both sides of the gambling dispute attended Edwards' funeral, which was closed to reporters. There have been no arrests in either death, but Canadian provincial police say they expect to make a ``major announcement'' sometime this week about the murder investigation. Cuomo said Monday in Albany that he would keep state police on the reservation while he and tribal officials discuss setting up an Indian police force. The governor also said conditions at the reservation may have improved to the point where direct negotiations over allowing some form of legalized gambling could begin. About 200 refugees from the Canadian side of the reservation remained sheltered Monday at the Transport Canada dormitory in Cornwall, Ontario. They are the last of a group who fled their homes last week after violence flared.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Jams US Broadcasts Around the Clock
DOC.TEXT: Cuba announced Monday that U.S. government radio broadcasts beamed to the island will be jammed 24 hours a day, a move that drew a critical response from the Bush administration. The action marked the latest escalation in the electronic war between the two countries. Cuba began jamming the Voice of America's Radio Marti broadcasts during the pre-dawn hours last month, then started interfering with programming between 6 a.m. and noon. After the announcement Monday that jamming would be carried out around the clock, the VOA issued a statement saying, ``We deplore this action, which is clearly designed to deny the Cuban people access to uncensored information.'' The jamming of the broadcasts first began shortly after the agency started testing TV signals to Cuba on March 27. Cuba has jammed the TV tests each day since then. The aim of both the audio and visual operations of VOA is to bring news and entertainment to the Cuban people that they can't get from official Cuban media. The Cuban government tolerated the Radio Marti broadcasts for five years but reacted sharply to the introduction of TV Marti, calling it a violation of national sovereignty. The VOA statement on Monday said, ``The inteference of Radio Marti and TV Marti broadcasts is an affront to the Cuban people's basic human right of free access to information.''

DOC.HEAD: Antigua, Israel Work to Solve Arms Switch to Colombian Drug Lord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 7th pvs `It said' to UPDATE with State Department comments. Pickup 8th pvs, `Bina said...' Edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: Israel said Monday that a delegation of Antiguan officials was en route here to find out how a load of Israeli-made arms bound for the tiny Caribbean nation wound up in the hands of a Colombian drug lord. Foreign Ministry spokesman Baruch Bina said after the Antiguans arrive Tuesday, ``we will start the process of investigating together what happened.'' Israel army radio said a policeman, a lawyer and one other man make up the Antiguan delegation. Vere C. Bird Jr., public works minister and national security adviser to his father, Antiguan Prime Minister Vere Bird, has been implicated in the case. The younger Bird denied wrongdoing, but stepped down until the issue is resolved. In April 1989, Israel delivered to the Antiguan government 100 Uzi submachine guns with short barrels, 400 Galil automatic assault rifles and matching ammunition, an Israeli official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The shipment ended up at the ranch of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a notorious drug lord who died last December in a shootout with Colombian police. After Colombian officials discovered the cache, they approached Israel with serial numbers from 200 Galils made by Israel Military Industries, a Defense Ministry statement said Monday. It said the serial numbers ``were found to match the numbers of the rifles belonging to the shipment delivered to the Antiguan government.'' In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the administration has expressed concern over the arms shipment. ``Since Israel was the source, our embassy in Tel Aviv has raised our concern about these arms with the government of Israel,'' he said, adding that Israeli is cooperating in the investigation. Bina said the weapons deal was brokered by a Maurice Sarfati who presented a letter introducing himself as an official envoy of Antigua's Foreign Ministry. Published reports said Sarfati is a former Israeli army officer. ``We received a receipt from the government customs agent in Antigua that they had received the shipment. We had no idea that anything went wrong for almost a year,'' Bina said. ``Then we got a message from the Antiguan government asking for the details of who made the order and who received it. They said the government did not order it,'' he said. Sarfati presented to Israeli authorities an order for the shipment, an end user certificate guaranteeing the arms would be for sole use of the Antiguan army, and his accreditation letter from the Antiguan government. The letters, on government letterheads, were signed by Bird, Jr. The New York Times, quoting Antiguan and U.S. officials, said Sunday that investigators traced the arms diversion to two former Israeli army officers, Sarfati and Yair Klein. Bina said his ministry could not identify Sarfati as Israeli or find links between him and the Jewish state. However, a woman who answered a telephone registered to a Maurice Safarti in the Tel Aviv area told The Associated Press on Sunday that Sarfati no longer lived there, having moved to the United States. Klein returned to his native Israel last year after accusations surfaced that he trained assassination squads for Colombian drug lords. Klein denied it, saying he was teaching Colombian farmers self-defense. He says he intended to set up a survival training school in Antigua for Panamanian rebels seeking to overthrow dictator Manuel Noriega, now on trial in the United States on drug charges. Klein said documents linking him to the arms diversion were forged. Klein said the guns were meant for his school and he thought they were ordered by the Panamanians. Israel army radio said both Israel's Defense Ministry and a U.S. Senate subcommittee asked Klein's firm Hod Hahanit (Hebrew for spearhead) for its version of the affair. The radio quoted security sources as saying many false documents existed in the arms case, but none was linked to Hod Hahanit. Bina said, ``I don't know about Hod Hahanit. From our point of view it was a government-to-government deal.'' The Defense Ministry stated that Klein acted in Latin America without the required permit and it knew nothing of his involvement in the Antiguan affair.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, Three Missing in Swiss Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers on Monday recovered the bodies of four off-trail skiers who died in an avalanche in the Bernese Oberland region, police said. Officials said three others were missing and presumed dead in Saturday's avalanche, which would make it Switzerland's deadliest snowslide in five years. Rescuers were forced to suspend their search Monday afternoon as warm temperatures increased the danger of new avalanches. The avalanche struck as members of the Swiss Alpine Club's youth organization were skiing on unmarked trails at about 7,200 feet. They were in a glacier crevice above Haslital Valley, about 25 miles east of Interlaken. Police said the victims whose bodies were found were aged 18 to 27.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor in Molestation Trial Says He's Unsure What Kids Remember
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to move up reference to first trial; SUBS 18th graf to CORRECT spelling to kamikaze sted kamikazi; ADDS 3 grafs at end with first witness' testimony. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA7
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor in the second McMartin Pre-School trial told jurors Monday he hasn't interviewed the three former pupils who claim they were molested and can't predict how they will testify. ``I don't know in what condition these children will come to you,'' Deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez said in his opening statement. ``I have not talked to them. They are now young ladies on the verge of puberty. ``I don't know how much they will recall, how much they have repressed,'' he said. But he urged jurors to ``just remember they are children and they are telling about a very traumatic thing in a courtroom full of people. It's very traumatic.'' The retrial of Ray Buckey is a case vastly diminished in scope from the scores of allegations that once enveloped the family-owned McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach and seven of its teachers. The school is now closed. The first McMartin trial ended in January when a jury acquitted Buckey's mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, of 12 charges. The same jurors acquitted the 31-year-old Buckey of 40 charges and deadlocked on 13 other counts. The district attorney's office decided to retry Buckey on eight counts involving the three children, a greatly diminished number from the hundreds that were once said to have been molested at the school. His mother was not retaried. The first trial lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million. It was the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. The second trial is expected to last about six months. Martinez, who spoke for less than one hour, said he would prove his case through the testimony of parents, medical evidence and videotapes of the children's controversial interviews with therapists in the case. The same tapes, recorded at Children's Institute International, were cited by jurors in Buckey's first trial as evidence that children were coerced by therapists into making accusations against Buckey and his mother. Ray Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, told jurors they would see that the institute's therapists asked leading questions and planted in the children's minds the idea they had been molested. Martinez said he would elicit testimony similar to that at the first trial that Buckey wore shorts without underwear. And he said he would show that the defendant once sat reading Playboy magazine in front of his preschool class. Davis asserted that none of the children, of their own volition, ever accused Buckey of molesting them. He promised that the defendant will take the stand, look jurors in the eyes and declare that he never molested anyone. ``You will have the opportunity to see this man charged with these heinous crimes, to look into his eyes and look into his soul,'' Davis told the jury. Outside court, Davis said he was shocked by Martinez's statement that he had not interviewed the children. He compared the prosecutors to World War II Japanese pilots on a suicidal mission with insufficient gas for a return flight. ``This is nothing but a kamikaze run before the primary (election),'' Davis said, referring to District Attorney Ira Reiner's candidacy for California Attorney General. ``There is no gas for a return trip for Ira Reiner,'' he said. Martinez, however, said he was confident. ``We feel we have the three best children and the eight best counts. You can't get any better than that,'' he said. The first prosecution witness was the mother of one of the three children. She said that in the spring of 1983 her daughter protested going to the McMartin school twice and became fearful. She also recalled that the child, who was prone to rashes, showed her mother redness on her bottom. ``I asked her if she knew why her body was in that condition and she didn't give me any answer,'' said the witness. On cross-examination, Davis noted that the woman was confused about dates of other events.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles, Princess Diana Visit Hungary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with gala dinner, quotes. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON6
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles on Monday hailed Hungary's role in ``changing the face of Europe'' as he and Princess Diana began the first official visit by members of Britain's royal family to a Warsaw Pact country. The royal couple were met at the airport by their host, newly elected interim President Arpad Goencz, the state MTI news agency reported. During their four-day trip, the couple will meet with government officials, business officials and artists. On Monday, Prince Charles visited Parliament, where he met separately with Goencz, Premier Miklos Nemeth and Prime Minister-designate Jozsef Antall, the leader of the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum. Last week, Hungary's new multiparty legislature met for the first time and elected Goencz, a liberal writer jailed for six years after the 1956 anti-Stalinist uprising, as interim president. Antall, whose party gained the most seats in the March and April elections _ the first freely contested since the Communists consolidated power in 1948 _ was asked to form the next government. He is seeking to form a center-right coalition with the like-minded Independent Smallholders and the Christian Democrats. Nemeth formally submitted his Cabinet's resignation but it will remain as a caretaker government until the new one is formed. Goencz presided over a gala dinner held for the royal duo Monday night. At the dinner, Prince Charles said his great-great-great grandmother, Countess Claudia Rhedey, was Hungarian. ``This evening I am especially proud of the Hungarian blood in my veins,'' he said, according to MTI. He praised Hungary's role in ``changing the face of Europe'' with its early moves toward political reforms. ``Making democracy work is never easy, but the effort is well worth the bother,'' the prince said. Goencz said Hungary now has a ``unique opportunity ... to irreversibly return to developed Europe,'' the news agency said. Upon arrival, their first stop was Heroes' Square, where they placed a wreath at a monument in honor of Hungarian heroes. About 1,500 people gathered at the square. Many applauded as the couple emerged from their car. The well-wishers included about 100 members of the British community in Budapest. ``I think the princess is beautiful,'' said Janos Nagy, a 21-year-old student. ``I have only seen pictures of her.'' ``I came to see how she looks in real life,'' he said, tapping a pair of binoculars. Amalia Roth, 67, with three grandchildren at her side, said she had been to Britain before World War II as a young girl. ``I love England and felt I must come,'' she said. The couple's schedule Tuesday included a speech by Prince Charles at the University of Economics in Budapest. Princess Diana is to view a display of British fashion at the Museum of Applied Arts. The private jet taking Princess Diana to Hungary diverted to Gatwick Airport shortly after takeoff from Heathrow Airport because of an electrical fault, Buckingham Palace and airport officials said. The four-engine jet of the Queen's Flight spent an hour and 20 minutes on the ground at Gatwick while the fault was repaired, said Roger Hamson, terminal duty manager for Gatwick Airport. It then left for Italy, where it picked up Charles before traveling to Budapest.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-China-Soviet Team Scales Everest
DOC.TEXT: Six climbers from the United States, China and the Soviet Union gave each other hugs and joyful slaps on the back after scaling Mount Everest in an ``international peace climb'' Monday, expedition leaders said. The climb was billed as an attempt to foster international good will and to remove litter from the world's highest peak. China's official Xinhua News Agency said the six reached the summit of the 29,028-foot mountain Monday afternoon. The climbers are Steve Gall of Woody Creek, Colo., who operates a mountain guide service in Aspen, Colo.; Robert Link of Ashford, Wash.; Sergei Arsentje and Grigory Lunjakov of the Soviet Union; and Da Cheme and Gyal Bu of China. Six to eight more climbers from the three countries were to attempt the summit this week. Expedition leader Jim Whittaker, reporting Tuesday from an advanced base camp at 21,325 feet, said the six climbers reached the summit in good condition and ``spent almost an hour in dead calm weather.'' Warren Thompson, deputy leader of the so-called ``Mount Everest International Peace Climb'' expedition, spoke Tuesday to a news conference in Seattle via a telephone patch from base camp at the terminus of Main Rongbuk Glacier in Tibet, elevation 17,100 feet. He said the six ``gave each other big hugs and slaps on the back,'' took photographs and planted flags from their respective countries before descending to camp, to symbolize the achievement possible through cooperation. Thompson said, ``I think the best word is ecstatic. Everybody here has got huge grins on their faces and we're very, very happy. This is really a great accomplishment.'' A brief video containing still photographs of Sunday's ascent was played at the news conference. In accompanying audio, Gall was heard saying once the top had been reached, ``It's balmy up here.'' The 46-member expedition began ascending Everest in March and had hoped to put a few climbers on the top on April 22, Earth Day. The returning climbers used duffle bags to haul down debris left on the summit in previous ascents. It was, they said, of supporting the world environmental movement. The climbers neared the peak in late April but high winds forced them to retreat to base camp. They set out a second time April 30.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Charge Dropped Against Irishman Held Since September
DOC.TEXT: An Irish citizen held since September in connection with the assassination of white SWAPO leader Anton Lubowski was freed Monday after the murder charge against him was dropped. Donald Acheson was arrested Sept. 13, the day after Lubowski was assassinated outside his home. Lubowski was the only white executive member of the South-West Africa People's Organization that won last November's elections and became the ruling party in the newly independent country. ``I never did this crime whatsoever and I just want to get out ... out of it,'' Acheson said after he was released. He refused to comment when asked if he had worked for the South African Defense Force's Civil Cooperation Bureau. The secret organization has been implicated by South African police in the deaths of Lubowski and a Johannesburg university academic, David Webster, last May. Namibian police issued warrants this year for the arrest of several former South African police who were members of the Civil Cooperation Bureau. The men went into hiding and emerged after March 21, when Namibia became independent from South Africa and the warrants became invalid. The two countries have no extradition treaty. Acheson said he came to Namibia last September to look for a job as a newspaper cartoonist but found none. He said he had previously done work for Britsh newspapers and U.S. magazines. Acheson's passport was returned to him and his lawyer said he would probably fly Thursday to West Germany before returning to South Africa where he has a fiancee. Achesion also said he was considering returning to Ireland, which he said he left ``too many years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Appeals to Poor to Ignore Political Ideologues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Veracruz visit, homily, details. Pick up 8th pvs, `The setting...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MO4,5; LaserColor MO6
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, preaching on a muddy field in one of Mexico's most impoverished cities, urged the poor to follow the Roman Catholic Church and reject political leaders who deny God. ``Throughout history there have been many `pastors' _ leaders, dictators, chiefs, ideologues and creators of opinions or currents of thought _ who have tried to `shepherd' or guide the people toward artificial paradises,'' John Paul said in his homily to a joyous, flag-waving throng of 200,000 people. But the only true shepherd, said the pontiff, is one like Jesus Christ, who ``is ready to give his life for his sheep.'' All others, one after another, ``showed themselves to be false shepherds.'' The Polish-born pope alluded to the reforms that have swept Eastern Europe, saying the church had defended human rights crushed by ``political systems with an inhuman face.'' On the second day of his second visit to Mexico, John Paul also made an afternoon visit to the coastal city of Veracruz, 200 miles east of Mexico City, where Roman Catholic missionaries first landed in the 16th century. The pope, speaking to about 20,000 people from a podium set up along the docks, defended the celebration of the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Christianity in the New World. The ceremonies, set to take place in 1992, celebrating Columbus' discovery of America have created some ire in Latin America, with critics saying the church arrived as an instrument of conquest that brought repression and disease. ``The discovery, the conquest, and the evangelization occupy a decisive, luminous place taken all together, even though they are not without shadows,'' the pope said in a homily. In Chalco, the field where the pope spoke was surrounded by thousands of gray concrete-block homes topped with corrugated aluminum slabs anchored by rocks against the wind. At least 700,000 people, most of them poor peasants who moved to the area the past decade, live in the Chalco valley 25 miles southeast of Mexico City. The setting is spectacular, but the snow-capped volcanic peaks of Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl were largely obscured by clouds as the pope spoke. People in threadbare clothes lined unpaved streets that had turned to seas of sticky mud after a night of rain. ``John Paul II, the whole world loves you,'' they cried. The pontiff earlier held a private meeting with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. John Paul made no statement about the meeting, but the presidential press office said the two ``spoke of the end of dogmas in the world and in Mexico, and of the changes occurring in Eastern Europe.'' It was the only reference to a possible discussion of church-state relations in Mexico. Although the church is constitutionally restricted, many of the restrictions are ignored, and Salinas has been moving slowly toward a more formal recognition of the status quo. The church had a history in Mexico of supporting conservatives and found itself on the wrong side in the last half of the 19th century, especially during Benito Juarez's reforms and during the Mexican Revolution that started in 1910. After the revolution, all church property was confiscated, numerous restrictions were written into the 1917 constitution, and relations with the Vatican were broken in 1926. The Vatican announced last month that the pope might travel to Cuba in December, but John Paul told reporters Sunday on the flight to Mexico that ``it seems that this project will not be mature'' by then. He said Cuban bishops, the Vatican and the government of President Fidel Castro have yet to agree on a date. John Paul has visited every country in Central and South America during his pontificate, but not Cuba. In Mexico, crowds have been smaller than expected because the rainy season started several weeks early. The field at Chalco was divided by fences, and scalpers seized control of some entrances, charging 10,000 pesos _ about $3.80, or the daily minimum wage. John Paul, speaking from a pyramid-shaped altar decorated with geometric Aztec designs, embraced a decision by Latin American bishops to change the church's tradition of siding with the rich ruling classes. ``The church ... wants to give witness to the dignity of man and be his relief and defense,'' he said. However, the pontiff emphasized that the church's first responsibility was to give spiritual aid, and called on better-off Mexicans to translate their Catholic faith into help for the poor. ``We cannot live and sleep peacefully while thousands of our brothers, very near to us, lack the necessities for a dignified human life,'' John Paul told the crowd. Since the pope's visit was announced, Salinas has made highly publicized vists to Chalco to dedicate street lights and electric lines. But John Paul recognized the poverty in which most residents still live, crammed into small houses without bathrooms or running water. ``In many of you I find the face of the suffering Christ,'' he said. Margarita Pinzon de Rios, 48, of Mexico City, slept overnight in a car to be able to see the pope. ``He is demonstrating the love he has for us, the humble,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Considering Boosting Hazardous Duty Pay for Diplomats in Manila
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is considering increasing hazardous duty pay for diplomats based in the Philippines because of threats by Communist rebels, officials said Tuesday. If approved, the 300 U.S. diplomats here would receive a 15 percent pay increase. Such a designation would place the Philippines in the same risk category as Colombia, Peru, Honduras, Afghanistan and Lebanon. U.S. Embassy spokesman Gerry Huchel confirmed the proposal was under consideration but that it had not yet been implemented. Other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the embassy was concerned such a designation would embarass the government of President Corazon Aquino, which the United States strongly supports. In the past three months, security has been stepped up for all U.S. government employees here, including diplomats, 300 Peace Corps volunteers and 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department employees and military dependents. On Saturday, the U.S. military canceled all off-post leaves for service members and their families after suspected Communist rebels killed U.S. Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic naval base, 50 miles west of Manila. Diplomats have been varying routes to work, switching automobile license tags and taking other security measures to prevent attacks by Communist rebels. The British and Australian embassies have quietly advised their nationals to avoid travel near U.S. facilities for fear they might be mistaken for Americans, sources in the diplomatic community said. Fears of rebel attacks have mounted because U.S. and Filipino officials begin talks next Monday on renewing the lease to the six American military bases here. The lease expires in September 1991. The rebels have demanded that Mrs. Aquino close the bases and have offered peace talks if she does. Mrs. Aquino rejected the offer. The rebels have been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: 16-Year-Old Girl Killed in Crossfire Between Soldiers, Militants
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old girl was killed Monday in crossfire between soldiers and Moslem separatists and the bullet-riddled bodies of two kidnapping victims were found by a river, officials and newspapers reported. In another development, a strike ordered by Moslem separatists brought businesses to a standstill in this city. The deaths raised to at least 352 the number of people killed since Jan. 20 when India launched a crackdown in Jammu-Kashmir state on Moslem separatists. The girl, identified only as Dolly, was accidentally killed in a shootout after Moslem militants hurled a grenade at infantry soldiers patrolling the city center, wounding three troops. Soldiers opened fire wounded five militants, and the girl died instantly after being hit by gunfire, security officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United News of India reported that the bodies of Prof. Kundanlal Ganjoo and his wife were found on the banks of the Jelum River, just north of Srinagar. The couple was kidnapped Saturday by suspected militants. Security forces closed off the area and were conducting house-to-house searches for their kidnappers, the news agency said. Ganjoo was a professor at the College of Agriculture in Sopore, north of Srinagar. In Srinagar, troops increased patrols on Monday as government workers opened offices for the summer. Government offices alternate each year between the winter capital, Jammu, in the south, and the summer capital, Srinagar. Commandos lined the streets and troops placed barricades outside government buildings. Government workers were moved to work in police vehicles, accompanied by troops in jeeps and trucks. Bands of Moslem youths stoned some of the vehicles and youths snatched the identity cards of government workers. A city-wide strike, called by Moslem separatist groups, brought the city to a standstill. Shops and businesses remained closed throughout the day. Posters on the walls of Srinagar had called the strike to protest the annual movement of the capital and warned of reprisals if the order was ignored. Most Moslem government workers stayed away from their jobs, official sources said. Sporadic gunfire echoed through the city and a curfew relaxation in several areas of Srinagar was cut short because of violence, police said. The crisis in Kashmir has heightened tension and animosity between largely Hindu India and Moslem Pakistan. India accuses Pakistan of harboring and arming the separatists. Pakistan denies the charge and says India is brutally crushing a movement for self-determination. The two countries went to war over the Kashmir valley in 1948 and again in 1965. Both nations have claimed Kashmir since they won their independence from Britain in 1947. The old princely state of Kashmir was mostly Moslem, but its ruler was Hindu and he opted to join India. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems make up 12 percent of India.

DOC.HEAD: California Bank Turned Over to Philippines Government
DOC.TEXT: A California bank that allegedly was used by the late Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos and his wife to launder stolen funds was turned over to the Philippine government on Monday. The transfer of all shares in the California Overseas Bank, of Los Angeles, to the Manila government was part of a March 16 plea bargain agreement in U.S. District Court where Imelda Marcos is on trial. The bank, estimated by a defense lawyer to be worth $20 million to $30 million, had pleaded guilty to one count of wire fraud. Other counts involving federal bank insurance fraud and racketeering conspiracy were dropped as part of the deal. The sentence giving the Philippines total control of the bank was a victory for President Corazon Aquino's government, which seeks to recover more than $220 million allegedly embezzled by the Marcoses from the country's treasury during Marcos' 20 years in power. The bank was owned by Robert S. Benedicto, a one-time Marcos crony who was charged with conspiring to help the former president shift stolen money to secret Swiss accounts and personal uses. Mrs. Marcos is alleged to have participated with her husband in the embezzlement, using the money to finance a luxury lifestyle and investments in New York real estate. Co-defendant Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi Arabian financer, is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal ownership of the New York properties. Marcos, originally indicted with his wife, died in exile in Hawaii last September. Benedicto, also indicted and listed as a fugitive by the court, was dropped from the case as part of the plea bargain approved by Judge John F. Keenan. Two former officials of the California Overseas Bank testified last week that Benedicto had said he bought the institution for $7 million in 1976 because ``the president (Marcos) needed the bank,'' and that he had personally managed several accounts whose owners were known only to himself. Government prosecutors say the accounts belonged to the Marcoses and were used to launder money being funneled to other accounts, to buy a Manhattan office building and Mrs. Marcos' jewelry, and to provide two of the Marcos children with $10,000-a-month allowances.

DOC.HEAD: 6.2 Quake Off Panama
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake occurred Monday night in the Pacific Ocean off Panama, the U.S. Geological Survey reported. Spokesman Don Finley said monitors did not believe the quake was strong enough to cause significant damage on land or major ocean surface disturbance. The tremor was centered about 250 miles southwest of Panama City, about 100 miles south of Puerto Armuelles or 120 miles southwest of Santiago. It occured at 8:02 p.m. EDT, which is also 8:02 p.m. Panama time. Survey monitors at Golden, Colo., said they recorded the quake at an estimated 6.2 magnitude on the Richter scale, according to Finley. The quake was reported felt in Veraguas province and in the city of Santiago. The center of the quake was given as latitude 6.9 north, longitude 82.7 west. Every increase of one number on the Richter scale corresponds to an increase of 10 times in the ground motion. On land a quake of 6.5 can cause severe damage in built-up areas. The San Francisco earthquake of last October was computed to be a 7.1 magnitude quake.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th item to CORRECT name of newspaper to The Grand Island Independent in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Ralph Clark, a former publisher and general manager of The Grand Island Independent, died Sunday from Parkinson's disease at age 79. Clark entered the newspaper business at the age of 13 in 1923. He was a Linotype operator and printer on several Kansas and Nebraska weeklies. Later he became an ad manager at Augusta and Larned, Kan., and was ad manager of the weekly Columbus (Neb.) News for five years before coming to Grand Island. Clark served as an advertising salesman at the Independent for six years, became advertising manager in 1949 and general manager in 1963. He also served as publisher in his final years of management. He was credited with guiding the newspaper from hot metal type to offset type in 1974. He retired in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Mrs. Bush Represents U.S. in Costa Rica Transfer of Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with arrival, quotes from remarks as delivered; CORRECTS that Ferre former Puerto Rican governor. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: First Lady Barbara Bush, on her first solo foreign mission, on Monday night praised the peaceful transfer of power to President-elect Rafael Calderon Jr. as ``another triumph of democracy.'' Calderon was to be inaugurated Tuesday afternoon. Mrs. Bush was greeted on arrival late Monday at Juan Santamaria airport outside San Jose by outgoing President Oscar Arias, Foreign Minister Rodrigo Madrigal and other dignitaries. Several dozen boy and girl scouts in beige shirts and blue bandannas welcomed her with rhythmic clapping, waving small U.S. flags. The first lady was dressed in a red print dress and blue jacket, wearing her trademark necklace of faux pearls. The first lady headed a U.S. delegation that included her Spanish-speaking son, Jeb, and his Mexican-born wife, Columba; White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and his wife, Nancy; Luis Ferre, the former governor of Puerto Rico, and his wife, Tiody; and Republican media strategist Roger Ailes of New York, who advised Calderon in his successful campaign. Mrs. Bush said she brought the best wishes of the people of the United States and a letter from President Bush to Calderon wishing him well as he begins his presidential term. ``We come to Costa Rica today to join you in commemorating another triumph of democracy _ the peaceful transfer of power from the Arias administration to the Calderon administration,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``Our main purpose for being in San Jose is to join all Costa Ricans in celebrating those most democratic activities _ the recognition of the will of the people, the rule of law and the peaceful participation of all citizens in the selection of their leaders,'' she said in remarks prepared for delivery on her arrival. She also spoke of the Bushes' ``great respect'' for Arias, winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for efforts to promote peace in the region. Mrs. Bush's press office in Washington released the text of her remarks in advance.

DOC.HEAD: 8 Dead, 3 Missing After High Winds Hit Washington, British Columbia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to update with a fisherman's body recovered, leaving 3 people missing; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The missing...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities abandoned their search Monday for a boy lost in a boating accident when high winds battered Washington and British Columbia over the weekend. Boating and other accidents left at least eight dead and three missing. Remnants of the winds reached 30 knots on Monday, forcing those looking for 5-year-old William Yoeman in the Columbia River to rely on a plane instead of a boat. ``We went back out today and had no luck,'' said Benton County Sheriff's Capt. Dave Donovan. ``We're going to call it quits because there's not any place else to look. It does not appear there's going to be a survivor.'' Also Monday, a Coast Guard helicopter spotted the body of Brian Bell, 22, in Puget Sound near the mouth of Discovery Bay, said Petty Officer Dennis Hall of the Coast Guard's Seattle office. Later in the day, the Coast Guard recovered the body of Bell's fishing companion, John Hoscouledge III, 34. The two had been in a 15-foot boat that sank in Saturday's storm. A search continued 10 miles east of Port Townsend for another man who had been fishing by himself, the Coast Guard said. The missing boy abandoned a 20-foot pleasure boat with his mother and two other adults in the Columbia River below Kennewick, in south-central Washington, when the craft took on water late Saturday. The mother _ Christine Barajas, 26, _ survived and was treated for hypothermia, shock and minor injuries. The other two adults died, one in the river and the other, boat owner Larry Davis, when he was hit by a train after reaching shore and going to seek help. Davis appeared shaken and disoriented after emerging from the cold water, Ms. Barajas reported. The gusty winds moved in suddenly Saturday as tens of thousands of people took to the water to enjoy warm, sunny weather for the Northwest's traditional opening day of boating season. The gusts quickly reached 61 mph. A gale warning, posted Saturday for the Strait of Juan de Fuca separating Washington from British Columbia, was reduced to a small craft advisory Sunday as winds diminished to 10 to 20 knots. The bodies of two fishermen were found washed ashore near their 15-foot boat Sunday about five miles east of Port Angeles on the Strait of Juan de Fuca, said Coast Guard Lt. Jim Beckham. A man was found dead on the Nisqually Flats between Tacoma and Olympia after searchers spotted his small aluminum boat tied to a tree near the mudflats, Beckham said. In southwest British Columbia, one person was killed during a para-gliding lesson, and another was missing and presumed drowned after a 20-foot pleasure boat capsized Saturday at the mouth of the Fraser River south of Vancouver, said Richard Hendrickson, a Canadian Coast Guard officer. An 8-year-old boy Bremerton boy died late Sunday when his canoe overturned on Lake Sutherland. But authorities later said his death was not storm-related.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Recipient on Symbion Heart Assist Dies
DOC.TEXT: A heart transplant patient put on a heart-assist mechanism after its use was restricted to last-resort cases died Monday of multiple organ failure. Darwin Kramer, 65, died minutes after the two Symbion Inc. assist devices, which had pumped blood through his transplanted heart since April 17, and other life support were disconnected, said University Medical Center spokesman George Martinez. Martinez said the cause of death was multiple organ failure. Richard Smith, UMC's chief biomedical engineer in charge of artificial heart and assist devices, said the Symbion devices had functioned well and caused no problems. In January, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration withdrew approval of Symbion artificial hearts and heart-assist devices, citing safety concerns. In February, the FDA said it would allow their use as a last resort. Kramer, of Scottsdale, received his new heart March 10. When his body began to reject it, the two Symbion acute ventricular devices, called a BIVAD, were implanted ``to let the donor heart recover,'' Smith said. The BIVAD, which sits on the abdomen and is connected to the heart by tubes through the chest, helped Kramer stabilize, Martinez said. But about five days ago doctors discovered a systemic infection of unknown cause. When Kramer lapsed into multiple organ failure and doctors saw no hope for recovery, his family was consulted and life support disconnected, Smith said. Kramer had been a candidate for another donor heart since April 28, when doctors determined his rejection of the first one was irreversible. Kramer's BIVAD implant was the second done on a heart recipient by Dr. Jack G. Copeland, head of UMC's transplant program, but his first use of a Symbion device since the FDA action. Smith said the first UMC transplant patient to receive BIVAD support had the device for 10 days after her donor heart failed to start. The heart recovered and the woman is alive more than a year later, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Once on This Island,' A New Musical, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.TEXT: ``Once on This Island'' is as endearing as it is exotic, a lush little musical set in the French Antilles but telling a love story that has universal appeal. Credit director Graciela Daniele and the songwriting team of Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty. The show, which arrived over the weekend at off-Broadway's Playwrights Horizons, explodes with music and motion. It never stops, thanks to Daniele's exuberant direction and the nearly continuous use of song and dance. This bittersweet fairy tale, based on the novel ``My Love, My Love,'' by Trinidad-born writer Rosa Guy, tells of the doomed romance between a simple peasant girl and a wealthy young man. But it's not condescending or simplistic in its treatment of the ill-fated lovers. And Ahrens, who adapted the book and wrote the lyrics, has come up with a leading female character an audience can cheer. In a season of such effective but emotionally cold musicals like ``City of Angels'' and ``Grand Hotel,'' that's something rare. Ti Moune is the sweetest Caribbean heroine since Ottilie, a role played by the wonderful Diahann Carroll in Harold Arlen's ``House of Flowers'' years ago. It's a sympathetic part played to perfection by a performer with a dazzling smile and an unusual name, La Chanze. The dark-skinned Ti Moune falls for Daniel, the mulatto son of an island landowner, and saves his life when his sports car crashes on a winding road. She nurses him back to health, but eventually the barriers of class and color prove to be too much. In Ti Moune's quest for love, she is helped _ and occasionally hindered _ by a quartet of rambunctious and rowdy gods, deities of water, earth, love and death. They add a touch of supernatural to the plot, an other-worldly quality that gives the story much of its charm. The score is completely different from ``Lucky Stiff,'' a daffy, dumb-fun musical that Ahrens and Flaherty wrote for Playwrights Horizons several seasons ago. The title character in that show was a corpse that refused to stay put, and the witty music reflected the musical's farcical nature. Flaherty's music for ``Once on This Island'' is more expansive and romantic. It embraces a wide range of styles from calypso, like in the gutsy ``Mama Will Provide,'' to more traditional theater love songs like ``Forever Yours.'' Ahrens' lyrics are unforced and fit the music beautifully. Daniele has gotten strong ensemble performances from the rest of the cast, fine singers and dancers all. Particularly effective are Eric Riley, a sensuous demon of death, and Kecia Lewis-Evans, as a big-voiced Earth Mother. The director's production team _ set designer Loy Arcenas, costume designer Judy Dearing and lighting designer Allen Lee Hughes _ has created an atmospheric island environment. A deep blue set, painted with primitive trees and birds, fills the small stage and embraces the actors. So does Daniele's inventive choreography which becomes an important part of the story. The dances swirl throughout ``Once on This Island,'' turning the stage into a tropical never-never land that won't disappear from memory even after the curtain has fallen.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of April 30-May 7:
DOC.HEAD: No Quick End in Sight to Newspaper Woes, Times Mirror Chief Says
DOC.TEXT: Not since the 1970s have newspaper advertising sales been so slow, and no quick recovery is in sight from Times Mirror Co.'s first-quarter earnings slump, company chief Robert F. Erburu said May 3. ``We are experiencing the impact of a very weak economy in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic area,'' Erburu, Times Mirror's board chairman and chief executive, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting. He said Times Mirror, whose flagship is the Los Angeles Times, was making hundreds of millions of dollars in capital investments at The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, the Newsday editions on Long Island, N.Y., and in New York City, and the Baltimore Sun newspapers. Those investments won't pay off until the economy recovers, he said. ``The most one can say is that 1990 is proving to be a very difficult year, and the future course of the economy will be a key factor in our outcome,'' Erburu said. Times Mirror said last week that its first-quarter profits fell 33 percent to $46 million, largely because of slow advertising at its Northeastern papers, consumer magazines and broadcast television operations. The first-quarter falloff was felt through much of the industry. On May 3, the Washington Post Co. said weak advertising pushed profits down 6 percent to $39 million. Even Gannett Co., where earnings had grown nonstop for more than two decades, had only a slight profit gain, from $74.9 million to $75 million. Gannett revenue fell 1 percent to $813.4 million. Erburu made his remarks in the Times' new $230 million Olympic Plant east of downtown, where state-of-the-art presses can churn out a 96-page paper with 24 pages in full color. The Times also is modernizing printing plants in Orange County and the San Fernando Valley, spending $405 million in all. In an interview, Erburu said the company is looking for more fresh ideas such as its partnership with KCAL-TV to produce 4{-minute Orange County news summaries to be inserted into CNN's Headline News every half-hour. The summaries, drawing on stories from Times reporters, will be shown by Times Mirror's cable company in Orange County.
DOC.HEAD: LA Times Becomes Largest Weekday Newspaper in the United States
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles Times surpassed the New York Daily News as the U.S. metropolitan newspaper with the nation's largest weekday circulation, according to preliminary figures released by the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The Times weekday circulation for the six months ending March 31 rose by 90,237 to 1,210,077, according to ABC figures released April 30. The New York Daily News decreased in weekday circulation over the period by 50,047, to 1,180,139. Two national-circulation newspapers, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today, have larger weekday circulation figures than the Times, 1,935,866 and 1,387,233, respectively. The Times' Sunday circulation rose by 81,230, to 1,504,540, making it second-largest in the nation behind the New York Times, which has a Sunday circulation of 1,706,013. The weekend edition of USA Today, published Fridays, sold 1,753,537 copies a week. About half the Times' circulation growth stemmed from the demise of the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Times publisher David Laventhol has said. The Herald Examiner had a circulation of roughly 230,000 when it closed in November. Perhaps up to 100,000 Herald Examiner subscribers already bought a second newspaper, the ABC figures indicated. Of the remainder, an estimated 50,000 to 70,000 may have stopped reading a daily newspaper altogether, newspaper executives estimate. Of the rest, about two-thirds switched to the Los Angeles Times, Laventhol has estimated. An additional 20,000 may have taken other newspapers, particularly the Los Angeles Daily News. Daily News circulation rose by 19,044 on weekdays to 202,384, and by 12,682 to 212,205 on Sundays. The Times quoted circulation experts as saying the Daily News may have picked up about 10,000 former Herald Examiner readers.
DOC.HEAD: Appellate Court Rejects Demand To Dissolve Freedom Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court has rejected a bid by Freedom Newspapers Inc. shareholder Harry Hoiles to dissolve the $1 billion media group. The court, in a ruling made public May 1, upheld a 1987 decision issued by Superior Court Judge Leonard Goldstein that found no basis in Hoiles' claim that one-third of the family-operated corporation illegally was undermined by the two-thirds majority. The lawsuit stems from Hoiles' claim that his sister, Mary Jane Hoiles Hardie, promised to back him as the successor to Harry's older brother Clarence, who headed Freedom until his death in 1981. But she refused to back him, and Harry Hoiles talked to potential buyers for his shares, including the rival Times Mirror Co. His sister and other family members offered to buy out his shares at an offer that reflected a minority discount. Harry Hoiles said the $125 million offer was insufficient. Concerned about a possible stock sale to competitors, the majority shareholders adopted a stock restriction to give the Hardies and the family of Clarence Hoiles the first chance to buy each other's stock. Harry Hoiles also was not re-elected to a three-member executive committee of Freedom. He sued, alleging the actions had denied him a fair price for his stock and devalued it. But Goldstein ruled the majority stockholders had acted legally, and the appellate court agreed. Fairness ``does not require the majority to submit to corporate blackmail at the whim of a minority, any more than it will permit a majority to take unfair advantage of a minority,'' wrote Associate Justice Thomas F. Crosby Jr. Harry Hoiles' lawyer, Kenneth Scholtz, said unless the appellate court grants a rehearing, he will seek review before the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders Predict Daily News Demise Without New Equipment
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders from the New York Daily News brought their battle with the Tribune Co. to the media giant's annual meeting May 3, predicting the newspaper would collapse in six months unless its decaying printing plant is replaced. But company officials reiterated their commitment to first bringing costs under control at the newspaper, once the nation's largest metropolitan daily. That position is now held by the Los Angeles Times. Also at the meeting, Tribune Co. head Stanton Cook announced he will retire in August as chief executive officer and as publisher of the Chicago Tribune. Cook told stockholders that 1989 was a record year, with earnings of more than $242 million. But he said the company will not pour money into the Daily News plant until ``excessive operational costs'' are eliminated. ``It would not be prudent to recommend these investments until costs are brought under control,'' said Cook. ``It would be a mistake to underestimate our resolve. The advertisers deserve it, and the shareholders deserve it.'' George McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, which represents 10 Daily News unions in contract negotiations with the company, said corporate officials had it backwards. The unions would make concessions, he said, but not until the Tribune Co. agreed to substantial investments at what he called the ``Dickens-like'' plant. ``Unless the investments are made now, the News won't be around in six months,'' McDonald said. ``Let's stop this charade and settle this at the bargaining table.'' Cook, who will be 65 in July, will remain chairman of the Tribune Co. after he steps down as chief executive officer and Tribune publisher. Charles Brumback, president and chief operating officer, will become chief executive officer. John Madigan, president and chief executive officer of the newspaper, will assume Cook's publishing duties.
DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Jurors' Names To Remain Secret During Criminal Trial
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on April 30 let stand a ruling that says the public has no constitutional right to know the names of jurors while they are serving in a criminal trial. The court, without comment, rejected a challenge to a Delaware judge's order that kept jurors' names secret during a much-publicized murder trial. Lawyers for Gannett Co., publisher of The News Journal in Wilmington, said the judge's order contradicts previous Supreme Court rulings on the public's right of access to criminal trials. The Delaware Supreme Court, saying those previous rulings do not apply to the release of jurors' names, upheld the judge's order last Nov. 13. ``Gannett has failed to carry its burden of establishing any historical tradition of constitutional dimension regarding public access to jurors' names,'' the state Supreme Court ruled. The dispute stemmed from the Wilmington murder trial of Steven Pennell, who was charged with the serial torture slayings of three women. State prosecutors sought the death penalty. Pennell was convicted of two of the murders and was sentenced to life in prison. Before the trial's jury selection began, the presiding judge ordered that potential jurors be identified in open court by numbers, not their names. Throughout the trial, only the judge, prosecutors, the defendant and his lawyers knew the jurors' names. The News Journal had published an article offering biographical sketches of all the jurors in a then-recently concluded murder trial, and the judge was concerned the newspaper might run a similar article during Pennell's trial. Jurors were not to be sequestered, and the judge said he was worried jurors might be harassed during the trial _ interfering in Pennell's right to an impartial jury. Lawyers for Gannett noted that jurors had not been sequestered in the previous trial, and that none was harassed after being identified in the newspaper. But names of jurors in Pennell's case were not made public until his trial ended. In a landmark 1980 ruling, the nation's highest court said the public has a constitutional right to attend criminal trials even when defendants object. The justices since have expanded that ruling to cover jury selection and pretrial proceedings in criminal cases. Judges cannot abridge that right, the court has said, without articulating the compelling interests to be served by secrecy. In the appeal acted on April 30, lawyers for Gannett said, ``By cloaking jurors in anonymity, the bond between the jury and the public is weakened ... Hearing the name of each juror called and relating that name to the juror's testimony (during jury selection) insures public confidence that the process is fair and the answers are truthful.'' The Delaware Supreme Court rejected those arguments. ``Contrary to the rather pietistic claims of Gannett and (other news organizations), there is nothing to suggest that such actions undermined public trust in the judicial system,'' the state court said. The case is Gannett vs. Delaware, 89-1324.
DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Reverses Himself; Las Vegas Data To Be Confidential
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has reversed himself and will keep confidential the financial data of a newspaper seeking approval of joint operations with a competitor in Nevada, a spokesman said April 30. The attorney general signed an order reversing his decision of Feb. 16 requiring the Las Vegas Review-Journal to disclose circulation and advertising revenue, said spokesman David Runkel. The publisher of the newspaper, Donrey of Nevada Inc., an arm of closely held Donrey Media Group, had sought reconsideration of the February decision in a March 2 petition. Donrey argued that disclosure would damage relations with customers, suppliers and unions not only in Las Vegas but in the 73 other markets in 21 states in which Donrey operates. In an agreement last June, the Review-Journal and the Las Vegas Sun said they planned to merge their business, circulation and production operations, keeping separate editorial departments, along the lines of joint operating agreements in force in 19 other cities. Such agreements are permitted if the attorney general finds that one newspaper is in danger of failing. In Las Vegas, both newspapers have said the Sun is in ``probable danger of financial failure.'' The data in question already has been submitted to the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Inquirer Loses $34 Million Libel Judgment
DOC.TEXT: A former city prosecutor won a record $34 million libel award May 3 from The Philadelphia Inquirer, but a media lawyer and a reporters group said the judgment will likely be overturned on appeal. The judgment was the largest ever awarded against the news media, surpassing the $28 million a heart surgeon won last month from a San Antonio television station, according to Henry Kaufman, general counsel of the Libel Defense Resource Center in New York. Common Pleas Court jurors awarded $2.5 million in compensatory damages and $31.5 million in punitive damages to attorney Richard A. Sprague, a former first assistant district attorney. Sprague sued in 1983 over articles dating to 1973 in the Inquirer, which has won 17 Pulitzer Prizes in 16 years, many for investigative stories. ``I am a very strong advocate of First Amendment rights,'' said James E. Beasley, attorney for Sprague. ``What I don't tolerate and I don't think society should tolerate is the use of investigative reporters or the power of the press for a personal vendetta. And that is what developed here.'' Sprague sued over stories questioning his actions and decisions as a prosecutor. He contended that Greg Walter, one of the reporters involved in the stories, had threatened to ``get and destroy'' Sprague, who had prosecuted Walter in 1972 for taping a conversation without the other person's knowledge. Walter has since died. Beasley said the jury's verdict, after deliberations of 2{ hours at the end of the 11-week trial before Judge Charles P. Mirarchi Jr., sent a message to investigative reporters ``not to destroy somebody's reputation.'' ``We will, of course, appeal,'' Eugene L. Roberts Jr., executive editor and president of the newspaper, said in a statement. ``And I am confident that however long it takes, the Inquirer will prevail. ``Most of our case never got to the jury. Thirteen witnesses were eliminated by (Judge Mirarchi). And an investigative report by the then state attorney general that supported the Inquirer story was not allowed into evidence.'' Sprague sued over articles that he said implied he was involved in an illegal wiretapping incident, an allegation he denied, and questioned his role in a homicide case involving a son of a friend, former state police commissioner Rocco Urella. An eight-week trial resulted in a $4.5 million verdict for Sprague in 1983. The state Supreme Court in June 1988 ordered a new trial, declaring reporters have an absolute right to invoke the state Shield Law in refusing to identify confidential sources during legal proceedings. In the original trial, Judge Charles A. Lord ruled the law did not apply in the case and excluded all testimony about information from unidentified sources. ``It's unimaginable to me that a punitive damage award in this amount could or would be upheld,'' said Floyd Abrams, a prominent First Amendment lawyer. He represents NBC in appealing a $5.3 million libel judgment won by entertainer Wayne Newton. ``This is another example of libel law running amok,'' Abrams said. ``I think that this case and others will sooner rather than later lead the Supreme Court to address the constitutionality of punitive damages in libel cases.'' Jane Kirtley, executive director of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, sees a First Amendment issue in such awards. ``All a punitive damage award is when it's awarded against a news organization is a fine for speaking,'' she said. ``But beyond that ... it doesn't have to bear any relationship to anything.''
DOC.HEAD: Weekly Newspaper Editor Arrested on Criminal Libel Charges
DOC.TEXT: A weekly newspaper editor was arrested May 2 on two criminal libel charges after publishing a story about the arrest of a high school principal. Editor-Publisher Drew Wilder of The Barnwell County Banner was released on $2,000 bond. Wilder turned himself in after learning that the principal of Wagener-Salley High School, Hammond Still, and his wife, Rhonda, had sworn out warrants for his arrest, Sheriff Joey Zorn said. The Banner reported that Still was arrested April 6 on charges of disorderly conduct and assault and battery stemming from a domestic dispute with his wife, Rhonda, at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg. Still claims he was never charged with assault and battery since Mrs. Still never signed a warrant. Tim Moore, an attorney for the Stills, said the paper erroneously published what was written in the Orangeburg County Jail's booking report as a charge. ``In this case the police officer put on his booking report a possible assault and battery and disorderly conduct,'' Moore said. ``He went back and (scratched) off on assault and battery and he did charge him with public disorderly conduct.'' Still was acquitted of the latter charge April 20. ``Five days after (Still) was acquitted, Mr. Wilder comes out with his newspaper story and on the radio station saying he had been charged with assault and battery and disorderly,'' the attorney said. ``He also said the charge of assault and battery was dropped. They hadn't been dropped; they had never been brought.'' Wilder said, ``We stand by our story as being factual.'' ``We do contend that he was charged,'' he added. ``Jailhouse records show that. That's what he was arrested on.'' The 4-year-old Banner, with a staff of five and a circulation of 5,000, reported the incident beginning with Still's arrest through his acquittal, Wilder said. Wilder also broadcast the story on the radio station he manages, WBAW AM-FM, which is owned by his father. The maximum penalty for criminal libel is a year in jail and a $5,000 fine.
DOC.HEAD: The Brownsville Herald Wins Counterclaim on Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A county commissioner and a former candidate for sheriff were ordered to pay more than $25,000 to The Brownsville Herald after a judge found no merit to libel suits they filed against the newspaper. Cameron County Commissioner Lucino Rosenbaum Jr. was ordered to pay $13,500, and Art Ramirez, a losing candidate for sheriff, $12,357, in connection with libel suits they filed separately on April 11, 1988. All but $5,000 from each man was to go to attorneys' fees and court costs. Their cases were dismissed last year and the Herald countersued, claiming the lawsuits were frivolous. Rosenbaum and Ramirez filed suit in connection with political advertisements the newspaper ran when Rosenbaum was running for the County Commission in 1988. The men, who also sued Rosenbaum's opponent, Ray Ramon, claimed that the Herald and Ramon conspired to run a political ad in which Ramirez endorsed Ramon for county commissioner. According to the lawsuits, the Herald published the ad while knowing the information to be false. After the suits were dismissed, the newspaper filed and won the counterclaim against Rosenbaum and Ramirez. State District Judge Robert F. Barnes said in his April 5 ruling that the complaints were ``totally without merit.'' The judge said that the newspaper was entitled to additional damages as sanctions. ``It's our intent to countersue for damages and attorney's fees any time we're faced with this kind of legal action,'' said Doug Hardie, Herald publisher. ``A large portion of those are frivolous lawsuits. A large portion of those are politically motivated in an attempt to control what newspapers and television stations report,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fayetteville Newspapers To Merge Into Morning Edition
DOC.TEXT: The jointly owned Fayetteville Observer and the Fayetteville Times will merge into one morning newspaper, Publisher Ramon L. Yarborough said. He said the merger will produce a newspaper that retains the best features of the afternoon Observer and the morning Times. The combined paper will have a bigger news staff than either of the individual papers and will be able to provide more thorough local and regional news coverage, Yarborough said May 1. The merger is tentatively scheduled for late fall or early spring. The Fayetteville Observer, established in 1816, is the oldest newspaper in North Carolina. The Fayetteville Times was established in 1973. The Observer's circulation exceeds 40,000 and the Times is over 30,000. Yarborough said that Michael Rouse, managing editor of the Observer, will be the executive editor of the combined paper. Tom English, managing editor of the Times, was asked to become managing editor of the new product but declined. Michael Arnholt, features editor of the two newspapers, will be promoted to managing editor of the combined paper.
DOC.HEAD: Division of Teamsters Recommends Support of Newspaper Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Teamsters newspaper division leaders approved a resolution May 2 asking the international union to support drivers and other employees of the New York Daily News, who have been without a contract since the end of March. The vote came after Michael J. Alvino, president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union, one of 10 within the Allied Printing Trades Council, told Teamsters the council was in the front lines of a struggle to break organized labor in the nation's largest, most-unionized city. ``If the News beats the printing unions, then every other union ... whatever they deliver, whatever it is, they will be taken on by their employers,'' Alvino said. John P. Kennedy, president of the Pressmen's union, another Allied affiliate, said union-busting tactics perfected in smaller cities since the 1960s were being tried in New York. ``This is going to be seen all over the country, and we're going to stop them,'' he said. Alvino denied a strike was imminent if the Washington-based Teamsters sided with the New York unions. He said his attorney was studying the paper's latest offer _ a three-year contract with wage increases of 5 percent the first year and 4 percent in each successive year. However, Alvino said the offer _ based on the current $20.38 an hour for a 35-hour week _ was a veiled attempt to destroy his 98-year-old union and added that a counterproposal was likely. The Daily News also seeks management-rights and no-strike clauses and the exclusion of all side agreements not included in the new contract. It says it must be able to weed out featherbedding in the pressmen's and drivers' unions in order to turn a profit. The offer was revealed May 1. The drivers are to respond at a May 14 bargaining session.
DOC.HEAD: Employer of Slain Reporter Contributes $16,000 to Memorial Fellowship
DOC.TEXT: The Tampa Tribune and its parent company, Media General Inc. of Richmond, Va., have contributed $16,000 to a memorial fund at Washington & Lee University for a slain reporter for the newspaper. The Todd C. Smith Memorial Fellowship Fund had raised more than $53,500 of its $100,000 goal from 392 donors as of the end of April, the school said May 3. Smith, a 1983 graduate of the school, was killed in Peru last November while investigating drug trafficking. The fellowship will be used to help Washington & Lee journalism students who want to become foreign correspondents.
DOC.HEAD: Meeting Postponed After Newspaper Sues Seeking Access
DOC.TEXT: A May 2 meeting between the Floyd County grand jury and the Rome-Floyd Industrial Development Commission was postponed indefinitely after a newspaper sued to open the meeting to the public. News Publishing Co., whch owns the Rome News-Tribune, filed the lawsuit April 30 in Floyd County Superior Court. Attorneys for News Publishing Co. contended the session did not meet the Georgia Open Meetings Act's provision for closed meetings of public organizations, nor was it a secret session of the grand jury. According to the suit, the current grand jury has had a special subcommittee investigating the operations of the IDC and the meeting was called to present the committee's findings to the IDC. Floyd County District Attorney Steve Lanier said there are no plans to reschedule the meeting, but the newspaper's attorneys said the publishing company will continue its suit so the meeting cannot be held secretly in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Ordered To Publish Controversial Advertisement
