DOC.TEXT: The weekly Calhoun Chronicle was ordered to publish a paid political advertisement urging defeat of a $5.3 million school bond issue it had supported. The newspaper had earlier rejected the ad. Judge Charles McCarty ordered it published May 3 because that was the last edition before a May 8 vote on the bond issue. The case stemmed from an appeal by Citizen Awareness Regarding Education, which opposed the bond issue designed to raise funds for a combined middle school-high school. Carl Morris, the paper's owner, refused to accept the ad on March 30, saying supporters of the bond issue would not have time to respond to it. The Chronicle had previously published two of the group's ads. The judge's ruling said, ``By refusing to publish the advertisement, the Calhoun Chronicle is depriving the plaintiff of the only legitimate forum available to reach citizens of the county.'' ``I see this as a critical assertion of the essential right of free speech,'' said Loren B. Howley, an attorney for the bond issue opponents. ``If there were a competing newspaper, it would be a different situation.'' Bill Childress, executive director of the West Virginia Press Association, said the ruling disregarded the First Amendment. ``The judge made a serious error in departing from what has been the standard legal position that a newspaper has the right to refuse any advertising it chooses to refuse, political or non-political,'' Childress said.
DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Open Meeting Law in `Restroom Lawsuit'
DOC.TEXT: Two Texas Water Commission members who talked about a case while in the restroom violated the state's Open Meetings Act, the Texas Supreme Court ruled May 2. The Supreme Court said such a discussion would be illegal any time there is a quorum or majority of the decision-making body present. The commission has three members. John Hildreth, director of the Southwest Regional Office of Consumers Union, said the decision ``reaffirms the fundamental concept of openness in Texas government.'' ``The Supreme Court remedied a decision which would have slammed the door on access to decision making by major regulatory agencies,'' Hildreth said. Nancy Monson, executive director of the Freedom of Information Foundation of Texas, hailed the ruling as ``an excellent decision.'' ``We're really grateful that the Supreme Court upheld the people's right to know,'' she said. The ruling was made in a lawsuit filed by Charles Acker in Travis County state district court. Acker was appearing before the Water Commission in 1986 seeking a waste water treatment plant permit to provide service to residents of his mobile home park in Huntsville. The hearing examiner recommended the commission grant Acker the permit. During a break in the meeting, Acker's lawyer, Andrew Taylor, said he overheard commission members discussing the application in the restroom. When the meeting reconvened, one of the commissioners voted to grant the application. The remaining two commissioners voted to deny it. Acker won his case in a state district court summary judgment, but the Austin-based 3rd Court of Appeals overturned the decision in May 1989.
DOC.HEAD: Keep Hostage Journalist's Story Alive, Colleague Says
DOC.TEXT: Keeping alive the story of Terry Anderson is crucial to winning the release of the captive Associated Press reporter, a colleague of Anderson said. ``While I think there is a lot of support out there, there has to be more support,'' Time magazine photographer Bill Foley said in accepting an award for Anderson, the longest-held of the Western hostages. ``And there has to be more of a message given to Washington that people out there do care, and that to get this over with, you're going to have to talk with people, and talking with people, we will see these men free,'' Foley added. ``They're not going to just appear one day because somebody said, `Oh, this is terrible. We must release these guys.' '' Foley, a former AP photographer, made his remarks while accepting the Mitchell V. Charnley Award on Anderson's behalf April 28 at the annual meeting of the Northwest Broadcast News Association. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for the AP, was kidnapped March 16, 1985. He was cited by the NBNA for his ``outstanding contributions to the field of broadcast journalism.'' The Charnley Award is given annually to a journalist with Midwestern ties who has distinguished himself in the broadcast industry. Anderson spent three years as a radio and television reporter at KRNT and KCCI-TV in Des Moines, Iowa, before joining The AP in Detroit in May 1974. The award, established in 1968, is named for Mitchell V. Charnley, professor emeritus from the University of Minnesota School of Journalism and Mass Communication. Charnley taught at the university from 1934 to 1968 and was a founder of the NBNA. Chartered in 1949, the NBNA includes broadcast professionals and students in Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper's Gun Photograph Denounced
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders have denounced a front-page photograph in The Boston Sunday Globe, saying it is racist and glorifies guns. The photograph in the April 29 newspaper, which accompanied an article on the widespread availability of guns, showed a black man with his athletic shirt pulled up to reveal a gun in his belt. The caption said the man identified himself as a drug dealer. State Sen. Bill Owens, D-Boston, said the Globe's photograph was exploitive and showed black youths in a negative light. He also said it seemed to have been staged for the photographer. ``The question that comes to my mind is, when do you begin to make news and when do you begin to sell it,'' he said. Owens said the photograph could fuel violence in the city: ``Suppose this person is a gang member. Another gang member will try to outdo that person.'' Globe Editor John S. Driscoll said in a prepared statement: ``We understand their concerns. Our intent was not to depict a particular person but to reflect the issue explained in the story.'' Rep. Shirley Owens-Hicks, D-Boston, said the photograph made dealing drugs look ``cool.'' ``The article had a lot of good information,'' she added. ``But a picture, as they say, is worth a thousand words. This picture is worth a thousand words to gang members. This says it is all right to carry a gun, in that you'll get acknowledgment in the newspaper for it.'' Bill Owens also said the story ``had a lot of truth.'' But, he said, a better accompanying photograph might have been taken of money-laundering in the city's financial district of ``white-collar guys counting the money that they have made off the black community.''
DOC.HEAD: SPJ Moving Headquarters to Indiana
DOC.TEXT: The Society of Professional Journalists' board of directors voted May 3 to move its headquarters to Greencastle, Ind., the site of the organization's founding in 1909 as Sigma Delta Chi at DePauw University. ``The society will be able to promote and improve the profession of journalism from Greencastle, where we can draw from DePauw's academic resources and traditions of excellence,'' Carolyn S. Carlson, SPJ president, said in a news release. The organization has been based in Chicago for more than 50 years. Ms. Carlson also announced the formation of an Industry Advisory Board to provide additional direction for the coming years. The board will be chaired by Jean Otto, associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News and president of the Sigma Delta Chi Foundation, the education arm of SPJ.
DOC.HEAD: Arrest Made in Tijuana Columnist's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A man sought in the slaying of popular journalist Hector ``Gato'' Felix is in custody in Tijuana, Baja California Gov. Ernesto Ruffo Appel announced May 1. Antonio Vera Palestina, former head of security at Agua Caliente racetrack in Tijuana, is one of two men accused in the killing of Felix, 47, who was gunned down April 20, 1988, as he drove to work. Ruffo said in a statement that Vera was returned to Tijuana from Southern California, where he was taken into custody by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies for allegedly being in the United States illegally. Victoriano Medina Moreno, a former guard at the racetrack, was sentenced last year to 27 years to life in prison for the murder of Felix. The journalist was co-editor of Zeta, a muckraking weekly tabloid. He died after being shot twice at close range with a 12-gauge shotgun. Co-Editor Jesus Blancornelas has charged repeatedly in the newspaper that although Vera may have been the triggerman, as authorities believe, investigators still must seek the ``intellectual author'' of the crime. Felix regularly lampooned Tijuana's elite in his gossip column, ``A Bit of Something.'' He was especially hard on Agua Caliente racetrack owner Jorge Hank Rhon, 35, in the weeks before his death. Rhon repeatedly and vehemently has denied any involvement, saying he had no reason to seek Felix's death.
DOC.HEAD: Flood of Anonymous Claims Leads to Caution
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a flood of phone calls and facsimile messages claiming responsibility for terrorist attacks, Colombia's news media are beginning to ignore the messages. The reason is simple _ it is impossible to tell who is really on the other end of the line. Drug traffickers? Police posing as drug traffickers? Leftist guerrillas? Pranskters? Until a few weeks ago, virtually all of Colombia's radio stations and newspapers used the statements without question. No one pointed out the information came from anonymous people and could not be verified. Recently, the country's two leading newspapers, Bogota's El Espectador and El Tiempo, chose not to publish news about some of the anonymous messages. An example of the confusion came after leftist presidential candidate Carlos Pizarro was killed April 26 by an assassin on a Colombian airliner. Within two hours, the anonymous telephone calls started. It was the Medellin cartel, one man said. Another president would be assassinated, he said. The next day brought another facsimile message, also supposedly from the Medellin cartel, to a Bogota radio station, Caracol. It wasn't us, the supposed cartel communique said. It accused the police of killing people and setting off bombs so that the cartel would be blamed. Another example came after a truck bomb in Medellin killed 20 people on April 11. Facsimile statements under the letterhead of the Extraditables, a name assumed by leaders of the Medellin cartel, said the cartel was not responsibile. Recently there have been facsimile and telephone messages from anonymous people claiming to speak for the cartel, saying those statements directly after the April 11 bombing were fakes. ``Somebody has been using us as their public relations office,'' a senior editor at a Bogota newspaper said April 28.

DOC.HEAD: Housewife Wants Station Admonished Over `Indecent' Material
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose campaign against talk show host Geraldo Rivera gathered support from some advertisers is asking the government to take action against a station that runs the show. Lynda Beams has asked the Federal Communications Commission to admonish KDFW-TV for broadcasting ``indecent'' programming during after-school hours. Mrs. Beams earned national attention when she persuaded some advertisers to pull their spots from the ``Geraldo'' talk show. She now claims that by airing ``Geraldo'' at 4 p.m. KDFW is violating FCC guidelines requiring that programming that panders to vulgar tastes not be aired before 8 p.m. The station has agreed to change ``Geraldo'' from its 4 p.m. time slot when the show's contract expires Sept. 1. Station manager Jeff Rosser sounded exasperated in discussing Mrs. Beams' drive. ``Enough's enough. I keep expecting Lynda Beams to claim victory,'' Rosser said. ``I am unaware of any brief she's filed, and I am a little bit surprised. But it's America and she's entitled.'' Rosser said that ``Geraldo,'' which is aired after school in about 130 markets, has toned down its topics since December. He said there has been a backlash of viewers who accuse the station of caving in to the assault by Mrs. Beams.
DOC.HEAD: Howell Named Washington Chief for Newhouse News Service
DOC.TEXT: Deborah Howell, editor of the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press, has been named Washington bureau chief for Newhouse newspapers and editor of the Newhouse News Service, the company announced May 2. Ms. Howell, 49, succeeds Robert G. Fichenberg, 70, who has been head of the Newhouse bureau in Washington since 1978. Fichenberg will retire in 1991 and in the meantime will serve as senior correspondent, the statement said. Ms. Howell was a reporter and editor at the Minneapolis Star before joining the Pioneer Press. She has been a Pulitzer Prize juror twice and was head of the Pulitzer public service jury in 1987. She was also on Harvard University's Nieman Fellows selection committee. Fichenberg was a newspaper editor and reporter for more than 30 years in New York state before joining Newhouse as Washington bureau chief in 1978.
DOC.HEAD: Byrd to Board Chairman, President of Winchester Evening Star, Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Thomas T. Byrd, publisher of The Winchester Star, has succeeded his father, former U.S. Sen. Harry F. Byrd Jr., as chairman of the board and president of Winchester Evening Star, Inc., the newspaper said May 1. Byrd began his newspaper career with the Star after graduating from Lynchburg College in 1971 and has served as business manager and general manager. Winchester Evening Star, Inc. also publishes three weekly newspapers: Amherst New Era-Progress, Nelson County Times and Front Royal-Warren Sentinel. The younger Byrd is also chairman of Page-Shenandoah Newspaper Corp., Inc., which publishes the Page News and Courier at Luray and the Shenandoah Valley-Herald at Woodstock.
DOC.HEAD: Strader to Publisher of The Meridian Star
DOC.TEXT: Jerry Strader, a veteran Texas newspaper executive, has been named publisher of The Meridian Star. The announcement was made by Larry J. Perrotto, president and chief executive officer of American Publishing Co. of Frankfort, Ill., which recently bought the newspaper. Strader, former editor and publisher of The McKinney (Texas) Courier-Gazette, will replace James B. Skewes, who is retiring. Strader is a past member of the board of directors of the Texas Daily Newspaper Association and Texas Press Association. He previously served in management capacities for newspapers operated by Harte-Hanks Newspapers of San Antonio. He was twice named Publisher of the Year by Harte-Hanks.
DOC.HEAD: Sowecke to Easton Express Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Timothy M. Sowecke has been appointed publisher of The Express, Thomson Newspapers announced May 4. He replaces Hal B. Neitzel, who led the Easton newspaper for a decade. Neitzel will retire on June 1 but will remain as a consultant to the newspaper and its three affiliated weeklies _ the Phillipsburg Free Press and the Star-Gazette and The Forum of Hackettstown. Sowecke has been general manager of the Chronicle-Telegram of Elyria, Ohio, since 1988. He began his career as a reporter for the Sandusky Register in 1973. After working in classified advertising sales and management for several Ohio papers, he was named general manager at Elyria. Neitzel joined Easton Publishing Co., former owner of The Express, as vice president in October 1979. He was elected president in 1980 and was named publisher of the newspapers when they were acquired by Thomson in January 1984.
DOC.HEAD: Arehart to General Manager of The Anchorage Times
DOC.TEXT: Gene R. Arehart, retired vice president and general manager of The Detroit News, was named general manager of The Anchorage Times on May 1. Arehart, 59, will direct all departments at the Times except news operations and the editorial pages, Publisher Bill Allen said. Arehart joined The Detroit News in 1972 as production manager. He also served as marketing director, business manager and circulation director before becoming general manager in 1980. He retired in January 1988 after serving through a transition period following the News' 1986 purchase by Gannett Newspapers. James H. Slack, acting general manager of The Times for the past two months, will be assistant to the general manager.
DOC.HEAD: Bessette Named Arizona Business Gazette General Manager
DOC.TEXT: Mary Lou Bessette, director of news and editorial resources for The Arizona Republic and The Phoenix Gazette, has been appointed general manager of the Arizona Business Gazette, a sister publication. Ms. Bessette previously held positions with the Gazette and Republic separately. She is a former reporter and managing editor for the Aurora (Ill.) Beacon-News and a former national board member of the Associated Press Managing Editors. The Gazette, Republic and Arizona Business Gazette are published by Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which is owned by Central Newspapers Inc. of Indianapolis.
DOC.HEAD: Golden to Publisher of McCall's
DOC.TEXT: Michael Golden, a former general manager of Child magazine, was named publisher of McCall's magazine on May 1. The move is part of a general reorganization of the monthly magazine, which has undergone changes since it was acquired last June by The New York Times Company Magazine Group, the company announced. Golden will replace John Beni, the magazine's publisher since 1988, who resigned. McCall's has a new design and editorial approach, and a new editor in chief, Anne Mollegan Smith. Golden was credited with vastly improving Child magazine during his two years there, according to a statement from the Times company, which owns both Child and McCall's, along with 15 other magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Wilson Elected Chairman of Canadian Publishers Association
DOC.TEXT: Paul Wilson, publisher of the Sault Star in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, was elected chairman of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers Association at its annual meeting May 2. Roger Landry, president and publisher of Montreal's La Presse, was elected vice chairman and treasurer, and Fred Mounce, president and deputy publisher of the Chronicle-Herald and Mail-Star of Halifax, Nova Scotia, was chosen as chairman-elect. Past chairman is K.A. (Sandy) Baird, publisher of the Kitchener-Waterloo (Ontario) Record.
DOC.HEAD: Deans Named Editor at Sun News
DOC.TEXT: Sue C. Deans was named editor and vice president of The Sun News on May 4, replacing Gil Thelen. Thelen was appointed executive editor of The State in Columbia. Both appointments at the Knight-Ridder newspapers take effect in June. Mrs. Deans has been managing editor of The Sun News since June 1987. She previously worked for 10 years at the Daily Camera in Boulder, Colo., as a reporter, city editor and assistant managing editor. Thelen succeeds Thomas L. McLean, executive editor of The State for the past decade. McLean will become the paper's editorial page editor, and both he and Thelen will become vice presidents of the State-Record Co. Thelen has been a reporter in Kansas City, Milwaukee, Washington and Chicago and for The Associated Press. Before going to The Sun News, he was assistant managing editor of The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer.
DOC.HEAD: Bruce Named Executive Editor of Longview News-Journal
DOC.TEXT: Jeff Bruce, executive editor of the Longview (Texas) News-Journal, has been named executive editor of Tribune Newspapers, succeeding Sandy Schwartz, who was promoted to general manager last month. Tribune Newspapers, owned by Cox Enterprises, publishes The Mesa Tribune, The Tempe Daily News-Tribune and The Chandler Arizonan-Tribune, all in suburban Phoenix. Cox also owns the Longview papers. Bruce previously was managing editor of another Cox paper, the Austin (Texas) American-Statesman, for 12 years. He also has worked at several Florida papers, including The St. Petersburg Times and The Miami Herald.
DOC.HEAD: Clark Named Plain Dealer Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Gary R. Clark, who has served in various editorial posts in 11 years at The Plain Dealer, has been appointed the Cleveland newspaper's managing editor. Publisher Alex Machaskee announced the appointment in the newspaper on April 29. Clark most recently has been the newspaper's city editor. He also worked as state editor and national editor. The promotion was one of 10 announced by the paper. J. Theodore Diadiun, metropolitan editor, was appointed assistant managing editor-metropolitan news. Features Editor Christine Jindra was appointed assistant managing editor-features. Assistant Managing Editor Maxine L. Lynch was appointed managing editor-personnel. Assistant City Editor John R. Griffith was promoted to city editor. Other appointments included that of Day City Editor Kevin P. O'Brien to suburban editor; Barbara Brucker-Galbicena to deputy suburban editor; Sunday Editor William O. Krohn to deputy features editor; Assistant News Editor Charles J. Caton to deputy news editor; and Assistant City Editor James G. Darr to deputy city editor.
DOC.HEAD: Brennan to Grand Island Independent Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Bill Brennan, managing editor of the Grand Island Independent for the past year, has been promoted to executive editor. He will be succeeded by Jeff Funk, managing editor of the Parsons (Kan.) Sun, said Editor-Publisher David Beliles of the Independent. Brennan joined the Independent in 1974. He succeeds Noel Hamiel, who resigned to take a job in Cincinnati. Funk has worked previously at the Beatrice Daily Sun and North Platte Telegraph in Nebraska, and the Hutchison (Kan.) News.
DOC.HEAD: Miller Named Telegrdaph-Forum Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Lisa K. Miller has been promoted to managing editor of the Telegraph-Forum, Publisher James Croneis said May 2. She succeeds Donald E. Wynn, who is retiring. Mrs. Miller, who joined the newspaper in 1980 as lifestyles editor, has been assistant to the managing editor the past five years. Croneis also announced the promotion of Donald E. Tudor to assistant editor and Daniel T. Clutter to sports editor. Tudor joined the Telegraph-Forum in December 1981 as Municipal Court reporter. He moved to the sports desk in 1984 and since 1985 has served as sports editor. Clutter joined the sports department in 1985 after a stint on The Galion Inquirer.
DOC.HEAD: Fadness Named Managing Editor of Fremont Tribune
DOC.TEXT: Gene Fadness, city editor of the Columbus Telegram, has been named managing editor of the Fremont Tribune, Publisher John McDougal announced. Fadness replaces Susan S. Russell, who has resigned. He was formerly Public Pulse editor and an editorial writer at the Omaha World-Herald. He also has been editor of the bi-weekly Fairbury Journal-News.

DOC.HEAD: Gazlay Named AP Assistant M.E. for Features
DOC.TEXT: Kristin Gazlay, who has been a reporter, editor and bureau chief for The Associated Press, is the AP's new assistant managing editor for features. Her appointment was announced April 30 by AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi. Ms. Gazlay, 32, has been the AP's special projects editor in New York since January. In that post she has worked closely with the assistant managing editor for features on planning, production and editing of AP's national enterprise report. Before her New York appointment, Ms. Gazlay was chief of bureau in Little Rock, where she directed AP operations for Arkansas. She joined the AP in Dallas in 1980 and was named correspondent in San Antonio in 1983. In 1984 Ms. Gazlay was named news editor for Texas, and she became assistant chief of bureau in Dallas later that year. Ms. Gazlay, a graduate of Southern Methodist University, succeeds Julia Dunlap, who resigned to join The Oregonian in Portland, Ore.
DOC.HEAD: Wessels to Director of Arizona Newspapers Association
DOC.TEXT: Fran J. Wessels has been named executive director of the Arizona Newspapers Association, President Robert B. Larson announced May 2. Wessels, who had been director of member services, succeeded James Evans, who resigned. Replacing Wessels as director of member services will be Deborah A. Stone, who had been serving as administrative assistant.
DOC.HEAD: Chavez Named City Editor at El Paso Herald-Post
DOC.TEXT: Ray Chavez, an El Paso native and journalism scholar, has been named city editor at the El Paso Herald-Post, Editor Tom King announced April 27. Chavez replaces Joe Old, who recently resigned to pursue other interests. Chavez rejoined the Herald-Post staff in January 1988 as an assistant city editor. He had been an assistant professor of journalism and editorial adviser of the student newspaper at the University of Texas at El Paso from 1982 to 1988. Chavez is a founding member of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists and has been active in a number of media organizations.
DOC.HEAD: David Stolberg Retiring from Scripps Howard
DOC.TEXT: David F. Stolberg, a Scripps Howard newspaperman and news executive for 38 years, will retire as the company's assistant general editorial manager, Scripps Howard announced May 1. Stolberg, 62, joined the company in 1952 as a reporter for the Rocky Mountain News in Denver. He was appointed city editor of the newspaper in 1960, became managing editor of The Washington Daily News in 1968 and assumed his current corporate position in 1975. He is to retire May 31 and a successor will be announced later, Scripps Howard said. Stolberg, on behalf of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, worked with the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati last year to set up a computer-access system to improve news media coverage of court decisions. He also helped establish the recently founded Society of Environmental Journalists, based in Washington.
DOC.HEAD: Jud Druck Retiring After 52 Years As Pharos-Tribune Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Justin M. ``Jud'' Druck will retire June 1 after 52 years as publisher of the Pharos-Tribune. Druck, 75, started in 1936 at the newspaper, which was owned by his uncle, S.O. Berman. Following Berman's death two years later, the 23-year-old Druck took over operation of the paper. In 1949, he bought the city's competing newspaper, the Logansport Morning Press. He operated the two with seperate editorial staffs for several years until the Press folded because of a circulation decline. In 1966, Druck sold the paper to Robert S. Howard and Howard Publications, staying on as publisher. Druck is a former president of the Hoosier State Press Association and former director of the Inland Daily Press Association.

George H. Beebe, who in a decades-long newspaper career helped guide The Miami Herald to a position of prominence, died April 30 of cancer. He was 80. Beebe helped found the World Press Freedom Committee in 1976 and served as its executive director and chairman of the anti-censorship alliance of 32 journalistic organizations. He also served as president of the Inter American Press Association. Beebe joined the Herald as a copy editor in 1944, served as managing editor in 1951-1966, then as senior managing editor until 1972, when he became an associate publisher and continued contributing travel articles. Survivors include his wife, Helen, three nieces and four nephews.

Thomas Boardman, who was editor of daily newspapers in Cleveland and Indianapolis, died of leukemia at his home May 4. He was 70. Boardman, who began his journalism career as a stringer covering Oberlin College for the Cleveland Press in 1939, worked his way through the ranks at the newspaper and was its editor from 1966 to 1979. The Press ceased publication on June 17, 1982. Before becoming editor of the afternoon newspaper, Boardman had served four years as editor of the Indianapolis Times, which has also ceased publication. He served in the Pacific during World War II and retired from the Naval Reserves as a captain. Boardman is survived by his wife, Cynthia, a son and a daughter, four grandchildren and a sister.

Robert H. Campbell, a retired Army colonel and former managing editor of the Washington Observer-Reporter, died April 30 after a long illness. He was 70. Campbell joined the staff of the Reporter in 1946 and was named promotion manager in 1952. When the Reporter merged with the Observer in 1967, he became associate editor and was named managing editor in 1972. In 1979, Campbell returned to the promotion department, which he directed until retiring in 1986. He worked part time for the newspaper until recently. Campbell is survived by his wife, Ruth; three daughters, a brother and six grandchildren.

Philanthropist Lenore Gantt Chandler, an original contributor to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the city's Music Center, died April 28. She was 97. A native of Texas, she was the widow of Ralph J. Chandler, a shipping executive and nephew of Harry Chandler, second publisher of the Los Angeles Times. Ralph Chandler died in 1966. The Chandler family was a major force behind the drive to give a home to the performing arts in Los Angeles with the construction of the $34 million Music Center, which opened 25 years ago. Mrs. Chandler is survived by a son, two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

Sister Annie Courage, a French nun who ran Roman Catholic radio and television stations in this central African nation, died in a car accident April 28. She was 45. Sister Courage died when the pickup truck she was riding in turned over near Mongo, 280 miles east of the capital, police said. She and the broadcast crew were traveling from N'Djamena to Bitkine, near Mongo, for the ordination of a priest, church sources said. Sister Courage had worked in the country for 20 years. She was in charge of all broadcasts by the church-owned radio and television stations in the largely Christian southern part of Chad.

W. Frank Gatewood, retired advertising vice president at The Washington Post, died May 1 of pneumonia at age 88. Gatewood joined the Post in 1954 when it bought the Washington Times-Herald, where he had been business manager. He retired from the Post in 1969. ``He was full of integrity, devotion and ability in the best sense of the word,'' said Katharine Graham, chairman of the board of The Washington Post Co. Gatewood is survived by his wife, Mae, three daughters and seven grandchildren.

George Haviland ``Chick'' Garrett Jr., former sports editor of the now-defunct Seattle Star, died May 2 at age 80. He went to work for the Star in 1933. After the paper folded he became a copy editor for the Seattle Times, then spent 27 years in the sports department of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer before retiring in 1976. Survivors include his wife, Marybelle; a son, a sister and five granchildren.

Nina Hyde, fashion editor of The Washington Post, died of cancer May 4 at age 57. In recent years, she devoted her energies to detection and treatment of the disease that was to kill her. The Nina Hyde Center for Breast Cancer Research was founded by designer Ralph Lauren and his friends a year before her death. Mrs. Hyde was a writer at Women's Wear Daily before joining the Washington Daily News. She moved to the Post in 1972 when the News was closed. She is survived by her husband, Lloyd S. Hyde, and two daughters.

Retired Baxley News-Banner Publisher Albert S. Jenkins, a former president of the Georgia Press Association, died May 1 of heart disease. He was 84. Jenkins, who bought the News-Banner in 1942, was editor and publisher until he sold the paper and retired in 1977. He was once head of a local renewal effort and the Baxley Planning Commission. Survivors include his wife, Dorothy, and two sisters.

Thomas C. Matts Sr., a former journalist and actor, died April 29 of emphysema. He was 66. Matts had worked for several Texas radio stations and for ABC News in Berlin. He also was a former editor of the Dallas Cowboys Insiders Newsletter and ``Bob Lilly's Football Fundamentals.'' As an actor he played Shelley Winters' husband in the 1983 movie ``Ellie.'' He also was cast in ``Bermuda Triangle.'' Survivors include his wife, Lou Noyola Matts, a son and two daughters.

Earl Brantley ``Brant'' Mewborn, senior editor of Rolling Stone magazine, died May 2 at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 38. Mewborn, a native of Greene County, N.C., was a resident of New York City and Woodstock, N.Y. Duke Medical Center spokeswoman Lisa Squires said it was against hospital policy to release Mewborn's cause of death. Survivors include his wife, Ronda, his parents and a sister.
DOC.HEAD: Elton Rule
DOC.TEXT: Elton H. Rule, the former ABC chief who was credited with the network's rise to broadcasting dominance in the 1970s, died of cancer May 5 at his home. He was 73. Rule, named president of ABC in 1968 and chief operating officer in 1972, introduced such innovations as the made-for-television movie and ABC Monday Night Football. During his ABC reign, the network added 68 affiliated stations, while ABC Radio Network grew by 1,435 affiliated stations. Rule is survived by his wife, Betty Louise Bender; three children, a grandson and a granddaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Post-Dispatch, Knight-Ridder Journalists Win Awards
DOC.TEXT: St. Louis Post-Dispatch correspondent-columnist Bill Lambrecht won the 46th annual Raymond Clapper Memorial Award on March 28 for a series on the export of U.S. garbage. Knight-Ridder Newspapers correspondent Christopher Scanlan was named winner of the Barnet Nover Memorial Award for a series on the effect of the budget crisis on government health care for veterans. The awards, which recognize excellence in reporting, were made by the Raymond Clapper Foundation and the Barnet Nover Foundation and were presented at the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner. Each also carried a $1,500 cash prize. Second place carried a $500 prize. John Hall of Media General was named the second-place Clapper winner for his series on the Navy's investigation of the explosion on the battleship Iowa. Andrew Melnykovych of the Casper Star-Tribune was named the second-place Nover winner for his series on federal oil and gas royalty audits and the nomination of James Cason to be assistant secretary of agriculture. The Clapper winners were selected from among 33 entries submitted to a panel of current and former Washington reporters. Raymond Clapper, a Washington correspondent and columnist for Scripps Howard Newspapers, was killed in an airplane crash while covering the invasion of the Marshall Islands in World War II. The Clapper award was established in 1944 to recognize a Washington-based newspaper writer whose work ``most clearly approximated the ideals of fair and painstaking reporting and good craftsmanship that were characteristic of Raymond Clapper.'' The Nover winners were selected from 24 entries submitted to a panel of five Washington journalists. Barnet Nover was bureau chief of The Denver Post's Washington bureau from 1947 to 1971. He also was a columnist for The Washington Post and a reporter with the Buffalo Evening News.
DOC.HEAD: Ketchikan's Lew Williams Jr. Honored by Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Retired publisher Lew M. Williams Jr. of Ketchikan was honored April 27 with a citation by the Legislature. Williams and his wife, Dorothy, retired Jan. 1 as publishers of the Ketchikan Daily News. They were succeeded at the family-owned newspaper by daughter Tena Williams and son Lew Williams III. The Legislature praised Williams in the citation as ``one of the most prominent figures in the news, community and political scenes in Southeast Alaska for most of his adult life.'' The citation recounts Williams' public service as mayor of Petersburg for five years before he moved to Ketchikan in 1966, and as a member of several state boards and commissions under four governors. ``We salute him for the many years of dedication to the communities he has resided in,'' the citation says. Williams continues to write a column for the newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: Columnist Wins Press Club Award
DOC.TEXT: New York Newsday columnist Murray Kempton will be the first recipient of the New York Press Club's Distinguished Service Award. Kempton, whose career spans five decades and who won the Pulitzer Prize for commentary in 1985, was called ``the obvious choice'' by club president Larry Celona. The presentation will be made at the club's annual awards and installation ceremony on May 24.

Turner Broadcasting System and ActMedia are joining forces to produce Checkout Channel, a satellite-delivered TV news program to be shown in grocery checkout lanes. A three-month test is scheduled in six cities starting in August ...``Saturday Night With Connie Chung,'' criticized for its re-creations of news stories, has been renewed for a second season on CBS. Chung says her show doesn't use re-creations often because they're too expensive, but she defends the technique, calling it ``a great way to tell a story when you couldn't tell it any other way.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Congress say serious budget negotiations with the White House now appear likely, with everything on the table _ including the possibility of new taxes. The leaders left the White House Sunday night after a private 90-minute meeting with President Bush saying they would be back for more talks with the president after consulting with other lawmakers. They said they discussed no specifics with Bush, but established that whatever negotiations take place will be without preconditions. House Speaker Tom Foley, asked if things now were on track for full-scale budget negotiations, said, ``I think that's going to be the outcome.''

Former hostage Frank Reed, in a riveting account of the brutal beatings he suffered at the hands of his captors in Lebanon, says he kept his spirits up by using matches to draw pictures of his family. He drew images of his Syrian-born wife, Fifi, and son, Tarek, on the ceiling and the door of his cell to remind himself that he must stay alive if he wanted to see them again, Reed said Sunday at a news conference. ``I knew ... if I didn't keep my life going there certainly wasn't going to be any Fifi or any Tarek,'' he said. ``And that permeates and transcends all of our thinking.'' Reed called for negotiations to free the remaining six Americans and 10 other Westerners held hostage, ``even if you have to get in bed with the devil.''

Pope John Paul II was cheered wildly by crowds as he began an eight-day visit he hopes will lead to restored diplomatic ties with this overwhelmingly Catholic nation that retains strict anti-clerical laws. In a gesture that indicated warmer relations lie ahead, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari changed plans at the last minute and met the pontiff at the airport Sunday instead of sending his foreign minister. Salinas, greeting the pope, said: ``Your visit is a new encounter with the generosity of a nation of many cultures, plural visions and deep religious sentiments.'' Since he took office two years ago, Salinas has encouraged improved ties with the Vatican while officials have widely ignored strict decades-old laws that intend to keep the church out of politics.

Republican James McClure's decision to retire from the U.S. Senate has set up a struggle between two would-be successors in a plot straight from a Frank Capra movie. Jim Jones, a plucky, populist attorney general with almost no cash or campaign staff, is giving five-term congressman Larry Craig a spirited but possibly futile run for his money in the May 22 Republican primary. ``I've always been an underdog in my political races,'' said Jones, who ran for the House twice before winning the state's top legal office in 1982. ``It's a role that I don't mind; you have to try harder.'' Craig, 44, is campaigning on his record and generally playing the role of the cautious, veteran politician above the fray.

A record flood crest on the rain-swollen Trinity River surged southward toward the Gulf of Mexico today, threatening to swamp rural areas along the way after devastating a Dallas suburb. Emergency workers helped sandbag rising streams in Arkansas, and a reservoir on the Texas-Oklahoma line that flooded shoreline homes reached a record height and kept rising. The death toll from the flooding caused by last week's thunderstorms stood at six today, all in Texas. Twelve Texas deaths have been blamed on weather in the past several weeks. The Red Cross in Texas counted 723 dwellings destroyed and more than 2,000 damaged in the last two weeks by the state's most serious flooding since 1908.

The White House put aside President Bush's pledge against new taxes and said Monday that talks to strike a budget deal with Congress will have ``no preconditions.'' Although Bush's position on taxes ``is well known,'' he wants ``an open debate that is unfettered with conclusions about positions taken in the past,'' said his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. Republicans involved in talks on Capitol Hill praised the White House's acknowledgement that all ways of reducing the deficit would be negotiable.

NATO's secretary-general rejected Soviet calls for German neutrality on Monday, saying a newly unified Germany must not only stay in the Western alliance but remain a base for its nuclear weapons. ``Our goal is clear _ we don't want a denuclearized Germany,'' Manfred Woerner told reporters. Woerner conferred with President Bush before leaving for a NATO meeting in Canada. He said it appears that despite weekend talks over the future of Germany Moscow has not yet accepted the Western allies' insistence that a reunited Germany be a member of NATO.

Two Colombians who claim links to the Medellin drug cartel were in custody Monday, accused of trying to buy Stinger missiles to use against aircraft carrying Colombian officials, the FBI said. The men agreed to hand over $1 million in cocaine profits as the down payment for a ``substantial number'' of the anti-aircraft missiles, federal authorities told reporters. FBI officials said a Stinger sells for about $14,000 on the legitimate arms market. The shoulder-fired missile uses an infrared homing device to aim itself at the heat generated by an aircraft's engine. It has proven highly effective against low-flying aircraft. The 4-foot-long, 35-pound missiles were to be used against official Colombian government aircraft, according to Allen McCreight, FBI chief in Tampa.

World Jewish Congress officials said Monday economic hardship has fueled anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe and they planned a solemn ceremony at the site where Nazis plotted the extermination of the Jews. On the second day of the congress' annual meeting, a U.S. Justice Department official said Washington has rejected Austrian President Kurt Waldheim's repeated requests for a lifting of the ban that keeps him out of the country. The official said the ban remains in effect because of Waldheim's role ``Nazi-sponsored persecution.'' The three-day meeting in Berlin is the Congress' first in Germany since the organization was founded in Switzerland in 1936 amid the horrors of the Third Reich.

A study has found evidence for the approximate location of a second defective gene that helps cause Alzheimer's disease, a possible step toward developing a therapy, a researcher said Monday. The gene appears linked to a form of the disease that runs in families and strikes at average age of 69, said Dr. Allen D. Roses of the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. Alzheimer's disease is a progressive, degenerative disorder that attacks the brain and impairs memory, thinking and behavior. An estimated 4.4 million Americans are affected, most of them older than age 65, according to the Alzheimer's Association. No cause or cure is known.

``Grand Hotel'' and ``City of Angels,'' two big musical productions, dominated the 1990 Tony Awards nominations announced Monday for the best of the Broadway season. ``Grand Hotel,'' a Tommy Tune musical set in 1920s Berlin, led the field in the musical category with 12 nominations. ``City of Angels,'' a 1940s Los Angeles detective musical, garnered 11. In the best-play competition, ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' an adaptation by Frank Galati of the John Steineck novel, received eight nominations. Its competition for best play includes ``The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson, ``Prelude to a Kiss'' by Craig Lucas and ``Lettice & Lovage'' by Peter Shaffer.

Convoys of Khmer Rouge trucks filled with the recent rice harvest move freely through this rural village in northwest Cambodia, and young guerrilla fighters flirt with relaxed villagers. In a scene played out in scores of villages in rural Cambodia in recent months, Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge have returned to areas they were driven out of when Vietnamese forces invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and installed a pro-Hanoi government. To much of the world, the Khmer Rouge are fanatics who killed hundreds of thousands of their countrymen during the 1970s in a savage bid to create a communist agrarian society.

The International Monetary Fund, struggling to meet increased financial needs in Eastern Europe and Latin America, worked Monday to resolve disagreements that have blocked a 50 percent boost in the agency's loan resources. Delegates to the spring meeting of the 152-nation agency expressed optimism that the IMF's policy-setting interim committee will reach an agreement by Tuesday, ending two years of debate on the issue. The increase would boost IMF resources from $120 billion to $180 billion, making $60 billion more available to support economic reforms in Poland and other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe.

Greyhound Lines' chairman said Monday the 2-month-old strike by bus drivers was ``irrelevant'' and effectively over, but strikers scoffed at the claim, and one compared it to Napoleon declaring victory at Waterloo. ``The strike is in effect concluded from the point of view of day-to-day operations,'' Greyhound Lines Inc. Chairman Fred G. Currey told reporters. He declared ``a new day in the life of the new Greyhound.'' Some union officials claimed Currey's statement was a publicity stunt to scare striking drivers back to work at the nation's only intercity bus company. The company's latest contract offer had included the elimination of 4,500 union jobs, a change from per-mile wage rates to hourly wage rates, plus a four-year wage freeze. The union called the proposal, made Saturday, an ``insult'' and officials refused to present it to membership. No further talks were scheduled.

Latvia promised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday that the Baltic republic will respect Soviet interests despite its declaration of independence, and expressed the hope that talks would open soon. Hours before, Gorbachev had asked for complete information about Latvia's independence declaration last Friday. Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov immediately assigned several members of Parliament to prepare a reply. Also Monday, Latvia's Parliament also elected a new prime minister, Ivars Godmanis, a physics professor and leader of the Popular Front.

Pope John Paul II, preaching on a muddy field in one of Mexico's most impoverished cities, urged the poor to follow the Roman Catholic Church and reject political leaders who deny God. ``Throughout history there have been many `pastors' _ leaders, dictators, chiefs, ideologues and creators of opinions or currents of thought _ who have tried to `shepherd' or guide the people toward artificial paradises,'' John Paul said in his homily to a joyous, flag-waving throng of 200,000 people. But the only true shepherd, said the pontiff, is one like Jesus Christ, who ``is ready to give his life for his sheep.'' All others, one after another, ``showed themselves to be false shepherds.'' The Polish-born pope alluded to the reforms that have swept Eastern Europe, saying the church had defended human rights crushed by ``political systems with an inhuman face.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Monday May 14 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Young Women Lead Japanese into Free-spending Life
DOC.TEXT: The transformation of Japan in two generations is embodied in Kimiko Omori, who scratched a living from the ruins of war, and her granddaughter, a child of prosperity who spends every yen she earns. Mrs. Omori, 70, was the privileged daughter of a prosperous restaurant owner. World War II changed everything. In 1950, in a devastated city, she became a kimono tailor. Hard work and prudence have left her comfortably fixed, but she gives her extra money to her children's families rather than treating herself to an afternoon of Kabuki theater or a trip abroad. Norie Omori, 22, lives in a world alien to her grandmother's experience. She is an unskilled office assistant at a Japanese securities firm, lives at home and earns the equivalent of about $640 a month after taxes. She gives $190 to her parents and spends the other $450 on clothes, cosmetics, eating out and skiing. Her grandmother doesn't think Norie is spoiled, but still, she shakes her head and says, ``Society has really changed.'' More and more, the pursuit of work yields to chasing pleasure, especially among the young. Many in Japan's working population still lead frugal lives, weighed down by high schooling costs and mortgages on houses priced at more than five times their annual incomes. Surveys show the average Japanese spends about half as much time on leisure pursuits as an American. The young, single woman has become Japan's big spender, and is a major target of those with something appropriate to sell. Like Norie Omori, she lives with her parents, pays little or nothing toward living expenses and has an office job she plans to hold only until marriage. With plenty of time and disposable income, she propels the fashion industry nearly $56.2 billion, travel industry $18.7 billion and publishing industry $13 billion. She travels with other young women to Hawaii and Australia, devours novels and magazines, buys the world's leading brand-name shoes, bags and perfumes, and goes to trendy restaurants. Her gifts for birthdays and Valentine's Day are generous and she spends thousands of dollars a year on golf or health club fees, according to a profile by Dentsu, Japan's largest advertising and marketing agency. Tokyo Disneyland, Japan's premier amusement park, overflows with young women. Female visitors to the park outnumbered males nearly 2-to-1 last year. ``Young adult females are the core of our repeat customers,'' said Disneyland spokesman Toshiharu Akiba. ``Leisure is here to stay. Unlike their parents, the younger generation knows the joy of taking holidays, and they have the knowledge, time and the money to spend.'' Of the 9 million Japanese who traveled abroad in 1989, about 780,000 were women aged 20 to 24. Men in the same age group, ambitious and less eager to take vacations, numbered only 430,000. In a magazine survey, 100 young women with office jobs in Tokyo said they spent an average of $554 a month on clothing, food and drink, athletics, language lessons and other non-essentials. They reported spending 13.5 hours a week on leisure activities, according to the May issue of Travail, a job-placement magazine for women. Japan became an economic powerhouse partly because of its people's sacrifices. Many Japanese who grew up with long work weeks, cramped houses and sky-high prices are bent on raising their standard of living. This follows the new national path desired by Japan's trading partners, who urge the Japanese to play and buy more as a way of reducing a $70 billion annual trade surplus with the world.

DOC.HEAD: Comedian Creates Stand-Up Comedy for the Deaf
DOC.TEXT: John Golub was selling used cars by day and playing comedy clubs by night when he mixed the two: While selling a car to a deaf woman, he slipped a joke into the written notes they were exchanging. She laughed. ``It just struck me right there that wouldn't it be great to make comedy accessible to deaf people,'' he said. Since that moment 10 years ago, Golub has sworn off the car trade. But he hasn't given up on comedy, and he hasn't given up on trying to reach people who can't hear the punchline. Golub has developed an act using a sign language interpreter and an infrared amplification device, and has brought hundreds of hearing-impaired people into comedy clubs for the first time. His shows are ``bringing people into the mainstream of recreation,'' said Ruth Green, head of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing. ``Comedy club owners never really realized there was an audience they were missing.'' Green's organization has supported Golub's efforts since he moved from Los Angeles six years ago. With the league's cooperation, he organized comedy benefit shows every year since in 1985. This year, there are four. Golub is 32, squarely built and energetic. He has a personal stake in the welfare of the deaf; he has two sisters who cannot hear. He tries to avoid making changes in his act to accommodate the deaf. His intention, he says, is not to develop two different audiences, but rather to integrate the deaf into the hearing audience. ``When I do these shows, I want it to be a show that anyone can enjoy, deaf or hearing.'' Still, some jokes don't translate well to the deaf, and interpreter Mara Zuckerman _ who has worked with Golub at every benefit _ says she sometimes has to explain this to the comedians. Jokes about popular culture from television or radio often do not work. One performer parodied the theme song from the television show ``Rawhide.'' But the act would bomb with a deaf audience because few deaf people have ever watched the show or heard the theme music. Puns and rhymes don't work with the deaf. Nor do impressions. ``They're not going to know something sounds like Cary Grant,'' Zuckerman says. But visual humor _ mime and physical impersonations, such as a funny walk or a parody of a famous rock musician _ often works. Dirty jokes also get laughs, she says: ``Most sexually related signs are very graphic, so both the deaf audience and the hearing audience get a kick out of that.'' At a recent benefit in Stamford, Conn., one comic asked an embarrassed couple in the audience whether they had ``done it yet.'' ``Oh, I'm sorry,'' he quickly apologized. ``It's none of my business, but I was just interested in seeing how Mara signed that one.'' That Zuckerman _ despite her protests _ often serves as the comedians' foil is an indication of the importance of the interpreter. Standing off to the side of the small stage during a recent benefit show, the black-clad Zuckerman interpreted for the night's three comics and gave quite a performance herself. Even though she moved her feet little, she used a wide range of facial expressions and body movements to convey humor. Always just a fraction of a second behind the comic, she gestured quickly with her hands and arms as she translated the jokes. Still, Zuckerman stays as close as possible to the traditional role of interpreter, despite comedy's non-traditional demands. ``If a comic is going to get up there and be bawdy, I'm not there to change his act to make it more palatable to the audience or funnier or less funny,'' she said. ``If he's going to bomb, then I'm going to let him bomb.'' But sometimes, she joins in the fun. At the start of one show, Golub jumped on stage and quickly announced, ``I'm going to talk really fast''; Zuckerman reacted by glaring at Golub, and the two stared at each other for seconds. The interpreters serve some of the hard of hearing; others listen to what is being said with the aid of the infrared system. Often found in theaters, auditoriums and churches, the system converts the electrical signal from the microphone into infrared light. This light is then transmitted throughout the club; hard-of-hearing members of the audience wear wireless headsets that pick up the signal and amplify it. Golub's shows have not all been sellouts, but the League for the Hard of Hearing deems them a success. Golub envisions a national comedy tour to benefit the hard of hearing. He has a dream of making comedy accessible to all deaf people in the United States. ``Who am I?'' he said. ``I'm nobody. ... But I think I can have an effect as a nobody.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, May 19, the 139th day of 1990. There are 226 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On May 19, 1536, Anne Boleyn, the second wife of England's King Henry VIII, was beheaded after she was convicted of adultery. (Anne had fallen from Henry's favor because their marriage did not result in any male heirs; however, she did give birth to a daughter, who later became Queen Elizabeth I.) On this date: In 1780, a mysterious darkness enveloped much of New England and part of Canada in the early afternoon. The cause has never been determined. In 1906, the Federated Boys' Clubs, forerunner of the Boys' Clubs of America, were organized. In 1921, Congress passed the Emergency Quota Act, which established national quotas for immigrants entering the U.S. In 1926, inventor Thomas Edison was called upon to speak on radio during the dinner of the National Electric Light Association in Atlantic City, N.J. (Faced with the microphone, Edison said: ``Why, I don't know what to say. This is the first time I ever spoke into one of these things. Good night.'') In 1935, T.E. Lawrence, better known as ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' died in England following a motorcycle crash. In 1943, in an address to the U.S. Congress, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill pledged his country's full support in the war against Japan. In 1958, the United States and Canada formally established the North American Air Defense Command. In 1964, the State Department disclosed that 40 hidden microphones had been found in the U.S. embassy in Moscow. In 1967, the Soviet Union ratified a treaty with the United States and Britain banning nuclear weapons from outer space. Ten years ago: Angry homeowners at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., detained two Environmental Protection Agency officials for nearly five hours, demanding the federal government evacuate the neighborhood because of toxic chemical contamination. Five years ago: Residents of the Philadelphia neighborhood ravaged by fire in a police confrontation with the radical group ``MOVE'' gathered for Sunday services to seek solace. One year ago: The NCAA announced sanctions against the University of Kentucky's basketball program for recruiting and academic violations. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average passed the 2,500 mark, ending the day at 2,501.10. Today's Birthdays: PBS newscaster Jim Lehrer is 56. TV personality David Hartman is 55. Author Nora Ephron is 49. Rock singer-composer Peter Townshend is 45. Singer-actress-model Grace Jones is 38. Singer Joey Ramone is 38. Baseball catcher Rick Cerone is 36. Thought for Today: ``If every nation gets the government it deserves, every generation writes the history which corresponds with its view of the world.'' -- Elizabeth Janeway, American author.

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Tues May 08 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout Chief's Departure Plans Follow Predictable Script
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Bill Seidman can be a hard man to get along with, but the White House may find he's even harder to get along without. Seidman has been both a leading man and a lightning rod in the savings and loan bailout. While his policy dissents have made the administration uncomfortable, his role provided political insulation. President Bush will lose that when Seidman leaves, probably in the fall. There'll be no argument over the credentials of William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's bank supervisor, to take over Seidman's dual role as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. And he is likely to prove as independent as Seidman. But Taylor will be a lot quieter about it. Seidman _ L. William is the name on the letterhead _ is out front, outspoken, a very public public figure. That's made him a popular man in Congress and with the news media, and an irksome one to some people in the administration, among them the high command at the Treasury and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. Seidman, now 69, was appointed to the FDIC post by President Reagan for a term that runs until October 1991, and the franchise was expanded when Congress passed the savings and loan bailout bill last year. The FDIC now insures both bank and savings and loan depositors, and the Resolution Trust Corp. sells the assets of failing S&Ls closed by the government. The chairman is appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate for a six-year term. Once he's there, he's independent; the president can't oust him. But there are ways. Seidman had said he planned to leave before his term was up, and hoped he could do so after getting the S&L rescue effort off to a good beginning. He also had sounded alarms about rising costs, complained about bureaucratic delays in the bailout, and dismissed some administration suggestions, sometimes with a wisecrack. And so there appeared in The Washington Post on May Day a report that Seidman had met with Bush in mid-April, had said he wasn't going to complete his full term, and had been encouraged to end it sooner rather than later. From that point, the script was predictable. When a president wants somebody to leave the government, it is customary that he praises the man's performance and says that he respects the fellow's wish to move on. Seidman knows the way it works. He's been around Republican politics for more than 30 years and he served in the White House as an economic aide to President Ford. ``Bill has indicated that he's not going to stay the whole term, and we are interested in getting new leadership there that will carry out an aggressive program when the time comes,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. That stirred Democratic congressional demands that Bush push Seidman to stay, for his credibility and demonstrable independence as the chairman of a bailout in which estimated costs are soaring. ``You do not solve these problems by shooting the messenger,'' said Rep. Bruce F. Vento, D-Minn., who heads a House task force on the RTC. ``Hey, listen,'' Bush countered, ``If all the people that brought bad news in here were asked to do something else, it would be a little lonely.'' Bush said Seidman had done a good job, with grace and ability, and had made his own decision to leave. ``And he also said, `Look, I understand if you might want to put your own person in there,''' the president said Thursday. ``It's his initiative with me, and today he suggested the name of a Bill Taylor who we're very high on to take over.'' The president inherited the savings and loan crisis and made the rescue bailout bill one of his earliest priorities. The initial cost estimate was $257 billion; that's now up to at least $325 billion and probably more. The General Accounting Office says the price could be $500 billion over 30 years. That's too costly not to become a political issue at some point. That may be hastened by Seidman's departure. It's an inherited mess, and both parties collaborated in letting it happen. But Bush is in charge now, and when his nominee takes over as the central figure in the bailout, his administration will have full custody of a no-win process. ``Don't be impatient,'' Seidman told a House hearing on Friday. ``This is a long, hard job. It isn't going to be accomplished any time soon.''
Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ The idea is to collect unmarketable food from supermarkets and distribute it to the needy. The supermarket gets a tax break and hungry people get something to eat. The concept has generated a network of food banks that last year distributed $846 million worth of food. But some wonder if this is a solution or part of the problem.

A woman scavenging in a supermarket's garbage to feed her 10 children gave Phoenix soup kitchen volunteers the idea. Why not gather wasted food and make it available to people who need it? ``It was meant to be just a little emergency program taking pressure off social workers,'' says John van Hengel, who founded the nation's first food bank in Phoenix in 1967. Today, that ``little emergency program'' is a network of 200 food banks linked by Second Harvest, an 11-year-old organization second only to the government in providing food to the needy. Last year, Second Harvest food banks distributed 419 million pounds of food and other products worth roughly $846 million to 39,700 soup kitchens, food pantries, and other non-profit programs. There are food banks independent of this network, but Philip R. Warth Jr., Second Harvest president and chief executive officer, says almost all ``legitimate'' food banks are affiliated. ``If you're a Second Harvest food bank, it's as if you've got the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval,'' says Catherine D'Amato, executive director of the Western Massachusetts Food Bank. In some segments of the hunger community, however, there is concern. Pointing to Second Harvest's dominance and its ties to the food industry, which provides board members and financial support as well as food, some food bankers and activists wonder whom the network really serves, the hungry or the donors. ``When somebody says we're leaning more toward the industry, well, heck. It's their food,'' Warth says. ``If we can't make it work from the industry's standpoint, we sure can't make it work from the food bank's standpoint.'' Reducing waste by distributing food in an efficient, cost-effective way fulfills the mandate of food banking, he says. ``We are not an anti-hunger organization. We are a service provider, helping people who fall through the cracks.'' Some critics, however, contend that some of its promotional materials suggest otherwise. They cite, for example, a direct-mail brochure soliciting donations headlined ``Hunger in America, Solutions From Second Harvest.'' Food banks are ``simply a mechanism to warehouse and distribute unmarketable food,'' says Christina Walker, a former board member of Food for Survival, a New York food bank. ``There's nothing wrong with that. It's in promoting food banks as an effective and cost-efficient remedy to poverty and hunger that a major problem arises.'' Warth says the brochure is accurate. ``We feel that we are a solution to the symptom of hunger.'' At the same time, Second Harvest is ``awfully quick to say to the public as well as to Congress that we do not hold ourselves up as having the role, the responsibility or the wherewithal to eliminate hunger in America.'' Further stirring controversy about whom Second Harvest serves is the questionable nutritional value of some donations, and the fact that roughly a fifth of its ``product'' isn't food at all. ``It's cleaning fluid and detergent and hand lotion. It's the way every business in America unloads stuff that isn't moving in the stores,'' says Nancy Amidei, former executive director of the Washington, D.C., Food Research and Action Center, the leading research and advocacy group on hunger. Warth says Second Harvest ``was founded on the notion of surplus. ... almost anything being produced by the industry would be of some use to the individuals and charities being served.'' The Toledo@Northwest Ohio Food Bank's inventory recently included salad dressing, cake mixes, bread crumbs, frozen pizza, apple butter, cereals, mint sauce, tostada shells, flour, crackers, pie crust mix, muffin mix, soda, chocolate milk, butter pats, pasta, sausage, cheese, frozen potatoes, zucchini and carrots. It also listed calendars, home permanent kits, soap, cold medicines, aspirin, bandages, copper cleaner, shoes, socks, toys, underwear, T-shirts, laundry detergent and Christmas ornaments. Bill Bolling, executive director of the Atlanta Food Bank, points out that food stamps can only be used to buy food. ``Whenever we can get good non-food items, agencies need that,'' he says. Catherine D'Amato agrees, to a point. ``Diapers are extremely useful. Wallpaper? No.'' Warth says such products of marginal value account for a relatively small percentage. While Second Harvest makes a concerted effort to capture nutritious foods, the nature of food banking is such that ``we'll never get as much food as we want, and we'll always be reactive.'' Food distributed by Second Harvest food banks ``probably amounts to less than one-tenth of 1 percent of all the food produced in this country,'' Warth says. Compared with federal food programs, he says, Second Harvest accounts for about 1{ percent of all food assistance in the nation. Even that 1{ percent, however, makes Second Harvest the nation's second-largest provider of food to the needy. And to J. Larry Brown, chairman of the Physician Task Force on Hunger in America and a leading critic, the issue isn't the amount of food, it's ``the perception by government that it can use Second Harvest as a key player. Any number of members of Congress who don't want to expand food programs point to the private system as a major player.'' Rep. Bill Emerson, R-Mo., the ranking Republican on the House Select Committee on Hunger, supports legislation calling for an additional $2.3 billion for food programs over the next three years. At the same time, ``I absolutely do see Second Harvest as a major player,'' says Emerson, who wants some of that money used to buy surplus commodities to be distributed by food banks and other private agencies.

UNDATED: private agencies.
DOC.TEXT: While bringing hunger to the public's attention is part of Second Harvest's mission, Warth says, ``we are not about providing systemic change. That has got to come from elsewhere in our society.'' In fact, Second Harvest largely stays out of politics, he says. ``If we grind too many political axes one way or another we're going to lose the credibility of the people we work with.'' Brown contends that with prominence and prosperity come responsibility. ``With the network and money they raise, they have an ethical obligation to speak to the root causes of hunger.'' At its downtown Chicago headquarters, the white walls, gray carpets and green plants set a sleek, corporate tone that mirrors the image Second Harvest presents to the food industry. One reason for its success has been a system that makes it easy to donate and that emphasizes cleanliness, efficiency and quality control, critical issues to the food industry, which puts a premium on brand protection and meticulous product-handling. In most cases, a single phone call by a manufacturer or retailer sets the system in motion. One of Second Harvest's 30 Chicago staff members determines the nature and location of the donation, then relays the information to one of three regional offices. The product is then allocated to specific food banks, which assume responsibility for transporting it. Of the 419 million pounds of food distributed to agencies last year, 172 million pounds was donated by way of this national network. The rest was donated to food banks locally. Food companies are entitled to a tax deduction equal to the cost of producing the goods plus half the unrealized profits, adjusted for damage and reduced shelf life. The value to the food industry has never been calculated. Warth calls it ``consequential but not compelling,'' but says it's not typically lucrative for companies to donate food. In a 1989 survey, 85 percent of food industry representatives queried said the tax break was an important factor in their decision to donate food. Warth says Second Harvest is organized along corporate lines because it's the most efficient way to do business. ``My board has made it clear that my job is to make this organization as efficient and effective as possible.'' If that sends a reassuring message to private industry, it also makes some food bankers uncomfortable. ``There's a bunch of corporate people in there with a bunch of degrees that do not belong in food banking. They have no idea what the concept is,'' says Lori Waggoner, office manager at the Toledo-Northwest Ohio Food Bank. ``The institution has become insensitive. They've lost touch with the way the rest of us worship in this religion,'' says Tom Ferraro, executive director of the Genesee Valley Regional Food Clearinghouse, a Second Harvest food bank in Rochester, N.Y. ``I'm not necessarily anti-white glove sanitation inspections or paperwork. That's needed to be accountable and responsible not only for taking corporate donations, but also for handling food that we're giving people to eat,'' Ferraro says. He's more bothered by a ``a kind of media slickness'' in Second Harvest's marketing in recent years. Warth says marketing ``makes us successful, just like anybody else. If you can't market yourself, you can't be successful. It's a fact of life that we're in a very competitive environment.'' But Ferraro says marketing efforts have gone too far. ``I'm not 100 percent opposed to packaging; some of it's necessary. But this is too much. I don't know if decisions are made on the basis of what's right and ethical, or if they're based on what some poll said would be best for public perception.'' At the same time, Ferraro acknowledges that for many food bankers, Second Harvest is a convenient scapegoat. Though food banks weren't designed to meet long-term nutritional needs, rising housing costs and shrinking public programs have forced many Americans to rely on donated food. Like many food banks, D'Amato's now buys high-protein foods such as peanut butter, chicken and beef to supplement the kinds of items that are most often donated: chips, cookies, cereal, juice and ice cream. It also grows food and makes vegetarian chili. Distributing more nutritious food is one way for food banks to better serve their communities, says Marc A. Thibodeau, a former Boston Food Bank board member. Zeroing in on high-risk populations _ pregnant women, infants, young children and old people _ is another. ``I think of hunger as largely a medical problem with severe medical ramifications, but food banking doesn't run programs designed to address that,'' Thibodeau says. ``If volunteers are going to bother to go to all this trouble, they should move beyond Second Harvest's rather myopic goal of eliminating food waste and try to have the private sector fill in gaps where government doesn't reach.'' Ferraro is among those searching for ways to broaden food banking's mission. He's using his Rochester food bank's warehouse to teach job skills to four disadvantaged teen-agers. The four-month program, designed with help from local food companies, covers shipping, receiving, sanitation, equipment and computer skills. Graduates will go to work for participating companies, and a new group of teen-agers will begin training. ``I think there's a real obligation that comes with having tax-exempt status. It means we should do some of the hard things. ``Doing outreach and advocacy as well as food banking makes us more of a comprehensive hunger-fighter,'' Ferraro says. ``Adding employment and training really puts the emphasis on systemic root causes, and not just on throwing dented cans at the symptoms.''

From AP Newsfeatures
With BC-APN--Feeding the Hungry-II
DOC.TEXT: Each Wednesday morning, a crowd gathers in a parking lot on the southwest corner of Toledo, outside the basement of Our Lady of Lourdes. As the church doors open, Bob and Ginny Pacholski assume their posts behind the soup kitchen serving counter, just as they have every Wednesday for eight years. ``We thought we'd do this for two or three years at the most, until the recession ended,'' says Pacholski, who opened his Hospitality Kitchen in 1982. Now, though, there's no end in sight. Roughly 600 men, women and children make their way through the food line every week, so many that the Pacholskis must assign them all numbers and serve them in shifts. The overflow crowd stands patiently outside the door, waiting to be called over the microphone Bob uses to keep things moving. The long cafeteria tables are packed, and the traffic between serving line, tables and door is heavy. The majority of clients are single men, old women and mothers with young children, although a number of two-parent families are here, too. ``We treat people with dignity,'' says Pacholski. A retired real estate agent, he's tanned and fit-looking with kindly blue eyes that continually sweep the tables searching for empty seats. Clinking flatware, scraping chairs and the muffled roar of dozens of conversations fill the room. Once the schools let out in June, the number of children will skyrocket, and noise levels will increase appreciably. Like most soup kitchens, the Pacholskis' does not require its clients to show identification. Those receiving the boxes of federal surplus commodities being dispensed at the far end of the room are required to prove need, with unemployment compensation cards or other such documentation. ``It used to be all general relief or AFDC (Aid to Families With Dependent Children). Now, we're seeing people unemployed, people laid off,'' Pacholski says. ``The first week we opened, we had 23 people. By that August, we had 1,013.'' Lately, in a typical month, the kitchen serves 2,400 people, although the numbers are once again going up. Today's menu includes barbecued pork sandwiches made of canned pork from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, as well as chicken, spaghetti, rice, corn, broccoli, peaches, rolls, doughnuts and cookies. Pacholski shops at the Toledo SeaGate Food Bank, which collects edible but unmarketable food for use by non-profit agencies at minimal cost. Behind the serving counter are several donated birthday cakes. Nobody seems to mind the smudged icing, judging from the number of celebrants lining up to pick out cakes. ``They're very popular,'' Bob says with a salesman's pride. Regulars at the soup kitchen include 70-year-old Marcile Battle, who until recently was supporting eight children along with her 92-year-old mother on a $182 monthly Social Security check and $63 worth of food stamps. Three of the children are cousins, girls aged 8, 5 and 3. ``The 5-year-old was 3 days old when she came to me. The 8-year-old was 2 months,'' says Mrs. Battle, who says she's been declared ineligible for welfare benefits. ``The other kids had parents, but they left the kids with me. In July of 1989, they said they were going to a funeral. That funeral never did end.'' A social worker from children's services finally picked up the children, bringing the size of Mrs. Battle's family back down to five. She says situations like hers aren't unusual, and blames them on Toledo's drug problem. The weekly lunch at the Hospitality Kitchen and the carefully wrapped leftovers she carries home help stretch her meager food budget, says Mrs. Battle, whose husband died three years ago. No matter how strapped she is, ``I always share.'' ``Food stamps buy me one trip to the grocery store, and the groceries last til the middle of the month. I can't keep up with the bills. It's hard.'' Though grateful for the help the Pacholskis gave her, Mrs. Battle says she finds eating at the soup kitchen hard. ``I would prefer to buy my own groceries. I like to try to feed my own self. I'd rather any day to help someone else than to have someone else helping me.''
