DOC.TEXT: DETROIT (AP) _ Good nutrition is just what the doctor ordered for nearly 850,000 Detroit residents. They're enrolled in the Focus: HOPE Food Prescription Program, one of the oldest and biggest supplemental food programs for people in high-risk groups: low-income pregnant and postpartum women, their children up to age 6, and the elderly. Each month, participants push grocery carts down the aisles of one of five Focus: HOPE food centers, stocking up on milk, fruit, meat, butter, vegetables, cheese, cereal, rice, dried beans, peanut butter, instant potatoes, egg mix and juice. There are six food ``prescriptions,'' depending on a participant's age. Having filled the appropriate one, the shopper then passes through a checkout counter complete with a bar-code scanner to speed things up. Similar foods are available to qualified people in two dozen cities under the Commodity Supplemental Food Program of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. But in Detroit, ``we do things differently,'' says Eleanor Josaitis, who co-founded Focus: HOPE, a civil and human rights organization, in the aftermath of the 1967 riots. One difference in the Detroit program is how it looks. Focus: HOPE food centers resemble grocery stores. ``We try to set things up where people can come in, get their carts and do their own shopping,'' Josaitis says. ``If a mother comes into the food center with a small child and pushes a shopping cart, that child may see his mother as just going to the grocery store. She may not have a lot of choices, but if she wants to pick one item over another _ green beans, say, instead of corn, she can do that. It's a small thing, but it's a symbol of dignity, of how we like to treat people.'' The food centers also are equipped with closed-circuit televisions that run ads encouraging people to look into other Focus: HOPE programs, such as employment training, housing, day care and education. Agencies in a number of cities have modeled programs after Detroit's, says Josaitis, who held a national conference two years ago to share information about its principles and design. The food packages, designed by a dietician, are intended as supplements, although infants are given a full month's supply of formula. The USDA buys the food. ``By using the national purchasing power, we can provide food to three times as many people,'' says Josaitis. She says 846,613 people filled food prescriptions last year. When the program began in 1971, it served 85,058. Senior citizens with incomes up to 130 percent of poverty ($7,774 for a one-person household), and women with incomes up to 185 percent of poverty ($11,063 for one) are eligible. Once accepted, each participant is entitled to six monthly trips to the food center. They then must be rescreened, by the state Health Department or a private doctor. If their condition is unchanged, they continue on the program another six months. A network of 40,000 volunteers provides transportation or food delivery to those who need it. It also builds awareness of the hunger problem. ``I believe you have to be touched by it,'' says Josaitis. ``If people don't see or feel an injustice they can't be part of the solution.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ He's the last survivor of the Big Four of the early civil rights movement. Now 70 and blind, James Farmer, founder of the Congress of Racial Equality, is teaching a special class at a predominantly white college in Virginia. This is the first of an intermittent series called Class Act, about prominent men and women in various fields who have returned to the campus to share their expertise.

The distinguished visiting professor with the patch over his right eye tugs at a tweed sleeve and bends an ear to his chiming wristwatch. ``Twenty-eight minutes past one,'' James Farmer announces in that resonant, mellifluous voice to a hushed class of 40 juniors and seniors, leaning forward, pens poised over notebooks. ``As I was saying, those troopers were bellowing, `Come on out, Farmer. We know you're in there.' ``I was meant to die that night. They were kicking open doors, beating up blacks in the streets, interrogating them with electric cattle prods. I got out alive in a hearse.'' It was a lovely spring day on the campus of predominantly white Mary Washington College, a state institution in historic Fredericksburg, Va. Bright sunshine slanting through the budding trees gave a roseate glow to the white-columned Georgian brick buildings. But the imposing black figure at the lecture desk in Monroe Hall was wrapped in the darkness of another time, in another Southern state. He couldn't see the azaleas blushing at the windowsill or sniff the cherry blossoms just come into bloom around the fountain in the square. There was too much tear gas billowing through the busted windows of the Plymouth Rock Baptist Church in Plaquemine, La. And the splashing fountain brought back the swoosh of the fire hose washing hymn books and Bibles down the aisle as the mob smashed pews and ransacked the church. ``Scared spitless,'' Farmer says, recalling that violent summer night a quarter of a century ago. One moment he's a terrified Freedom Rider pleading with the local telephone operator to put a call through ``to the White House, the attorney general, the FBI in New Orleans.'' Then he's a redneck deputy, snarling through jowls chock-full of chaw, ``We know you're in there, Farmer.'' Next he's the spunky lady operator of the funeral parlor down the street telling him to ``play dead in the back of that hearse'' and ordering the driver to take dirt roads known only to blacks since plantation days. Then he's himself, the founder of CORE, the Congress of Racial Equality, wondering if that night in Louisiana, less than a week after the march on Washington and Martin Luther King's ``I had a dream'' speech, would be his last on Earth. ``This guy is tremendous,'' says senior Eric Cooper, one of the students in Farmer's course, ``The History of the Civil Rights Movement,'' a full three-credit course in the history department. ``He's a living piece of history. It's hard for students our age to imagine an America where blacks could not go into a restaurant, had to ride in the Jim Crow coach next to the engine and were hunted down like possums or some other swamp dweller for daring to register to vote. ``Here is a man who has changed history. He's seen it all, and now the tragedy is he sees nothing.'' But in the classroom the now totally blind champion of civil rights sees something he never saw before in his 70 years _ a ray of hope, ``just a glimmer.'' ``The hope for America is with these young people,'' he says, gathering up a bundle of their term papers. ``Their minds are not closed. At the beginning of the semester, black kids and white kids alike find it difficult to grasp that this is the way things were here.'' With Martin Luther King, Roy Wilkins and Whitney Young now dead, Farmer is the last of the Big Four of the civil rights movement. ``We were the knights of the round table,'' he chuckles, counting the nine steps down to the taxi taking him home for a brief rest before facing an evening class of nearly 200 freshmen and sophomores. Farmer is now in his fifth year at the college named for George Washington's mother, where in a student body of 3,500, two-thirds are female and 4 percent black. The preacher's kid from Marshall, Tex., who grew up on a series of black Baptist campuses, where his father, a Ph.D. from Boston University, taught theology, is still at it, preaching, teaching with compelling charm a non-violent approach to racial harmony. Eloquently he drives home the ``fundamental lesson of the civil rights movement: Be better than your former self, not better than the South Africans, and thereby make a better world.'' Students are awed at Farmer's lack of bitterness toward those who have wronged him and his race. Sherry Brinser, a Spanish major from Richmond, says, ``He's fascinating. It all happened to him, and yet there's no bitterness. None. How can he forgive what he can't forget?'' In the Eagle's Nest, the student snack bar, some compared Farmer with the actor James Earl Jones: the rich voice, the fullback's build, the features borrowed from a Roman coin, the deep infectious laughter, the mimic's ability to play all parts. They cited the morning lecture when he was suddenly the owner of a diner on U.S. Route 1 between New York and Baltimore, turning away young blacks trying to integrate eateries along what they had renamed ``Freedom Highway.'' ``We don't serve Negroes here.'' ``Well, that's fine by us,'' Farmer replies in his own voice. ``We don't eat them.'' ``He's very expressive. You think you're right there,'' says Patty Charron, a junior from Springield. Va. ``But he's a lot more than just a performer,'' insists Rich Cooper, from Pittsburgh. ``He speaks from the heart. It's not like a lecture, it's personal history. Others graduating with me agree his is one of the five classes you should take before leaving here.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
FREDERICKSBURG, Va.: leaving here.''
DOC.TEXT: In his campus office, surrounded by plaques, awards and 19 honorary degrees, Farmer says, ``Two-thirds of the graduates have gone through my class. About 500 a year. A Japanese girl, one of my brightest students, came here just to attend my class.'' ``Once thought of becoming a doctor,'' he reminisces, his hands laced behind his head. ``Couldn't stand the sight of blood. That's another of life's jokes, considering all the busted heads I've seen.'' Instead, he studied for the ministry at Howard University in the nation's capital, where his father taught the New Testament and Greek. But he decided against ordination ``because the Baptist church, like others, was still segregated. Even today, to this nation's shame, segregation is nowhere as complete as at 11 o'clock on a Sunday morning.'' Taking up the civil rights struggle at age 22, Farmer employed the Gandhi techniques of non-violence to organize a sit-in at the Jack Spratt Coffee House in Chicago in May, 1942. Thus began CORE. ``A lot of soup was dumped over heads and garbage jammed into sandwiches,'' he says, before the movement was strong enough to invade the South with unarmed legions of black and white Freedom Riders. In later years, Farmer was a union organizer, ran for Congress in Brooklyn, N.Y., and lost to Shirley Chisholm, went on the lecture circuit and engaged in a memorable debate with Malcolm X. He angered his liberal friends by serving as assistant secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Nixon administration. His personal life was never easy. There was resentment among both his black and white friends against his devoted wife Lula, who was white and his staunchest supporter. She died in 1976 after a long, debilitating battle with Hodgkin's disease. In 1979, Farmer lost the sight of his right eye to retinal vascular occlusion, a rare disease that he thinks was brought on by those hours of exposure to tear gas in Louisiana. ``But the doctors say there is no evidence in the literature.'' He reached Chapter 6 in ``Lay Bare The Heart,'' his poignant autobiography, when the left eye began to go. ``I had to resort to a powerful magnifying glass to go on writing in longhand on yellow legal pads,'' he says. When he began teaching, he could make out vague, shadowy shapes in the first few rows of lecture chairs. ``Now I don't see the students at all. I just hear voices.'' Then, with booming laughter, as if the joke had just occurred to him, he pronounces himself ``literally colored blind. Used to be I could tell black kids from white kids by their voices. But as blacks move into the middle class and attend Eastern colleges, they begin talking like whites. You can't tell anymore by their enunciation and pronunciation. ``No, I don't think black English will disappear. Blacks who speak downtown English still speak the ghetto language when they go back to visit the family or attend church.'' One reason Farmer's classes are the most popular on campus is the gallery of national figures he summons up from personal experience: The Kennedys: ``When the Freedom Riders reached Montgomery and rioters held us virtual prisoners in the First Baptist Church, Bobby Kennedy telephoned Martin Luther King to get me to halt the march and have a cooling off period. My response was: `We have been cooling off for 350 years. If we cool off anymore, we will be in a deep freeze.' The attorney general was furious and that fury was shared promptly with his brother, the president. So I was never on good terms with the Kennedys. '' Lyndon Johnson: ``At first I was welcome in the Oval Office: `From Marshall! Doggone, Jim, that's Lady Bird's hometown. Her daddy had a filling station there.' That bond of Texas engulfed us. But I soon fell from grace when I refused to go along with a moratorium on demonstrations during the campaign against Goldwater.'' Adam Clayton Powell: ``A clever man. He had more charisma than Jesse Jackson, but he didn't like the NAACP, which we joked meant, `Never Annoy Adam Clayton Powell.''' Louis Farrakhan: ``Racism of any color is bad. I hate the things he stands for, but I'd fight for his right to be heard.'' On the day civil rights leader Ralph Abernathy died, April 17, Farmer told the class about encouraging Abernathy to write his controversial autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' But ``I warned him: don't tell all. ``He just grinned, but now I wonder if his death wasn't hastened by the inner turmoil he must have gone through wondering if he had done an injustice to his dear friend, dearer than a brother, Martin Luther King. I just wish he hadn't written those three pages about Martin's sexual escapades on his last night alive. It wasn't needed. There was nothing new. It had all been written before.'' In February, Black History Month, Farmer is a guest speaker at dozens of colleges. Whenever an opportunity arises, he encourages black athletes to get their diplomas before turning pro. ``It's not easy,'' Farmer sighs. ``They are quick to ask, `Hey, professor, where did it ever get you? Show us your new BMW.'' But the professor says he learns a lot from his students, especially from their term papers. ``I give them a choice of a research paper or writing some personal experience with race relations. More than half chose a personal experience. They tell of having a black friend i childhood. ``In most cases, as they approached puberty, entered middle school, they were yanked apart by parents or neighbors who ostracized them and called them nigger lovers. ``It came as a revelation to me that so many white kids had black playmates and had that traumatic experience. It came up in paper after paper read to me. Their poignant childhood memories show that race has colored _ no pun intended _every aspect of this country's life. None of us, black or white, is untouched by it.''

DOC.TEXT: but I keep up the vigil anyway outside the local elementary school. My 4-year-old daughter, Rebecca Schiffres, is determined to attend Lafayette with her big brother, Ethan. But there is only room for 40 children in the two pre-kindergarten classes, and if I leave my post under the school's portico I give up my chance to get one of them. It's 3:45 a.m. I have been there since 8:30 the night before. I stretch out on a borrowed lawn chair, wrapping myself in a sleeping bag that had not been used for 15 years. I cannot get to sleep. All around me, four dozen other parents wait. A lone man paces on the school courtyard, while someone shoots hoops on the basketball court around back. A few people use flashlights to read. The silence is broken by a few snores from some of those fortunate enough to sleep and the whispered conversations of those who couldn't. I haven't done anything like this since 1969, when the ``Amazing Mets'' got into the World Series and I tried to get into the ballpark. I was in high school then, and staying up all night was pure excitement. Not anymore. Why then are we all here, camping out on a rainy night hoping to win a cherished spot in a public elementary school in the District of Columbia, a city not known for educational excellence. Pre-school programs abound in an area where the majority of mothers work outside the home. The good ones fill up fast. Ask Marty Crutsinger, AP's economics writer, who has survived four all-nighters to get his 4-year-old daughter, Elizabeth, into a church-run pre-school in suburban Virginia. What's different about the Lafayette vigil is that we're waiting to get our children into a public school. The school board has mandated that there be at least one pre-kindergarten class in each of the city's 124 elementary schools. Some schools, including Lafayette, have added a second. But it's not always enough. ``If people knew that there were enough pre-kindergarten programs for everyone, then there wouldn't be the panic,'' says Maurice Sykes, the district's director of early childhood programs. But there's not enough money to accommodate everyone, he says. Sykes attributes the high demand to the ``second baby boom'' reaching school age, the phenomena of working parents, the full-day program and the price. ``The reason those slots become coveted is because we became part of the day care network,'' Sykes said. ``If you can provide a service for free that's when you get competitive.'' As for the all-night vigils, he says, ``No one is satisfied with the system. We're trying to figure out a reasonable, equitable solution.'' Three years ago, when we considered signing Ethan up for pre-kindergarten, I arrived at 9:10 the morning of registration and got No. 32. In the ensuing years, parents have lined up earlier and earlier to guarantee themselves a slot. Last year, people who showed up at dawn still got into the program. This year, panic set in. The first would-be pre-K parent arrived at 5:30 p.m. the evening before registration. Someone soon arrived with numbers to pass out. There was a sign-in sheet, too, just as a backstop. My husband, Manny Schiffres, and I stopped at the school at 8:15 p.m. as we were returning from a reception. Eight people were there. We drove the three blocks to our house. When we got there, the phone was ringing and a notice was posted near the telephone. ``Get over to Lafayette. People are already there.'' It was signed by my next-door neighbor and timed off at 7:30. I changed my clothes, putting on a 20-year-old sweater and a pair of jeans. My neighbor rang the bell. ``Come on. We have to go,'' she said. Grabbing a down jacket and a cup of cherry yogurt, I returned to the school with her. I was number 16. Rebecca was in! People milled around the courtyard. Spouses came with dinner and with kids to say goodnight. A table with wine and cheese was set up under a newly posted sign warning that no alcohol or drugs was permitted within 1,000 feet of the school.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
WASHINGTON: the school.
DOC.TEXT: I sipped apple juice from a box that had been purchased for my son's lunch and devoured my yogurt. Not much of a dinner. Then the rain came, and everyone ran for cover. At 9:42 p.m., the 40th parent came. Anyone who arrived after that would be on a waiting list. Some people had alternative plans if their kids didn't get in. We could have continued sending Rebecca to Gan HaYeled, the nursery school run by our synagogue. In Rebecca's two years there, the teachers instilled in her a love of school. Along the way, she learned her alphabet and her numbers, to write her name and to get along with her peers. We met the January application deadline, sent in our deposit and even requested the same teacher that Ethan had as a 4-year-old. But Lafayette was part of her life too. She went to the fall harvest festival and the spring fair. She dressed up for the annual Halloween parades and applauded at the sixth-grade shows. ``I'm going to Lafayette,'' she would brag to anyone who asked her. My husband and I spent hours debating what to do. We knew she would fare well, and learn as much, at either school. So the quality of the programs was not at issue. The deciding factors came down to cost (the Lafayette program is free, compared with $3,100 for the synagogue-run school); the convenience of having two children at the same school and Rebecca's wishes. And so I keep the vigil. Before midnight, the school's custodian opens the building for a short time, so parents can use the telephone or bathroom. He turns the lights on under the portico but turns them off again when people protested that they want to sleep. And people slept. Sitting up. Stretched across two chairs. On the cold cement. Bodies next to bodies. I talk to the mothers of two of Ethan's classmates. Each is trying to get a son into the pre-K program. It would be great, we say, if our younger kids could be together too. We share a pound cake, and conversation _ a real conversation without interruption from one of the kids. As temperatures drop into the 40s, one of the women stuffs her legs into a plastic garbage bag trying to keep warm. It really works, someone had told her. The other wears layers of borrowed clothing. Friends who had been through this before brought extra coats. I go back to my chair and the warmth of my sleeping bag. Husbands come to relieve wives and wives to relieve husbands. There were CARE packages for those who stayed, brought in paper bags and plastic bags and kids' lunch boxes. My husband is home sleeping. I take a bathroom break. Someone decreed, and everyone agreed, that you could leave for 15 minutes without losing your place on line. But no one really keeps track. Dawn breaks, and people begin awakening. They stow their gear in car trunks and then line up according to number. Principal Sandra Bond, wearing a T-shirt declaring ``the principal is always right,'' opens the doors to the school at 8 a.m. Coffee and doughnuts await us, courtesy of the Home and School Association. Later, Mrs. Bond would say she thought of us each time she saw a flash of lightning or heard a clap of thunder. Why then, parents grumbled, wouldn't she let us camp out in the gym or cafeteria? There has to be a better way, people said. Those that had kids in the school, as I did, pushed for preference for siblings. Those who missed the cut argued for a lottery. Others said a missed night's sleep was a small price to pay to get their kids in Lafayette. School personnel checked our documents _ birth certificates, proof of residency and immunization records. All my papers were in order, and Rebecca was accepted. Another family was not so lucky. They were told they were ineligible because they lived outside the district. Welcome to Lafayette, No. 41.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Even as communism crumbles in much of the rest of the world, Robert Mugabe is still adamant about establishing a one-party Marxist-Leninist state in Zimbabwe, formerly Rhodesia. While that makes a lot of businessmen and others uneasy, few dispute Mugabe's successes in social reforms that have largely bettered the lot of his people.

When former guerrilla chieftain Robert Mugabe led Rhodesia to independence as black-governed Zimbabwe 10 years ago, he faced a daunting task. The economy of the former white-led nation was in tatters. Racial tensions were rife. Civil war loomed in Matabeleland, stronghold of opposition leader Joshua Nkomo. And Mugabe's support for South African guerrillas raised the risk of a backlash from Pretoria's white-led government _ a break in his main trade routes through that country, or even a military strike. Zimbabwe on April 18 celebrated the 10th anniversary of independence from Britain with military marches and tribal dancing. Speaking to a crowd at a stadium outside Harare, Mugabe said he welcomed the expiration of the 10-year constitution brokered by the British that contained ``entrenched racial provisions'' protecting the interests of the 90,000-strong white community. He said the second decade of independence would witness even greater moves toward unity, peace and progress. Few dispute that during those first 10 years Zimbabwe made remarkable progress in the areas of education and health care. Now comes the hard part. Unemployment is at record levels, along with urban crime. Vague economic planning has led to rampant inflation, shortages of essential commodities, and deterioration of the national transport system. And Mugabe's vow to transform one of Africa's few Western-style democracies into a one-party Marxist-Leninist state has split the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) and divided the country's 9.2 million people. It has also alarmed local businessmen and foreign governments. Some question whether the one-time schoolteacher is on the right political track as his old Eastern European models undergo radical reforms. ``He is obsessed with a unitary system,'' a member of the party's 160-member Central Committee told The Associated Press, on condition of anonymity. ``But by no means does he have all the support he needs in the party or cabinet unless he stampedes it through.'' One-party rule has been Mugabe's dream since he was held for a decade as a political prisoner by the last white Rhodesian prime minister, Ian D. Smith. At that time, it was a fashionable system in Eastern Europe and much of the Third World. With that system largely discredited abroad, Mugabe's own credibility is at stake. But Mugabe won't budge. ``The multiparty system spells the destruction of our nation,'' he said last year. ``We believe we are one people, one flag, one identity. Why shouldn't we have one party?'', Mugabe won distinction as an eloquent chairman for three years of the 102-member Non-Aligned Movement of developing nations, an alternative to the East and West power blocs. ``No one ever expected the Non-Aligned Movement to do anything really tangible,'' says a Western diplomat in Harare. ``But Mugabe made all the right noises, and his chairmanship was a great success in those terms.'' The Zimbabwean leader, habitually clad in dark suits that match his businesslike manner, exercises the impatient authority of an austere headmaster. Associates say he is sharply intolerant of those who challenge him, but he rewards loyalty richly. He rarely exposes his human side, except on occasional visits to the mud-and-grass hut villages in the countryside that remind him of his own birthplace. A teetotaler and non-smoker with a fondness for hot, spicy foods, Mugabe enjoys watching the sedate English game of cricket. He works out daily at State House on a static exercise bike and relaxes near a hi-fi to songs from the 1950s, Pat Boone being a favorite. A blinking stare from behind thick spectacles hides stiff mannerisms. He sports a toothbrush mustache. And, in common with many African men his age, he dyes his hair to conceal specks of gray. Educated at a Roman Catholic mission, Mugabe is described by church leaders as an ascetic with high moral principles. However, he is no longer a practicing Catholic like his aged mother and his Ghanaian-born wife, Sally, who all attend Mass regularly. Yet he's comfortable in the company of clerics, according to the Rev. Oscar Wermter, spokesman for the Catholic Bishops' Conference, which opposes his one-party state objective.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
HARARE, Zimbabwe: state objective.
DOC.TEXT: ``He shares our concerns for moral and social justice,'' Wermter says. ``But when it comes to the freedom of political choice as a fundamental human right, that's where we part company.'' Wermter and others fear Mugabe may be sealing his own fate by pursuing his Marxist goal. ``We are afraid, from the African experience, that one-party states normally end in military coups because there is no other mechanism for change,'' he says. Relations between church and state were not always cozy. In 1984, Mugabe vilified church leaders who accused North Korean-trained Zimbabwean troops of atrocities in the western Matabeleland province where armed rebels loyal to Nkomo posed a threat to the government. Thousands of civilians were killed, wounded or driven into exile in operations against the dissidents. But the remaining 120 rebels laid down their guns under an amnesty that followed a unity pact between Nkomo and Mugabe in December 1988. Nkomo, a former political foe now turned friend, is to be sworn in as one of two vice-presidents this year. But his promotion from senior minister may not mollify supporters of Nkomo's defunct Zimbabwe African People's Union, which has merged with the ruling party, says Masipula Sithole, a U.S.-trained professor of political studies at the University of Zimbabwe. Some ex-ZAPU officials from the minority Ndebele tribe, 30 percent of the population, are already disenchanted with the disproportionately small role they say they play in government, Sithole says. Sithole says Mugabe's popularity is increasingly being viewed as vain, moody, paranoid and isolated from the people. He has no children. An only son died at age 6 while Mugabe was in prison. Mugabe lives behind high walls capped with coils of razor wire. He travels in a high-speed motorcade escorted by police cars with wailing sirens, motorcycle outriders and a jeepload of soldiers armed with machine guns and automatic rifles. Mugabe, who won several college degrees while in detention, is an admirer of executed Romanian dictator Nicolai Ceaucescu, Kim Il Sung of North Korea and Fidel Castro of Cuba. He argues that democratic one-party rule eliminates tribal and ideological divisions that hamper the development of Third World nations. ``It is absurd to argue that democracy exists in a one-party state,'' Sithole says. Yet Mugabe makes no attempt to conceal his distaste for opposition. Before recent elections he spoke darkly about reports that influential whites were backing opposition politicians. ``If whites rear their ugly terrorist head ... we will chop that head off,'' he declared. But, on another occasion, talking about his image abroad, Mugabe smiled and said, ``Look, I am not a monster. I haven't eaten anyone.'' Few people, including the 90,000 whites who remain from a peak of 270,000 in the mid-1970s, dispute Mugabe's successes in social reforms that have largely bettered the lot of his people. Infant mortality dropped as some 450 new rural clinics were built and 70 percent of all children were immunized against disease. High school enrollment swelled ninefold to 695,000, and primary school attendances doubled to 1.2 million. In his anniversary speech, Mugabe said that apart from wheat imports, Zimbabwe is self-sufficient in food. He also praised local industries, mainly in the hands of white entrepreneurs. Manufacturers generate nearly 30 percent of the gross domestic product of about $4 billion, he said. But today unemployment is estimated at almost 25 percent. Only Western investment and effective trade liberalization will ease the unemployment and an inflation rate of 22 percent annually, says leading black businessman Sam Gozo. ``But you can't have proper investment and liberalization where Marxism is the order of the day,'' he says. ``It just won't fly.'' Despite recent reforms in neighboring South Africa, and an easing of regional tensions with black-ruled states, a strong economic union between the two countries is unlikely while Mugabe remains a vocal critic of apartheid and an advocate of trade embargoes against Pretoria. ``Whether Mugabe likes it or not, our survival will go hand-in-hand with the fortunes of South Africa,'' Gozo says.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ In the early days they had to be registered nurses. Then they had to be young and pretty. Now with the aircraft cabin ``graying,'' as one said, the nation's flight attendants are fighting weight restrictions.

There was a time when airline stewardesses were fired if they turned 32, got married, became pregnant or had to put on eyeglasses. Stewardesses are called flight attendants now, in deference to men who have joined their ranks, and many of the restrictive rules have been dumped as a result of anti-discrimination laws and lawsuits. Some flight attendants, however, still are being fired for weighing too much. At American Airlines, the nation's largest employer of flight attendants, the union is suing the company and challenging some of the industry's most stringent weight requirements. The Association of Professional Flight Attendants, the union for American's 16,000 attendants, says the 37-year-old weight guidelines are an extension of age and sex discrimination. The union contends they hearken to the ``Coffee, Tea or Me'' era when sexy, young stewardesses were marketing tools. Congress had not yet outlawed age and sex discrimination. National Airlines urged travelers to ``Fly me, I'm Cheryl,'' Braniff's sky girls wore hot pants, and Continental promised, ``We move our tails for you.'' Now union officials call it an irrational and cruel policy that forces women in their 40s and 50s to weigh what they did when they were 21. They say attendants sometimes resort to crash diets, liposuction, breast reductions and drug use, and some develop eating disorders in an effort to stay trim. ``We truly believe the flying public wants professional, efficient and well-groomed flight attendants, safe airplanes and on-time service,'' said Tommie Hutto-Blake, a flight attendant from Ridgewood, N.J. and former union president. ``We don't think the public cares if a flight attendant wears a size 6 or a size 10.'' Union members are wearing buttons urging patrons to ``weigh my job performance, not my body.'' Billboards with similar messages are going up outside airports. Both sides are girding for a 1991 trial date in federal court in Fort Worth, Texas. In April, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission joined the flight attendants' battle, filing a federal class-action suit in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. The lawsuit charges the weight policy discriminates against women, particularly those over 40. ``American still wants their flight attendants to appeal to a male sexist notion of what is sexy,'' said EEOC lawyer Ralph D.H. Fertig. ``And that's thin.'' He said American's policy reads that a ``firm, trim silhouette, free of bulges, rolls or paunches, is necessary for an alert, efficient image.'' ``We believe it's in our rights to have an appropriate grooming standard for our employees,'' said American spokesman Ed Stewart. ``We want a neat, attractive person representing American.'' Union lawyer Kathleen King of San Francisco said the job has changed since the 1950s when women like her mother became flight attendants ``on a lark'' before settling down and getting married. ``You've got flight attendants with 20 and 25 years of seniority who are being thrown out the door because they're a few pounds overweight,'' she said. Last year, Pan American World Airways ended six years of litigation by raising weight requirements and allowing an extra 9 pounds as flight attendants age. Pan Am also agreed to pay $2.3 million in lost wages to 115 employees who were not allowed to work because of their weight. Other carriers, including Delta Airlines and USAir, have less stringent weight charts. Delta and Trans World Airlines allow considerable leeway in pounds for aging flight attendants. United Airlines is proposing dropping its weight regulations. Northwest and Continental have already done so. American's weight standards are roughly tied to a 1959 Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. chart. At American, a 5-foot-5-inch attendant may weigh no more than 129 pounds. The same employee could weigh up to 138 pounds at Delta, with 4 added pounds as she ages, and up to 150 pounds at Pan Am, plus an additional 9 pounds as she ages. At United Airlines, she could weigh up to 137 pounds, plus an extra 9 pounds as she ages. American Airlines' weight guidelines were modified slightly in 1975, after a court challenge, but the union argues that 80 percent of the flight attendants were under 35 then. American dismisses the argument that a woman inevitably gains weight with age, children or menopause. American Airlines President Robert Crandall, during a recent speech to about 500 employees in New York, was confronted by Ms. Hutto-Blake. ``We're not all young, thin employees today,'' she told him. ``There has been a graying of the cabin.'' By her side stood Doris Johnson, 46, of New York, who was suspended without pay in September after 17 years of flying. She is 5-feet-4, 139 pounds, wears a size 9 shoe, has undergone a hysterectomy, and has spent a decade fighting to stay below 125 pounds to keep her job. ``I must say, in looking at you, I'm surprised. You don't look like you have a weight problem,'' Crandall told Ms. Johnson. She took a demotion last week to a ground position to avoid being fired. But Crandall insists weight standards are necessary. ``We've got some people on our airplanes that are way too heavy.'' In Los Angeles, 28-year veteran Patt Gibbs took a four-year leave to become union president. Upon her return, the 5-foot-3-inch Ms. Gibbs was 154 pounds, 29 pounds over her limit. ``It was pretty humiliating,'' she said. ``They said, `That's that. You're too heavy. Lose the weight or you won't have a job.''' She lost the weight and returned to work. Also in Los Angeles, Sherri Cappello was fired the day she received her 25-year service pin. In March, she was elected vice president by the largest number of votes in the union's history, some measure of how the rank-and-file think about weight standards. In Wisconsin, after flying 43 years, Petey Peterson retired two years before turning 65 and getting a full pension. She was in the Berlin Airlift, received American Airlines' Award of Valor, and was among the last of those who started in days when flight attendants had to be registered nurses. ``I was forced into early retirement because I could no longer fit the image and take the harassment of the Flight Attendant Weight Program as enforced by my 29-year-old supervisor,'' she says.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ The first spring publishers' list of the decade is loaded with books on sex and love, many looking at what the AIDs threat has done to the sexual revolution, with some hints at what the future holds. Here is a sampling.
DOC.HEAD: By DAVID SMYTH
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Sex in the 1990s: What are we in for? The Naughty Nineties? The Nice Nineties? A recent spate of books on sex, love and related matters _ about one title a day came out in February alone _ could offer hints at the sexual mores of the next 10 years. But many of them look more at where we are coming from, rather than where we are going. In ``Mayflower Manners: Etiquette for Consenting Adults,'' former madam Sidney Biddle Barrows brings up the delicate matter of good breeding and condoms. ``Is it assumed,'' she asks, ``that the man will provide them? Is it therefore rude of the woman to pre-empt that sacred responsibility by producing them herself?'' This is definitely a Nineties question. In the World War II era of Rosie the Riveter, even to hint that a woman carried a supply of condoms in her pocketbook was decidedly bad form. It was absolutely unspeakable in the 1930s, the decade of the censorious Hays Office in Hollywood and a prudish Motion Picture Code. But May 6, 1960, was apparently a pivotal date in the history of American sex. On that day, say Jane and Michael Stern, co-authors of ``Sixties People,'' ``the Federal Drug Administration declared Enovid _ the first birth control pill _ safe for prescription sales. ``Within six years, one out of five women of child-bearing age had a prescription. Sixties people were infatuated with `the pill.' It was a prime symbol of modern life in general. ``Thanks to the pill, carefree sex became yet another of the futuristic possibilities that the new decade offered. A girl on the pill could have sex any time she pleased.'' And so we find this passage in Daniel Mark Epstein's ``Love's Compass, A Natural History of the Heart,'' which contains recollections of life and love in the 60s: ``When Madeline returned to the little college town in the autumn of my junior year, we found each other at once ... I tried to assure Madeline that I would love her as she deserved to be loved, and in the true spirit of the 1960s, we became lovers without further ceremony or preamble.'' ``Sex out of wedlock,'' adds Epstein, ``was simply forbidden until the 1960s, when we legitimized it per force majeure, by resacralizing erotic love. Such an experience as ours may never be normal again.'' For homosexuals, too, the world has changed in recent decades as many came out into the open. But with AIDS, the Nineties offer the bleak prospect that life for gays may never be the same again. As Allan Berube argues in ``Coming Out Under Fire: Gay Men and Women in World War II,'' the war itself _ thanks strangely enough to the growing power of psychiatrists _ was a setback for the gay community. ``Traditionally the military had never officially excluded or discharged homosexuals from its ranks,'' says Berube, ``but in World War II a dramatic change occurred. As psychiatrists increased their authority in the armed forces, they developed new screening procedures to discover and disqualify homosexual men. ``The generation of gay men and women who served in World War II grew into adulthood fighting one war for their country and another to protect themselves from their government's escalating mobilization against them.'' Half a century later it is a different and deadlier war for the nation's homosexuals. ``There are an estimated 12 million gay men in the United States, many of whom seek long-term, committed relationships in the face of the AIDS epidemic,'' says the publisher of Rik Isensee's ``Love Between Men: Enhancing Intimacy and Keeping Your Relationships Alive.'' A clinical social worker in San Francisco, Isensee deals with such things as what to do ``when a lover has AIDS.'' Could this disease in fact become the bubonic plague of the 1990s, the 20th century version of the Black Death that wiped out a third of Europe in the 14th century? ``More than a million Americans are infected with HIV (human immunodeficiency virus); of these, statistics indicate that 20 percent to 50 percent will develop AIDS within five years,'' according to Dr. Alan Brauer and his wife Donna J. Brauer, who run the Brauer Medical and Health Center in Palo Alto, Calif. Curiously, the Brauer's dire scenario appears in their jointly written ``The ESO Ecstasy Program,'' which the publisher bills as the Sensual Guide for the Nineties. Noting that ``orgasm is totally safe,'' this hefty work explains step by step, in relentless detail, how to achieve ESO (Extended Sexual Orgasm) in a methodical 12-week program of sexual exercises. In the 13th week the reader then comes to a chapter titled ``Beyond Ecstasy.'' Another medical writer questions whether sex is really a necessary ingredient of love at all. ``Is love always sexually connected?'' asks Dr. Theodore Isaac Rubin, M.D., in ``Real Love: What It Is and How to Find It.'' He says the answer is no. ``Heterosexual men can love heterosexual men. Heterosexual women can love heterosexual women. I disagree with those Freudians who believe that there is always a sexual current or correlation present.'' ``Love,'' concludes Rubin, the author of a couple of best-selling books and a frequent guest on TV shows, ``can be sexual or non-sexual.'' Love set free at last in the 1990s from the tyranny of lust? ``How much was hoped from sex. How little sex can deliver,'' Professor Camille Paglia observes in her massive study ``Sexual Personae: Art and Decadence from Nefertiti to Emily Dickinson.'' Take, as an example, Emily Dickinson herself. The New England poet, says Paglia, associate professor of humanities at Philadelphia College of the Performing Arts, ``is the American Sade. She is frightening. This shy Victorian spinster was a male genius and visionary sadist, a fictive sexual persona of towering force.'' As Archie Bunker, that amiable television bigot of the 1970s, once said, ``Sex used to be up in the mind. That's where it belongs.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Richard Beymer says he had no idea how rotten his character would become when he was cast as the kingpin of ABC's ``Twin Peaks.'' Beymer plays business entrepreneur Benjamin Horne in director David Lynch's new series that offers a quirky blend of soap opera, murder mystery and black comedy. He says Johanna Ray, the casting director, had originally considered him for the role of the psychiatrist, the part Russ Tamblyn plays. Then Lynch suggested he could be Benjamin Horne. ``I had no idea now nefarious and slimy he was going to be,'' Beymer says. ``Every time I got a new script he was doing this or that. It's like waking up one morning and finding yourself an arch villain. Isn't that a nightmare?'' Horne owns the Great Northern Hotel, a department store and other properties, but is also conspiring with Catherine Packard Martell (Piper Laurie) to acquire the Packard Sawmill. The show centers on the murder of Laura Palmer, a high school homecoming queen who had a mysterious link to virtually everyone in the picturesque lumber mill town of Twin Peaks near the Washington-Canadian border. Each episode slowly reveals the dirty secrets of its characters. ``Twin Peaks'' is an acting comeback for Beymer, whose career faltered after youthful starring roles in such hit films as ``West Side Story'' and ``The Diary of Anne Frank.'' He worked mostly as a film editor, cinematographer and filmmaker before returning to acting in the 1980s. Beymer was born in Iowa, but his family moved here when he was a child. He began working on a local television show when he was 10. At 13 he was in ``So Big'' and went to Rome for ``Indiscretions of an American Wife.'' He was in ``Diary of Anne Frank'' when he was 19 and ``West Side Story'' two years later. This summer Beymer will direct a theatrical movie based on his adaptation of Michael Wolk's novel, ``The Big Picture.'' ``I did four or five films after `West Side Story,''' Beymer says. ``I didn't quit. Things changed. I went to New York and got into the Actors Studio with the encouragement of Joanne Woodward. I'd been in pictures with Joanne and Paul Newman and Eli Wallach and I had never studied acting. ``Then in early 1964 I became socially conscious and went to Mississippi for the voter registration drive. It struck me as a wonderful thing to document. I bought a 16mm Bolex camera and filmed everything I saw. I brought the film back to Los Angeles and spent the next nine months editing it.'' The documentary, which became ``A Regular Bouquet,'' was narrated by Robert Ryan. It was shown on the PBS series ``Eyes on the Prize.'' Beymer later made educational films and spent six years on a film called ``Innerview.'' In 1984 he had a starring role in the ABC series ``Paper Dolls.'' ``Thankfully, they canceled it,'' he says. ``I ran a sportswear fashion company. I was ready for it to be over after 13 shows. It was totally about hair and makeup and glamour.'' Beymer says he wants to film ``The Big Picture'' as inconspicuously as possible in New York City. He wrote the screenplay and will direct, but will not appear in it. He says the title will be changed because another movie has the same title. ``The process is what interests me,'' he says. ``I'm not interested in going out with trucks and hair and makeup and creating a big circus. I want a film that uses real people and integrates real situations into the film. Hollywood films focus on the star. You don't get to know anyone else.'' The main character in ``The Big Picture'' is Max Popper, who writes pornography to support his other writing and becomes caught up in a murder. ``It takes place around Times Square, where all those wonderful old movie houses now show porno films.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, May 20, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Curt Dempster champions the one-act play, an art form embraced by playwrights but usually ignored by Broadway. Eugene O'Neill wrote a lot of one-acts. So did Tennessee Williams and Joe Orton. Neil Simon turned out ``Plaza Suite'' and ``California Suite.'' David Mamet still writes one-acts. So do Arthur Miller, Harold Pinter, Christopher Durang, Tom Stoppard and others. But except for Simon's efforts, the works rarely get to Broadway. One-act plays, considered death at the box office, are the stepchildren of the commercial theater. And most of the time, they are not part of the regular subscription seasons at the country's larger regional or non-profit theaters either. One-act plays flourish, however, at festivals, celebrations that offer everything from simple readings to fully staged productions. And there are scores of them across the country, according to the Theater Communications Group, a national organization for non-profit professional theater. From the Tennessee Williams New Orleans Literary Festival One-Act Play Contest to the Minnesota One-Act Play Festival to the National One-Act Play Contest by Actors Theater of Louisville to the Young Playwrights Festival in New York, they all celebrate the short drama. One of the best-known is the one-act marathon run by Dempster at New York's Ensemble Studio Theater, a small theater company located in an old West Side furniture warehouse a block from the Hudson River. This off-off-Broadway theater, founded by Dempster in 1971, does a lot of other things. EST, with a staff of about 35 full- and part-time employees, presents full-length works and staged readings each year. But the jewel in its theatrical crown is its annual six-week marathon of one-act plays. This year's festival began in early May and runs until June 20. Among the well-known writers represented by the 12 one-acts spread over three separate evenings are Mamet, Frank D. Gilroy, John Ford Noonan, Romulus Linney and Joyce Carol Oates. But there are newcomers, too, such as 24-year-old Paul Weitz and Susan Kim, who is having her first professional production anywhere. Among the one-acts being done this year are a blues-tinged, 1990s version of ``Hamlet,'' by Shel Silverstein; ``Eulogy for Mister Hamm,'' a short musical by Michael John LaChiusa set in a seedy hotel, and ``Tonight We Love,'' a comedy by Romulus Linney about love in a nursing home. Ensemble Studio Theater, which Dempster heads as artistic director, began its one-act festival in 1978. At that time, they were all alone, Dempster says. Now there are nearly a dozen one-act festivals in New York alone. ``We wanted to focus attention on the neglect the one-act had fallen into,'' he recalls. ``We wanted to restore it to its place in literature.'' Most of the one-acts EST performs are by its playwriting unit, which now numbers about 60 members. But the theater, which has a yearly budget of about $800,000, also looks at one-act plays sent in by regional theaters and unknown writers. ``We get a couple thousand a year,'' Dempster says. ``Play readers go through them and evaluate them.'' After the number is cut to about 100, the EST staff reads them and the number is sliced to 40. After more discussions, the list is cut to 20 finalists and then 12 plays are chosen from that group. ``It's a long process that takes all year to do,'' Dempster says. ``There's some yelling and screaming. I'm sort of like the president, but have an unofficial gentleman's agreement with a committee of artist members. They have a veto over one play that I may love and they hate, and if I hate a play they all love, I can veto that. The plays we finally have up on stage are plays we can all support.'' With all the material coming in, the readers tend to notice fads or trends. ``Those types of plays don't tend to get into the marathon because they usually are plays that are topical ideas rather than artistic ideas,'' Dempster says. ``Like child abuse plays or plays about alcoholism. Phone sex and incest plays are big now. We probably read 20 plays a year on incest. ``If somebody writes a play now about alcoholism, I say, `Did you ever read ``Come Back, Little Sheba,'' by William Inge?','' Dempster says. ``That's a wonderful, little, realistic American play about a man who's an alcoholic. And it says everything you can say about the tragedy of alcoholism. If you can't do better than that, why write one?'' Things looked up for the lowly one-act play in New York this season. There were several major collections of one-acts. At Lincoln Center, artistic director Gregory Mosher paired Mamet's ``Bobby Gould in Hell'' with ``The Devil and Billy Markham'' by Shel Silverstein, two devilishly funny one-acters. The New York Shakespeare Festival currently has a big success with ``Spunk,'' a trio of plays adapted by George C. Wolfe from three stories by the black writer Zora Neale Hurston. It also is doing Caryl Churchill's ``Hot Fudge,'' pairing it with a short two-act play by the same playwright called, what else, ``Ice Cream.'' And Manhattan Theater Club revived Terrence McNally's zany double bill that went under the collective title of ``Bad Habits.''

The nation's unemployment rate climbed in April to 5.4 percent, its highest level in more than a year, the government said. Friday's report triggered a huge rally in bond prices that sent interest rates skidding as analysts said the figures indicated the economy could slip into recession. There was little growth in the number of U.S. jobs for the second straight month, and the total would have declined if not for the hiring of temporary census workers.

Trade ministers representing the largest industrial countries reported they had failed to resolve major disputes blocking an ambitious effort to overhaul the global trading system. Speaking at the end of a three-day negotiating session, officials of the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said Friday that sharp differences still remained over such issues as a U.S. demand for the elimination of costly agricultural barriers.

In an attempt to avoid a ``crippling nationwide rail strike,'' President Bush named an emergency board to help settle bargaining disputes between 11 unions and most of the nation's major railroads. Rising health care costs had been a major holdup in contract negotiations, which had been going on for two years. Nearly 300,000 trackmen, engineers, signalmen and other railroad workers at about 15 of the nation's largest freight railroads are affected. Bush's move Friday was hailed by organized labor as a sign that the administration is concerned about workers' medical coverage.

Congressional testimony by convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken before he is sentenced could complicate the securities fraud case, the nation's top securities regulator said. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said Friday the commission will ``try to work with Congress to make sure they understand the status of the case as they consider what hearings they wish to have and when they want to have them.'' The oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted unanimously Tuesday to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties last month.

Departing savings and loan cleanup boss L. William Seidman said that ``real pain'' is yet to come in the bailout and urged patience with his successor. Seidman told a House Banking Committee task force on the S&L bailout Friday that rising interest rates and falling property values indicate ``the costs will exceed those originally estimated.'' At Seidman's suggestion, President Bush is turning to William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's director of bank supervision, to take over the position.

Greyhound Lines Inc. said it lost $55.8 million in the first quarter and would miss millions of dollars in payments due in coming weeks because of problems related to a 2-month-old strike by bus drivers. The disclosures Friday were the first indication since the strike of the financial condition at Greyhound, which operates the the only nationwide bus system. Greyhound in large part blamed $20 million in unanticipated expenses to cope with strike-related violence.

Donald Trump's three casinos are being investigated in a financial review that state officials said was routine and had nothing to do with disgruntled contractors or the Manhattan developer's desire to sell some assets. Anthony J. Parrillo, director of the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said Friday the review has been under way for two months. Parrillo said it was coincidental that the review coincided with statements from Trump last week that he was considering selling some of his holdings, which include Manhattan real estate and the Trump Shuttle airline.

Whittle Communications said it is consolidating its media properties designed for schools into one division and named a former executive of Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. to head the new unit. The Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company said Friday it expects its new Whittle Educational Network division to generate annual revenue of $125 million by 1991, or about 40 percent of the company's expected revenue of more than $300 million by 1991.

Two key directors of the troubled advertising and consulting giant Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC have resigned. Roy Warman and Terry Bannister served as joint chief operating officers of Saatchi's communications division with responsibility for worldwide advertising operations. Saatchi's deputy chairman Jeremy Sinclair was named Friday to replace them. Saatchi is trying to sell the consulting business.

Stock prices staged a broad advance Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 14.19 to 2,710.36, stretching its weekly gain to 65.31 points. Bond prices staged a furious rally that sent interest rates sharply lower. The dollar fell against every major currencies except the Japanese yen. Sugar futures prices plunged; cocoa futures fell sharply; copper futures retreated; precious metals were mostly lower; oil futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Center Puts Wal-Mart History on Display
DOC.TEXT: Forty years after Sam Walton first hung out his shingle, Walton's 5&10 will reopen to show how a little rural storekeeper built a discount retail empire. Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s Visitors Center opens Wednesday in the same building on the downtown square where Walton first opened for business on May 9, 1950. The center chronicles the rise of the nation's fastest-growing discount chain, using displays and audio-video presentations. It concentrates on how the free enterprise system works and how Wal-Mart thrived when similar companies didn't. The window displays date back to the store's opening, with Simplicity patterns and Johnson's Glo-Coat, a box of Dreft and some Ivory Snow. Inside, an electronic map details the company's 1,500-plus store chain today. Also on display at the center is the hula skirt that Sam Walton donned for his ``dance on Wall Street,'' which he performed after challenging the company to reach a record 8 percent pre-tax profit in 1984. The goal was accomplished and he danced. The old and the modern together reflect the corporate culture of the nation's biggest discount retailer behind K mart Corp. of Detroit. Walton and his brother, Bud, opened the first Wal-Mart Discount City in 1962. Both will be on hand for the opening, along with a sprinkling of other dignitaries, including Gov. Bill Clinton, the dedication speaker. Aside from the other displays and presentations, the center also has a replica of Sam Walton's original office at the store, including many fixtures he used 40 years ago. Also on display is a photograph of young Sam Walton, a fat-faced baby born in Oklahoma in the 1920s. Typical of the Wal-Mart outlook, Dust Bowl Oklahoma is termed ``a place to grow and to dream'' in a video on the Walton family. After a stint with J.C. Penney Co. and the Army, he opened a Ben Franklin store in Newport in 1945. He lost the lease on that one, and relocated to Bentonville. That's where the story took off. Sam Walton convinced Bob Bogle, then a public health officer, to take over management of his Bentonville Ben Franklin store in 1955. Walton ``said he wanted to put in about a dozen stores'' and needed someone to tend the shop in Bentonville while he and his brother built a chain of Ben Franklins, Bogle said in a recent interview. That's when Bogle found himself in Walton's ``learn as you go'' training program. ``I got home at 10 o'clock that night after scrubbing and waxing the floor with Sam,'' Bogle said. Inauspicious first impressions are part of the story. In one video, David Glass, who succeeded Sam Walton as chief executive of Wal-Mart in 1988, recalled his impressions after attending the opening of the second Wal-Mart Discount City at Harrison in 1964. The first store, at Rogers, opened two years earlier. ``I thought to myself this is absolutely the worst discount store, or retail store, I have ever seen,'' said Glass, who was president of a drugstore chain at the time. And Wal-Mart Vice Chairman Donald Soderquist recalls that when Walton took his idea of putting discount stores in rural areas to Ben Franklin headquarters in Chicago, officials there ``just really didn't see a future in it.'' Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart's director of corporate and public affairs, attributed Wal-Mart's success to its ``associates'' _ the term for employees first coined in 1972 to stress that all Wal-Mart employees are partners in the company _ and to Sam Walton's leadership and knack for hiring the ``right person at the right time.'' At the start of 1990, Wal-Mart owned 1,402 stores, employed 272,000 and listed sales of $25.8 billion. Sam's Wholesale Club closed out the year with 123 units and Wal-Mart announced plans to enter the California market.

DOC.HEAD: Middle School Students Flying 5,000 Miles to Visit McDonald's
DOC.TEXT: Four local middle school students are traveling 5,000 miles for a hamburger and fries. The students, members of an eighth grade civics class, are flying to the Soviet Union this week on an 11-day tour sponsored by Steel of West Virginia Inc. They'll be free to do and see what they want in the Soviet Union and Berlin, with one exception. To make sure they understand the ins and outs of world economics, the students must visit the Moscow McDonald's. ``Just to drive it home to 14-year-olds, the only stipulation is that they have to stand in line at McDonald's and buy a hamburger,'' said teacher and chaperone Jean McClelland. Officials of Steel of West Virginia, which makes custom steel products, have been participating in a program in which local business officials visit Ms. McClelland's civics classes once a week to teach students about economics. But while the other visitors have been content to provide gifts for a school-sponsored auction at the end of the term, Steel of West Virginia's representatives opted for a more expensive present. The company is footing the $14,000 bill for the trip including air fare, lodging and the cost of obtaining passports. ``We believe that we can have an impact upon the children ... that will affect them positively for the rest of their lives,'' said Larry Gue, vice president of human affairs at Steel of West Virginia. ``That's all we're looking for.'' He said the company picked the Soviet Union because of the economic lessons presented by the Moscow McDonald's: the difference between Huntington's McDonald's and its inexpensive fast food, and the Moscow operation, where customers are willing to stand in line for hours to spend a substantial part of their paycheck for essentially the same items. ``The idea is hopefully they'll understand the American free enterprise system,'' Gue said. McClelland has 25 students in her civics class. The class came up with the criteria their teacher used in picking the four winners including attendance, grades and willingness to go new places and eat strange foods. They also were given one week for research and then asked to write an essay about the Soviet Union. Even the worst students gave it a shot, McClelland said. ``I had never, ever gotten essays of that quality before,'' she said. One eventual winner, Jason Simms, wrote a paper titled ``Is the Party Over?'' Another, Sonja Meenach, wrote about communications in the Soviet Union. ``It's exciting and the chance of a lifetime,'' said another winner, Sara Walker. The group flies to New York on Steel of West Virginia's corporate jet Wednesday, then catches a flight to Frankfurt, West Germany, for a 5-hour layover and a connecting flight to Leningrad. McClelland and the students will tour the Soviet Union for a week, then travel to Berlin for three days before returning to the United States. Although just four students were chosen for the trip, their fellow students have been caught up in the excitement, McClelland said. ``The whole school's been studying the Soviet Union,'' she said. ``They've been having speakers, videos. Music classes have been studying Russian composers. Health classes have been studying jet lag. Even math classes have been studying how far it is to Moscow.'' During their trip, the students will make videotapes and attempt to call their classmates during class. ``We wanted to share the experience,'' McClelland said. ``We didn't want to be selfish.''

DOC.HEAD: Brush With History: Copies of Masterpieces Entering Art Market
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, Last month ..., to CORRECT that defacer of Rembrandt was a man. SUBS 26th graf pvs, But even ..., to CORRECT spelling of de Hory. First moved for AMs
DOC.TEXT: Even the Louvre's curators would envy the masterpieces in the gallery next door to the lunch counter advertising a grilled cheese special. Van Gogh's ``Les Iris'' is around the corner from a few Monet landscapes at the storefront gallery in Fort Lauderdale. Across the room, works from the Italian Renaissance and the early American Hudson River School share the same wall. They're all fakes. They're all for sale. ``A forger? Yes, we're expert forgers you could say. But we make no attempt to deceive. We don't pretend to sell original works. We sell reproductions,'' said Ernest Thomas Cummins, president of Heritage House Trading Group Ltd. ``We have all the thrill of being a forger, but no risk.'' With prices for original art rising into the tens of millions, some art lovers are turning to high-quality copies done by expert artists. In addition, some museums confronting skyrocketing insurance premiums are considering stashing the authentic pieces and displaying a reproduction, said Cummins. No major U.S. art museum is known to be displaying reproductions in place of originals. Such a practice would raise questions about why people visit museums in the first place. But museum security has become a growing concern. Last month, a man in Amsterdam sprayed a Rembrandt with an acid solution and caused minor damage. In March, thieves dressed as police officers robbed 11 paintings and other objects from Boston's Gardner Museum. Bids for paintings have climbed at auction houses. In 1987, Australian investor Alan Bond paid a record $53.9 million for ``Les Iris.'' At Fort Lauderdale-based Heritage House, prices run from about $1,000 to $10,000 for the paintings of paintings, depending on the size and complexity of the original, said Cummins, 34, a founder of the upscale Robb Report magazine. Heritage House, which started producing the repainted masters in late 1987, also has opened a shop in Carmel, Calif. The Heritage House works are full paintings, rather than photographs or prints. ``We deal with people who want to live with great art, not just visit it,'' he said. A telephone call usually begins the three- to four-month process of making a reproduction. Heritage House advertises in art and leisure publications. A small classified in The Wall Street Journal recently brought in dozens of inquiries, said Cummins. ``We get all kinds of calls,'' he said. ``Some people want specific paintings or copies of originals they already have to put in a second home. On the other hand, we get calls from people saying, `Can you do something with a dog?''' Once a commitment is made, Cummins contacts one of the nearly 200 European artists used by the gallery. In Europe, where copying masterpieces is a centuries-old craft, specially trained painters often use the pigments and brushes typical of the period of the original. A completed painting is then placed in a frame closely resembling its era. Sometimes, the gallery purchases 17th century furniture to use the wood for frames, said Cummins. The final step is the antiquing process using chemicals and natural heat and humidity. ``We can make special types of cracks from little spider-web types to long splits,'' said Cummins. To guard against misrepresentations, the canvases and frames are stamped and the paintings contain markings only visible under an ultraviolet light. ``We're working in techniques that have been handed down for centuries,'' said Cummins. ``The master copier hands down his knowledge to the apprentices and so on. There is nothing new to what we are doing.'' Only recently, however, has the demand for near-perfect reproductions reached beyond a handful of collectors. Several European galleries now specialize in copies of priceless musuem works. Parisian gallery owner Daniel Delamere has gained status in the art world for selling repoductions and promising never to copy the same work again. Although Delamere bills his so-called one-of-a-kind reproductions as an investment that could appreciate in value, Cummins said Heritage House works are merely decorations. ``People want our paintings because they love art and appreciate a real painting as opposed to a lithograph or something,'' he said. Thomas Hoving, editor of Connoisseur magazine and former director of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, said there may be a limited market for quality reproductions, but he knows of no major U.S. museum displaying copies. ``Some people may want these paintings in their home. I do not see any market for museums,'' he said. But even known forgeries are finding a niche among art auctioneers. Last month in London, Bonhams gallery put on the block 30 paintings by the late master forger Elmyr de Hory. Nearby, the British Museum's exhibit ``Fake? The Art of Deception'' features nearly 600 skillful imitations. International copyright laws prohibit commercial copies of artists' works until 50 years after their death. Heritage House also does not attempt reproductions of watercolors and multi-media works, said Cummins. Cummins closely guards the identities of his copiers, claiming many fear public disclosure would drop the prices for their original pieces and draw ridicule from peers. ``It's a very sensitive subject and most would prefer to simply keep it a secret,'' he said. Still, some of the artists' eccentricities cannot be hidden. ``We have some artists who walk around in the clothes of the period they are painting in,'' said Cummins. ``Sometimes we get letters from them written in an archaic style that you can barely understand. It's a strange business.''

DOC.HEAD: Union at McDonnell Douglas Approves New Three-Year Contract
DOC.TEXT: Members of the largest union at McDonnell Douglas Corp. have approved a new three-year contract at the aerospace-defense giant, averting a strike that union officials said appeared almost certain a week ago. Union members voted Sunday to accept the contract 5,379 to 2,463, said Cassell Williams, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers District 837. Negotiators reached agreement on the contract Saturday, following an 18-hour bargaining session that began Friday morning. Negotiations had been held intermittently since March 20. Williams said he was surprised by the abrupt change in contract negotiations last week. ``I thought we'd be on the picket line,'' he said. Vince DeBlaze, McDonnell Douglas' chief negotiator, said the vote showed the union agreed that the new contract is fair to both sides. ``We've been through a tough round of negotiations, but it all paid off today,'' he said. Under the new contract, workers are guaranteed a 5{ percent pay increase in the first year, followed by two annual raises of 3 percent each, Williams said. In addition, workers will get a 4 percent salary bonus each year, he said. Hourly wages now average $14, Williams said. ``We're happy that we don't have to strike, but we're unhappy about not getting more,'' Williams said. ``We would have liked to have gotten more money for our retirees, and we would have liked to increased benefits in our insurance and savings plans.'' Had a strike developed, it would have been one in a series of blows that have been dealt to McDonnell Douglas, the area's No. 1 employer with 40,000 workers based in St. Louis. The market for the company's jet fighters, helicopters and giant military cargo planes has shrunk because of cuts at the Pentagon. McDonnell Douglas' commercial aircraft subsidiary, Douglas Aircraft in Long Beach, Calif., also is losing money, and the company's stock price has traded recently at a 52-week low. The contract vote was announced at the close of a three-hour meeting Sunday. Some union members said they had wanted more from the pact. Terra Johnson, who has worked at the company two years, said she had voted against the contract because she felt the retirement benefits were inadequate. ``Most of the young people here don't think about retirement, but I'm getting old enough to start worrying about it,'' she said. But DeBlaze said, ``What you have to look at is the total package. We came up with a package that was acceptable, that had substantial improvements for the union.'' District 837 represents 11,850 of about 13,000 hourly wage-earners at McDonnell Douglas. Other McDonnell Douglas unions in St. Louis include two Teamsters locals, Electrical Workers Local 1 and one representing plant guards. Each union has a separate contract and separate negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Sees Trade Accord As Step To Full EC Membership
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak Prime Minister Marian Chalfa Monday signed a trade and economic cooperation accord with the European Community, which he termed a key step to full membership in the bloc by 1999. The accord showed Czechoslovakia's commitment to democracy and market economy that must lead to EC membership ``before the end of the century,'' Chalfa told the foreign ministers of the 12 EC nations at a signing ceremony. ``Our objective is to achieve total compatibility with the European Community,'' he said, adding Czechoslovakia was ready to begin talks in the fall on associate EC membership. ``We aspire to become a full member of the Community (and) are optimistic on that score,'' Chalfa told reporters later. The accord he signed with the EC replaces a commercial agreement signed in December, 1988. The EC's two-way trade with Czechoslovakia now totals $2.4 billion a year. The new 10-year accord covers trade in industrial and agricultural goods and will remove quantitative trade restrictions. It also opens the door to economic cooperation in industry, agriculture, financial services, environmental protection, vocational training and energy, including nuclear energy.
