DOC.HEAD: Good Planting Weather Sends Corn, Soybean Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened lower today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Weighing on the market is the dry weather that is forecast for corn and soybean crop areas this week. Dry weather should aid in the planting of crops. Corn futures aren't expected to be helped by Friday's announcement that the Soviet Union has purchased 600,000 metric tons of corn, traders say. Victor Lespinasse, a trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the purchase already has been factored into the market. The return of good weather to South America is allowing Argentine farmers to resume the harvesting of their soybean crop. That is expected to effect soybean futures. Analysts say strong export demand should give some support to wheat prices. In early trading, wheat was 1 cent lower to } cent higher with the contract fordelivery in May at $3.78 a bushel; corn was a \ cent to 1{ cents lower with May at $2.86{ a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2{ cents lower wtih May at $1.65 a bushel; soybeans were 3} cents to 7 cents lower with May at $6.22 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Higher cash prices and retail purchases in advance of the Memorial Day holiday are giving a boost to livestock futures. Higher cash prices for pork products and and light movement of live hogs to slaughter is supporting pork futures. Live cattle were .02 cent to .25 cent higher with June at 74.90 a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .52 cent higher with May at 84.37 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent lower to .68 cent higher with June at 64.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .63 cent to .85 cent higher with May at 69.80 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed and pork futures were higher in Friday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Big Raider Concedes He Could Lose in Important USX Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 1-15 NEW with details from meeting, Icahn says he lacks support from crucial shareholders, ADDs late-morning stock price. Picks up 14th graf pvs, The USX...
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn took his battle with USX Corp. management to the company's annual meeting today, but the corporate raider conceded that his plan to split the steel-energy giant in two could fail. Icahn, USX's biggest shareholder, disclosed the pessimism as he urged other stockholders to approve his proposal for separating the company's healthier Marathon Oil Co. subsidiary from its laggard U.S. Steel business. About 600 shareholders packed a junior high school auditorium in Findlay, Marathon's hometown, to hear Icahn and USX management present their views on how to shape the future of one of the biggest U.S. industrial corporations. The vote on Icahn's plan is widely seen as a test of how much influence corporate takeover strategists still have, now that much of the muscle to back up their threats _ billions of dollars in financing _ has atrophied because of a severe decline in their war chest, the market for high risk ``junk bonds.'' Results of the vote aren't expected for at least a week. But Icahn, who has 13.3 percent of USX shares, or about 34 million shares, admitted as the meeting began that he might not have the crucial support needed from five or six large institutional investors. About 200 million shares were expected to be voted. These large institutions, whom, Icahn didn't identify, preferred to allow management to ``do it on their own,'' he told shareholders. Under Icahn's plan, 80 percent of U.S. Steel would be spun off as a dividend to shareholders. Each shareholder would own stock in U.S. Steel and Marathon that Icahn estimated would be worth a combined value of $48. The unlikelihood of approval evidently depressed USX's stock price late this morning. Shares were trading at $33.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, down 50 cents from Friday. Several shareholders objected to Icahn's plan and backed USX Chairman Charles Corry, who wants to keep both steel and energy under one roof. The anti-Icahn shareholders said they want USX to remain intact so the steel and energy businesses could support each other when one wasn't doing well. Corry also contended that the steel business's profitability had improved in recent years and that he too was frustrated by the company's relatively low stock price. Nonetheless, he told shareholders, ``The real question is would the specific Icahn proposal address that?'' Icahn's comments generally were met with polite appluse, but shareholders calling for the defeat of his proposal got a larger hand from the gathering. The meeting today was preceded by an intense lobbying effort by both sides to woo shareholders. ``It's disappointing when a management appears to reject a program that could do nothing but benefit all shareholders,'' Icahn said in an open letter in newspapers to Corry last week. Corry respnded with his own open letter, calling Icahn's proposal ``is flawed and is neither cost nor tax efficient.'' Even if Icahn's proposal doesn't garner a majority, analysts who have followed the company and the takeover business in general speculated USX would have to respond if his plan received a substantial number of votes. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, is a veteran of wars with management at USX and other big companies, and has learned he can win even in defeat. He lost a fight to unseat the board of Texaco Inc. two years ago, but the oil giant later restructured and he took home a $338.6 million dividend. The USX vote represents a test of sorts on the future of takeover strategists. Stymied by a lack of financing since the collapse of the junk bond market last fall, would-be dealmakers and corporate raiders have returned to proxy votes and shareholder proposals to seek control of companies or a bigger voice in management. A clear loss for Icahn would place into doubt how much power a strategist has these days. In March, investor Harold Simmons lost a fight to unseat the board of Lockheed Corp. The big winners in that battle were the big institutional investors, who forced Lockheed management to make some big concessions in exchange for their support.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Shows Small Increase of Three
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and natural gas rigs improved slightly this week, increasing by three to total 930, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The rig count showed a modest gain after posting declines for several weeks. Last week, the count slipped by five to 927. A year ago, the rig count was 764, Baker Hughes said. Baker Hughes' rig count is the widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Louisiana posted the largest gain with eight, followed by California with three. Michigan and Wyoming each gained two, while Colorado, Ohio and Texas had one more each. Oklahoma's count was down by seven, while New Mexico and Pennsylvania each lost two. Kansas and North Dakota each lost one.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Urges Crackdown on Delinquent IMF Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today the United States will support increasing the resources of the International Monetary Fund only if it agrees to crack down on poor countries behind in their loan payments. Brady's comments, to IMF's policy-making Interim Committee, came one day after finance leaders of the world's seven largest industrial powers endorsed a 50 percent boost in the fund's resources to $180 billion from the current $120 billion. Brady acknowledged that the 152-nation lending organization needs more money to meet new demand for its loans from Eastern European countries moving from communism to capitalism, as well as for developing nations. Although the United States had supported a smaller boost, he said it has agreed to 50 percent as a compromise. ``We firmly believe that the IMF must have adequate resources ... to continue to fulfill its critical responsibilities in the world economy,'' he said. However, he said the United States would support an increase in capital contributions from member nations, called quotas, only if the fund adopts a new strategy to wring $4 billion in back payments from 11 countries _ Sudan,Zambia, Peru, Honduras, Guyana, Cambodia, Vietnam, Liberia, Panama, Sierra Leone and Somalia. ``These arrears pose a fundamental challenge to the IMF's financial integrity and its central role in the world economy,'' Brady said. The Group of Seven _ finance ministers and central bank chiefs from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada and Italy _ met Sunday in an ornate caucus room in the Capitol. They said a 50 percent quota increase ``would provide the fund with the resources to fulfill its central responsibilities in the world economy.'' IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus originally sought a 100 percent increase to enable the fund to support emerging capitalism in Eastern Europe and back Brady's strategy for easing the crushing $1.3 trillion Third World debt. Many developing countries are pushing for a bigger increase, and 70 percent of the IMF membership has supported an increase of two-thirds or more. The issue moves today to the 22-nation Interim Committee, the IMF policy board. The increase must be approved by 85 percent of the fund's voting power. The United States, with 20 percent of the voting power, effectively has a veto on the matter. ``It's going to be a difficult meeting, one that will take some time and some very sensitive listening,'' said Canadian Finance Minister Michael Wilson, chairman of the Interim Committee. Currency markets, often the focus of Group of Seven gatherings, received less attention. Exchange rates have been relatively stable since the ministers' last meeting on April 7 in Paris, but the yen remains near a three-year low against the dollar. In Sunday's statement, the officials ``noted with satisfaction the recent stability of exchange markets'' but said they ``remained of the view that the present level may have undesirable consequences for the global adjustment process.'' A weak yen helps boost the U.S. trade deficit by making American goods more expensive in Japan and Japanese products cheaper in the United States. Also on the agenda of the session, closed to reporters and the public, were the economic efects of the reunification of Germany and a review of progress since Brady launched the new debt strategy in March 1989. The Group of Seven gathering preceded the spring meetings today and Tuesday of the IMF and its sister lending organization, the World Bank. Its seal of approval is the crucial first step for the $60 billion increase in capital contributions, known as quotas. The U.S. share would be about $12 billion. The increase faces opposition from members of Congress skeptical of foreign aid programs, even though the complex treatment of IMF finances keeps the U.S. contribution from showing up in the budget deficit. At the urging of the United States, the Group of Seven also agreed to link the quota increase with a plan to deal with the 11 countries which are about $4 billion behind in loan payments to the IMF. Money in a special IMF fund would be used to help the countries pull their economies up. However, nations in arrears would lose their voting rights, and gold roughly equivalent to their original contribution to the IMF could be sold if they did not meet their obligations. The Group of 24, which represents Third World countries, said in a statement that suspending voting rights ``will not serve a useful purpose and is not acceptable.'' Regarding German unification, the Group of Seven said it ``would contribute to improved non-inflationary global growth and to a reduction of external imbalances.'' However, most private economists worry that plans to give the East German mark equal value in many instances with the West German mark will add to inflation worldwide, pushing interest rates higher.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has Agreed to No Preconditions on Budget Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing thruout. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has agreed with congressional leaders to set ``no preconditions'' on their effort to negotiate a bipartisan budget compromise, the White House said today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the talks will be ``unfettered'' by stances from the past, including Bush's longstanding insistence that there be no new taxes. He said new efforts to forge a compromise were motivated in part by ``anxiety over a deficit that is fighting every reduction attempt that we can come up with.'' ``The participants agreed on two or three kind of basic operating principles. One would be that there are no preconditions, that anyone can bring up an issue for discussion and debate,'' Fitzwater told reporters. ``They agreed that they can't negotiate a budget in public, that it does take a lot of give and take and moving back and forth, so we'll try to keep a little mystery in the marriage,'' the spokesman said. ``They will continue the process as long as they believe that it has a chance of being productive. There are no deadlines,'' he said. Asked whether Bush was abandoning his refusal to consider raising taxes, Fitzwater reke over investigations in Kashmir. At least 300 people have been killed in the northwestern state since the government cracked down on a Moslem separatist movement in January. Just south of Kashmir, bureau agents are investigating separatist violence by Sikh extremists in Punjab state. Many Punjab police are virtually confined to their barracks because they are favorite targets of Sikh extremists, who have killed more than 5,800 people in Punjab since 1987. In Assam, a remote northeastern state, bureau agents are looking closely at the Bodos, an animist tribe that believes spirits live in rocks and trees. The Bodos want a separate state within India and have attacked Assamese Hindus. The real work of Shekhar's agency, however, is fighting corruption. India's British colonial rulers established the Central Bureau of Investigation soon after World War II to investigate links between Indian businessmen and the government. That work continued after independence in 1947. Of the 1,200 cases filed by the bureau's 3,907 agents every year, about 1,000 are corruption-related, Shekhar said. Corruption is the grease of South Asia's wheels. Traffic cops routinely take ``baksheesh,'' small cash payments, to ignore violations. Businessmen consider payoffs and kickbacks part of the job. Shekhar said the problem has been growing. Industrialization, inflation, development, unemployment _ all contribute to it, he said, and ``the facets that give impetus to corruption are getting more and more pronounced.'' Preliminary charges have been filed in three cases involving members of Gandhi's government. Two concern alleged payment of bribes by Europe's Airbus Industrie consortium and Hawaldtswerke-Deutsche Werft, a West German submarine manufacturer. A former high-level civil servant was charged in connection with a $1.47 billion Airbus deal for 38 planes and a former defense secretary was named in a case involving four West German subs worth $334 million. The agency also has filed preliminary charges related to a $1.4 billion artillery contract with the Swedish arms manufacturer AB Bofors. Bureau investigators have charged Bofors with cheating India out of $37 million and Indian government officials, not identified, with criminal misconduct. Charges related to an alleged political dirty tricks campaign against the son of Prime Minster Singh are expected soon. Western diplomats say the growing scope of bureau responsibily is a sign local police cannot cope with the level and complexity of crime in India. It also indicates, they say, that the central government does not trust local officials. ``Under these circumstances, it's easy for the law enforcment process to break down,'' a diplomat said, on condition of anonymity. ``The bureau is stretched too thin. They don't have good relations with local police and the crooks keep committing crimes.'' Critics say many of the bureau's investigations are politically motivated. Charges of corruption haunted the Gandhi administration. Singh, formerly Gandhi's finance minister, quit the government when his corruption investigations were stymied. Diplomats say there appears to be vindictiveness in the investigations, and cite the one concerning the prime minister's son. By forcing the bureau to concentrate on what many consider a minor case, Singh's administration is using law enforcement to fight its political battles, another Western diplomat said. Shekhar denied his bureau could be used for political purposes. ``Our work has nothing to with politics,'' he said. ``If we think the case is legitimate, we investigate.'' Shekhar made his mark late in his career when he led the investigation of one of India's biggest bank robberies, the theft of $3.35 million from the Punjab National Bank in 1987. Ten of the original 24 suspects wound up dead, but Shekhar says the police didn't kill them. Several others disappeared and only a few were convicted and jailed. In the Indian context, the case was considered a success. The director general looks at his current post in a similar light: Incremental steps can be taken, but no major changes should be expected. ``If we can set an example with one or two corruption cases, I suppose we are doing our job,'' Shekhar said. ``But, then again, nobody could pay any attention.''

DOC.HEAD: K-III to Buy Automotive Industry Publisher Ward's Communications
DOC.TEXT: The publishing concern K-III Holdings LP said Monday it has agreed to acquire the assets of Ward's Communications, which publishes several highly-regarded publications dealing with the automotive industry. Neither K-III nor the seller, Thomson Corp., a Canadian publishing and information services conglomerate, disclosed terms of the deal. Among Ward's publications are the weekly newsletter Ward's Automotive Reports, which is widely read within the auto industry for its news and production statistics. It also publishes the monthly magazines Ward's Automotive World and Ward's Auto Dealer, the biweekly newsletters Ward's Engine Update and Ward's Automotive International and the annual Ward's Automotive Yearbook. Charles McCurdy, executive vice president of K-III Holdings, said the purchase was ``part of our continuing program to build the K-III group of companies through acquisitions and product development.'' He said his company has ``no current plans for changes'' at the Ward's publications, had recently met with the staff and was pleased with the quality of the publications. He said Ward's was profitable. Thomson, based in Toronto, had put Detroit-based Ward's up for sale in early March, citing a strategic decision by its information publishing group. A Thomson spokesman said several parties expressed interest but declined to say how many bids were received. Ward's has been in business since 1924 and was acquired by Thomson in 1981. K-III, which was formed last year by several former executives of the publishing company Macmillan Inc. and the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., said it was making the purchase through its Intertec Publishing Corp. subsidiary. Intertec is a publisher of trade magazines and technical books in the telecommunications, agricultural and industrial fields. In addition to Intertec, K-III Holdings owns the Macmillan Book Clubs Inc., which operates professional books clubs, and K-III Press Inc., which provides information to the rail, truck and ocean freight industries. K-III Press includes assets of International Thomson Transport Press Inc., another Thomson subsidiary which K-III Holdings agreed to buy in January. Terms of that transaction were also not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: French, British Firms Reportedly To Develop New Supersonic Plane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT that British Aerospace is owned by investors, not government.
DOC.TEXT: The major aerospace companies of France and Britain will team up to develop a supersonic passenger plane with greater speed, capacity and range than their existing Concorde, according to a report published Monday. La Tribune, a Paris-based financial newspaper, said the accord between privately owned British Aerospace PLC and France's Aerospatiale, which is owned by the government, would be announced Wednesday. Aerospatiale confirmed ``an important agreement'' would be announced in Paris on Wednesday regarding a new supersonic airplane, but it declined to give other details. The project would cost between $8.5 billion and $13.5 billion, according to La Tribune. It would require about five years of research and take eight years to manufacture, the newspaper said. International aviation experts agreed that the next generation of supersonic passenger planes would need to carry at least 200 people at speeds of Mach 2.5, or 2{ times the speed of sound, on flights up of to 7,460. The Concordes, developed in the mid-1970s, carry about 110 people at Mach 2, twice the speed of sound, and have a range of about 3,730 miles. Aerospatiale announced Monday that it has agreed to expand cooperation with the state-controlled Italian group Selenia Industrie Elettroniche Associate SpA to cover all areas of their missile operations. Aerospatiale said the accord will cover research, development and joint industrial projects, expanding on a previous accord for ground-to-air missiles signed in 1988. It said the two groups have also agreed to study cooperation in the field of satellites.

DOC.HEAD: Help-Wanted Index Dips in March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source until 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The Help-Wanted Index of the Conference Board, which tracks the volume of employment ads in newspapers, dipped slightly in March, the business group said Monday. The seasonally adjusted index, in which 100 represents 1967, stood at 139 in March, down from February's 140. The index was 12 points below the year-ago figure of 150. ``Although labor demand was softer in March than three months earlier, it is no longer declining,'' Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein said. ``The pace of economic activity was strong enough in the first quarter of 1990 to halt the decline in help-wanted advertising volume.'' He said he expected ad volume to pick up in coming months. Ad volume registered declines in six of the nine regions of the country monitored by the business group. The west north central region recorded the steepest drop, 11 percent. The east south central and east north central regions posted increases of 4.5 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively. The Conference Board surveys help-wanted advertising volume in 51 major newspapers. The group says the ad volume is sensitive to job market conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic Richfield Profits Off 22 Pct
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. reported Monday that its first quarter profit declined 22 percent over a year ago despite firmer crude oil prices. The oil giant said a big after-tax gain in last year's quarter and additional provisions for future clean-up costs this year helped depress its latest results. For the first three months of 1990, Arco netted $547 million, or $3.28 per share, down from earnings of $704 million, or $4 a share, in 1989. Sales were up 6 percent to $4.21 billion from $3.96 billion. Arco said the 1989 quarter included a $634 million after-trax gain from the initial public offering of Lyondell Petrochemical Co., although that was partially offset by $345 million in charges for future environmental and other expenses. In this year's quarter, Arco adopted new accounting procedures, resulting in a $323 million reduction in its deferred tax liability. However, that was partially offset by $233 million in charges for expenses such as future clean-ups, it said. Excluding those one-time considerations, earnings would have risen 10 percent, to $457 million from $415 million, due to improving prices for crude oil and refined products and higher natural gas sales, Arco Chairman Lodwrick M. Cook said. After-tax quarterly earnings for worldwide oil and gas operations rose 64 percent to $319 million from $195 million. Arco's average price for domestic crude oil was $14.72 per 42-gallon barrel, up from $11.85 per barrel in the first quarter of 1989. Average domestic natural gas prices were $1.89 per thousand cubic feet, compared with $1.80 in the first quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Carrier Orders from CFM
DOC.TEXT: Gulf Air, the airline of four Middle Eastern countries, has ordered CFM International jet engines worth $225 million to power Airbus Industrie A320 jetliners, the engine maker said Monday. CFM said the CFM56-5 engines would power 12 Airbus jetlines, with an option for six more. Delivery is to begin in 1992 and continue through 1994. Gulf Air, owned by Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and Abu Dhabi, plans to use the Airbus jetliners to expand its fleet of short- to medium-range aircraft and to replace aging Boeing 737-200s, CFM said. The engine maker, a joint venture between General Electric Co. and the French company SNECMA, is based in suburban Evendale.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Double Price Paid to Grain Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government on Monday doubled the price paid to grain farmers in hopes of stimulating this year's harvest at the risk of a substantial increase in its budget deficit. The price paid for top-quality soft grain will rise from 260 rubles to 500 rubles per ton under Monday's order from the Council of Ministers, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The price paid for other grains will rise by 30 percent to nearly 100 percent. But while farmers will be paid more to produce animal feed, they will not be asked to pay higher prices for the feed they buy, the announcement said. That could mean a hefty increase in government subsidies and the 90 billion ruble, or $150 billion, budget deficit. The deficit is considered a factor in the country's problems with inflation and extreme shortages of food and consumer goods. Farmers who raise their crops without pesticides will be paid a premium, Tass said. The Soviet Union two years ago awoke to a severe problem of food contamination due to overuse of agricultural chemicals.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Senses Imminent Defeat But Expects Eventual Victory
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn sounded Monday like he expected USX Corp. shareholders to defeat his plan for splitting up the steel-energy conglomerate, but he still foresaw an eventual victory for his campaign to boost its stock price. ``We'll stick around to see that (stock) value appreciate,'' the takeover strategist said USX held its annual meeting. ``We're not going anywhere.'' Icahn conceded at the meeting that he might not have the crucial support of several big institutional investors for his non-binding proposal to spin off USX's lackluster U.S. Steel subsidiary from the more robust Marathon Oil Co. The takeover strategist, well-known for his forays against Texaco Inc. and other industrial giants, says the breakup would boost USX's stock value. But in the face of an anticipated defeat, Icahn _ whose 13.3 percent stake in USX makes him the company's largest shareholder _ already had his next move figured out. Icahn said he would continue talking with the ``strong nucleus of shareholders'' who he said agreed that USX management must do something to improve the company's stock price. Icahn said he was unlikely to make a takeover bid for USX because the company's ``poison pill'' defense limited the number of shares he could buy. Nevertheless, he indicated he expected his restructuring strategy to win out at USX, as it had at Texaco even though he lost a fight to win control of that company's management. Icahn lost a fight to unseat Texaco's board of directors at the oil giant's 1988 annual meeting. But several months later, Texaco management decided to undertake a restructuring _ including the sales of billions of dollars worth of assets _ that Icahn had campaigned for as a means of boosting share values. ``We were right at Texaco,'' he told reporters Monday. Before the USX meeting, observers said Icahn eventually could force management to restructure aggressively even if his proposal failed. The company has said it will continue its 10-year-old restructuring, but management wants to accomplish it on its own terms. There was no surge of support for Icahn apparent at Monday's gathering. He received polite applause for his comments, but shareholders who spoke in favor of management and against breaking up the company got a slightly more enthusiastic hand. The three and one-half-hour meeting was attended by some 600 shareholders, most of them individual stockholders and retirees of USX subsidiaries. The meeting largely was uneventful _ the company's biggest shareholders, the institutional investors, did not speak, and many already had submitted their proxies. Results of the vote were not expected for at least a week. Icahn got the most support from the crowd when he complained about the USX stock price, which he contended would improve if U.S. Steel were spun off and shareholders were issued separate stock for U.S. Steel and for Marathon. The outcome of Monday's vote was being watched as an indicator of how much strength takeover strategists have in the 1990s, now that the debt-financed takeover boom has ended. In March, takeover strategist Harold Simmons lost a proxy fight that sought to remove the board of directors at Lockheed Corp. The biggest winners in that battle were institutional investors who extracted concessions from Lockheed management.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Double Price Paid to Grain Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to restore cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government on Monday doubled the price paid to grain farmers in hopes of stimulating this year's harvest at the risk of a substantial increase in its budget deficit. The price paid for top-quality soft grain will rise from 260 rubles to 500 rubles per ton under Monday's order from the Council of Mnisters, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The price paid for other grains will rise by 30 percent to nearly 100 percent. But while farmers will be paid more to produce animal feed, they will not be asked to pay higher prices for the feed they buy, the announcement said. That could mean a hefty increase in government subsidies and the 90 billion ruble, or $150 billion, budget deficit. The deficit is considered a factor in the country's problems with inflation and extreme shortages of food and consumer goods. Farmers who raise their crops without pesticides will be paid a premium, Tass said. The Soviet Union two years ago awoke to a severe problem of food contamination due to overuse of agricultural chemicals.

DOC.HEAD: USX Takes Over Junior High For Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: It was a typical Monday morning at Central Junior High School. Athletes pounded the boards in the gymnasium and sewing machines hummed in home economics classes. But the assembly in the school auditorium wasn't a gathering of seventh- or eighth-graders. The 600 people who packed the room were shareholders of USX Corp. It was the first time Central Junior High hosted an annual meeting, USX spokesmen said. But the school was ready for its visitors. In addition to the auditorium, school officials turned over their board room, which was used by reporters as a press center, and the school cafeteria, which provided hot dogs for the journalists' lunch. Reporters wandering through the basement, past the cafeteria and lockers said they had a sense of deja vu. Of course, this all begs the question, what were they doing in a junior high school, and what were they doing in Findlay? Easy: It was the only place with enough space to handle the crowd, and Findlay is home to Marathon Oil Co., one of USX's biggest subsidiaries. USX also was well-organized, with an army of security officers and ushers inside the school, and attendants guiding cars to parking spaces. The 3{-hour meeting was orderly and cordial, despite the presence on the agenda of a proposal by takeover strategist Carl Icahn to break up the steel-and-energy conglomerate. However, one shareholder, Peter Rosko of Minneapolis, used Icahn's proposal to make a few jabs at USX management. Icahn has contended his plan would give shareholders a higher price for their stock. Rosko asked USX Chairman Charles A. Corry what the USX stock price would be in 1992 if Icahn's plan was rejected. Corry responded that he did not know, and Rosko later laughed as he told a reporter, ``I was simply goading him.'' Most of the shareholders at the meeting were individual stockholders, and most of these appeared to be retirees who make regular appearances at such corporate sessions. One shareholder, who did not give his name, stood up toward the end of the meeting and complimented Corry for his handling of his first stockholder gathering. Corry succeeded David M. Roderick as USX chairman last June.

DOC.HEAD: Offers Guarantees to Business Travelers, Reduces Childrens' Fares
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines on Monday announced a money-back guarantee to business travelers and sharply reduced fares for children on some flights, in the latest bid to attract passengers to the rebuilding carrier. Martin Shugrue, the court-appointed trustee running Eastern, said travelers buying certain tickets could get their money back if they are for any reason unhappy with the flight. The fares are geared to business travelers. Shugrue also said that summer fares for children to nine Florida cities would be $39 on peak days and $29 on other days. Normally, children pay standard fares. Eastern has tried a variety of promotions in recent months in an attempt to bounce back from more than a year of financial difficulties related to the strike that pushed the airline into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Miami-based airline, whose largest hub is in Atlanta, expects to lose $330 million this year and has been operating at 65 percent to 70 percent capacity on its flights. Delta Air Lines and American Airlines said Monday they were reviewing Eastern's offers but indicated they are not likely to match them. ``Delta's position is you have to charge what it costs to produce the service, or you go out of business,'' spokesman Bill Berry said. ``What we've got to look at it is, `Does it make sense to match a fare that's totally unrealistic?''' Eastern's announcement followed its recent introduction of ``Y-Not'' reduced rates for passengers who purchase first-class seats. Shugrue was named last month by a federal judge in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York to operate Eastern during its reorganization. He said he was not concerned the rash of special offers would be viewed by the public as desperation moves. ``I think that prior to the change in control, perhaps there was a feeling in the marketplace that Eastern wasn't long for this world ...,'' Shugrue told a news conference at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. ``Obviously what I'm trying to do is to put that to rest. We are here. We've got plenty of cash available to us to fund our operation while we go through the reorganization process,'' he said. Shugrue shed little new light on plans for guiding Eastern through reorganization. Labor talks are continuing with pilots and the striking Machinists union, he said. Shugrue's appointment as trustee stripped control of Eastern from Frank Lorenzo, whose Texas Air Corp. still owns the airline.

DOC.HEAD: Riney Ad Agency Resigns Remaining Perrier Assignments
DOC.TEXT: Hal Riney & Partners, fired in late March as the advertising agency for the Perrier sparkling water brand, has resigned as the agency for several other brands handled by Perrier Group of America Inc. John Yost, an executive of the San Francisco-based ad agency, on Monday confirmed published reports that Riney had quit the Arrowhead, Zephyrhills, Ozarka and Calistoga bottled water accounts last week. He said the four brands spent about $8 million last year on advertising. That is roughly what Perrier Group said it spent on advertising the Perrier brand as well last year. ``It was clear they were breaking up their business into a lot of smaller pieces,'' Yost said. ``And it became clear we were not going to be able to negotiate a satisfactory compensation agreement.'' The moves come just weeks after Perrier was reintroduced in the United States following a February recall. Some bottles of the trendy and expensive import were tainted with traces of benzene, believed to cause cancer when ingested in large doses. Perrier Group spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said no plans had yet been made to find a new agency for the four brands. She said Riney would continue to service the accounts until mid-summer. She said one reason Riney may have left is that Perrier plans to consolidate media buying for all 10 of its bottled water brands at one agency. That would give it greater clout than several agencies buying media for one of two brands at a time. But such an arrangement may mean less compensation for agencies that do only the creative work without being responsible for arranging media placements. Lazgin said Perrier has not yet decided which agency would handle media buying, but said spending on all 10 brands should amount to about $25 million a year. In addition to Perrier and the four brands handled by Riney, Perrier Group distributes Poland Spring, Volvic, Oasis, Great Bear and Ice Mountain water. Perrier Group, based in Greenwich, Conn., awarded the Perrier brand assignment to Waring & LaRosa Inc., a New York-based ad agency, on March 28, several weeks before the re-launch. Riney had created the campaign that used the slogan ``It's perfect. It's Perrier'' for the Perrier brand and had worked on various Perrier Group brands for about five years. Waring & LaRosa had formerly worked on Perrier advertising, creating the slogan ``Earth's first soft drink'' for the brand in the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Playboy Recap Would Double Outstanding Shares
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Playboy stock... to UPDATE with closing price.
DOC.TEXT: Playboy Enterprises Inc. on Monday unveiled a recapitalization plan aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of founder Hugh Hefner. The recapitalization, subject to shareholder approval, would establish two classes of common stock, including a new class of non-voting stock. It would increase the number of outstanding Playboy shares from 15 million to 37.5 million, including 30 million shares of non-voting stock, the company said. The plan would not dilute the holdings of Hefner, who owns 70.6 percent of the current outstanding common shares and said he would vote to approve the plan. Under its present structure, Playboy could not raise money by selling additional common stock without making the stake held by Hefner, who is chairman emeritus and Playboy magazine editor in chief, relatively smaller. ``We believe that the proposed recapitalization will provide Playboy with increased flexibility to use equity in future acquisitions, financings, and employee benefit plans without diluting the voting power of existing stockholders,'' said Christie Hefner, Playboy's chairman and chief executive officer, in a telephone interview. Playboy stock rose 12{ cents to $12.87{ a share in New York Stock Exchange trading. Under the plan, Playboy stockholders will receive half of a Class A voting share for each of their current Playboy shares, followed by a dividend of three non-voting Class B shares for each of the Class A shares their received in the split. The recapitalization includes a ``minority protection'' feature designed to help ensure that the two classes of stock trade at approximately equal market prices, Ms. Hefner said. The provision requires that anyone wanting to buy a specific voting position of the Class A voting stock must buy a proportionate amount of the non-voting shares. Some industry analysts said the plan, already adopted by Playboy's board of directors, reflects the publishing and video company's renewed financial vigor. Playboy last week reported net income of $554,000 for its third fiscal quarter, up from from $262,000 a year earlier. For the nine months ended March 31, net income was $6 million, including a $4.8 million gain on the sale of the assets of its Boarts International Inc. subsidiary, compared with $2.2 million in the year-earlier period. ``I really see the recap as another building block, that having established a base of profitability ... we now are looking ahead to the '90s with an eye to expanding internationally in both publishing and entertainment, and doing that with other companies,'' said Ms. Hefner. After succeeding with the ``Playboy Late Night'' television series in Europe, Playboy has begun talks with foreign and domestic production companies about possibly co-producing television programs, Ms. Hefner said. Playboy is the sole producer of ``Playboy Late Night,'' a weekly television magazine-format series that debuted in France last September and now appers in 10 countries. Playboy also is talking with potential publishing partners about forming an alliance similar to its link with duPont Publishing, Inc., she said. Playboy in 1988 acquired a 20 percent interest in the publisher of the duPont Registry, a monthly magazine for car buffs. Buzz Zaino, an industry analyst and managing director of Trust Co. of the West in New York, said the recapitalization will help Playboy make similar deals. ``It does provide her the flexibilty to expand the business with the use of stock, either by selling stock in a public offering or using the stock to acquire other business,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Anticipated Export Business Boosts Grain, Soybean Prices
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as expectation of additional export sales fueled buying interest. On other markets, energy futures were higher, precious metals prices rose, copper futures retreated, and livestock and pork futures advanced. Wheat settled 3 cents to 5} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.83 a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 3{ cents higher with May at $2.90} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with May at $1.68 a bushel; soybeans were 8{ cents to 11 cents higher with May at $6.37 a bushel. Trading opened Monday with prices down across the board in a follow through to Friday's negative close. But investor fund buying set in at mid-morning when the lower prices failed to trigger heavy selling. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said soybean prices were helped by an anticipated surge in export business. He said there are indications the Soviet Union may enter the market for 150,000 to 200,000 metric tons of soymeal. The sharp rise in soybean prices came despite weekend progress in the harvest of the South American soybean crop. But even with the surge in harvest activity, the export pace remains slight, analysts said. The strength of soybean prices helped boost corn futures. Corn prices also were helped by expectations that the Soviet Union may buy more corn. After the close of trading Monday, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced the sale of 1.75 million metric tons of corn to the Soviet Union. On Friday, the USDA announced the Soviets purchased 600,000 metric tons of corn. Wheat prices were higher, with traders anticipating the Agriculture Department will offer export bonus terms to several foreign countries, Karlin said. Livestock and pork futures surged on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures climbed on higher than expected cash hog prices and expectations that prices would continue rising Tuesday. Hog movement from farms to market has been curbed as farmers concentrate on planting corn. Livestock futures rose on commission house buying stemming from higher cash prices at the wholesale level. Live cattle were .25 cent to .55 cent higher with June at 75.20 a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .80 cent higher with May at 84.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to 1 cent higher with June at 64.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.40 cents higher with May at 70.30 cents a pound. Gold and silver futures closed higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with both metals trading in a narrow range. Gold prices largely were influenced by the weakness in the dollar against other currencies. Silver prices followed the action in gold. Gold was 90 cents to $1.20 higher with June at $374 a troy ounce; silver was 1.5 cents to 1.6 cents higher with May at $5.016 a troy ounce. Comex copper prices fell due to a late round of commission house selling. Helping to push prices lower was Friday's news that the strike at the Southern Peru Copper Corp. mine has been settled, said Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. Copper was 1.60 cents to 1.80 cents lower with May at $1.1172 a pound. Energy futures closed higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Robert Baker, analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said the market reacted positively to Friday's official statement by the Saudi Arabian government endorsing the pledge by OPEC oil ministers to reduce their combined output by 1.5 million barrels a day. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 9 cents to 29 cents higher with June at $18.27 a barrel; heating oil was .36 cent to .50 cent higher with June at 50.44 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to .74 cent higher with June at 61.86 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell Monday against most major currencies due to a stronger West German mark and continuing concern over the U.S. unemployment rate. Gold prices strengthened. Gold rose $1 a troy ounce to $371.90 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.70, up 40 cents from late Friday. Traders said the currency market continued to feel the effects of Friday's unemployment report, which showed the jobless rate rose from 5.2 percent in March to 5.4 percent in April, the highest rate in over a year. Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York, said the unemployment report ``was not only weak, but it raises the question of whether we're seeing a slowdown in the service sector.'' The report sparked concern that the Federal Reserve would be reluctant to let interest rates rise due to the signs of economic weakness. Hodge said interest rates, which have risen in recent weeks, have been a prime supporting factor for the value of the dollar. Higher interest rates tend to make the dollar more valuable relative to other currencies. Hodge said the mark rose relative to most other currencies after officials of East and West Germany gave assurances that the upcoming merger of the monetary systems of the two nations would not disrupt financial markets or be excessively inflationary. The mark also continued to be boosted by the settlement of a West German metalworkers union contract Friday that was viewed as less inflationary than many observers feared, he said. In Europe, where London markets were closed for a holiday, the dollar fell against the British pound. One pound cost $1.6710, more expensive than $1.6595 late Friday. In in New York, the pound cost $1.6685, up from $1.6635 late Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.75 yen to close at 157.80 yen. Later, in Europe, the dollar was quoted at 157.55 yen. In New York trading, the dollar bought 158.15 yen, down from 158.30 yen late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.6556 West German marks, down from 1.6660; 1.4310 Swiss francs, down from 1.4430; 5.5615 French francs, down from 5.5930; 1,214.50 Italian lire, down from 1,221.00; and 1.1633 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1629. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, included: 1.6550 West German marks, down from 1.6710; 1.4320 Swiss francs, down from 1.4435; 5.5555 French francs, down from 5.6060; 1.8590 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8782; 1,213.50 Italian lire, down from 1,224.50; and 1.1617 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1630. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $371.70, up from $371.00 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 34 cents to close at a bid $373.10. Silver prices also rose. Silver for current delivery traded at $5.016 a troy ounce from $5.00 late Friday on the Commodity Exchange. London silver trading was closed due to the holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Rise on News of Shutdown in Gulf of Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose late Monday, strengthened by word that an important pipeline feed from Gulf of Mexico platforms off the Louisiana coast had been shut down because of a suspected leak. Traders said the shutdown raised the prospect of shortages for a quality grade of oil extracted from the area just as the oil industry is preparing for higher demand from the impending summer driving season. They said there was little other external news affecting the market. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the June-contract price of the key West Texas Intermediate crude rose 29 cents a barrel to $18.27 after trading in a narrow range through much of the day. Later contract month prices also finished higher. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale home heating oil for June delivery rose .59 cent a gallon to 50.44 cents. Subsequent contract months also rose. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 0.56 cent a gallon to 61.68 cents, while later contract months finished higher as well. Natural gas for June delivery finished at $1.580 per million British Thermal Units, vs. its $1.575 closing price Friday. Subsequent months were mixed. Traders speculated the Eugene Island Pipeline System off Louisiana could affect as much as 120,000 barrels of production per day, aggravating previously existing shortages in that area. The pipeline is operated by Texaco Inc. and is owned jointly by six major oil companies.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Volume on... to CORRECT consolidated volume to 160.89 million shares sted 891.84 million; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `As measured...
DOC.TEXT: The stock market forged ahead Monday, extending last week's rally as Wall Street awaited a record-sized offering of government securities. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 65.31 points last week, rose another 11.26 to 2,721.62. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 943 up, 571 down and 493 unchanged. Over three days beginning on Tuesday the Treasury is scheduled to auction $30.5 billion in bonds and notes. The mood of stock and bond traders has vacillated as the quarterly financing operation approaches. At times, fears have spread that the auction will be poorly received, prompting further increases in long-term interest rates. But those worries lost a little of their edge late last week, when the Labor Department issued figures showing much smaller-than-expected employment growth in April. The data abruptly silenced talk that the Federal Reserve might be about to tighten its credit policy. Some financial and utility issues continued to benefit from more optimistic views of the interest-rate outlook. Dow Jones's average of 15 utilities rose 2.13 to 210.51, for a 1 percent advance that more than doubled the industrials' percentage gain. Columbia Gas System rose } to 47\; Pacificorp \ to 22[; Philadelphia Electric \ to 16; Peoples Energy { to 22\, and Niagara Mohawk Power \ to 12~. In the financial sector, Federal National Mortgage rose { to 35] and Federal Home Loan Mortgage, which reported higher first-quarter earnings, gained } to 67]. Among the blue-chip industrials, Digital Equipment climbed { to 88{; General Motors { to 46\; Bristol-Myers Squibb | to 57; General Electric { to 65~, and Procter & Gamble 1{ to 75. Universal Matchbox, up 1 at 5\, posted the day's biggest percentage advance. The company declined to comment on the activity. Suave Shoe rose } to 7. Earnings from continuing operations came to 44 cents a share in the first quarter, against 16 cents in the like period last year. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 132.76 million shares, against 140.55 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 160.89 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $18.32 billion, or 0.57 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.07 to 186.45. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.34 to 396.54, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.14 at 340.53. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 2.62 to 431.23. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 347.33, up 1.60.

DOC.HEAD: Chevy, Dodge Delay Convertible Introductions
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. said Monday that new convertibles will not be introduced until after the prime spring buying season for the cars. Company spokesmen said vehicle quality was below a desired level, but they did not elaborate. Chevrolet spokesman Ralph Kramer said it is unlikely that GM will market any 1990 Chevrolet Beretta convertibles, which had been forecast to account for about 5,000 in sales this year. Dodge spokesman Scott Sweeney said the introduction of a 1991 Dodge Shadow convertible would be delayed by six to eight weeks, until late summer. Kramer declined to discuss the problems, but said they occurred after the cars were assembled as hardtops at GM's Wilmington, Del., plant and then taken to C&C Inc., based in Brighton, for conversion into convertibles. Such an arrangement is not unusual for manufacturing convertibles. Chrysler builds the Dodge Shadow in Toluca, Mexico, and converts the cars to convertibles there. The cars are then brought into the United States for sale. Chrysler also builds Shadows at its Sterling Heights factory.

DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Extends Bond Offer Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Ingersoll Newspapers Inc. said Monday it is extending until May 11 the deadline for its offer to buy back $159 million in high-yield junk bonds. No shares were tendered by the previous May 4 deadline, said Stanley J. Kay, vice president of Dewe Rogerson Inc., a financial public relations firm representing Ingersoll. Terms of the deal were unchanged. Ingersoll has offered to buy back up to 80 percent of $125 million worth of bonds for 55 cents on the dollar. It also would pay 25 cents on the dollar for 51 percent of $115 million in bonds that won't start paying interest until June 1991. The bonds, issued at 13 percent interest, have been selling at 40 cents on the dollar. The reset provision would require Ingersoll to raise the interest rate on June 30 that the bonds would sell at $1.01. Ingersoll owns 19 daily newspapers. Analysts say the company is under pressure of a June 30 deadline to reset its interest rate to restore the value of the notes to face amount.

DOC.HEAD: Office of Thrift Supervision Names New Counsel
DOC.TEXT: The new director of the Office of Thrift Supervision on Monday appointed a lawyer with little direct experience in the savings and loan industry as the agency's top attorney. In his first appointment since taking office a month ago, thrift supervision director Timothy Ryan named Harris Weinstein, 54, as chief counsel. Weinstein will be in charge of nearly 200 lawyers and support staff. Since 1971, he has been a partner in the Washington law firm Covington & Burling, which he joined in 1962. Although he has little background in the thrift business, he has extensive experience in financial matters. He was one of the lead attorneys in his firm's representation of the then bankrupt Penn Central Railroad. From 1967 to 1969, he was the assistant to the solicitor general of the United States in charge of tax matters. Ryan, whose background is in pension and employee benefit law, also has been criticized for his lack of expertise in savings and loans. He was confirmed by the Senate on April 5 over the objections of 37 Democrats. In a statement, Ryan said he regarded Weinstein ``as one of the most astute lawyers I've ever met'' and said he ``has attained a high degree of skill in financial matters.''

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Director Responds To Keating Allegations
DOC.TEXT: Financier Charles Keating Jr. is ``full of baloney'' to say that bungling by federal regulators led to the collapse of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the nation's top thrift regulator said Monday. ``Mr. Keating took the view that regulators ought to stick their nose out of his business without recognizing that 97 percent of his assets were guaranteed by the federal government,'' said William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. He said any assertion that the thrift industry's problems can be traced to heavy-handed or incompetent regulation ``is way off the mark.'' ``He's just full of baloney,'' Seidman said of Keating. Seidman, who also heads the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency created to oversee the sale of failed savings and loans, met Monday with two local RTC advisory committees and addressed the National Council of Savings Institutions. The advisory boards passed a resolution urging the RTC to speed up disposals of seized savings and loan properties. ``It is clear to us that Arizona is poised on the recovery of its real-estate market,'' said Hank Rivoir, superintendent of the state Banking Department and chairman of the two committees. ``All that is missing is a track record of sales by the RTC.'' Seidman acknowledged there have been delays but said the RTC's ``essential job'' is to market the properties it has seized. He said the market for failed institutions ``is very limited'' and that the agency generally has not been able to sell them as ``whole and going'' operations. ``The next step is to take the institutions apart and sell them by parts,'' he said. The resolution passed by the advisory boards called on the RTC to come up with alternatives to appraisals as a means of selling thrift assets _ including options such as public auctions and acceptance of sealed bids _ to eliminate the backlog of real estate awaiting sale in Arizona. The committees also called on Seidman to move quickly to appoint a director of the RTC's Phoenix field office. Seidman told reporters that several candidates are being interviewed and someone would be appointed ``before too many more weeks.'' Responding to reporters' questions about the seizure of Lincoln S&L last year, Seidman said ``the inevitable happened'' after the thrift experienced three or four years of explosive growth and invested its profits in high-risk enterprises. He said the RTC has run into numerous difficulties with the thrift since the seizure and he blamed those problems on Keating, saying Keating had ``carefully constructed'' Lincoln as a ``series of bankrupt subsidiaries of a bankrupt holding company.'' ``It has been slow and difficult because it was set up to be that way,'' Seidman said. Asked about Keating's claim that federal regulators improperly wrote down the value of its assets, Seidman said that if Keating can sell those assets for what he claims they are worth, ``we'll give him a commission.''

DOC.HEAD: Douglas Managers Too Permissive, Air Force Official Says
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force official said permissive managers are contributing to widespread production problems at Douglas Aircraft Co., including instances where tools and stray parts have been left inside finished planes. Col. Kenneth Tollefson, the Air Force's top representative at the company, said separately that the many contractor deficiency reports issued by his office suggest Douglas' problems are widespread. Douglas, a unit of McDonnell Douglas Corp. of St. Louis, lost $84 million last quarter and has begun eliminating 3,000 white-collar jobs in an attempt to rein in costs. Major programs include the MD-80 and MD-11 passenger jets and the C-17 military cargo jet. Air Force officials have issued 34 deficiency reports against the C-17 program and also have written more serious ``letters of concern'' to senior Douglas executives, the Los Angeles Times reported Monday. The reports and letters of concern are issued when the Air Force finds a company out of compliance with regulations or beset with serious problems that affect cost, schedule or product performance. The Times also said it had obtained a memo from Douglas President John Capellupo that criticized a lack of discipline among white-collar and blue-collar workers. The memo said Douglas' ``total quality management'' program, instituted during a reorganization last year to encourage worker participation, had led to a ``permissive'' system. The Air Force's Tollefson agreed in an article in Douglas' employee newsletter. ``The lack of leadership, which includes the failure to recognize the difference between participative and permissive management, is the biggest problem facing Douglas Aircraft Co.,'' he wrote. The C-17 is at least 10 months behind schedule and is now expected to fly in June 1991. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week recommended slicing $11.9 billion from the $41.8 billion C-17 program by cutting back the number of planes to be produced from 210 to 120. Douglas spokesman Don Hanson acknowledged the program has had problems but said the company is striving to correct them. ``If you look around, you find that most contractors have some outstanding contractor deficiency reports on any program at any given time,'' he said. ``The objective is to have none, but since we are human there are some.'' One problem involves stray parts, tools and other foreign objects left in planes. Air Force officials bagged and sent to senior Douglas officials 40 pounds of such objects left inside the wing of one C-17, the Times reported. On at least one occasion, the C-17 line had to be shut down to clean up debris, the newspaper said. Now, the production line is vacuumed at the end of each shift.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Company Plans Gaming Ventures in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A group of Nevada businessmen said they have signed an agreement with the Soviet government to bring blackjack to the Black Sea. Simon Furman, general manager of Uniquad, said the company plans to spend about $1 million to open four casinos in existing hotels. The casinos will include ``Las Vegas'' in their name, he said. The first casino will have six or eight table games and 35 to 50 slot machines. It is expected to open this summer in the Dagomys Hotel in Sochi, a popular Soviet resort on the Black Sea, Furman said. Two other casinos are planned at resorts near Moscow and another is to be opened on the Black Sea. ``The foreign business climate has changed in the Soviet Union,'' Furman said last week. ``We think the casinos will do well.'' Furman said Uniquad plans to split profits from the casinos 50-50 with the Soviet government. The company said it will get part of its profits in hard currency and part in rubles, which aren't convertible into Western currencies. A former Nevada lieutenant governor, Cliff Jones, is a consultant to the corporation and will supply management teams for the casinos. He said several people with experience in gaming operations will travel to the Soviet Union to help open the casinos.

DOC.HEAD: Central Bank Chief Forecasts Surplus Decline Buttressed by Stability
DOC.TEXT: Japan sought to assure world financial leaders Monday that its stock and money markets are sound and it will continue efforts to cut its huge trade surplus. ``There was no major movement of capital out of the stock and bond markets despite this uneasiness'' over sharp market declines earlier this year, Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, told the 22-nation interim committee of the International Monetary Fund. ``There has been no change in the basic soundness of Japan's fundamentals,'' the central bank chief said. ``In fact, the markets are now considerably more stable than they were earlier this year.'' The key index of the Tokyo stock market plunged more than 25 percent early this year as interest rates shot up and the yen lost roughly 10 percent of its value against the dollar. The stock market has stabilized in recent weeks and the index has rebounded more than 10 percent from its low. Mieno also said he is ``confident that the current account surplus will continue to come steadily down,'' provided the yen doesn't weaken further. The yen's decline has made Japanese exports cheaper and imports more expensive. The current account surplus should be reduced by a combination of strong growth in Japan's domestic demand and promotion of adjustments such as expanding overseas production by Japanese firms, he said. But ``realizing that the yen's depreciation may well put a damper on such promotion of adjustments, I believe it is important for the exchange rate of the yen to be stabilized in such a way that better reflects Japan's economic fundamentals,'' Mieno said, in effect advocating a stronger yen. Mieno told a news conference Sunday he is not advocating a specific yen-dollar exchange rate but would prefer some strengthening of Japan's currency. Japan's current account surplus fell from $79.7 billion in 1988 to $57.2 billion last year, or 2 percent of gross national product, he said. The world economic ``outlook is for continued firm growth,'' Mieno said. Still, there will be a slight decline in the growth rate this year, he predicted, adding that the sweeping change in East Europe and German unification have brought ``unprecedented uncertainties.'' The sudden need for massive new investment in Europe along with continued capital for the Third World makes it imperative for ``industrial countries as a whole to increase their savings to prevent a global upsurge in interest rates and to support sustained global economic development,'' Mieno said. He predicted Japanese consumer prices would rise only 1.6 percent this year, with real economic growth of 4 percent and domestic demand up 4.6 percent. He predicted Japanese consumer prices would rise only 1.6 percent this year, with real economic growth of 4 percent and domestic demand up 4.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prices in Third World Rose Record 86.3 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices rose a record 86.3 percent on average in the Third World last year, spurred by a 350 percent rise in Latin America, the International Monetary Fund reported Monday. Among 22 industrial countries prices rose 4.5 percent, up from the 3.4 percent of 1988. The increases ranged from 1.1 percent in the Netherlands to 20.8 percent in Iceland. Japan had 2.3 percent and West Germany 2.8 percent. The United States, the world's largest economy, was a little above the average at 4.8 percent. The fund gets figures from its member countries but calculates on its own basis to make them comparable, so rates for individual countries sometimes differ from those published by governments themselves. Latin American average prices were influenced heavily by runaway inflation in two of the area's most important countries: Argentina, which had inflation of 3,079 percent, and Brazil at 1,287 percent. The Argentine figures meant the price of a basket of goods rose 30 times during the course of the year. Peru had an even higher inflation rate of 3,398 percent. Mexico, which has adopted a strict austerity program, saw its inflation rate drop to 20 percent from 114 percent in 1988. The fund classifies 130 of its members as ``developing countries,'' including those in eastern Europe. The Soviet Union does not belong and the fund gives no figures for it. For its seven European members outside the industrial group, the inflation rate rose in 1989 to an average 232 percent. The average reflected Yugoslavia's 1,239 percent inflation rate and Poland's rate of 244 percent. A fund official said Poland's inflation rate has dropped sharply this year because of the new non-communist government's shock program to shift away from central planning to a market system. The program has abolished subsidies and cut back government spending. Annual figures for Africa and the Middle East were incomplete. Many Middle East countries have not been reporting in recent years. Among those that have, Israel's inflation rate rose to 20.2 percent last year from 16.3 percent in 1988, and Egypt's rose to 21.3 percent from 17.7 percent. Africa's average appeared steady: 18.9 percent in 1988 and 21.2 percent in the third quarter of 1989. The African average masked a wide range, from Zambia's annual 186 percent rate last October to small price reductions in several countries including Chad, Togo and the Central African Republic. Only Asia showed a decline in the inflation rate. For 21 countries in that region the annual average inflation rate dropped to 10.2 percent last year from 11.8 percent in 1988. China's rate declined to 16.3 percent from 20.7 percent and India's also was falling, from 9.4 percent in 1988 to an annual rate of 6.2 percent in the third quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Proposes Easing of Antitrust Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Adds three grafs, Metzenbaum reaction. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Monday proposed changes in antitrust law that would relax restrictions on joint production ventures between U.S. companies to produce new technologies. The measure, intended to enable U.S. companies to better compete in the global marketplace, would reduce the amount of damages that plaintiffs in antitrust suits could collect from companies involved in the joint ventures. The legislation, unveiled by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, would also require courts to consider the effects of a joint venture on competition in foreign as well as domestic markets when determining if there is an antitrust violation. Antitrust restrictions on joint research and development ventures were relaxed by Congress in 1984. The administration bill would extend the concept to joint production ventures. The bill would ``help U.S. firms face unprecedented, worldwide challenges by bringing important research from the laboratory to the marketplace efficiently, cost effectively and with less risk,'' Mosbacher said in a statement. Under the proposal, plaintiffs could not collect treble damages from an antitrust judgment against companies that participate in a cooperative joint venture. The bill would allow plaintiffs to collect only the money they lost as a result of the anti-competitive practice. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, chairman of the Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the proposal was unnecessary and could be harmful. ``I say to the president, show me which deals are being lost due to fears of antitrust suits,'' Metzenbaum said. ``The real reason American companies are falling behiond is because they have been too busy trying to devour the competition with mergers, LBOs (leveraged buyouts, or management takeovers with borrowed money) and hostile takeovers.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Northrop Employees May Continue With Parts of Suit Government Rejected
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has allowed two former Northrop Corp. employees to proceed with portions of their lawsuit against the defense firm that the Justice Department declined to include when joining the suit. U.S. District Judge David V. Kenyon's ruling Monday means former Northrop manager David Peterson and engineer Jeff Kroll can pursue claims that could net them as much as $60 million in damages, said attorney Phillip E. Benson. ``It's a novel issue ... and precedent-setting,'' Benson said. Peterson and Kroll allege in their ``whistleblower'' suit that Northrop committed more than $100 million in fraud in the production of the MX missile guidance systems. The suit accuses the firm of falsifying tests and mischarging the government for tests and parts used in the Inertial Measurement Units on the missile, which are vital parts in the guidance systems. The Justice Department announced last year it was picking up ``substantial portions'' of the suit. Northrop had sought to dismiss the claims that the government declined to join. Those remaining claims involved specific instances of alleged mischarging and test falsification. But Kenyon said Monday the former employees ``will be permitted to pursue the claims which were not adopted by the government,'' even though those claims will be dropped from the joint government-employee lawsuit. Kenyon said he would call another hearing to determine whether the severed claims could be included in a separate lawsuit. Northrop attorneys declined to comment. In related rulings, Kenyon rejected Northrop's contention the employees' lawsuit was unconstitutional, but he agreed with the company that the government failed to be specific enough in alleging wrongdoing. The judge gave the government 30 days to file a tighter version of the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Trio Indicted; Face Arraignment Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: A Wall Street broker, his lawyer brother and a third man have been indicted on federal charges of perjury and obstruction of justice stemming from a $1.7 million embezzlement scheme, prosecutors said. A grand jury last week indicted the trio and a fourth individual in a case that prosecutors say dates back to 1980 and involved attempts to conceal both the laundering of checks and income tax evasion. The indictment was announced by the U.S. attorney's office Monday and the men are scheduled to be arraigned Tuesday. The checks, according to the indictment, represented about $1.6 million that had been embezzled from Bankers Trust Co. by other individuals, plus nearly $95,000 in stock loan fees. Three people pleaded guilty previously to the embezzlement and were given probation, said Jeff Fardella, assistant U.S. attorney. The new defendants are accused of having tried to obstruct that investigation, in part by falsely claiming that dead or non-existent persons had been the source of the money. Named in the indictment are Joseph J. Stella, a former vice president and manager of the stock loan department of Bear Stearns & Co. Inc., his brother Fred C. Stella, a lawyer, and Roger C. Capozzi Sr. The indictment charges all three with one count of conspiracy to obstruct justice. In addition, Fred Stella was charged with five counts of obstructing justice, and Capozzi with three counts of perjury and three counts of obstructing justice. The fourth defendant, Joseph A. Pontarelli Jr., was accused of income tax evasion and filing a false tax return, according to Fardella. Bear Stearns was not involved in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors' Group Asks Nutri-System To Stop Using Its Name
With AM-Weight Loss
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association said it has asked Nutri-System Inc. to stop using the AMA's name in advertising for the weight loss program, a recent target of lawsuits by people claiming health problems. ``The American Medical Association does not endorse that company's or any other diet plans,'' an AMA statement said Monday. Neither the AMA nor Nutri-System could provide details about the ads, though AMA spokesman John Hammarly said he believed the ads began in February and ran in both broadcast and print media. Commercially administered weight-loss programs should be ``appropriate for the individual's physical condition,'' says an AMA report on treating obesity in adults drafted two years ago by the AMA Council on Scientific Affairs. The report, which the AMA cited in its statement, says such programs should offer proper medical supervision ``by physicians who have knowledge of the metabolic consequences of the prescribed regimen.'' ``The AMA is thus particularly concerned by recent published reports alleging a failure of proper medical supervision in connection with the Nutri-System program,'' the AMA said in a May 4 letter to Nutri-System. Nineteen women in Florida filed separate lawsuits against Nutri-System earlier this year alleging they were inadequately supervised under the program and that it caused them to develop gallstones. Most required gallbladder surgery. The gallbladder produces and stores bile used in digestion. The company has said the lawsuits are without merit, suggesting that the gallstones in the plaintiffs occurred coincidentally and that the risk of gallbladder disease among the obese can be reduced by prudent dieting. Nonetheless, ``Nutri-System has complied with the AMA's request,'' said Tim Hermeling, a spokesman for Nutri-System in Willow Grove, Pa. ``We are reviewing the letter,'' he added. ``Nutri-system meets the guidelines of all leading health organizations. And we'd be pleased to discuss the issue with the AMA.'' The AMA also notified U.S. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of a congressional subcommittee holding hearings on the nation's $33 billion annual weight-loss industry, that it had asked Nutri-System to leave the AMA out of its advertising. Nutri-System, with nearly 1,600 weight-loss centers in all 50 states, Canada, Britain and Australia, offers a 1,000-to 1,500-calorie-a-day meal program that can cost several hundred dollars to enroll in, depending on wight-loss goals and special promotions offered.

DOC.HEAD: Survey of 50 Companies Finds Potential $14 Billion Pension Shortfall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, bgng: The agency xxx to CORRECT employer to employee.
DOC.TEXT: A survey of 50 companies with pension plans underfunded by $40 million or more each shows those corporations together have a potential $14 billion shortfall, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. said Monday. James Lockhart, director of the agency, said the firms on the list were not necessarily in poor financial health. He also said their inclusion did not mean they had failed to properly fund their pension plans. Guaranteed benefits earned by participants in the plans are still secure because the funds' assets are growing and guaranteed by the federal agency, Lockhart said. The agency released the list because ``employees should be aware of how their pension plans are funded,'' said an agency spokeswoman. The list of 50 companines came from a survey of information filed by about 7,000 corporations with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The survey did not include a review of pension plans for banks, utlities, life insurance, property and casualty firms or companies not required to file with the SEC. Potential abuse within the nation's $1.7 trillion pension system is a growing concern on Capitol Hill, where both House and Senate panels are looking into the matter. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole has asked Congress to approve funding for an additional 100 agents to police the pensions system.
